Because of the 1988 agreement, a federal court in Cincinnati never ruled on the substance of case: whether the Energy Department and its contractors should be fined for improperly handling hazardous waste or polluting air or water. The issue the Energy Department was appealing was the federal court's ruling that the government, under the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and the Clean Air Act, waived its immunity from lawsuits. The plant 18 miles northwest of Cincinnati processes uranium for nuclear weapons. Neighbors of the plant won a $78 million settlement last summer, claiming its contamination lowered property values and caused emotional distress. Hazardous wastes stored at Fernald date back to the Manhattan Project, which developed the atomic bomb during World War II. A citizen watchdog group has said barrels of hazardous and chemical wastes are rusting and leaking. The Environmental Protection Agency is supervising the cleanup, which is expected to take as long as 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Mayor Said Concerned About Timing of Retirement Announcement
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry, embattled by drug charges, still plans to abandon a re-election bid, but aides say he wants to make the announcement without appearing to be pressured into doing so. Barry aides said the mayor had planned to make that announcement Monday in a television interview but didn't do so because of publicity surrounding his discussions with civil rights leader Jesse Jackson and the efforts of others to get Barry to abandon his re-election plans. ``There have been some intrusive parties, Jesse and others,'' said one source close to Barry who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``The man wants to act on his own, without seeming to be pushed around.'' Barry has decided he must forgo plans for seeking a fourth, four-year term in this November's election if he hopes to restart stalled plea-bargain talks in his drug possession and perjury trial, several sources have said. The mayor has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. Meanwhile, selection of a jury to hear Barry's case in U.S. District Court is continuing, with the aim of seating a panel by week's end. Ten people were added to the pool on Monday, bringing the number of potential jurors to 58. Plea discussions, which started more than two weeks ago, broke down last week with U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens insisting that Barry plead guilty to a felony charge and the mayor willing to consider only a misdemeanor plea, sources familiar with the situation have said. The talks have not revolved around Barry's re-election plans, the sources said. Barry, interviewed on WHUR-FM radio Monday night, denied any kind of linkage. ``Those have been false reports,'' he said. ``My defense team has not asked for or sought any plea bargain. ... Moreover, there's been an effort to link that to any political decision that I may make. ``There is no linkage, there is no connection between the two. Any decision I make about my political future will be made independent of the legal case,'' the mayor said. But several aides who met with Barry on Sunday insisted that he has decided not to run. ``When he announces it, it may be one of those things where he tells no one except a couple of close advisers,'' one aide said. ``He wants to avoid that circus atmosphere.''

DOC.HEAD: Murphy's `48 HRS' Unseats `Total Recall' at the Box Office
DOC.TEXT: ``Another 48 HRS.,'' Eddie Murphy's crime-stopper sequel, pushed the Arnold Schwarzenegger sci-fi thriller ``Total Recall'' out of the No. 1 spot at the box office in its debut weekend. ``Another 48 HRS.,'' which critics said offered no improvement on the 1982 original, sold $19.5 million in tickets, or $4 million less than ``Total Recall'' did the previous weekend, according to figures Monday from Exhibitor Relations Co. ``Total Recall'' plummeted 41 percent, making $15.1 million for second place. In third was ``Back to the Future Part III'' with receipts of $7.7 million. ``Bird on a Wire,'' the Mel Gibson-Goldie Hawn road movie that was lightly considered at the summer season's start, continued to do vigorous business. In fourth place, it grossed $4.8 million and now has made $49.7 million. Not in the top 10 but playing strongly with $286,992 in 85 theaters was ``Longtime Companion,'' the acclaimed movie about a group of men dying of AIDS. ``Longtime Companion'' has now passed the $2 million mark in five weeks, and its distributor is trying to market the film to a wider audience. ``Dick Tracy,'' one of the summer's most anticipated titles, opens Friday, and the Walt Disney Co. already is being slammed for its plans to count special ``Dick Tracy'' T-shirts as part of the film's opening gross. Disney said the shirts, which give early patrons a guaranteed seat for the film, should be counted as regular admissions, although some theaters are selling the shirts for up to $20. Here are the top movie ticket sales for Friday through Monday as tallied by Exhibitor Relations, with distributor, weekend gross, number of theater screens, average per screen, total gross and number of weeks in release. Figures are based on a combination of actual box-office receipts and studio projections where actual figures are not immediately available. 1. ``Another 48 HRS.,'' Paramount, $19.5 million, 2,301 screens, $8,461 per screen, $19.5 million, one week. 2. ``Total Recall,'' Tri-Star, $15.1 million, 2,076 screens, $7,255 per screen, $51.1 million, two weeks. 3. ``Back to the Future III,'' Universal, $7.7 million, 2,054 screens, $3,725 per screen, $49.5 million, three weeks. 4. ``Bird on a Wire,'' Universal, $4.8 million, 2,008 screens, $2,400 per screen, $49.7 million, four weeks. 5. ``Pretty Woman,'' Disney, $4.5 million, 1,777 screens, $2,521 per screen, $133.3 million, 12 weeks. 6. ``Cadillac Man,'' Orion, $1.8 million, 1,795 screens, $993 per screen, $22.4 million, four weeks. 7. ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles,'' New Line, $1.6 million, 1,588 screens, $1,002 per screen, $123.2 million, 11 weeks. 8. ``Fire Birds,'' Disney, $1.2 million, 1,539 screens, $810 per screen, $12.4 million, three weeks. 9. ``The Hunt for Red October,'' Paramount, $802,750, 822 screens, $976 per screen, $113.5 million, 15 weeks. 10. ``Driving Miss Daisy,'' Warner Bros., $642,840, 964 screens, $666 per screen, $102.7 million, 26 weeks.

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Council Gives Balaguer Victory
DOC.TEXT: Election officials declared Monday night that President Joaquin Balaguer won re-election in last month's disputed balloting. The review of tally sheets from each polling district took 27 days. The Central Electoral Council said the 83-year-old president won a sixth term by defeating longtime rival Juan Bosch, an 80-year-old Marxist former president, by a margin of 678,268 to 653,423 votes. Bosch had claimed massive electoral fraud in the May 16 vote. The nearly blind Balaguer, leader of the Social Christian Reformist party, is to begin his new term on Aug. 16. He and his political allies won 35.7 percent of the vote, the council said. It said Bosch, of the Dominican Liberation Party, received 34.4 percent. The council said the mayor of Santo Domingo, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez of the Dominican Revolutionary Party that governed between 1978 and 1986, won 449,323 votes, or 23.6 percent. Former president Jacobo Majluta of the Independent Revolutionary Party won 135,645 votes, or 7.1 percent, the council said. Balaguer had won the 1986 election over Majluta, then the Dominican Revolutionary Party candidate, by just 40,000 votes. Voter turnout in last month's election was just 59.2 percent, the lowest since free elections were first held after the 1961 fall of the military dictatorship of Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo. The governing party did not comment Monday night on the electoral council's announcement of Balaguer's victory. Nor did Bosch have any immediate comment.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,322.31, down 217.87 points, or 0.67 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Internal Strife Slows Rapid Growth of Southern Baptist Convention
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Election of president not set until late afternoon. Lead prospects uncertain.
DOC.TEXT: The Southern Baptist Convention's phenomenal growth in the late 1960s and '70s dramatized the resurgence of religious conservatives. Now, weakened by internal strife between moderates and fundamentalists, the denomination that pledged in 1976 to ``reach every person in the world with the gospel of Jesus Christ by the year 2000'' is struggling to hold its own. The 14.9-million-member church grew by barely half a percent last year and experienced its first decline in foreign missionaries in nearly 20 years. And even after 11 straight presidential victories by the fundamentalist wing, the theological and political war rages over how to interpret the Bible and share authority within the nation's largest Protestant denomination. ``Welcome to the battle of New Orleans, 1990 version'' is how convention spokesman Alvin C. Shackleford greeted reporters at the denomination's annual meeting. More than 30,000 delegates, or ``messengers,'' are expected for the three-day meeting opening today. The presidential election was set for today. The church more than doubled membership since the mid-'60s to surge past the declining United Methodist Church as the nation's second-largest denomination behind the 55 million-member Roman Catholic Church. But the church's gain of 95,000 members last year was a rise of only .64 percent, the second-smallest increase since 1936. Giving to denominational programs increased 1.89 percent to $137.3 million, less than half the average 4.63 percent increase of the last five years and far lower than the 10.39 percent increases throughout the 1970s. And for the first time since 1972, the number of foreign missionaries declined, dropping 87 to 3,867. The controversy that is blamed for the church's decline dates to 1979, when a group of fundamentalists concerned about ``liberal'' tendencies in the church began the first in a series of campaigns for control of the denomination. The church's moderate wing since has expressed increasing concerns it is being shut out. In some cases the moderates have held back financial support. The conservatives contend the Bible is free from error even in its historical and scientific claims. The moderates charge the fundamentalists are chipping away at the concept that church members have the ability to interpret the Bible for themselves. On specific issues, fundamentalists are more likely to support school prayer and oppose legalized abortion and ordination of women. Some moderates said it is critical they stop their losing streak this year. ``To say that this convention is an important convention is an understatement. This is a crucial convention,'' said the Rev. Daniel Vestal of suburban Atlanta, who lost the presidency last year to the Rev. C. Jerry Vines of Jacksonville, Fla. Vestal's opponent this year, the Rev. Morris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, asked a group of Hispanic ministers Sunday to help Southern Baptists ``complete the course correction'' that he said would make the denomination the first to ever reverse a trend away from believing the Bible can't be wrong.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Explode Car Bomb in Cuzco, Killing One Person
DOC.TEXT: One person was killed and at least eight injured by a powerful car bomb exploded by Shining Path guerrillas near an election office in this Andean tourist center, police said. It was the first rebel attack of note in Peru since Alberto Fujimori beat Mario Vargas Llosa by a landslide in a runoff presidential election Sunday. A police spokesman said the attack also devastated a number of buildings adjacent the election office. The explosion killed bank guard Erasmo Pena Chipa, 29, and injured eight bystanders, the spokesman said. ``The blast was felt all over the city,'' said the spokesman, who asked that his name not be used. It was the most damaging attack by the Maoist-inspired rebels in this city 350 miles southeast of Lima since the 1986 bombing of a tourist train in Cuzco station. Seven foreigners died in the blast. On June 2, rebels took over a local radio station and broadcast an appeal to boycott Sunday's elections. More than 18,500 people have died in political violence in the decade since the Shining Path began its armed insurgency.

DOC.HEAD: Veterans Push for Constitutional Amendment
With PM-Flag Burning, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Veterans said the U.S. Supreme Court decision striking down the flag-burning law shows that the way to protect Old Glory is by constitutional amendment. Civil libertarians said such a move would itself be a desecration. The 1989 law ``was a thinly veiled attempt by Congress to avoid the issues of a constitutional amendment which will protect our nation's flag,'' American Legion commander Miles Epling said at national headquarters in Indianapolis. The high court Monday ruled 5-4 that Congress violated free-speech rights when it outlawed flag burning. William Ramsey of the Nebraska Freedoms Foundation Board said he supports ``whatever it takes'' to protect the flag. ``It's sad we have to do anything,'' he said. ``It should be a matter of common decency that we respect such a symbol of freedom. It's a sad day.'' R. Jack Powell, executive director of the Paralyzed Veterans of America, said of the ruling, ``This seems to clearly indicate that those who felt a constitutional amendment was necessary all along are right.'' But Harvard law professor Lawrence Tribe said, ``It would desecrate the Constitution to carve out an exception to the First Amendment, and I hope the House and Senate resist that temptation.'' ``I think it's a proper decision. I hope it doesn't lead to a panic to adopt a constitutional amendment to override it,'' said civil rights lawyer William Kunstler. ``That would be a tragedy for all Americans.'' One decorated Vietnam War veteran on Capitol Hill, Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., called amendment efforts a mistake. He urge restraint. ``I think the current need is fueled by things that we need to control a bit, and the emotional response that we feel when we see people damaging the flag should not lead us to amend our constitution,'' said the Medal of Honor recipient.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Representative to Study American Presidency
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs lead of 3rd item to CORRECT ``worked'' to ``word''
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has dispatched an envoy to the White House to study the inner workings of the U.S. presidency. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday that the visit was arranged after Gorbachev, meeting at Camp David during his recent summit meeting with Bush, expressed interest in the operations and organization of the Executive Office of the President. Gorbachev's representative, Mikhail Shkabardnya, business manager of the Council of Ministers of the Soviet Union, also will observe the operations of the Treasury, Justice and Agriculture departments as well as the General Services Administration, Fitzwater said.
DOC.HEAD: Lincoln Assassination Display Reopens
DOC.TEXT: A newly renovated museum with more than 400 historical objects relating to Abraham Lincoln's assassination is in operation at Ford's Theater where the Civil War president was fatally shot the night of April 14, 1865. Included in the new permanent exhibition dedicated Monday is the single-shot derringer pistol that actor John Wilkes Booth used to wound Lincoln mortally while he was attending a play at Ford's Theater. Also on display is life-size model of Lincoln in the clothes he was wearing that night, including the large, black broadcloth frock coat made for the president by Brooks Brothers to wear at his second inaugural. The museum was closed two years ago for renovation. ``After 20 years of accommodating more than a half-million visitors annually, the museum was ready for a change,'' said Park Service official Robert G. Stanton. The 400 items are more than double the number on display when the museum first opened in 1968.
DOC.HEAD: Bush Spokesman Suggests Budget Talks Involve Taxes
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's spokesman briefly used the ``t'' for taxes word in discussing budget negotiations with Congress. But Marlin Fitzwater quickly amended his remarks Monday. Fitzwater was asked at his daily press briefing whether there was significance to the fact that Bush, in a series of recent political speeches, failed to repeat his vow against tax increases as he talked about economic conditions. ``Yes,'' Fitzwater said. ``The significance is that we're involved in tax negotiations on the hill, where we have agreed. ... '' When reporters expressed astonishment, Fitzwater backtracked. ``I mean the budget negotiations,'' Fitzwater said. ``Budget negotiations,'' he repeated, ``where we have agreed not to talk publicly in any way that would specify preconditions.'' ``And we will not do so,'' the president's spokesman added.
DOC.HEAD: U.S. Puts Extra Security on Gregg
DOC.TEXT: The White House says it has stepped up security for U.S. Ambassador to South Korea Donald P. Gregg in response to death threats from student radicals. South Korean police clashed with students in Kwangju as Gregg reopened a U.S. cultural center that has been repeatedly attacked. Some 500 students hurled rocks and firebombs at police who blocked them from marching off the campus of Chosun University. They had claimed they had formed ``death squads'' to kidnap Gregg during his visit to Kwangju. The city 155 miles south of Seoul is a hotbed of anti-U.S. sentiment. The radicals accuse the United States of condoning the lethal suppression of anti-government demonstrations in 1980, when South Korea was still under military rule. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Monday: ``We take all such threats seriously and be assured that we are taking the proper security measures and that they are in place.'' Fitzwater noted that radicals broke into Gregg's residence last October. The ambassador and his wife escaped unharmed. He said the United States took ``a number of security measures to augment the situation'' after that incident.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Higher
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange plunged Tuesday, while the dollar closed higher against the Japanese yen. The dollar finished at 154.40 yen, up 0.30 yen from Monday's 154.10-yen finish. It opened at 154.38 yen and ranged between 153.80 yen and 154.55 yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average lost 217.87 points, or 0.67 percent, ending at 32,322.31. The index lost almost 260 points before recovering by the end of the morning session, and fell back in the afternoon. Traders attributed the index's afternoon plunge to an unexpected recovery in the morning session despite Monday's 453.11-point decline. Yoshio Ogawa, chief dealer of Nikko Securities Co., said the index's early decline came following arbitrage selling in an attempt to take profits between the spot and futures markets. The yen's early weakness against the dollar also prompted selling, he said. In currency dealings, the dollar reversed its early downswing and edged higher in the afternoon as market players sold the yen to buy the British pound, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. The dollar fell earlier as market players made position adjustments, she said. Other participants remained on the sidelines ahead of a series of releases of the U.S. economic indicators this week, dealers said. Among the announcements are U.S. retail sales, producer prices, consumer prices and the monthly trade figures for April.

DOC.HEAD: Two Whites Given Maximum Sentences in Bensonhurst Slaying
LaserPhotos NY4, NY5
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David N. Dinkins appealed for a healing of racial divisions after a judge handed down maximum prison terms to two young white men for their roles in the mob attack that left a black teen-ager dead. Justice Thaddeus Owens imposed the sentences Monday for what a prosecutor called ``Neanderthal-type'' behavior by whites who jumped and shot 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins after he ventured into mostly white Bensonhurst on Aug. 23. Joseph Fama, 19, named by prosecutors as the triggerman, was sentenced to 32 and two-thirds years to life in prison for murder and other crimes. Keith Mondello, 19, identified as the ringleader, drew five and one-third to 16 years in prison, plus a $2,000 fine. He had been acquitted of murder and manslaughter but convicted of riot and other offenses. Fama and Mondello each must serve the lower range of their sentences before they become eligible for parole. The slaying heightened racial tensions during the campaign that resulted in Dinkins' election as New York's first black mayor. The verdict in Mondello's case in May set off rock- and bottle-throwing melees by blacks in Brooklyn. In a statement from City Hall, Dinkins said ``the stiff sentences imposed today speak for themselves.'' Now that the criminal justice system has spoken, we all must join our hearts, heads and hands together to rid our city of the racism that destroys lives and communities,'' he said. ``We have had enough of tragedy. Together, we must and we will move the healing process forward.'' When Fama's sentence was read in the packed courtroom, the victim's father, Moses Stewart, murmured ``Yes!'' Later, Stewart called the ruling ``a small joy for myself but a great victory for black people all over the state.'' Members of Fama's family screamed in Italian and wept. ``Not my son! Not my son!'' shouted his mother, Josephine Fama. Hawkins and three friends had gone to the Brooklyn neighborhood to look at a used car. A mob of whites, having been warned by Mondello's ex-girlfriend about ``outsiders,'' set upon the black teen-agers with baseball bats. Assistant District Paul Burns, arguing for the maximum term, called the killing ``a Neanderthal-type of behavior.'' ``We need to send the message to every community that we will not tolerate senseless violence,'' the prosecutor said. Mondello's attorney, Stephen Murphy, told the judge, ``I believe that the law should rise above public opinion.'' On Monday, jury selection began for co-defendant John Vento, and trial dates were set for five other young men accused in the case. Vento, 21, is charged with murder as well as riot, assault and other crimes. He faces 25 years to life in prison if convicted of murder.

DOC.HEAD: Christian Prisoners Get Amnesty
DOC.TEXT: Nepal, the world's only Hindu kingdom, will free all Christian prisoners who were jailed by the former government for illegal proselytizing, the royal palace said today. The palace said in a statement King Birendra has ``granted amnesty to all religious prisoners'' on the advice of Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai in view of the ``new political environment ... in the country.'' Currently, 29 Christians, including 14 children younger than age 18, are serving sentences for proselytizing. There are no religious prisoners of other faiths. A human rights report recently said 144 other Christians were in police custody across the country facing trial. The royal statement said King Birendra has ``given instructions for the dismissal of all cases against persons awaiting trial for religious activities.'' A Home Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said orders had already been issued to prison authorities to set free the 29 imprisoned Christians. ``We believe this is the Lord's doing,'' said Samuel Sotemba, the pastor of Nepal Christian Fellowship, a local church that like hundreds of other protestant churches in Nepal operates unofficially. The amnesty appeared to be the first step towards Nepalese church leaders' demand that the new pro-democracy government change a 32-year-old law banning religious conversion. Human rights activists in Nepal say the country's Christians have faced widespread persecution by previous governments that were dominated by the monarchy. A popular movement in April forced King Birendra to loosen his grip on power and appoint pro-democracy leaders to government offices. Although the current constitution, which will soon be rewritten, allows freedom of religion, it prescribes a one-year prison term for freely converting oneself to another religion, three years for an attempt to convert someone else and six years for successfully converting others. Christian leaders say there are between 35,000 and 40,000 Christians in the country, but government records put the number at 3,000. About 75 percent of the Himalayan kingdom's 17 million people are Hindus, 5 percent Moslems and 3 percent Buddhists.

DOC.HEAD: Jew Stabbed In Old City; Palestinian Suspected
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old Israeli going to pray at the Western Wall was stabbed twice in the stomach today at the entrance to Jerusalem's walled Old City, police and hospital officials said. Police arrested a 15-year-old Palestinian suspect immediately after the attack at Damascus Gate, one of the main entrances to the Old City, a police spokesman said. The victim, whose name was not released, was in satisfactory condition at Sharei Tzadek Hospital, spokeswoman Orna Cohen said. He is a student at a yeshiva, or Jewish seminary, and is from Dimona in Israel's Negev Desert. The Western Wall is the last remnant of the ancient Jewish Temple destroyed by the Romans in 70 A.D. It is the holiest site for Jews.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Carries Indian Satellite into Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with satellite in orbit. PICKS UP 4th graf pvs, `Abid Hussain ...'
DOC.TEXT: A Delta rocket lifted into orbit today an Indian communications satellite that was grounded a year because of damage first from a launch pad accident and then the California earthquake. The unmanned rocket thundered skyward, the moon in the background, at 1:52 a.m. About an hour later, the satellite separated from the rocket and settled into a temporary orbit 130 miles high. The satellite will reach a circular orbit 22,300 miles high in 10 days, said Sastri Vasantha, project director of India's Department of Space. McDonnell Douglas launch commentator Ray Adams said the rocket went ``right down the middle of the path.'' ``That's the way we like to see them fly,'' he said. Abid Hussain, India's ambassador to the United States, said Monday the satellite will ``spread education and knowledge, science and new culture to hundreds and thousands of those who have been out of the mainstream of life.'' India has 800 million people. Its communications ``are mostly guided by land facilities, and there are hundreds and thousands of villages that are remote from the metropolitan cities and we have not been able to reach there,'' Hussain. The $80 million Insat satellite will replace one that was deployed in 1983 by the shuttle Challenger. Once it becomes operational in mid-July, the satellite will send video and voice signals to TV, radio and disaster-warning receivers, and transmit weather observations to a forecasting center in New Delhi. McDonnell Douglas' rocket and launch services cost nearly $50 million. It was the fourth commercial launch of a Delta. The satellite was scheduled to ride a Delta rocket into orbit last June, which would have made it America's first commercial launch to reach orbit. But a cable on a crane broke and dropped a heavy hook on the satellite 10 days before liftoff. Ford Aerospace, which built the satellite, returned the spacecraft to Palo Alto, Calif., and replaced an antenna and made other repairs at a cost of $10 million. The earthquake that struck Northern California in October caused further damage _ about a dozen cells in the satellite's solar panels had to be replaced at a cost of about $150,000. Ford Aerospace insured the satellite for any problems on the ground. The Indian government, which also has insurance, assumed responsibility after liftoff. Because of the one-year delay, India has had to lease the services of other satellite communications companies, Vasantha said. The Insat satellite that will be replaced is operating at about 70 percent capacity, he said. The new craft is the fourth and final in a series of India's Insat 1 satellites. It has a working lifetime of seven years. An updated version, the Insat 2, will be carried into space next year by Europe's Ariane rocket.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Journalists Publish Own Newspaper
DOC.NOTE: Eds: To ADD number of journalists invovled, INSERT one graf after 5th, `Most of ...'
DOC.TEXT: Journalists stood on street corners hawking a newspaper they published on their own after launching Norway's first newspaper strike in 44 years. The 32-page tabloid Avisa, the Norwegian word for newspaper, appeared on Monday, a day after wage negotiations collapsed. It competed with regular newspapers that succeeded in publishing thin Monday editions. The Norwegian Union of Journalists had ordered strikes at eight major newspapers and the national news service NTB, said union officer Bente Sabel. Norway's publishers association responded by locking out reporters from 57 other newspapers. Most of the 65 newspapers published Monday editions, filled mainly with advertisements. In all, about 2,000 journalists were on strike or locked out. Employers offered less than half the journalists' demand of a 4.57 percent increase on their $34,460 average annual salary, reports said. ``In our view, it is mostly a wage problem,'' said Tore Cappelen, the publishers chief negotiator. Cappelen said it was too early to attempt new talks. ``A lot depends on what happens with NRK,'' he said. Journalists at the state NRK radio and television network have also threatened to strike. Sabel said the closest they came to new talks was ``when I sold a copy of Avisa to a publishers negotiator.'' The union, founded in 1946, has claimed it is ready to make its first strike a long one, and to publish Avisa and similar newspapers daily. Monday's Avisa edition was delayed, and limited to 10,000 copies, due to problems in buying newsprint, Sabel said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Plunge, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index plunged after nervous fluctuations today, while the dollar continued its upward trend against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 217.87 points, or 0.67 percent, closing at 32,322.31. The index declined almost 260 points, more than regained that loss by the end of the morning session and then fell back in the afternoon. Traders attributed the fluctuations to investors' caution after Monday's 453.11-point plunge and to the yen's weakness against the dollar. In early trading, market players used arbitrage selling in an attempt to take profits from price differences between the spot and the futures markets, but after a round of selling began picking up underpriced issues, said Yoshio Ogawa, a chief trader with Nikko Securities Co. Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co., said caution and discouragement over the yen sent prices back down in the afternoon. ``The morning recovery was too quick considering the situation _ yesterday's decline and the yen's weakness,'' he said. First section volume was estimated at 500 million shares, up from Monday's 350 million. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 154.40 yen, up 0.30 yen from Monday's 154.10-yen finish. It opened at 154.38 yen and ranged between 153.80 yen and 154.55 yen. Since closing at 149.45 yen on May 28, the dollar has gained against the yen on 10 of the last 11 trading days. The dollar reversed an early downswing today and edged higher in the afternoon as market players sold the yen to buy the British pound, said Minori Takeuchi, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``The yen plunged against the pound and the dollar because of the Financial Times story today,'' she said. The Financial Times reported from London today that Britain is prepared to join the European Monetary System as early as September if the British pound is strong enough in the foreign exchange market then. The dollar fell earlier as market players made position adjustments, Ms. Takeuchi said. Many participants remained on the sidelines awaiting a series of U.S. economic indicators due to be announced this week, other dealers said. These include U.S. retail sales, producer prices, consumer prices and the monthly trade figures for April. About $13.98 billion changed hands in spot trading. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds rose to 87.45 points as of 5 p.m. from Monday's close of 87.18. The yield stood at 7.085 percent, down from 7.140 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Pioneering Horror Movie Producer Dies
DOC.TEXT: Sir James Carreras, who as head of Hammer Films produced horror movies that scared the daylights out of a whole generation of filmgoers, has died, according to a family death notice published today. He was 81. Carreras died peacefully on Saturday of a stroke at his home at Henley-on-Thames, west of London, the notice said. Known as a mild-mannered family man, Carreras always said the ghastly monsters with which Hammer Films filled screens around the world were harmless, escapist entertainment. Carreras built up the Hammer company after World War II, and in the mid-1950s began making the gruesome, low-budget horror films for which the British studio became internationally famous. His first big hit and the first Hammer film to be distributed in the United States was ``The Quatermass Experiment,'' based on a 1954 television science fiction series. The horror aspects of that film inspired Carreras to look for material among the monsters popular with film fans in the 1930s. He raised from the dead Frankenstein, Dracula and other creepy characters of legend and novel who had faded from the screen. ``The Curse of Frankenstein'' in 1956 struck an immediate chord with the public who liked its fantastic sets, garish color and melodramatic plot. Hammer horror films boosted the careers of two actors who became synonymous with escapist horror fare _ Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee. ``Dracula,'' with Lee in the title role and Cushing as Van Helsing, followed Frankenstein and several sequels were made to each. Lee played Dracula in nearly a dozen films. The sound stage at Hammer was filled at one time or another with Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, Jack the Ripper, and Sherlock Holmes in ``The Hound of the Baskervilles.'' Carreras shunned the creative side of filmmaking, preferring the role of impresario. Born June 9, 1909, he inherited his flair for showmanship from his father, Enrique Carreras, the owner of a chain of London movie theaters. Carreras made sure films were shot quickly and cheaply, and played a role in the British film industry similar to that played by Roger Corman in Hollywood. Like Corman, Carreras made films that were the objects of critical scorn, but developed a strong cult following. The company did not hold press screenings, but devoted resources and imagination to promotion. In one typical Carreras-inspired stunt, coffins were carried through the streets to promote the opening of a horror film. The Hammer company also produced pirate adventures, war epics, bloody thrillers and a peculiar prehistoric yarn, ``One Million Years BC,'' which helped make a star of a little known American actress named Raquel Welch. Even in the 1970s, films under Carreras rarely cost more than a modest 200,000 pounds ($336,000 at current exchange rates). At the studio's height, it produced eight films a year.

DOC.HEAD: University President, Under Fusion Fire, Announces Retirement
DOC.TEXT: University of Utah President Chase N. Peterson, a cheerleader for the phantom phenomenon of tabletop fusion, is retiring under fire for a hidden, $500,000 transfer of money toward its development. Peterson, 60, said Monday he would retire next year but had no intention of resigning under pressure. In a resolution last week, the faculty's Academic Senate had questioned Peterson's ability to run the 23,500-student university in light of the furor over the money transfer. Peterson has held the post since 1983. The president acknowledged that the ``period of time I can effectively provide leadership is nearing an end.'' Peterson had come under sharp criticism twice before in the past 15 months, first for the school's announcement of a breakthrough in the quest for fusion and then for his handling of a $15 million donation that later was returned. Last month, controversy erupted when it became known that a $500,000 donation to the school's fusion research center that had been characterized by the university as an ``anonymous,'' outside gift actually was the result of a Peterson-authorized transfer of money from the school's Research Foundation. Peterson on June 1 said that hiding the origin of the donation was a mistake. He said he had hoped to avoid jealousy within other departments, but had ``hurt the credibility of the institute.'' Chemist B. Stanley Pons of the university and British colleague Martin Fleischmann announced in March 1989 that they had achieved a sustained nuclear fusion reaction in a tabletop experiment. The announcement held out the prospect of a cheap, safe and virtually inexhaustible source of energy. Despite extreme scientific skepticism that continues today, the Legislature appropriated $5 million last fall to establish the National Cold Fusion Institute at the school and to protect the state's patent rights. The center has tried to raise money from the government and corporations but has had limited success. A Department of Energy panel recommended against funding, and the only confirmed contribution was $50,000 from Utah Power & Light Co. in March. In June, Salt Lake medical equipment manufacturer James L. Sorenson donated $15 million in pharmaceutical stock to the university with the understanding the medical school and hospital would be renamed in his honor. Peterson was forced to return the money after protests from doctors, faculty and students. Pons said he was grateful for Peterson's support. ``He made a strong effort to see it through. We regret that it is an issue in his retirement decision,'' Pons said. ``We still know that we are right, and we are sure that soon he will be able to list cold fusion as one of the positive accomplishments by the University of Utah.'' Critics lauded Peterson's decision to retire at the end of the 1990-91 academic year. ``I think that his timetable is entirely appropriate and his statement is appreciated by the faculty,'' said Sandra Taylor, a history professor who had introduced the Academic Senate resolution. Peterson was the school's vice president for health sciences when surgeons completed the first artificial heart implant in 1982 on Barney Clark, who died after 112 days on the device. Peterson became the university's 11th president in 1983, succeeding David P. Gardner. His supporters most often cite his talent for fund-raising. ``We don't raise money. We generate support for important programs,'' Peterson said in an interview Monday night. That support totaled $42 million this year, while ``before I came the highest was $17 million.'' Donations for the last five years amounted to $207 million, he said. But Peterson said the period in which he could effectively lead was nearing an end. ``Leadership needs to be rather forceful, occasionally bold and likely occasionally wrong _ or judged to be wrong _ and occasionally bruising, which probably means you shouldn't be here forever,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Woman's Suicide Accidentally Kills Roommates
DOC.TEXT: Carbon-monoxide seeped into a condominium and killed two roomates of a woman who committed suicide by shutting herself in the garage with her car's engine running, authorities said. The bodies of Ruth M. Goran and her roommates were discovered Friday night after Ms. Goran's daughter, who had traveled from Las Vegas to get married, got no answer at the home and called police, Sgt. Jim Flonacher said Monday. The deaths of the roommates, Claude R. Hillhouse, 42, and Gordon Gear, 32, were ruled accidental. ``I'm sure she didn't mean to take two with her,'' said Hillhouse's nephew, Scott Hillhouse. ``She wasn't suicidal,'' said Ms. Goran's daughter, Karen McLaughlin, 29. ``She was real happy. We were looking forward to holding the reception at her home. We were going to bring everything over Friday night.'' She said Hillhouse was her mother's boyfried.

DOC.HEAD: `Money World' TV Show Planned For Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: ``Adam Smith's Money World,'' public television's weekly look at business, will run this fall on Soviet television, dubbed in Russian. ``Adam Smith has come to the land of Karl Marx,'' said the show's host, George J.W. Goodman, who uses the name of the 18th century Scottish economist who outlined the workings of capitalism. Co Star, a Soviet company that produces and distributes films, will get the broadcast rights to ``Money World'' and sell advertising to U.S. companies doing business in the Soviet Union. Those companies include General Motors and AT&T. In return, the show's U.S. producers will get technical support for a public TV special on perestroika and glasnost. Goodman said in today's New York Times that much of the show would be beyond the comprehension of the typical Soviet viewer. ``Money World'' is produced by Alvin H. Perlmutter Inc. and WNET, the public TV station in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Could Cause Serious Damage to Wildlife
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A catastrophic spill from the burning supertanker Mega Borg couldn't come at a worse time of year for shellfish and birds on the Texas coast, environmentalists say. The Coast Guard estimated the Norwegian ship had spilled up to 100,000 gallons of its 38 million-gallon cargo of light crude. Much of the oil was being consumed by fires that erupted Saturday 57 miles southeast of Galveston. Currents and winds were expected to push escaping oil toward a 200-mile stretch of coast between Freeport and Corpus Christi. But the Coast Guard said the currents also were expected to keep the spill from coming ashore. Roy Hann, a Texas A&M environmental engineering professor, said damage to the ecology would be catastrophic if millions of gallons reached the bays and estuaries along the central coast where fish hatch and birds nest. Gary Clark, president of the Houston Audubon Society, said the spill ``couldn't have happened at a worse time of year'' for shellfish and birds. ``In mid-June the immediate consequences on breeding birds would be devastating,'' he said. ``It could wipe out the brown pelican.'' Clark said light crude would be more devastating to birds over the short-term because it floats, and ``just a slight ingestion of light crude could kill numerous birds.'' Heavy crude, which sinks to the bottom, would have a long-term impact. Pat Rogers, who owns a seafood business in Galveston and a fleet of shrimp boats, said any oil that might make it to the ocean floor could kill the shrimp. ``This is a critical time for the brown shrimp because they're leaving the estuary areas for the Gulf,'' Rogers said. ``It couldn't be any more critical than what it is right now.'' Brown and white shrimp are the two species most often found in restaurants, and major populations of the species are found in the area of the burning tanker. The response to the disaster was delayed during the weekend as firefighting and oil containment equipment was brought in from Louisiana, Alabama and even the Netherlands. ``What I guess disturbs me,'' said Clark, ``is I don't understand why the Texas coast, the Houston area, doesn't have a well-coordinated response to something like this. It's all reactionary, it's all ad hoc, it's all here after the fact.'' ``I think we need to hold our public officials responsible in a big way,'' he said. ``There should have been equipment in place to take care of this thing right away.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Great Lakes, Sunshine in Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Fair weather prevailed early today across the United States, accompanied by a threat of thunderstorms in the Great Lakes region and the Plains. Sunny skies were forecast in New England and much of the East, and scattered thunderstorms were expected in the South. Gusts to 60 mph and cool weather were predicted in the northern Rockies. Snow was likely at high altitudes in Montana and strong winds with thunderstorms were forecast for the northern Plains and the upper Midwest. California and the Southwest were in for sunshine and mild temperatures after cool weather Monday, when thunderstorms dominated the nation's weather. A tornado touched down Monday near Mobridge, S.D., but there were no reports of injuries or significant damage. Thunderstorm winds gusted to 66 mph and hail fell in Rapid City. Showers and thunderstorms Monday struck portions of Wisconsin, North Dakota, South Dakota, Nebraska, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, Montana, Idaho, Oklahoma, Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Florida, Virginia, Delaware, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New England and Washington state. A high Monday of 96 degrees broke Fort Lauderdale's record high for the date. The nation's high was 102 degrees in Laredo, Texas. DOC.HEAD: Ryan No-Hitter Breaks Own Record
DOC.TEXT: Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers struck out 14 batters for his sixth no-hitter, more than any pitcher in major league history. The 43-year-old right-hander broke his own record in the 5-0 victory over the Oakland A's Monday night and also became the oldest ballplayer to pitch a no-hitter _ two years older than Cy Young. Ryan now has two more no-hitters than Sandy Koufax and three more than Bob Feller. It was career shutout No. 59. ``I haven't gotten bored with no-hitters, yet,'' Ryan said. ``I don't know how many more chances I'm going to get, but the way I've been throwing, it's certainly not out of the question that I'll get another shot.'' Ryan is the first player to pitch a no-hitter for three teams _ the Rangers, California Angels and Houston Astros. His no-hitters span three decades, from the 1970s to the '90s _ also a first. In 24 seasons, Ryan has pitched 12 one-hitters and 19 three-hitters. He is the all-time strikeout leader with 5,152 and six wins short of 300. ``He's amazing,'' Oakland manager Tony La Russa said. ``Obviously, I pull for the A's more than I do for Nolan Ryan, but you just have to respect him. ... There is honor in defeat sometimes.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed today against most major foreign currencies in calm European trading. Gold prices were higher. Traders said the dollar is drifting in a narrow range as markets wait for U.S. economic figures scheduled for release at the end of the week. U.S. May producer prices, due for release Thursday, are expected to be up 0.2 percent to 0.4 percent from a drop of 0.3 percent in April. On Friday, the May consumer price index is expected to be up 0.3 percent from an increase of 0.2 percent in April. The same day, the U.S. April trade balance is expected to register a deficit between $6.5 billion and $7 billion, down from $8.45 billion in March. A Milan trader said the U.S. currency is fundamentally sturdy. ``The dollar is strong but it's going to need more substantial support to take it any further,'' the trader said. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.30 yen to a closing 154.40 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.60 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Monday: _1.6923 West German marks, up from 1.6910 _1.4375 Swiss francs, down from 1.4400 _5.6963 French francs, up from 5.6900 _1.9000 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9040 _1,243.00 Italian lire, up from 1,242.75 _1.1740 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1705 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6997, compared with $1.6858 late Monday. Gold dealers said they expect bullion to move higher. ``It may take a few days, but I think that after the market gets a bit longer we'll see a pretty good drop,'' said a dealer with a London bullion house. ``The fundamentals haven't really changed.'' Gold opened in London at a bid price of $355.40 a troy ounce, up from $354.45 bid late Monday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $356.00. In Zurich, the bid price was $355.60, up from $355.00 late Monday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $2.07 to close at a bid $357.82. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $5.02 a troy ounce, from Monday's $5.01.

DOC.HEAD: India To Re-open Border Crossings with Nepal
DOC.TEXT: India's agreement to re-open border crossings should end the economic hardships suffered by landlocked Nepal since New Delhi imposed the restrictions 15 months ago, Indian newspapers said today. Prime Ministers V.P. Singh of India and Krishna Prasad Bhattarai of Nepal announced an agreement Sunday on restoring trade and transit links, and India agreed to re-open the border crossings by July 1. ``Today we have finally put an unfortunate interlude behind us and have fully normalized our relations,'' Singh told a news conference in announcing the agreement. The agreement provides for concessions on customs duties for goods traded between the two countries and the dropping of restrictions on Indian citizens seeking employment in Nepal. The two countries also agreed to consider their mutual security concerns. Major Indian newspapers praised the agreement in editorials today. The agreement will ``put an end to the hardships suffered by the people of Nepal as a result of a major interruption in the flow of essential consumer goods,'' said the independent Indian Express newspaper. Relations between the two neighbors soured in March 1989 when Rajiv Gandhi, then India's prime minister, closed 13 of the 15 goods transit points on its border with Nepal when trade and transit treaties expired. Gandhi imposed the restrictions after Nepal refused to agree to Indian demands for a single treaty covering both trade and transit. India refused to renew the existing treaties. India saw Nepal's refusal to negotiate a single treaty as reflecting a desire to forge economic ties with other countries at India's expense. India also was apparently concerned about Nepal's increasingly close ties with its northern neighbor, China. In 1988, India opposed a decision by Nepal to purchase a large quantity of anti-aircraft weapons from China. The border closings severely restricted the flow of imports to Nepal, which have to be transported overland from Indian ports to the Himalayan kingdom. Nepal's exports are not significant. During the past 15 months, new governments took over in both countries and moved to resolve the disputes. Singh's National Front coalition replaced Gandhi's government in December. Bhattarai was sworn in as head of an interim coalition government in April after an eight-week pro-democracy campaign forced King Birendra to end a partyless system of government. The new agreement basically restores the situation as it existed before March 1989 when the treaties expired. The two countries have agreed to begin negotiations on new trade and transit treaties, but did not set any date. The ``absurdity of India waging a war of economic attrition against Nepal with which it is closely bound by ties of history, geography, culture and economic independence is all too clear,'' The Hindu, a conservative, English-language newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pleads Guilty in Three Boys' Slayings
DOC.TEXT: A man has pleaded guilty to stabbing to death three boys _ including two brothers who had gone cycling in a park _ and trying to murder a youngster he snatched from a movie theater. A jury will be selected June 25 to decide the penalty for 28-year-old Westley Allan Dodd _ death or life in prison without parole. Dodd had been held without bail since his arrest Nov. 13 on charges of murdering Lee Joseph Iseli, 4, of Portland, Ore., and brothers Cole Neer, 11, and William Neer, 10, of Vancouver. Dodd, who had earlier pleaded innocent, offered no explanation for the change of plea. The Neer brothers' bodies were found Sept. 4 in a park. Iseli's body was discovered near Vancouver Lake Nov. 1, three days after he disappeared from a Portland schoolyard. Rape charges were dropped for lack of evidence. Dodd was arrested after he carried 6-year-old James Kirk II from a Camas theater. The child was let go, but his mother's boyfriend tracked down Dodd and brought him back. Dodd was charged with kidnapping and attempted murder in that case. The kidnapping charge was dropped Monday.

DOC.HEAD: British Airways Suspends Engineer In Windscreen Investigation
DOC.TEXT: British Airways said today that it has suspended an engineer at the airport where maintenance work was done on the jetliner that lost a windshield at 23,000 feet, sucking out the pilot. Pilot Tim Lancaster was saved by cabin staff who clutched his ankles as he was buffeted against the nose cone for 15 minutes on Sunday until the copilot managed to bring the BAC 1-11 down for an emergency landing. The 41-year-old pilot was recovering at Southampton General Hospital from broken bones, bruises and frostbite. British Airways said the engineer, based at a maintenance depot in the central England city of Birmingham, has been suspended with full pay. The employee was not identified. ``The suspension does not imply anything. It is quite normal in an investigation like this,'' said an airline spokesman, who asked not to be identified in accordance with British custom. The domestic British news agency, Press Association, quoting airline sources, said the suspended engineer was directly involved in the routine replacement of the flight deck windows of the 18-year-old plane two days before the near-disaster. British Airways refused to confirm this, but did say that the windows were replaced Friday in Birmingham. Investigators for the government's Air Accident Investigation have recovered the 2-by-3-foot windshield and have interviewed the flight crew. The plane had taken off from Birmingham in northern England carrying 81 holiday makers to Malaga, Spain. On Monday, Lancaster met for an hour with his rescuers _ purser Nigel Ogden, steward Simon Rogers and stewardess Susan Prince _ and posed with the trio, smiling and barechested in his hospital bed. ``They were magnificent. If it was not for them I would not be here now,'' he said of the crew. Lancaster, responding to written questions from reporters, said he remembered hearing a bang when the window blew out of the 18-year-old jet, and then felt himself being pulled from his seat. He was wearing a lap belt but had unfastened his shoulder harness after takeoff. ``I remember the buffeting of the wind,'' he said. ``I tried to shout back at the crew but I'm sure they could not hear me.'' He said the thought of death ``did cross my mind for a moment or two.'' Lancaster, whose replies were relayed by a British Airways spokesman, said his first thought was that he had to keep breathing in the thin, cold air. He described the ordeal as ``extremely fast _ frantic,'' and said he felt no pain during the 15 minutes it took the plane to land. The 21-year British Airways veteran, however, said the experience would not make him stop flying.

DOC.HEAD: Media Duped By Bogus Elizabeth Taylor Story
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Members who used a0439, PM-People-Taylor, transmitted June 11 under a Los Angeles dateline, may wish to use the following story.
DOC.TEXT: A hoaxer used a public relations firm's answering machine to trick the news media into running a bogus story about Elizabeth Taylor, a publicist says. The story, distributed worldwide by The Associated Press and United Press International, said Miss Taylor, 58, was romantically involved with a 23-year-old man and had undergone surgery over the weekend. ``It is a hoax,'' Miss Taylor's publicist, Chen Sam, said Monday. ``I have contacted Miss Taylor's attorneys and we are going to conduct an investigation. It is apparently somebody using my (telephone) service.'' Ms. Sam's New York City public relations firm has been the sole media link during Miss Taylor's nine-week hospitalization for pneumonia at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica. The Sam organization has discouraged the news media from calling St. John's about Miss Taylor and has instructed the hospital's public relations staff not to answer reporters' questions. Under California privacy law, hospitals must abide by the wishes of patients who don't want information released about them. The hoaxer said Miss Taylor underwent an abdominal biopsy and was expected to be released from the hospital within two weeks on the arm of Julian Lee Hobbs of Lake Orion, Mich., described as Miss Taylor's boyfriend. Hobbs is apparently an aspiring actor sometimes known as Rory Emerald. Newspaper editors in Michigan say his representatives have pitched stories to them in the past but they doubted their veracity. The AP office in Los Angeles had placed calls to the hospital and to Chen Sam and Associates after receiving a message Sunday from an AP affiliate in England, the Press Association. Editors at the British domestic news agency had heard Miss Taylor had undergone another operation and wanted a story. Paulette Weir, the hospital spokeswoman, was unavailable for comment Sunday. When the reporter called New York, he was connected to Ms. Sam's answering service and left a message. A short time later, a woman returned the call, saying she was Lisa Flowers from Chen Sam and Associates. She then gave the reporter the bogus information about Miss Taylor's romantic involvement and the surgery. The hoaxer also provided the same story to UPI and City News Service, a metropolitan Los Angeles wire service. The AP reporter, in an effort to verify the authenticity of the source, later placed a second call to Ms. Sam's answering service, leaving a message for Lisa Flowers. The answering service operator accepted that message without question. Later, an AP reporter placed a third call to Ms. Sam's answering service. A woman identifying herself as Ms. Sam returned that call and verified the identity of ``Ms. Flowers'' and the story she had told. Ms. Sam said Monday that no one from her organization had talked to reporters on Sunday. Ms. Sam said a woman involved in the hoax had telephoned Billie's Registry, her answering service, and was given the publicist's messages after somehow providing proper coded identification to the switchboard. ``It was all very cleverly done,'' Ms. Sam said. ``It was done on a Sunday when we weren't around. I can't understand how they got the code. I've had to change the entire system here.'' Billie McDonald, owner of the answering service, said she couldn't offer any details about her staff's role in the hoax. Ms. Sam said Miss Taylor was still recuperating at the hospital and had not undergone any surgery over the weekend. ``I was out there last week,'' Ms. Sam said. ``She's looking wonderful and doing much better. She should be there two more weeks.''

DOC.HEAD: Students Call Strike To Protest Alleged Election Irregularities
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th pvs, `Down with...' to ADD details of student protest; Pickup 8th, `The Socialists...'
DOC.TEXT: Students formed a human chain around Sofia University today and declared a strike over alleged government manipulation of what were billed as Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. The long-ruling Communists, who have renamed themselves the Socialist Party as they strive to break with a repressive past, appeared headed for a decisive victory in Sunday's elections. Initial official results announced today for 111 seats in the 400-seat Parliament gave the Socialists 68 seats against 32 for the main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces. Eight seats went to the mainly ethnic Turkish Rights and Freedoms Movement, and the other three were split among lesser parties. Leaders of the 16-party Union of Democratic Forces claim a series of election irregularities affected the outcome of Sunday's first round of balloting. They rejected the Socialists' offer to join a governing coalition, and about 60,000 opposition supporters staged a protest rally Monday night outside election headquarters. ``Down with the Red Mafia'' and ``We Won't Work For the Red,'' they shouted. Today, demonstrations forced the closure of several downtown roads. Today, about 3,000 students staged a strike against what they said were election manipulations. Some ringed a university building, blocking entrances. The Socialists, heir to the Communists who have controlled this Balkan nation since 1944, appeared on the verge of becoming the only Communists to win a free election in an Eastern European country newly free of the Soviet orbit. West German and Bulgarian projections gave them about 48 percent of the vote. The Union of Democratic Forces was second with about 36 percent. In third place was the Agrarian Party, a former docile Communist ally that declared its independence this year, with about 8 percent of the vote. It was followed by the Movement for Rights and Freedoms, with about 5.7 percent. The rest of the vote was divided among 34 other parties that fielded candidates. Half the seats in Parliament are to be filled through races for single-seat constituencies, the other half based upon parties' proportional showing. The results announced today were for single-seat constituencies. Sofia radio said runoffs would be held Sunday in the at least 73 districts where no single candidate won the necessary majority. Sixteen constituences apparently were not yet fully counted. Premier Andrei Lukanov, a leading Socialist Party member, went on television Monday night and urged all parties ``to look beyond party passions'' and take part in a ``broad national coalition.'' ``There are no losers in the present elections because in the final reckoning the victory of democracy is a victory for all,'' he was quoted as saying by the Bulgarian news agency BTA. But the Union's chairman, Zhelyu Zhelev, told Monday's rally that the opposition alliance would not form a coalition the former Communists; ``In the National Assembly we will be a powerful opposition faction.'' The Union picked up immediate backing from the Agrarian Party and the Alternative Socialist Party, which split from the mainstream Socialists because it favors more radical reforms. The growing support for a united opposition means the Socialists will probably have to tackle Bulgaria's growing inflation, $10 billion debt, and consumer shortages alone. The Union favors a quick move to a Western-style free-market economy, while the Socialists favored slower reforms. Union spokesman Georgi Spasov alleged that irregularities in the voting included political agitation in front of polling stations. Petar Beron, a Union official, claimed that the irregularities made as much as a 6 percent difference in the vote. He said the opposition coalition would seek another vote in some places. Western observers reported election irregularities but said they did not affect the overall results substantially. With nearly a century as a strong political force in Bulgaria, the Communist Party was the known quantity. The municipal and local party structures of the former Communist Party are largely intact in small towns and villages and have been taken over by the Socialists. According to the projections, the Union topped the Socialists only in Sofia, with the Socialists carrying the countryside and provincial cities. The opposition had wanted the elections postponed until fall to allow more time for non-Communist parties to organize. Bulgaria had only a nascent opposition when reform Communists ousted longtime Communist strongman Todor Zhivkov last November.

DOC.HEAD: Korean Air Signs Contract for 23 Boeing 747-400s
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs first three grafs to insert word ``contract'' in lead, change ``which each'' to ``each of which'' in graf 3.
DOC.TEXT: Korean Air has signed a $4.8 billion contract for 23 Boeing 747-400s to be delivered by the end of the decade. The contract signed Monday includes spare parts and training and commits Korean Air to 31 of Boeing's most sophisticated and biggest jetliner, more than any other carrier except Japan Air Lines. JAL has signed up for 40 of the world's largest passenger jets. Frank Shrontz, Boeing chairman and chief executive officer, said at a news conference that the large order reflects the fact that traffic growth in the Pacific has been higher than in either the United States or Europe. The 747-400s, each of which will be equipped to carry 392 passengers, also are best suited to meet the long-range flights and high-capacity needs of the region, Shrontz said. Boeing officials said 307 of the Seattle, Wash., company's 747-400s have been ordered, with 71 so far delivered to airlines around the world. The Korean order was the third largest ever received by Boeing and the third multibillion-dollar purchase of Boeing aircraft in as many weeks. The others also were from Asian air carriers: a $2 billion order from the Chinese government and a $3.1 billion order from Japan Air Lines.

DOC.HEAD: Former National Security Aide Draws Six-Month Term, Rebuke
LaserPhoto WX9
With PM-Iran-Contra-Glance
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 9th graf, bgng, Poindexter's sentencing ... to show that Iran-Contra case continuing in court
DOC.TEXT: Former national security adviser John M. Poindexter received a six-month sentence and a stern lecture from a judge who said he undermined democracy by lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter became the first of seven people convicted in the scandal to receive a prison term when he was sentenced Monday by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene. The judge said Poindexter, who plans to appeal, deserved incarceration as the ``decision-making head of the Iran-Contra operation.'' Probation ``would be tantamount to a statement that a scheme to lie (to) and obstruct Congress is of no great moment,'' Greene said. Poindexter, who served as President Reagan's national security adviser from late 1985 until the Iran-Contra scandal forced his resignation in November 1986, was convicted of conspiracy, making false statements to Congress and obstructing lawmakers' inquiries into the Iran-Contra affair. Greene said Poindexter, former White House aide Oliver L. North and others usurped political power from Congress when they set up a covert operation to arm the Contra rebels in Nicaragua in defiance of a congressional ban on such aid. ``When Admiral Poindexter and his associates obstructed the Congress, what were they seeking to accomplish?'' the judge asked. ``In a word it was to nullify the decision that body had made on the issue of supplies to the Contras.'' Poindexter was found guilty of conspiring to thwart attempts by Congress in 1986 to verify reports that North was coordinating the secret resupply operation for the rebels. He was also convicted of lying and destroying documents to conceal the U.S. role in a 1985 shipment of Hawk anti-aircraft missiles to Iran. Poindexter's sentencing doesn't close the Iran-Contra affair. A newly-empaneled federal grand jury is trying to determine the precise roles of Reagan, then-Vice President George Bush, CIA officers and others in the case. The grand jury probe is being conducted by the office of independent counsel Lawrence Walsh. Poindexter, 53, a retired Navy rear admiral, made no statement in court and showed little emotion, except to smile at his wife, Linda, after the sentence was imposed. The couple kissed and walked arm-in-arm out of the courtroom. Outside the U.S. District Courthouse, Poindexter briefly joined a throng of about 30 demonstrators who held placards urging President Bush to pardon the Iran-Contra defendants and fire their prosecutor, independent counsel Walsh. His car drove off to the strains of ``Anchors Aweigh,'' which was broadcast over loudspeakers set up by the demonstrators, who chanted ``Full pardon now.'' White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater declined to comment on the sentence. Asked if he would rule out a pardon by President Bush, Fitzwater said: ``I can rule out having any comment on this matter while the case is under appeal.'' Greene said Poindexter violated ``a principle fundamental to this constitutional republic _ that those elected by and responsible to the people shall make important policy decisions.'' ``It is unfortunate that, whatever may be his view of his own purposes and actions, the defendant still gives no evidence or recognizing that principle and the seriousness of its violation,'' the judge said. The judge did not impose any fine, saying Poindexter had already amassed large legal bills. The former national security adviser was allowed to remain free pending appeal of his conviction. Defense attorney Richard W. Beckler urged Greene to show leniency because of Poindexter's 33 years of service as a Navy officer. ``He cared for his country, he cared for his family,'' Beckler said. ``All his life he set an example of dedication of service to his country.'' Prosecutor Dan K. Webb ``there is nothing about this man's background that would have predicted ... he would have committed five serious felony offenses. Yet, the jury's verdict stands as a monument to that fact.'' Afterward, Webb said the term imposed by Greene was ``a very fair and very proper sentence'' that would warn other public officials. Both the judge and Webb noted that Poindexter sought leniency without expressing any regrets or remorse. Greene said that under sentencing guidelines that took effect after the Iran-Contra affair, Poindexter could have been sentenced to between 21 and 27 months. But the judge said that it would be unfair to impose that long a sentence while other Iran-Contra defendants ``received the benefits of probation, community service or fine.'' North drew 1,200 hours of community service and a $150,000 fine, and Robert McFarlane, Poindexter's predecessor as national security adviser, received two years' probation, a $20,000 fine and 200 hours of community service.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Scores Bush on Administration Cambodia Policy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, The administration, to restore full reference to Bush; SUBS 7th graf, In the literal, to CORRECT `credible' to `incredible.'
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, criticizing the Bush administration's Cambodia policy, says he's determined to find out if any American money is reaching the Khmer Rouge. Mitchell said Congress passed a law in 1985 that bars the Khmer Rouge from getting any military help _ direct or indirect _ from the United States. ``It appears that there is reason to question whether this law is being obeyed,'' Mitchell said, adding that the Senate Intelligence Committee plans to hold oversight hearings into U.S. policy on Cambodia and the administration's compliance with the law. The administration has denied that the Khmer Rouge benefits from U.S. aid. But President Bush said last month he ordered a review of U.S.-Cambodia policy, saying he was troubled by the perception that the United States is aiding the Khmer Rouge. ``To the degree it has any effect to help them, yes, I am uncomfortable about that,'' he told reporters. Mitchell's attack Monday is the third time he has sparred with the administration in recent weeks. ``In the literal sense of the word, the Bush administration's Cambodia policy is incredible, it is insupportable and it must be changed,'' Mitchell said. Last week the Maine Democrat criticized President Bush for granting trade benefits to the Soviet Union without obtaining concessions on Lithuania, and he has vowed to try to thwart extension of a trade pact with China because of that country's human rights policies. China is also involved in Cambodia, Mitchell said. ``It is time to admit that China does not share our goals in Cambodia,'' he said. ``It is time for American policy to reflect American goals.'' The Chinese are the prime sponsors of the Khmer Rouge, the group that committed genocide in the 1970s, he said. The Khmer Rouge were driven from power by the Vietnamese. The Khmer Rouge, along with two non-communist factions, have been trying to oust the Vietnamese-installed government. The United States provides non-lethal assistance to two non-communist guerrilla groups in Cambodia, one headed by Prince Sihanouk and the other by Son Sen. Mitchell said the non-communists, like the Khmer Rouge, also get support from the Chinese. ``Joined in a coalition, they do not fight against the Khmer Rouge, they fight with the Khmer Rouge,'' he said. ``Increasingly there are reports of tactical and strategic military cooperation between Sihanouk's forces and the Khmer Rouge,'' he said. Moreover, ``it is alleged that all factions share intelligence information during battlefield operations,'' he said. Mitchell said the United States is making a big mistake by refusing to talk with the Hun Sen government. ``The current regime is not ideal. But it is not the Khmer Rouge.'' Mitchell urged the administration to use its influence to divorce the non-communists from the Khmer Rouge, to state that it will not support any future government that includes the Khmer Rouge and to ease restrictions of U.S. development aid for the Cambodians. He also said the Khmer Rouge should be stripped of their representation of Cambodia at the United Nations. The State Department has said it opposes any return to power of the Khmer Rouge, but the Cambodians themselves must determine their future in fair and free elections. The United States supports a comprehensive settlement in Cambodia, which involves a major role for the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Republic Passes Non-Binding Sovreignty Measure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with detail on declaration and its lack of legal force, background on Yeltsin and Gorbachev, more comment from deputies. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The vast Russian republic proclaimed its sovereignty today with a declaration that signaled a sharp break with the central Soviet government but carried no legal force. Deputies of the Russian Congress, who overwhelmingly approved the declaration, stressed the move does not amount to a declaration of independence like that of the breakaway Baltic republic of Lithuania. ``We didn't declare ourselves a separate government from the U.S.S.R.,'' said Ruslan Khasbulatov, the Congress' deputy chairman. ``We think our Russian fate should be within the framework of the U.S.S.R.'' The lawmakers last month elected as the republic's president Boris N. Yeltsin, the populist reformer who backs a more radical shift to a market economy than Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. There was no immediate reaction by Gorbachev, who has warned that the Kremlin cannot carry out its reforms if the Russian heartland is not firmly behind it. Yeltsin had urged quick passage of the measure so that June 12 could become ``Russia's independence day.'' The vote was 907-13, and the result was met with applause and a standing ovation. Yeltsin stood and applauded the deputies. Earlier in the day, deputies voted 704-206 not to drop the ``Soviet Socialist'' from the republic's formal name: The Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic. Today's declaration does not actually have any effect on the laws of Russia, by far the largest of the country's 15 republics, comprising two-thirds of the country's territory and just over half its population. The declaration is, however, the basis for writing a new Russian constitution. Passing a declaration that carried legal force, Khasbulatov said, ``would have called forth a big crash.'' The declaration ``solemnly proclaims the state sovereignty of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic on all its territory'' and says laws of the Russian Federation should have priority over centrally dictated Soviet laws. The declaration says the republic has the right to secede from the Soviet Union under conditions to be stated in a future nationwide treaty. But the proclamation serves only as a political statement of intent, with no legal weight. Still, it ``expresses the mood of decentralization in the country,'' said Vyacheslav Maslennikov, a consultant for the Congress' editorial commission. The Russian action falls far short of secessionist drives in the Baltic republics of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. The three Baltic presidents formed a united front last month to press their drives to restore the independence they lost 50 years ago when forcibly annexed. Lithuania has gone the farthest toward secession by declaring its immediate independence on March 11. A radical Russian deputy, Mikhail Maley, said his wing ``had a great desire to pass a real declaration'' of sovereignty, but conceded that lawmakers would not have accepted such a move. Yeltsin, elected to the republic's presidency last month, has been a strong proponent of Russian sovereignty. He included it in his platform and predicted it would be declared in the first 100 days of his tenure. ``I think it has great political significance for our government,'' Khasbulatov, a strong supporter of Yeltsin, said of the declaration. ``It's an extraordinary event for our country, for our Russia.'' Eventually, he said, Russia would ``go on our own ideas,'' especially in the area of economic reform. He said the Russian government hoped to take control of its own foreign trade. Yeltsin, who has become Gorbachev's political nemesis in the last two years, has said he hopes to cooperate with the Soviet president despite their personal and political differences, but that his first priority is defending Russia's interests. Gorbachev, who had opposed Yeltsin's election as president of the Russian republic, indicated last week he would seek a reconciliation with him. ``What would disturb me more than anything at this stage is a split in the democratic forces,'' he said. That implied that he viewed Yeltsin as an ally in the reform movement.

DOC.HEAD: Death Toll in Central Asia Unrest Now 139
DOC.TEXT: Protesters have clashed with police in a Central Asian republic, where the death toll in ethnic fighting has risen to 139, the official Tass news agency said today. In recent days, Soviet media reports from the Soviet republic of Kirghizia had said the unrest between Kirghiz and Uzbeks was subsiding. But Tass said a new clash occurred Monday night when youths in Frunze, the capital of Kirghizia, pelted police with stones and bottles. Several of the youths were detained, it said. No injuries were reported. As of late Saturday, 107 deaths had been reported, with the situation in western Kirghizia reported in the state-controlled newspapers and television to be returning to normal. By today, however, the Kirghiz Interior Ministry said 139 people had been killed and 486 wounded, Tass reported. It did not detail any major clashes in the intervening days. Tass reported again today that ``the situation is stabilizing,'' with residents staging counter-demonstrations and discussing how to resolve the crisis. Soviet officials said the violence began June 2, with fighting between the two Sunni Moslem groups flaring on June 4 in the border city of Osh, a city of 210,000. Uzbeks, who make up one-third of the population, discovered that Kirghiz were being given parcels of land for housing. Housing is critically short in the densely populated region of Central Asia. The fighting spread to districts around Osh, and thousands of troops were sent in to reinforce the local police.
