Soviet troops sealed off the border to prevent thousands of Uzbeks from crossing into Kirghizia to join the battle, and curfews were imposed in the region, including Osh, Frunze and border areas inside neighboring Uzbekistan. At least 500 acts of arson were committed, Soviet media reported. Kirghiz Prime Minister Apas Dzhumagulov said all houses would be rebuilt in a few months if life returns to normal, Tass reported. Dzhumagulov met Sunday with Uzbek Prime Minister Shukurulla Mirsaidov and they pledged that the instigators of the unrest ``will be severely prosecuted,'' Tass reported.

DOC.HEAD: Tempers Flared in Senate over Proposed Flag-Burning Amendment
With PM-Flag Burning Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Recasts 1st two grafs; picks up 3rd graf, ``I'll place ...
DOC.TEXT: Tempers flared on the Senate floor over the Supreme Court's decision to allow flag burning as Republican and Democratic leaders debated renewed calls for a constitutional amendment. Shortly after Monday's ruling, Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., urged action this week on a constitutional amendment protecting the flag from desecration and suggested that those who oppose it side with flag burners. ``I'll place my money on the young men and young women who serve in American's armed services,'' Dole said. ``The rest can place their money on the Jennifer Campbells and the others involved in this flag-burning case.'' Campbell, 23, of Seattle, was one of four defendants accused last fall of violating a law against flag burning that Democrats guided through Congress last year to avoid a constitutional amendment. As many predicted it would, the Supreme Court on Monday overturned the statute as an unconstitutional violation of First Amendment guarantees of freedom of expression. ``We pointed out that it would never work,'' Dole said of the 1989 law. ``It's not as if we have to go back and reinvent the wheel. We've had the debate; we're ready to take up the constitutional amendment.'' Senate Democratic Leader George Mitchell of Maine accused Dole of demeaning those who on principle oppose opening the Constitution up to what in effect would be the first change in the Bill of Rights. ``The question before us is whether or not after 200 years, the American Bill of Rights _ the most concise, the most eloquent, the most effective statement of individual liberty in all of human history _ is to be changed,'' Mitchell said. ``You can debate the issue vigorously ... without suggesting for a moment that the Senate is choosing between Jennifer Campbell and the men and women in our military service,'' he added. ``No such choice is before the Senate ... or the country.'' Dole turned his back to Mitchell, walked to the rear of the Senate chamber and conferred with an aide as the Democratic leader continued his remarks. Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., later took up Mitchell's theme, calling Dole's request for Senate action this week ``the fast food school of constitutional amendments.'' ``Some would rather debate symbols than reality ... that we have mortgaged our children and our children's children, ... that the United States has fallen behind Japan and Europe in our competitiveness,'' Leahy said. Mitchell said he wanted to confer with several people, including Dole and House leaders, before deciding when to allow the Senate to consider a flag-burning amendment. Amending the Constitution would require support from 67 of the 100 senators and 290 of the 435 representatives. It would then have to be ratified by the legislatures of at least 38 states.

DOC.HEAD: Jew Stabbed In Old City, Cabinet Discusses New Measures
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with new government ministers proposing measures against uprising. Pickup 10th graf `The Israeli...'; EDITS thereafter to trim
DOC.TEXT: A 17-year-old Israeli going to pray at the Western Wall was stabbed twice in the stomach today in the walled Old City, authorities said. A police roundup of Palestinian suspects set off more violence. The incidents came the day after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir won a vote of confidence in Parliament for his new right-wing government. Cabinet members today promised new steps to put down the 2{-year-old Palestinian uprising. Israel radio reported that the new defense minister, Moshe Arens, began consulting high-ranking army officers today on how to end the uprising in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The new foreign minister, David Levy, suggested the army could withdraw from the occupied lands as part of a peace settlement. But he repeated the new government's opposition to Palestinian demands for statehood in the territories. The new government's agriculture minister, Rafael Eitan, who led Israel's forces in the 1982 invasion of Lebanon, suggested on army radio that more Palestinians be deported. ``Instead of shooting at children you have to deport those responsible, the inciters, the organizers,'' he said. Since the start of the uprising in December 1987, 60 Arabs have been expelled to neighboring Lebanon. After today's stabbing in Jerusalem, police seized up about 100 Palestinians near Damascus Gate, one of the main entrances to the Old City, said Jersualem police commander Arieh Bibi. The arrests set off a spate of stone-throwing at Israeli cars on Sultan Suleiman Street just outside the city walls, but no injuries were reported. The victim, identified as Yosef Edri, was in moderate condition at Sharei Tzadek Hospital, spokeswoman Orna Cohen said. He is a student at a yeshiva, or Jewish seminary, and is from Dimona in Israel's Negev Desert. Bibi told Israel radio that police had recovered the knife. In the West Bank and Gaza Strip, meanwhile, soldiers destroyed three houses of Palestinians accused of throwing firebombs or killing suspected Arab collaborators and sealed two other homes of Palestinian suspects. One of the suspects, 25-year-old Abdel Hakim Shana, was convicted of murdering alleged collaborators and sentenced to life imprisonment. Soldiers tore down the four-room house owned by his father, which was home to a family of 12. The Supreme Court rejected appeals from some families of the suspects. U.S. policy opposes the demolition of houses as an unfair collective punishment. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories said there has been a marked decline in recent months in destruction of houses by the army. It said that through the end of May a total of 293 houses were destroyed and 173 sealed for security reasons. Several hundred others have been destroyed for being built without a permit.

DOC.HEAD: Casino Gambling Wins November Ballot Spot in Ohio
DOC.TEXT: A constitutional amendment for a casino gambling pilot project has gained a spot on the November ballot in Ohio. Secretary of State Sherrod Brown announced on Monday that the Let Us Vote Ohio Committee submitted 318,899 valid signatures on its initiative petitions, 12,238 more than required by law. The group gathered the minimum number of signatures required from 44 of the state's 88 counties. If approved by voters statewide, the referendum would allow the City Council in Lorain _ a Lake Erie port town about 30 miles west of Cleveland _ to place a referendum on the local ballot proposing a five-year pilot project casino. After that time, the Legislature could end the project or create seven additional resorts districts in Cleveland, Columbus, Cincinnati, Toledo, Dayton, Youngstown and Steubenville. ``We think it's the responsible approach, to stick your toe in the water and not go, as they did in Atlantic City, whole hog,'' said backer Alan Spitzer. Representatives of the horse racing industry and some churches already have lined up in opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Reagan, Ford To Attend Opening of Nixon Library; Carter Begs Off
DOC.TEXT: Richard M. Nixon will be joined by President Bush and former presidents Gerald Ford and Ronald Reagan at next month's opening of his presidential library. Bush, Ford and Reagan will attend the July 19 dedication at Yorba Linda, 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles. Former President Carter declined the invitation, citing a previous commitment. Hugh Hewitt, director of the Nixon library foundation, said Monday that he had not received White House confirmation that Bush would attend. The Los Angeles Times, citing an administration source, reported today that the president would be there. The privately funded library on the site where Nixon was born in 1913 opens almost 17 years after he resigned in the wake of the Watergate scandal. The gathering would mark the first time since Bush was elected that the four living Republican presidents have met. The 8,400-square-foot library will house replicas of Nixon's White House papers, materials from his congressional terms, private papers and White House diaries.

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Said Reached in Northeast Sri Lanka
DOC.TEXT: Government troops and Tamil rebels have agreed to a cease-fire in northeastern Sri Lanka, government and rebel officials said today. Fighting has raged for two days between government forces and the Tamil Tigers for two days in the Batticaloa and Ampara districts in northeastern Sri Lanka. Witnesses said more than 85 people were killed. The clashes were the worst since a cease-fire was declared in Sri Lanka 13 months ago between the rebels and the government of President Ranasinghe Premadasa. The new truce was to take effect Wednesday. Government officials speaking on condition of anonymity said the agreement had been reached in negotiations by Justice Minister Shahul Hameed and Tamil Tiger in Jaffna, a Tiger stronghold in northern Sri Lanka. A Tiger spokesman, contacted by telephone in Jaffna and also speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the agreement. Tamil rebels, a minority in Sri Lanka, are fighting for more political autonomy. They claim they are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, while Sinhalese comprise 75 percent. Journalists and residents contacted by telephone in Batticaloa on Tuesday said the dead in fighting that began Sunday included 30 Tamil civilians in the villages of Chavalakadai and Chadayantalawa. Batticaloa residents said the city was deserted and that transportation was halted and shops, businesses and schools were shut down. They reported heavy fire by helicopter gunships. The Tigers took virtual control of the northeastern districts after Indian peacekeeping forces withdrew in March. Premadasa's government, which has been negotiating with the Tigers for the past year, requested the Indians' departure. At least 11,000 people, including 1,200 Indian soldiers, have been killed in the Tamil war since it started in 1983. Another 6,000 people have been killed since 1987 in a backlash to Tamil demands whipped up by Sinhalese guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Algeria Holds First Multiparty Elections; Opposition Parties Urge Boycott
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with police deployed, no violence reported. Pick up 3rd graf pvs, `Other opposition...'; SUBS 15th graf pvs, `The Front...', with 2 grafs to ADD background on boycotting parties' positions. Pickup 16th graf `Many Algerian...'
DOC.TEXT: Algerians cast ballots today in the country's first contested elections since French rule ended in 1962, but some opposition parties contended the voting was rigged and urged a boycott. The main challenge to the National Liberation Front, which has held sole power since this North African country gained its independence, was expected to come from the fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front. Police were deployed throughout the country, but there were no reports of violence. Authorities said the heavy police presence was to protect voters, but they also feared violent street protests if the fundamentalists failed to win a majority. Other opposition parties looked for a low turnout among the country's 13 million eligible voters as an indication of support for their boycott call. They claimed the election was rigged in favor of the National Liberation Front because the ruling party controls nearly all the media, has greater resources than other parties to help get out the vote, and has its functionaries in the local government offices where the votes will be counted. In all, 11 parties were contesting the election, which is to fill nearly 15,000 seats on 1,541 municipal councils and 48 provincial councils. Elections for the National People's Assembly, or parliament, are not scheduled until 1993 but President Chadli Bendjedid could decide to advance the date for parliamentary elections depending on the outcome of the municipal voting. Until recently, the National Liberation Front was the country's only legal political party. Its candidates continue to enjoy access to state funds, office space and the media, although there have been official efforts to assist the new parties. The National Liberation Front is an old-line Marxist party born out of the Algerian independence struggle. It has abandoned its efforts to turn Algeria into a one-party socialist state. Although the Front takes note of Islam as a major tradition in Algeria, it has steered clear of fundamentalism. The Islamic Salvation Front, the best organized among the new parties, wants to establish the Islamic legal code, the Sharia, as law and openly opposes the democratic process. ``We expect the people to give us 75 percent of the vote,'' said Islamic Salvation Front leader Ali Madani, a philosophy teacher. Hundreds of university faculty members wrote a letter to Algerian newspapers denouncing Madani's remarks as a provocation. Some of the country's most important opposition political groups were either barred from the elections or calling for a nationwide boycott. The opposition covers a broad political spectrum, including communists, social democrats and conservatives. The Algerian Popular Party, the National Liberation Front's main rival during the independence struggle against France, was among several parties refused official recognition by the government and barred from fielding candidates. Two other opposition parties, the Front of Socialist Forces and the Movement for Democracy in Algeria, chose not to run and instead called for an election boycott. The Movement for Democracy is a leftist populist group headed by former President Ahmed Ben Bella, who was forced out of office by a military coup n 1965 and now lives in exile in Switzerland. The Front of Socialist Forces is headed by Berber leader Ait Ahmed, a historic figure in the country's liberation struggle. It is a middle-of-the-road group that places strong emphasis on preserving the Berber language. Many Algerian women have little say in the elections. Under the country's Islamic family code, any man can vote on behalf of his wife, or wives, without producing a document authorizing him to do so. The attitude of the 120,000-strong Algerian military could prove decisive for the country's political future. The fundamentalists have called for the military to intervene to establish an Islamic republic, but senior army officers seem more likely to support a state free of religious interference.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader, Government Delegation Arrive for Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: Government and rebel leaders traveled to neighboring Malawi today for their first direct peace talks aimed at ending a 13-year-old civil war, the national news agency reported. Afonso Dhlakama, commander of the Mozambique National Resistance known by its Portuguese acronym RENAMO, arrived in Malawi's capital Blantyre, the AIM news agency said. The delegation of the leftist government included Transport Minister Armando Guebaza and Foreign Minister Pascoal Mocumbi, both members of the Political Bureau of the ruling FRELIMO Party, AIM said. ``By midday, all the actors in the drama were present in Blantyre, although the talks had not yet begun,'' AIM said. Also in Blantyre to mediate the talks were government officials from Kenya and Zimbabwe. Kenyan President Daniel Arap Moi and President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe arranged several indirect, low-level meetings last year aimed at bringing the two sides to the negotiating table. Earlier today, a spokesman for the guerrillas in Lisbon, Portugal, denied that RENAMO would hold talks in Malawi. ``We are prepared to meet anytime, anywhere, except Malawi,'' Manuel Frank told the independent TSF radio station in Lisbon. RENAMO had said it would prefer talks in Kenya or Portugal, which ruled Mozambique until 1975. The war has claimed an estimated 600,000 lives and turned the southeast African nation into one of the poorest countries in the world. Almost half of Mozambique's 15 million people require food assistance and the annual per capita income is less than $200. The rebels are active throughout Mozambique, waging hit-and-run attacks on both military and civilian targets. They have been accused of committing atrocities against civilians. No government acknowledges supporting the rebels, although South Africa openly backed them in the early 1980s, and the white-minority government of Rhodesia helped them until it became black-ruled Zimbabwe. The rebels have demanded recognition by the government and free elections in Mozambique, but their political aims have never been clear. Chissano's government officially dropped its Marxist label last year and has moved away from its socialist-oriented economy toward a more market-oriented system in recent years. The government has proposed a new constitution to allow elections in which independents could challenge candidates from Chissano's ruling party, the Front for the Liberation of Mozambique. However, the government has refused to allow opposition parties. The government receives most of its military aid from the Soviet Union, but it also has developed good relations with the West in recent years. The United States is the leading donor of food aid in Mozambique.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Renews Call for United Germany in NATO `With No Conditions'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 9 grafs with Bush comments on latest Gorbachev proposal; picks up 4th graf pvs, De Maiziere said ...
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said anew today that a united Germany must belong to NATO without conditions, and not the associate membership suggested by Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But Bush, at the outset of a meeting with Republican congressional leaders, said he stood ready to listen and discuss ``without rancor'' any ideas the Soviets have for solving the dispute over the future of Germany. Gorbachev suggested in a speech today to the Supreme Soviet legislature that he could accept a German ``associative participation'' in NATO, provided that there were no changes in the ``mutual obligations'' that East Germany now has to the East bloc and West Germany to NATO. Gorbachev also said the two military alliances both must be transformed from their Cold War status. Bush, fielding a question from reporters, indicated that the Gorbachev proposal was not new, but had come up during the superpower summit here two weeks ago. ``Our position is well known to him, which is that a unified Germany should be in NATO with no conditions,'' said the president, who was observing his 66th birthday today. ``But the more talking we do, the more convinced I am that they will see that what we're proposing is more stabilizing and is best for the Soviet Union as well as Western Europe and Eastern Europe.'' ``So we'll keep on trying,'' Bush added. ``But these ideas, let them float them out there and we'll listen and we'll discuss them without rancor.'' Bush met Monday with East Germany's first non-communist leader, Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, who said afterwards that NATO must be ``significantly changed'' if Soviet concerns about membership for a united Germany are to be met. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the United States believes ``considerable progress'' has been made in persuading Gorbachev that a unified Germany inside the Western alliance will not threaten Soviet security or European peace. ``I made clear to him what psychological difficulties this would signify,'' de Maiziere said after his Oval Office meeting with Bush. ``I made clear to him that it must be a significantly changed NATO in order to be acceptable to our East European neighbors.'' De Maiziere said he and Bush agreed that creating a new, lasting and stable security order in Europe is possible only ``if the role of the Soviet Union is written into it.'' The prime minister added that membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization for a united Germany ``is only thinkable'' if a treaty clearly defines the status of Soviet troops now stationed in East Germany. It remains open whether such a treaty should be between NATO and the Warsaw Pact or between Germany and the Soviet Union,'' he said. De Maiziere said Bush insisted that questions over such a treaty would have to be resolved by the countries negotiating the unification of East and West Germany. A White House statement said Bush and de Maiziere agreed that a united Germany ``should enjoy full sovereignty from the time of its unification, with no discriminatory constraints on its sovereignty, and that Germany should be free to choose its own alliance arrangements.'' The March election of De Maiziere, chairman of the East German Christian Democratic Union, replaced a once rigidly communist regime. He now heads a government rapidly moving to unify with West Germany. He was responsible for church affairs in the government of Hans Modrow, the last communist leader. Fitzwater said Bush stressed his belief that a united Germany's membership in NATO is essential for European security and will pose no threat to the Soviet Union. Gorbachev has said he is unwilling to accept continued German membership in NATO on grounds it is a U.S.-led, anti-Soviet military alliance. He wants a united Germany to belong to both the Warsaw Pact and NATO. But Fitzwater said Gorbachev's summit meeting with Bush this month, and later assurances offered by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, may be helping to change Gorbachev's mind. ``It's clear that this is going to be a gradual process ... I can't report any conclusion to the matter, but we do feel progress is going to be made,'' the spokesman said. De Maizierie said he took his reception by Bush, the first between an American president and an East German leader, as ``an honor to the people of my country who won their freedom in a peaceful, democratic revolution.'' Bush told White House visitors that the East German prime minister was clearly moved by his visit, an event that would have been all but unthinkable at the height of the Cold War. ``He was so emotional about it. He had never been here,'' the president said, describing his meeting with de Maiziere as ``wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: Chubby Checker's Bus Aboard In Crash; Checker Unhurt But 5 Slightly Injured
DOC.TEXT: A bus carrying rock-'n'-roller Chubby Checker struck a semi-tractor trailer early this morning. Checker was not among the five people injured, authorities said. ``He's on there,'' said Charles Lynch, a supervisor for the Oklahoma Department of Transportation, referring to Checker. ``He's just wandering around. He ain't hurt. About four or five were hurt.'' Lynch said he was told the bus slammed into the rear end of an 18-wheeler. Five people were being treated for minor injuries at the Love County Health Center in Marietta, said hospital spokesman Richard Barker. ``We did not treat Mr. Checker, so evidently he was not injured,'' Barker added. The Oklahoma Highway Patrol said the 5:45 a.m. accident involved a semi-tractor trailer and a bus carrying 12 passengers. The accident closed both southbound lanes of Interstate 35 just north of the Texas border. Checker gained international fame three decades ago as the man who popularized the dance known as the ``twist.'' He reportedly was en route from Chicago to San Antonio when the accident occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Weather Improves, Patching Expected to Begin
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with better weather, repairs expected to begin but fuel to remain on ship. Picks up 6th graf, `I'm not...'.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The weather improved today and divers should be able to begin patching a 90-foot gash in a cruise ship off Cape Cod, the Coast Guard said. Cleanup crews had been waiting for calmer seas and clearer weather to unload thousands of gallons of diesel before repairs began. But the Coast Guard said today the fuel would probably be left on board. ``The weather's definitely better today,'' said Petty Officer Kelly King in Boston. ``The first thing on the agenda is to fully check the hull and patch it up.'' About 7,500 gallons of diesel fuel already had leaked from the 617-foot Bermuda Star, which ran onto a rocky ledge Sunday, and some oil washed onto about five miles of a rocky shoreline of pristine Naushon Island, the Coast Guard said. About 100,000 gallons of thick fuel remained on board, exposed by a 90-by-2-foot tear, but pressure from seawater kept the oil inside while the vessel lay at anchor, officials said. ``If you moved the ship now, the inertia of the sea would take away the balancing effect we have, and it would suck the oil right out of the tear in the ship,'' said Coast Guard spokesman Steve Aitkins. Repairs and unloading were called off Monday because of rain, fog, winds of 15 to 30 mph and 2-to-4-foot waves that endangered repair crews, the Coast Guard said. ``I'm not in any rush to hurry through that,'' said Cmdr. Larry Doyle, executive officer of the Coast Guard's Marine Safety Office in Providence, R.I. ``The vessel is stable; it's safe.'' The fuel spilled so far threatens wildlife in Buzzards Bay, including the world's largest population of roseate terns, a shorebird, experts said. The Bermuda Star was freed Sunday nearly 13 hours after it strayed too close to shore and ran aground in dense fog on a cruise from New York to Nova Scotia. Sunday evening, 680 passengers and about 380 crew members were taken off the ship by ferry. ``There was a sudden stop and then a metallic noise, then immediately there was an oily smell. We went out on deck and we could see the oil coming out on the water,'' said passenger Paul Kelly of Columbia, S.C. Blood and urine tests were given to key members of the crew. Results were not immediately available. David Roddy, senior vice president of Bermuda Star Line Cruises in Teaneck, N.J., said the ship's captain, Hans Lewing, was an excellent skipper with 20 years of shipping experience. Lewing had been with the company for three years and had no record of problems, Roddy said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Celebrates 66th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: President Bush turned 66 today, and several reporters trooped into the Cabinet Room wearing children's birthday hats in honor of the occasion. They were rewarded with laughter and applause from Bush and the Republican congressional leaders he was meeting with. The lawmakers had already burst into a chorus of ``Happy Birthday'' as the first wave of media entered the room. ``It's a vast improvement,'' a smiling president told the reporters in the silly hats. He then gave them a birthday present: he waived his rule against answering questions at these so-called photo opportunities. There was one catch. ``Only those wearing hats get their questions answered,'' Bush admonished the hatless reporters in the Cabinet Room. Bush said he did not know if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had sent him a birthday card. But, he added diplomatically, ``I've got to be careful. He may well have sent something.'' He also fielded a query about the latest Soviet suggestion on how to resolve East-West differences over NATO membership for a united Germany. Bush was being feted with more ceremony tonight at a black-tie GOP fund-raising event in his honor, the annual President's Dinner, at the Washington Convention Center. Some 4,000 guests were paying $1,500 apiece to attend the event, expected to raise several million dollars for Senate and House GOP candidates.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Administration Accepts Reluctance in Congress on Trade Pact
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today the Bush administration accepts the fact that Congress won't approve a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement until Moscow loosens its grip on Lithuania. Baker, making his first appearance on Capitol Hill since the U.S.-Soviet summit ended June 3, said President Bush has made this point to Soviet Leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``We do not believe that Congress will approve the commercial agreement until the deadlock over Lithuania is broken,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. ``That is a fact of political life.'' Bush said he would not send the agreement to Congress for approval until the Soviet Union passed a law granting free emigration to Soviet Jews and others. But he did not link the trade pact to Lithuania. Many members of Congress promised to oppose the trade agreement until the Soviet Union ended its embargo against the breakaway Baltic republic and participated in negotiations aimed at achieving Lithuanian independence. The agreement requires majority approval by both the House and Senate. Baker said wide distances remain between the United States and the Soviets regarding Lithuania. He said he wished he could report the two superpowers' positions were close, ``but they are not.'' At the same time he said, administration officials are encouraged that Baltic leaders are in Moscow for talks. The administration hopes a ``systematic dialogue'' will lead to a peaceful resolution of the problem, he said. On other issues, Baker praised the recent multi-party elections in Czechoslovakia in which pro-democracy groups received the plurality of the votes. ``The big winner was democracy,'' Baker said. But Baker said the administration was reserving judgment on what happened in the Bulgarian elections, where the socialist party _ the former communists _ took almost half the vote. ``Questions about possible election-day abuses are being explored by government and party representatives,'' Baker said. While Baker said the summit provided solid underpinning for future U.S.-Soviet relations, differences remain between the two superpowers. Specifically, he criticized the Soviets for continuing to support Cuba. ``We are still concerned ... about Soviet support for Cuba and Cuban support for the rebels in El Salvador,'' he said. ``Continued Soviet military assistance for Cuba is a striking exception to the Soviet Union's `new thinking' on regional issues.'' Baker reiterated the U.S. position that a unified Germany should remain in NATO. He said he believes the Soviet Union eventually will come around to accepting this view. The Soviets now oppose giving a unified Germany NATO membership. On arms control, he said the administration has been heartened by recent Soviet statements renewing a commitment to seek a rapid agreement on reducing conventional forces in Europe. Overall, Baker said, there will be aftershocks from the momentous changes in the world in 1989. ``There will also be great opportunities to create a more democratic, more prosperous and more secure world,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Delegation Arrives In Sierra Leone for Liberian Peace Talks
DOC.TEXT: A delegation of Liberian rebels arrived this morning for talks with government officials aimed at ending the tribal war in the West African nation, U.S. Embassy sources said. A delegation of government representatives and members of the Liberian Council of Churches, which is to mediate the talks, arrived Monday in Sierra Leone, Liberia's western neighbor. The embassy sources said the talks were to be held in the U.S. Cultural Center auditorium, but they could not say when they would begin. The talks were delayed Monday, when rebel sources said their delegation was taking a roundabout route to avoid the danger of attack. Both sides made concessions to permit the talks possible. But the talks could be headed to an early impasse if rebels stick to their demand that Liberian President Samuel Doe resign and leave the country before a cease-fire can be arranged in the five-month-old war. Doe agreed to send a delegation after rebels had advanced to within 25 miles of the capital of Monrovia. His troops, unable to halt the rebels since they invaded from the Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, were accused of killing hundreds of civilians believed to support the insurgents. The rebels had met little resistance until a week ago, when government troops managed to retake the headquarters of the Firestone rubber plantation. Doe, who had refused negotiations with the rebels as long as Taylor, a former aide, led them, agreed to begin talks after his troops chased the rebels from the plantation. Rebels claim to have subsequently retaken the plantation, but its American employees told their headquarters that it was not clear who was in control. Taylor had been insisting Doe surrender before any negotiations could begin but accepted the appeal from church leaders to enter talks. He said he would send a delegation to the talks but no cease-fire could be arranged until Doe leaves Liberia. Taylor's delegation was believed to be headed by Tom Woewiyu, who had been serving as the rebels' spokesman. The government delegation to the peace talks was to include Justice Minister Jenkins Scott, Information Minister Emmanuel Bowier, Senate Presi

DOC.HEAD: Texas Wasn't Ready for a Catastrophic Spill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `But at...', to CORRECT some equipment, not crews, were far away; CLARIFY that equipment in Europe not `a continent away.'
DOC.TEXT: Texas should prepare for oil spills the way California prepares for earthquakes, a state official said as emergency crews braced for a possibly catastrophic spill from the Mega Borg burning in the Gulf of Mexico. ``We've got some plans. But they're not capable of handling a gigantic spill,'' Andy Mangan, deputy land commissioner, said Monday. The 886-foot Norwegian supertanker had been carrying 38 million gallons of light crude when explosions and fire crippled it Saturday. But at the time some of the needed equipment for oil containment and salvage was in Europe. Equipment to spray flame-choking foam was in Louisiana. More powerful explosions hit Sunday, spilling blazing crude into the Gulf and nudging the ship closer to sinking. Early today waves were breaking over the tanker's deck. Officials estimated as much as 100,000 gallons of oil had spilled. On Monday, Mangan and other state officials urged lawmakers to unify the state's scattershot approach to dealing with spills. He said the state should prepare for such disasters the way San Francisco prepares for earthquakes. ``The focus has not been there. There hasn't been any concerted effort to put such a contingency plan together,'' Mangan said. Mangan said state officials have worked closely with Alaska and other states since the Exxon Valdez spill, the nation's worst at nearly 11 million gallons. He said Texas probably is better prepared than some coastal states but not as well prepared as it could be. In Florida on Monday, Gov. Bob Martinez signed what he said is the nation's most comprehensive law for preventing and cleaning up oil spills. The law, a compromise with oil shippers and retailers, requires vessels and terminals to develop detailed spill-response plans and terminals to buy spill-containment equipment. Among other things, it also raises liability limits for spill damage and cleanup costs for transporters and owners of cargo. Texas Land Commissioner Garry Mauro, a member of the Governor's Oil Spill Advisory Committee, agreed Texas has some work to do. He said Texas ports handle 300 million tons of cargo each year, 75 percent of it oil products. ``This is our worst nightmare,'' Mauro said. ``We're not ready to deal with a catastrophic oil spill off the coast.'' The delay-plagued cleanup effort bears out Mauro's words. Firefighters were hoping to start battling the blaze with foam on Sunday. But that tactic was pushed back because equipment to spray the foam had to be brought from Louisiana, said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Sam Wilson. Other oil containment and salvage equipment was brought from as far away as Holland. The private companies responding to the Mega Borg fire had their equipment overseas because there are more offshore fires in the North Sea and Middle East than the Gulf of Mexico, Coast Guard Adm. Williams Merlin said. John Sharp, Texas railroad commissioner and a member of the Governor's Oil Spill Advisory Committee, said the Exxon Valdez accident in 1989 had prompted state efforts to try to better coordinate a plan. ``When you're talking about a spill that is possible _ the size of an entire tanker _ I'm not sure you can make plans that are going to always adequately cover one that size or the size of a Valdez,'' Sharp said. ``What you have to do is make sure you do everything you can to ensure they don't happen to begin with.'' Other state officials said the response has gone well so far. Gov. Bill Clements said the state is ``pulling out all the stops'' to prepare for a major spill. He noted that there was a meeting Monday of the State Emergency Management Council, which includes 27 state agencies and the Red Cross. Buck Wynne, chairman of the Texas Water Commission, said a recent drill that simulated a 200,000-gallon spill in the Gulf helped prepare the state. ``Hopefully, we've identified problems in coordinating a response to a major oil spill,'' said Wynne, whose agency is part of a regional response team that also includes the Coast Guard and other federal agencies. ``I think we are as ready as we can be.''

DOC.HEAD: Environmental Groups Sue to Block Restart of Nuclear Arms Plant
DOC.TEXT: Two environmental groups said today they had filed a federal lawsuit in South Carolina to try to block the restart of a federal nuclear weapons plant closed more than two years ago for safety reasons. The suit by the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Energy Research Foundation was filed Monday in U.S. District Court in Columbia, said Daniel W. Reicher, an attorney for NRDC. The Energy Department, which owns the Savannah River Site, has said it intends to restart the first of Savannah River's three active reactors by next January. The plant produces tritium gas for nuclear warheads. The reactors were closed in 1988 after an accident at one facility raised troubling questions about safety standards and the risk of mechanical failures. More than $1 billion is being spent to upgrade the reactors and retrain workers. Energy Secretary James D. Watkins has said the timetable for restarting the plant is tentative, but that putting the reactors back in production soon is vital to the nation's security. Tritium decays at a rate of 5.5 percent a year, so the quantities in warheads must be replenished. The government says its stockpile of tritium is running low, although information about tritium inventories is classified. A secretary in the Energy Department's public affairs office said no one was immediately available to comment on the lawsuit. Reicher said the suit contends that the government should not be permitted to restart the K reactor at Savannah River until it completes construction of a cooling tower for water discharged from the reactor into man-made lakes. Environmental groups contend the water, at temperatures of up to 180 degrees, interferes with fish migration and causes other environmental damage. The cooling tower is scheduled for completion in 1992. Reicher said the department could remain in compliance with the federal Water Pollution Control Act of 1972 without finishing the cooling tower if President Bush issued a waiver of the pollution requirements on national security grounds. Bush has given no indication of whether he would grant such a waiver. The weapons plant, whose reactors were built in the early 1950s, is situated on a 315-square-mile federal reservation near Aiken, S.C., along the Savannah River.

DOC.HEAD: N.D. Voters Decide Whether to Bail Out Schools
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `At the...', to clarify that pregnancy was reason woman's feet were swollen.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Primaries Rdp
DOC.TEXT: Last summer, Rebecca Donovan landed her dream job as head librarian for Hazen's three schools. She had spent 12 years in nearby Stanton as an English teacher who also ran the school library, arranged the prom and sold popcorn at basketball games. ``I was pregnant. At the end of the night, my feet would be swelled up like bowling balls,'' she said, recalling those grim days of being ``spread too thin.'' But her joy was brief. Donovan, 37, got laid off in April. North Dakota cut its education budget by more than $31 million this spring after voters rejected tax increases, and some schools closed, others cut out art, music and home economics, and more than 300 teachers lost their contracts. Donovan's hopes of getting her job back may rest with North Dakota's voters, who decide today whether to raise the sales tax from 5 percent to 6 percent for a year to bail out education by raising an estimated $42 million. John Conrad, a retired businessman who has campaigned to raise the tax, said voters' reluctance to open their wallets wider has harmed education. ``People have to look kids right square in the eye and say, `Are these kids worth it?''' he said. Conrad has billed his campaign ``A Penny for Our Kids.'' Opponents said the schools will benefit by being forced to consolidate and share. Government spending, they added, is bloated and needs a crash diet. ``State government has become a monster, not a servant of the people,'' says Republican state Sen. Bryce Streibel. ``The special interests want to have their way _ `Let the poor sucker who's out in the boondocks struggling along ... pay the bill.''' Voters rejected increases in income, sales and gasoline taxes in December but showed the most sympathy for higher sales taxes, with 47 percent approving an increase. Kent French, a businessman who led the drive last year against tax increases, argued the state budget is big enough to provide for education. If lawmakers want to provide more, they should cut from other areas, he said. ``While no one wants education to suffer, some necessary changes are being made,'' French said. Because of the financial crunch, North Dakotans are taking a harder look at how their school boards manage their budgets, he and others said. Wayne Sanstead, state superintendent of public instruction, said teacher morale could take a dive if the measure is voted down. ``I think the school administrators and the teachers are going to wonder, `Where is the support that people talk about having?'' he said. The Hazen district is cutting $400,000 from its budget next year, said Superintendent Ray Frank. Hazen shed the equivalent of five teaching jobs, reducing its music and library staffs and laying off a counselor. The district also canceled plans to hire another sixth-grade teacher, which probably means larger classes, Frank said. Donovan said she is troubled by the cuts, especially when she looks at her young son, who has shown talent at local art contests. Offerings such as music and art are ``the only things that separate us from the animals,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Softens Position over Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev easing position on Germany in NATO, Bush reax, comment from official radio, diplomat's interpretation; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today proposed that a united Germany could be an associate member of a transformed NATO. Western diplomats said Gorbachev, in his hourlong speech to the Supreme Soviet legislature, appeared to show more flexibility on the German question. Only days earlier, he had reiterated Soviet opposition to NATO membership. Gorbachev also said the Washington summit achieved ``huge results'' in arms control. The speech, broadcast live on Soviet TV, gave Gorbachev the chance to highlight his area of greatest success, foreign policy. His domestic policy faces increasing criticism from citizens. The country is beset with severe economic problems, ethnic clashes and secessionist movements. Speaking calmly and smiling frequently, Gorbachev told the legislators that his warm reception in the United States and the signing of a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement were evidence of U.S. faith in his domestic reform program. Gorbachev recounted his discussions at the Washington summit with President Bush on a united Germany joining the North Atlantic Treat Organization, the Western military alliance. East Germany is a member of the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. ``Our position is thus: We could agree to the joining, if you accept associative participation, the principle of blocs coming together in conjunction with the unification of Germany in the process of which mutual obligations are not changed, neither from the side of West or East Germany, and if simultaneously the blocs are reformed in natural connection with Vienna and the all-European process.'' Gorbachev did not define his concept of associate membership for Germany. Vienna is the site of talks on arms cuts and the Europe-wide Conference on Security and Cooperation aimed at reducing tensions. Bush, asked by reporters in Washington about Gorbachev's speech today, said, ``a unified Germany should be in NATO with no conditions.'' But Bush said he stands ready to listen and discuss ``without rancor'' any ideas the Soviets have for solving the dispute over the future of Germany. Official Radio Moscow explained Gorbachev's comments saying: ``it might be possible to agree with Germany being in NATO as an associated member provided there are changes in the nature of the military alliances, both NATO and the Warsaw Treaty organization. Gorbachev appeared to be demanding that a united Germany fulfill East Germany's obligations to the Warsaw Pact only during a transition period, when the function of the two military blocs would change. A Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Gorbachev's comments appeared to signal ``positive movement'' on the German question. But he said it was still unlikely Gorbachev's position would be acceptable to the Western allies without further modification. Previously, the Soviet Union sought membership in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact for a united Germany. A West German newspaper reported Monday that, at a meeting in Washington, East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere would give Bush a new proprosal from Gorbachev to break the deadlock over Germany's military allegiance. The Sueddeutsche Zeitung said Gorbachev would agree to NATO membership for a united Germany if the Western alliance made ``a clear decision to transform itself into a political alliance.'' Speaking of the May 30-June 3 summit with Bush, Gorbachev said: ``As a whole, I think huge results were achieved in Washington toward limiting nuclear and conventional weapons.'' ``All this has great meaning,'' he said. ``Another practical step was taken to realize the idea of a non-violent, non-nuclear world.'' There is difficult work ahead, but the danger of the Cold War has begun to recede, he said. Gorbachev and Bush signed agreements to eliminate the two sides' chemical weapons and to reach a final accord this year to cut sharply their strategic nuclear weapons. Speaking to the legislature, Gorbachev cited the trade bill he signed with Bush as evidence that the ``American government indeed has faith in us.''

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says PLO Response Inadequate on Terrorist Attack
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today the actions of the Palestine Liberation Organization in the wake of an aborted terrorist attack on an Israeli beach have been inadequate. But he told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the United States has not made any decision on whether to cut off dialogue with the PLO because of the matter. ``We want to weigh matters carefully and do so without the pressure of artificial deadlines,'' said Baker, noting that suspending talks with the PLO would have far-reaching ramifications on future Middle East peace efforts. Abu Abbas, a member of the PLO executive committee, claimed responsibility for the attempted seaborne attack. While the PLO has disassociated itself from the attack, the group's top leaders have given no indication that they intend to take steps to discipline Abu Abbas, and they have not condemned the attack directly, Baker said. The United States has urged the PLO to take such steps, he said. So far the PLO's ``public and private responses have fallen short of the mark,'' Baker said. He said U.S. allies, such as Britain, have interceded with the PLO, asking the Arab group to follow the United States' advice. Over two dozen members of the Senate have urged the Bush administration to suspend the dialogue with the PLO as a result of the attempted attack.

DOC.HEAD: Space Shuttle Columbia Returns to Hangar for Repairs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Columbia in hangar. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Columbia's flight ...'.
DOC.TEXT: Columbia returned to a hangar today for repair of a hydrogen leak that will ground the space shuttle until August. NASA started rolling Columbia off the launch pad before daybreak. The shuttle completed the 3{-mile trip nearly six hours later. Columbia was to be secured on a pedestal later today, and access platforms were to be placed around the shuttle, said agency spokesman George Diller. Columbia's flight with the $150 million Astro observatory was called off two weeks ago when the leak was detected during fueling. NASA officials suspect the leak is in or near a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the orbiter and the external fuel tank. The tank will have to be disconnected, a job that can only be done at the hangar. Atlantis is scheduled to be taken from the hangar to the launch pad on Saturday for a secret military mission next month.

DOC.HEAD: Group Claims Responsibility for Attack on U.S. Company Office
DOC.TEXT: A leftist terrorist group today claimed responsibility for a weekend rocket attack that damaged the offices of a U.S. company. The November 17 group said it launched the Sunday attack against Procter & Gamble Co., a household products manufacturer, because it recently bought a debt-ridden company from the government at a low price. ``We will automatically consider such a move as robbing the Greek people ... and consequently we will strike without warning,'' the group said in a letter to the Socialist daily Epikairotita. Authorities had already said they suspected November 17 in the attack on an office of Cincinnati-based company. The building, located on a main thoroughfare, was damaged but no one was injured. Officials said the attackers apparently used a stolen anti-tank missile and a small World War II bazooka. The conservative Greek government elected in April says that it plans to privatize or liquidate most of the 70 former private companies operated by the state because they are losing about $1 billion annually. Labor unions have protested the move. Procter & Gamble bought the property of a defunct Greek company for $2.77 million at a public auction in May, said Gerassimos Vassilatos, a company spokesman. The Greek company had a total debt of $37.5 million, he said. ``Eight previous auctions failed to provoke any interest from anybody else. The price, as a result, was lowered by the court to a price that it considered appropriate,'' he said. He added that the Greek company had laid off its work force two years ago and that the property would be used as a warehouse. Procter & Gamble has been in Greece for 30 years and last year did $106 million in business, Vassilatos said. November 17 has claimed the killings of 14 people since 1975. No member of the group has ever been arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Electoral Council Says Balaguer Won Elections
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquin Balaguer won last month's election a margin of less than 25,000 votes over challenger Juan Bosch, the Central Electoral Board has announced. The board issued its final official count Monday night of the May 16 election, giving Balaguer 678,268 votes, or 35.7 percent vote of those cast, to 653,423, or 34.4 percent, for Bosch. The outcome had been left hanging five days after the election when the board suspended counting pending a review of tally sheets in the presence of six international observers. The board acted on the recommendation of former President Jimmy Carter, an observer. Leftist challenger Bosch, a former president overthrown by a military coup in 1963, had accused conservative Balaguer of fraud. Bosch threatened street protests and a national strike until he agreed to the board's review. At the time the count was suspended, Electoral Board President Troilan Tavares did not mention fraud, although he said officials found errors by some polling stations in compiling tally sheets. There was no immediate victory statement from Balaguer or his party, nor any public reaction overnight from Bosch to the results. Balaguer, 83 and blind, will assume his sixth term in office on Aug. 16. Bosch is an 80-year-old Marxist, but says he is not a communist and recognizes capitalism as necessary for reviving the Dominican economy, Balaguer was first elected president in 1966 and served three consecutive four-year terms before losing in 1978. He was re-elected in 1986. During his current term Balaguer has undertaken a $2 billion public works project that created thousands of jobs but fueled inflation. He appeared to be in trouble before the election because of the country's economic crisis, frequent electricity blackouts and water shortages. Opinion polls showed Bosch leading by up to 10 points.

DOC.HEAD: Jazzman Hubert Rostaing Dies at Age 71
DOC.TEXT: French saxophone and clarinet player Hubert Rostaing, a legend on the Paris jazz circuit in the 1940s, has died of liver cancer, family members said. He was 71. He died Sunday in a Paris hospital, and funeral services will be held Thursday. Born in Lyon, Rostaing learned to play the clarinet and saxophone during a boyhood in Algiers, Algeria, and made his jazz debut in local clubs during the 1930s. After moving to Paris he caught the attention of orchestra leader Alix Combelle, for whom he performed throughout the Nazi occupation at the celebrated Hot Club de France. With a clarinet style heavily influenced by Benny Goodman, Rostaing also performed successfully throughout the 1950s. In later years he turned his attention to composition and writing music for films. It was not immediately known whether there were survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Cuba Recalls its Students from Hungary
DOC.TEXT: Cuban students studying at Hungarian universities say the Havana government has ordered them to return home, the state MTI news agency reported Tuesday. Cuba remains staunchly communist, but Hungary, like other Eastern European nations, has been swept by democratic reform. North Korea and Vietnam, which also have hard-line governments, brought their students home from Hungary last year. MTI said 70 Cuban students were affected. The news agency quoted students as saying they were told to return home next week when summer break begins. A Cuban diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity, told MTI the students ``will be given every chance to continue their studies'' at home.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwan Refuses Party-to-Party Talks With China
DOC.TEXT: A top Taiwanese official on Tuesday rejected a proposal from China for talks between their ruling political parties on communication and trade links as steps toward reunification. Tsiang Yien-si, President Lee Teng-hui's secretary general, told reporters the talks must be between the rival governments, as proposed earlier by Taiwan. Tsiang was responding to an offer made Monday by China's Communist Party general secretary, Jiang Zemin. Jiang said Taiwan and China should establish trade and communications links before the two sides hold formal talks on reunification, but that the initial meetings must be between China's Communist Party and Taiwan's ruling Nationalist party. Jiang's remarks were the Communist leadership's first detailed response to last month's proposal by Taiwanese President Lee for government contacts in trade, academia, science and other fields. Tsiang, a leading member of the Nationalist party, said Jiang's offer failed to recognize the existence of the Nationalist government. The Nationalists have ruled Taiwan, an island province of China, since 1949 when they lost a civil war to the Communists on the China mainland. The Nationalists continue to claim they are the legitimate government of all China.

DOC.HEAD: `Off With Their Fingers' Urges Party Boss
DOC.TEXT: A ruling party boss has urged followers to chop off the fingers of people who flash a two-fingered salute in support of allowing opposition parties, newspapers reported Tuesday. Wilson Leitich, chairman of the ruling Kenya African National Union branch in Nakuru, made the comment Monday during an address celebrating the ruling party's 30th birthday. Leitich told members of the party's youth wing to carry knives and chop off the index and middle fingers off anyone seen giving the opposition salute. He said they should take the fingers to the party offices in Nakuru, in the southeastern Rift Valley. ``We are not cowards for them to play around with us like that,'' the Daily Nation quoted Leitich as saying. That paper and the daily Standard reported the address, but Kenya's other English-language newspaper, the ruling party's Kenya Times, did not. Several prominent clergymen and former politicians have increasingly called for a return to multiparty politics. Kenya has been a one-party state since 1982. Daniel arap Moi is president and leader of the ruling party.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Spokesman Says Amtrak Vote Will Be Close
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's spokesman said today the Senate's vote on overriding the veto of a $2 billion Amtrak bill will be close, but he voiced optimism it will be sustained. ``We haven't lost a veto yet. We'd hate to lose a first one,'' said press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The House voted last week to override the veto. Both houses must vote to override by a two-third majorities for a measure to be enacted over a veto. ``We're hopeful we will be able to sustain that vote in the Senate. It will be close, but we're hopeful,'' he said. The Senate was scheduled to vote tonight on the veto override. In vetoing the transportation authorization bill, Bush objected to a provision expanding government regulation over railroad aquistions. But critics accused him of vetoing the measure primarily to kill the government's subsidy of Amtrak rail passenger service. ``We have a good chance of winning,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., told reporters after he and other Republican leaders met with Bush at the White House. ``Everything's on track,'' he quipped.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Blames Low Birth Rate on More Higher Education for Women
DOC.TEXT: Japan's finance minister suggested Tuesday that Japanese women are having fewer babies because more of them are going to college, according to a health official. The health official said the comments came during a Cabinet discussion about a report that says Japan's birth rate reached a record low in 1989, indicating the country could have problems in meeting future labor force needs. Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto questioned whether all young people needed higher education, said the health official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Hashimoto said people could study while working. A government report, issued last week, said the average Japanese woman had just 1.57 children as of 1989, an all-time low. The previous low was 1.58 in 1966. The health official said Cabinet members asked Health and Welfare Minister Yuji Tsushima to take positive measures to help increase the birth rate. ``Women's higher education may also be related to the matter,'' the health official quoted Hashimoto as saying. He said Tsushima told the other ministers the issue was worth studying.

DOC.HEAD: NRC Proposes $160,000 Fine Against 3M For Leaky Ionizers
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has proposed a $160,000 fine against 3M Co. for failing to fully report radiation leaks from air guns filled with a radioactive chemical. ``There were more leaking devices than they informed us of,'' Jan Strasma, an NRC spokesman in Glen Ellyn, Ill., said Monday. The NRC cited 3M for placing the devices in ``unacceptable environments'' and failing to give adequate handling instructions to customers. The citations were based on 1988 inspections by the federal agency. Mark Fenner, a 3M spokesman, said the company will study the charges and respond within the allotted 30 days. The manufacturer also has 30 days to pay or protest the fine. ``We are surprised by the size of the proposed penalty,'' Fenner said. The NRC ordered 3M in February 1988 to recall all 52,000 of its air ionizers _ air guns that are used to change the electrical charges of atomic particles during manufacturing. The ionizers are filled with polonium, a radioactive substance. By changing electrical charges, the devices are able to eliminate static and dust in computer chips, chemicals or in the air. Between 1,500 and 2,000 of the 3M ionizers were used by companies that make food, beverages, pharmaceuticals and cosmetics. The NRC said Monday it was unlikely that any consumer products were contaminated or that any handlers of the devices were exposed to significant radiation. The agency said its inspection identified seven violations of its policies. According to the NRC summary of the inspection, 3M sales representatives ``willfully failed, in some cases, to perform evaluations to assure that customers would use static eliminators only in acceptable environments which would not cause leakage.'' Strasma said some sales were made to customers required to test for radiation leaks but not equipped to make the tests. 3M also failed to follow up with its customers after it determined that its air guns were leaking, the NRC inspection summary said. In addition, NRC inspectors have accused 3M of failing to report to the NRC all results of tests performed on the ionizers for 1986 and 1987. Fenner said the company would not respond publicly to the allegations until it reviews the case.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Vow Fight to Amend Constitution to Protect Flag
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 13 grafs GOP leaders at White House, Foley comment; picks up 4th graf pvs, Rep. Don Edwards ...; edits at bottom to tighten
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Republicans emerged from the White House today waving the flag, criticizing the Supreme Court and vowing to press for quick action on a constitutional amendment to restore special protection for the flag. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., holding a small flag in hand, took a swipe at Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens, who warned in his dissent Monday against leaders' manipulating the flag ``for partisan disputes.'' ``As far as I know he's never run for political office,'' Dole told reporters on the White House driveway. ``If he wants to get out there and run, well, go right ahead. He has a right to criticize those of us in politics, and we have a right to criticize the court, and they're wrong.'' ``We're not manipulating. We're going to go out and tell the American people this is how people voted on this issue. And then we can tell them how Justice Stevens voted in the court. Nobody would care,'' said Dole. Stevens was in the minority on the 5-4 decision that overturned the federal flag protection act. In a dissent, he wrote that the integrity of the flag as a national symbol ``has been compromised by those leaders who seem to advocate compulsory worship of the flag ... (or) manipulate the symbol of national purpose into a pretext for partisan disputes about meaner ends.'' President Bush was renewing his call for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag later today at a Rose Garden ceremony in which he was receiving a replica of the Marine's famed statue of the World War II flag-raising on Iwo Jima. Dole said the flag debate was very important to ``real'' people, and ``the Democrats should give us a very quick vote.'' ``We don't need more hearings. ... We're ready to vote on Flag Day,'' which is Thursday, Dole said. Asked if he would question the patriotism of lawmakers who vote against the constitutional amendment, Dole said no, but quipped, ``I might make a 30-second spot.'' Congressional Democratic leaders strongly oppose amending the Constitution to ban flag burning. But votes were being scheduled around such symbolic days as the Fourth of July and Flag Day, June 14. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., meanwhile, said today he would not delay a House vote on a constitutional amendment and said it could come within two weeks. But Foley said he intended to vote against the proposal, despite tradition that has the speaker refrain from voting. ``I do not support amending the First Amendment,'' Foley said. ``Flag burning isn't worth tampering with the most important repository of freedom any country has ever established in its history.'' Foley said Republican efforts to use the vote as a political weapon against Democrats who oppose the amendment will not succeed, and that a vote against the amendment ``will not be one that leads to any political embarrassment.'' Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on the Constitution and a leading House opponent of an amendment, predicted an amendment would fail again. ``I'm confident we're going to get enough members to stand up and say, `No, I love the Bill of Rights,''' Edwards said. With flag burning no longer a federal crime since the court's action, some said a vote for a constitutional ban would be politically irresistible just a few months before the fall congressional elections. Republicans hoped so. ``Certainly the vote on the constitutional amendment will become a campaign issue,'' said Ed Rollins, head of the House Republican campaign committee. ``It's a good issue to define your opponent,'' Rollins said. ``If your opponent is for flag burning, he's got to go through a very sophisticated explanation of why he is.'' Democrats were aware of the political pitfalls the issue poses for them, recalling how George Bush exploited the flag's patriotic values at Michael Dukakis's expense in his 1988 campaign. ``It will be very tempting to play politics with it, with the Fourth of July,'' said Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., a fierce opponent of a constitutional change. Democratic National Chairman Ron Brown warned his potential candidates away from turning the fall campaign into a contest for patriotism. He urged all Democratic candidates ``not to seek any political gain by challenging their opponents' patriotism or position on the flag amendment.'' Brown said the flag and Bill of Rights were ``more important than any political tug of war.'' But some backers of a flag-burning ban acknowledged public support for the issue may have dropped since the dispute was temporarily defused last fall with passage of the now-overturned law. ``I think candidly it will be a difficult vote,'' said Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House minority whip, who backs a constitutional amendment. ``It's not going to happen automatically.'' Opponents of the amendment argue that the Bill of Rights and its First Amendment protection of free speech are too sacred to tamper with because of a few dissenters who burn flags to gain publicity for themselves or their cause. An amendment to prohibit burning the American flag would temper the First Amendment by saying the right of free speech excluded burning the flag as a form of political expression. The Bill of Rights, comprising the first 10 amendments, has never actually been amended. The proposed amendment was scheduled for a vote next week in the House Judiciary Committee, where Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, supports it. Sen. Joseph Biden, D-Del., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee and an author of the law, said, ``We are left with no other option but a constitutional amendment.'' He said he would begin hearings and try to write an amendment ``that doesn't do violence'' to the First Amendment. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, an opponent, said he would move more slowly. ``The issue is not the flag. The issue is whether we are going to amend the Bill of Rights,'' Mitchell said. To be added to the Constitution, the amendment needs two-thirds majorities in both the Senate and House and approval by 38 of the 50 state legislatures.

DOC.HEAD: Saving Soup Labels to Get Free Van
DOC.TEXT: A group of families looking for a way to transport their children to a Catholic school have collected nearly a million Campbell Soup Co. product labels needed to get a free van. Diana Goebel, who's heading the drive, said Monday that 994,000 labels had been collected. Friday's the deadline. The group gathered 150,000 labels in the campaign's first eight months and more than 764,000 in the last four months. The late rush of labels bordered on the miraculous, Goebel said. ``It was like the loaves and fishes, only they were Campbell's Soup labels,'' she said, referring to the New Testament story of Jesus feeding 5,000 men, plus women and children, with just five loaves of bread and two fish. ``It just seemed like it was an impossibility,'' Goebel said of the group's efforts. ``The way I figured it, if the good Lord wanted it to happen, it will happen. All we had to do was work hard.'' And she did. With more than 50,000 labels a week pouring into her mailbox during the last couple of months, Goebel spent 15 hours a day clipping and packaging labels. ``I've got blisters and calluses,'' she said. Goebel said she received labels from more than 150 Minnesota communities, at least 35 states, and from Italy, Canada, Mexico, Asia and the Bahamas. The effort got a lift in February, when it attracted national attention. But the 15-seat, $20,000 van won't solve their problem; it will be too small for the 20 students who ride a rickety 1971 school bus. Instead, the group plans to sell the van and use the money to buy a new or used 48-passenger bus. On Friday, Goebel and her supporters from Jordan _ a town of about 3,000 people about 20 miles southwest of the Twin Cities _ plan to pack the labels into the old bus and travel 50 miles to a Campbell's office in Monticello, where the labels will be counted. Under Campbell's 18-year-old Labels for Education program, schools can redeem labels from Campbell's products for school-related equipment. During the last three years, several schools nationwide have turned in enough labels to earn vans, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovakia Says Warsaw Pact Can Play Useful Role
DOC.TEXT: The disintegrating Warsaw Pact should be preserved in some form to prevent the Soviet Union from becoming dangerously isolated, Czechoslovakia's foreign minister said Tuesday. The minister, Jiri Dienstbier, said the Warsaw Pact is moving away from its role as a military alliance but can still play a role in European affairs. The Warsaw Pact, led by the Soviet Union, sent tanks into Czechoslovakia to crush the 1968 ``Prague Spring'' reforms. But now Czechoslovakia wants to remain in the alliance so it can have a voice in negotiating disarmament and a new European security order, Dienstbier said. ``For the first time, the Warsaw Pact is useful to us,'' he said in an interview with The Associated Press and two other news organizations. The foreign minister was considered certain to keep his post in the new Czechoslovak government being formed after weekend elections won by the pro-democracy forces that led last year's revolution. Dienstbier, recalling the isolation of Germany following World War I, said of the Soviets: ``We should do everything to pull them into Europe.'' ``We don't want to create any Versailles complex in Russia,'' he said, referring to the treaty that punished Germany at the end of World War I. ``It's even more dangerous because they have all those nuclear arms.'' The Warsaw Pact was created in 1955 and had always been dominated by the Soviets until the dramatic changes that swept eastern Europe last year. Pact members met in Moscow last week, and the Soviets agreed that the other six member nations should have command of their own armies. They had nominal command before. But with the exception of Romania' refusal to join the 1968 invasion of Czechoslovakia, they had never exercised it. The supreme military commander of the Warsaw Pact was always a top Soviet general or marshal. ``Even the Warsaw Pact military command was not important,'' Dienstbier said. ``It was just subordinated to the Soviet army.'' Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland want the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe to make its headquarters in Prague. The 35-nation group includes the United States, the Soviet Union, Canada and all of Europe except Albania. Under the three-nation proposal, a parallel center for arms control, verification and confidence-building measures also would be established in Berlin. The three east European nations want their idea discussed at a meeting of the Conference on Security in Vienna July 10. That meeting is to pave the way for a Paris summit in December. Dienstbier and Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel have long advocated the eventual break-up of the Warsaw Pact and its Western counterpart, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Unlike Hungary's new leaders _ who want their country out of the Pact _ Dienstbier and Havel say the East bloc alliance should break up only gradually. Meantime, they want to remain members. Dienstbier said there are ``positive forces in the Soviet Union'' who want to work with Czechoslovakia, East Germany and Poland on transforming European security. East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere told President Bush in Washington Monday that NATO must be ``significantly changed'' to meet the Soviet Union's security concerns. The West is insisting that a united Germany be a member of NATO. Moscow wants the new country to either be neutral or a member of NATO and the Warsaw Pact. De Maiziere said a united Germany would consider membership in NATO only if a treaty clearly defined the status of Soviet troops now stationed in East Germany.

DOC.HEAD: Four Killed, One Critically Injured in Train-Car Collision
DOC.TEXT: A loaded coal train slammed into a car, killing four members of a family and leaving a fifth in critical condition, authorities said. The accident occurred Monday afternoon at a crossing about one-half mile east of Seneca, a ranching community of about 100 people in the Nebraska Sandhills. ``I don't know how it happened,'' Thomas County Attorney Warren Arganbright said. ``He was not going fast. He was not trying to race the train or anything. It was a horribly tragic accident.'' The loaded Burlington Northern Railroad train was traveling about 49 mph in an area where the posted speed for trains is 50 mph, Arganbright said. The crossing, where about 40 trains pass daily, has no lights or wooden arms to bar traffic when a train is approaching, he said. The accident killed Mark and Vanna Goodpasture, ages 34 and 35, respectively, their 13-year-old son, Lance, and 9-year-old daughter, Brook. Another daughter, Brandi, 10, was listed in critical condition at Good Samaritan Hospital in Kearney.

DOC.HEAD: Research Group Critical of Administration Economic Policy
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's term may mark the end of American industrial strength unless he adopts an economic policy that provides more assistance to develop new technologies, a research group said Tuesday. Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif., chairman of Rebuild America, said the United States needs an industry-led strategy with government cooperation and support to compete in the world market. ``The next three years represent a critical turning point in economic history,'' the group said in a report titled, ``Fiddling While U.S. Industry Burns.'' ``If President Bush sides with the pragmatists, America can remain a world-class power for the foreseeable future,'' the report said. ``If he continues to allow the ideologues to dominate decision-making, his term may mark the end of American industrial might.'' Rebuild America describes itself as a non-profit, bipartisan research group established to ``promote productive investment in people and industry.'' The organization report was critical of Bush's economic advisers _ Chief of Staff John Sununu, Budget Director Richard Darman and Economic Adviser Michael Boskin _ for what it called hands-off, laissez-faire policies toward commercial ventures. Those policies, it said, have failed to produce sufficient commercial research and development, close the investment gap with Japan, ensure continued U.S. leadership in strategic industries, protect the U.S. manufacturing base and ``are keeping us the world's largest debtor and increasingly dependent upon foreigners.'' The report was written by Lester Thurow, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Professor George Lodge of Harvard Business School; Ed Miller, president of the National Center for Manufacturing Sciences, and Rebuild America director Fred Branfman. Thurow, who joined Levine at a news conference, the United States spends only ``one-half as much per capita on plant and equipment as the Japanese, two-thirds as much as the Germans'' with those governments ``footing 50 percent of the research and development bill.'' ``We have to spend equivalent amounts,'' he said. The administration's three proposals for closing the investment gap _ reduction of the federal budget deficit, a capital gains tax cut and its family savings plan _ ``will do little to boost productive investment in the United States,'' the report contended. Unless the administration changes its policies, the report said, ``the U.S. could be a second or third-rate industrial power in the year 2000, and President Bush will be remembered as the Herbert Hoover of U.S. industrial competitiveness.'' Hoover, elected in 1928, was president during the stock market crash of 1929 and resulting collapse of the economy that led to the Great Depression.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Ethics Committee Begins Durenberger Hearings
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 9th graf pvs, The committee's ... with 4 new grafs to UPDATE with later testimony, color
DOC.TEXT: The Senate ethics committee today opened two weeks of trial-like hearings into the financial dealings of Sen. Dave Durenberger, warning the Minnesota Republican that he could face ``strong sanctions.'' The panel said earlier it found ``substantial credible evidence'' that the 12-year senator broke Senate rules and federal law in transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium, a book promotion deal and free limousine rides. Committee Chairman Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., told Durenberger today the committee had to answer two questions: Whether he violated Senate rules or laws and whether his conduct had discredited the Senate. Looking straight at Durenberger, Heflin, a former chief justice of the Alabama Supreme Court, said, ``If the evidence clearly and convincingly leads me to the conclusion that you have violated the public trust, I will not hesitate to recommend appropriate sanctions.''
