In opening its first hearings in nine years on charges that a senator abused his office, committee members also promised Durenberger they would not prejudge his case, which the panel has spent more than a year investigating. ``The theory expounded by some that the committee will, because of the current political climate, take harsh action against Senator Durenberger in order to prove that it is tough is ludicrous,'' said committee Vice Chairman Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H.. ``If the facts warrant, the committee will recommend strong sanctions. But, if they do not, we will not,'' Rudman said in opening remarks at the hearing. Durenberger sat between his attorney and an aide at a table facing committee members, his back to around 100 onlookers and several tables full of reporters. The committee's special counsel, Robert Bennett, later opened his case by saying that Durenberger ``knowingly and actively'' used a book promotion scheme to circumvent Senate honoraria limits and divert $100,000 in speaking fees into his own pocket. ``This is unethical, this is not honest,'' said Bennett, who was expected to take most of the day laying out his case. One of Durenberger's four sons, Dan, 22, asked his father during a hearing break, ``How are you?'' ``Perfect,'' his father replied. Bennett is familiar with the role of prosecutor, having brought the case in 1981 against then-Sen. Harrison A. Williams Jr., D-N.J., the last senator to face these kinds of hearings. Durenberger spent Monday polishing an opening statement to the committee to ``give a context'' to the defense by his attorney, said press secretary Lois West. The senator is represented by Jim Hamilton, a former counsel to the Senate Watergate Committee. Durenberger, who has been silent on the case in recent days, apologized to Minnesotans last December for ``mistakes and lapses in judgment.'' But the intense, public scrutiny of his finances could spell the end of his career if voters in Minnesota, a state known for clean government, aren't satisfied with his defense. Many public radio stations in Minnesota will broadcast the hearings live and television stations are planning heavy, daily coverage. ``People are concluding that something is seriously wrong,'' said William Luther, the Minneapolis attorney whose complaint initiated the Senate investigation. ``Now it's a matter of seeing if any kind of reasonable evidence or defense is presented.'' Durenberger does not have to run for re-election until 1994, but opinion polls indicate a majority of Minnesotans think he should resign if the committee finds serious violations. The six-member ethics committee is made up equally of Republicans and Democrats. It will decide after the hearings whether its allegations are true and then recommend a punishment to the full Senate ranging from a mild reprimand to expulsion. Bennett recommended removing Williams from the Senate after the 1981 hearings, but he resigned before his colleagues had to vote on ousting him. The ethics committee began its investigation after Williams had already been convicted in federal court in the Abscam bribery case. The committee began investigating Durenberger early last year and brought charges against him in February and again in May. The first set of allegations focused on the book contract Durenberger used to earn $100,000 in speaking fees in 1985 and 1986 for promoting two books he wrote on defense and health issues. In May, the panel charged that Durenberger abused his office and misused public funds in a ``pattern of improper conduct'' involving his Minneapolis condominium. Durenberger has acknowledged that he tried to cut the cost of maintaining homes in Washington and Minnesota by claiming Senate reimbursement for nights he stayed in the condominium.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Back in Hangar for Repairs
DOC.TEXT: Columbia was returned to the hangar Tuesday for repair of a hydrogen leak that has delayed the shuttle's Astro observatory million until at least August. NASA started rolling Columbia off the launch pad before daybreak. The shuttle completed the 3{-mile trip within six hours. Columbia's flight was called off two weeks ago when the leak was detected during fueling. Officials suspect the leak is in or near a tight cavity between two metal plates that connect the orbiter and the external fuel tank. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration planned to remove the orbiter from the tank on Wednesday. It is only the fourth time a shuttle has been transported from the launch pad back to the hangar because of problems. Atlantis is scheduled to be taken from the hangar to the launch pad this weekend, or early next week, for a secret military mission in mid-July.

DOC.HEAD: Wife Says She Tried to Help Husband Stop Speeding Car
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with wife testifying she tried to help husband stop car from going in river. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A woman testified today that she tried to help her husband pull his foot off the accelerator of their speeding station wagon before it plunged into the Detroit River, drowning their four children. Lawrence DeLisle, 29, is charged with four counts of murder in the drownings of their children, ages 8 months to 8 years. He is also standing trial on one count of attempting to murder his wife. He faces mandatory life imprisonment without parole if convicted. DeLisle has said a leg cramp prevented him from taking his foot off the accelerator as the car sped down a street and into the river last Aug. 3. Boaters rescued him and his wife, Suzanne. The children were trapped. Mrs. DeLisle has said her husband is innocent. She was subpoenaed by the prosecution and agreed to testify. Mrs. DeLisle said she managed to pull her husband's foot about an inch off the accelerator as he struggled to do the same. Assistant Wayne County Prosecutor Kevin Simowski asked why she hadn't mentioned the effort to police or during her husband's preliminary examination. ``I didn't remember it then,'' she replied. Mrs. DeLisle, 32, also testified that she escaped the sinking station wagon through a side window. She was unable to release the strap holding her infant daughter in a safety seat, and it was too dark to see the children in the back. During the first day of testimony Monday, witnesses said DeLisle made no attempt to save his children. Aaron Stoneburner he was in his boat when he saw the car go into the water. He helped pull the the DeLisles into his boat. ``They embraced, Mr. DeLisle was sobbing, something to the effect of `Oh my God, what have I done?''' Stoneburner said. Prosecutors claim DeLisle deliberately drove into the river in suburban Wyandotte to rid himself of family and financial burdens. ``It wasn't spur-of-the-moment,'' Assistant Prosecutor Kevin Simowski told the jury in Wayne County Circuit Court. ``Mr. DeLisle had a lot of options in front of him, and he chose the option to drown his children.'' Defense lawyer Frank Eaman mentioned the leg cramp in his opening arguments and also said the 1977 Ford was defective. ``This case is so obviously an accident that you're all going to wonder why you were here,'' Eaman said. Eaman has said DeLisle initially was unemotional because he was in shock, and didn't dive after the children because he couldn't swim well. Jurors won't hear one piece of evidence _ a purported confession from DeLisle, given after nine hours of questioning by police. Judge Robert Colombo Jr. ruled the confession resulted from police coercion and couldn't be used.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Reported on Minnesota River
With PM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: More than 75,000 gallons of diesel fuel leaked from a pipeline into the Minnesota River and spread downstream for about eight miles just south of the Twin Cities, authorities said today. ``It's a major spill as far as I'm concerned,'' said Savage Fire Chief Al McColl. Most of the oil was contained in the downtown Savage area, but containment devices also were set up near Burnsville, McColl said. River traffic will be halted until the spill is cleaned up, he said. The leak came from a Williams Pipe Line Co. pipe where it crosses the river in Eden Prairie, McColl said. The exact cause of the leak was not immediately known, he said. A spokesman for Williams did not immediately return a phone call. McColl said the leak was noticed around 6:20 a.m. today, but he did not know how long the pipe had been leaking. There were no injuries reported.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter in Woman's Death
DOC.TEXT: An FBI agent pleaded guilty today to manslaughter in the strangulation death of a pregnant woman with whom he purportedly was having an affair. Pike Circuit Judge Bayard Collier sentenced the agent, Mark Putnam, to 16 years in prison after Putnam accepted a plea bargain and pleaded guilty to killing Susan Daniels Smith, 28, of Freeburn, Ky., on June 8, 1989. Sources have said that Ms. Smith met Putnam when she was serving as an FBI informant. The Pike County grand jury indicted Putnam earlier today. The indictment said Putnam killed the woman ``while under extreme emotional duress.'' The FBI has said it has no record of any agent ever being convicted of killing someone in a similar case. Dressed in a starched white shirt, blue jeans and tennis shoes, Putnam said little during the 18-minute proceeding, except to answer Collier's questions. Ms. Smith's family on Monday bitterly denounced the pending plea agreement and asked the grand jury to indict him for murder. Shelby Ward, Ms. Smith's sister, and several sources say Putnam admitted killing Ms. Smith during an argument over support payments for the woman's expected child. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, and Ms. Smith's family say the agent described the killing and location of the woman's body in exchange for a plea bargain. The remains were found only last week. Mrs. Ward and her brother, Billy Joe Daniels, said Commonwealth's Attorney John Paul Runyon did not consult the family about the plea bargain. ``Because he was a big FBI, famous and everything, they don't want him to get justice,'' Mrs. Ward said after meeting with the grand jury. ``I'd still like to have a murder trial. ... I don't care what that clique there says. To me it was a brutal murder. Brutal, brutal.'' Runyon declined to respond, saying only: ``I can't control what she says.'' Ms. Smith's family has retained Pikeville lawyer Larry Webster to file a lawsuit against the agent and possibly the FBI. Webster said he intends to file the suit today, seeking ``millions'' in damages and lost earnings. ``If she was working for them at the time and she lost her life, she could be entitled to get paid for that,'' Webster said.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions At Mississippi Fireworks Plant Kill Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with number of dead put at two, sted at least two; fewer people in plant than previously feared, quotes. Picks up 6th graf pvs, `There was...'. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: Explosions felt up to 30 miles away leveled a small fireworks plant today, killing two people, authorities said. An hour after the first explosion at 9 a.m., witnesses said there were still minor explosions at the Mid-South Fireworks plant, located six miles southeast of this east-central Mississippi town. ``We have not found the bodies yet, but we are sure there are two,'' Don Harris of the Lowndes County medical examiner's office said at late morning. ``We have just now been able to put water to it.'' He said two people were injured. Suzy Powers, a spokesman for the Golden Triangle Regional Medical Center in Columbus, said one person had been brought in ``with fairly minor injuries.'' The plant usually employees about 20, but that increases to about 35 this time of the year. But at the time of the explosion, only four people were believed to be in the plant, witnesses said. The old brick school that housed the plant ``is down to the ground,'' Harris said. ``There was one small explosion, then a real big one,'' said Ed Markham of Ekanobel Inc., a chemical plant about four miles from the fireworks factory. ``After the first one, I thought it was a sonic boom from a plane. Then the second one went off and I knew it was something big.'' Markham said he understood a trailer containing more explosives survived the initial blasts and that officials were trying to move it to a safe area away from the plant. The blasts were felt as far away at Mississippi State University about 30 miles away in Starkville. ``We felt two distinct booms and the windows on the east side of our building, which is located in the center of campus, were rattled,'' said Sammy McDavid, a university spokesman. ``It did no damage here. It was one of those things that you say, `What was that?''

DOC.HEAD: Committee Hears Testimony on Credit Privacy Laws
DOC.TEXT: Consumers' privacy rights are not violated when businesses share their credit records, banking and retail officials said Tuesday in opposing legislation to restrict the practice. In fact, consumers benefit from quick availability of credit and direct-mail sales they otherwise might not hear about, William Bloom of the National Retail Federation told a House subcommittee that is considering revisions to the 20-year-old Fair Credit Reporting Act. But other witnesses told the panel the law should be changed so that consumers, not private credit reporting agencies, control access to their credit records. ``Credit records are more than just account numbers. They are a consumer's reputation,'' Rep. Matthew Rinaldo, R-N.J., told the House Banking Subcommittee on Consumer Affairs. ``Since credit bureaus make huge profits by finding new ways to sell personal credit records, they have shown no interest in seriously protecting a consumer's privacy,'' Rinaldo said. The chairman of the subcommittee, Rep. Richard Lehman, D-Calif., proposes allowing credit reporting bureaus to release customer records to solicitors and other companies only if the consumers have a chance to bar such action. Rinaldo would go further. His proposal would allow credit reports to be provided only for transactions initiated by consumers _ not for such things as direct-mail marketing or pre-approved lines of credit. In a third proposal, Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., would allow credit files to be released only with consumers' consent, and only to companies seeking new customers by offering them credit. Bloom, vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue, defended the sharing of customers' credit records through credit reporting bureaus. The practice ``is innocent in its operation and the benefits to both creditors and consumers are real,'' Bloom said. Consumers get quicker credit, and direct mailings help new businesses enter a local marketplace, he said. A proposal to allow the Federal Trade Commission to impose civil penalties against those who misuse credit records should be dropped because enough penalties already exist, contended Alan Heuer of Marine Midland Bank, representing the Consumer Bankers Association and the American Bankers Association. Jean Noonan, associate director of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection, said that although there is a danger that use of credit reports can be an invasion of privacy, her office would rather regulate it than ban it. And Rep. John Hiler, R-Ind., ranking minority member of the subcommittee, said the proposals to restrict the credit reporting law go too far. ``We also have to be concerned that we do not shut off the flow of credit to all but the most gold-plated credit risks,'' Hiler said. Bonnie Guiton, director of the U.S. Office of Consumer Affairs, said, ``Most consumers are concerned about how much information is known about them'' by private business. She noted that industry estimates the error rate in credit records could be as high as 40 percent. But she opposed proposals to require credit reporting companies to provide customers a free annual copy of their credit record. The consumers will end up paying the cost, she said, adding that credit companies instead should have to conduct random checks on their own work and publish the results. The various proposals include language to give consumers new power to correct errors in their credit reports, and require that they be notified when their credit report is used to deny them a transaction.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Says It's Willing to Resume Loans to Peru
DOC.TEXT: Japan said Tuesday it is willing to resume loans to Peru if the South American nation's new government shows willingness to deal with its serious economic and social problems. The Japanese ancestry of Peru's new president, Alberto Fujimori, has raised hopes of greater access to Japanese aid. Fujimori said Monday he hoped to visit Tokyo before his scheduled July 28 inauguration. Fujimori's victory over Mario Vargas Llosa in Peru's presidential runoff election Sunday was the top story in many Japanese newspapers. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe extended the government's ``heartfelt congratulations'' to Fujimori. He noted that Fujimori would be the first ethnic Japanese to head a foreign government. ``But at the same time, the diplomacy and the relations between the two countries should not be swayed by such factors,'' Watanabe said. Peru was the largest recipient of Japanese aid in Latin America in cumulative terms until 1988, but dropped to fourth-largest after it defaulted on payments and Japan cut off its yen credits. Fujimori faces widespread unemployment, a 2,000 percent inflation rate, terrorism and extensive drug trafficking. Despite Peru's previous default, ``if there is a willingness to cope and overcome those problems and explain to us in concrete manner what means they will take, and if we are satisfied, yes, there is always a possibility of more loans,'' Watanabe told a news briefing. Peru reportedly estimates its current worldwide medium- and long-term debt, both public and private, at about $15.2 billion. One Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity, estimated Peru owes Japan $1 billion in government and private debts. The ministry said Japanese government credits to Peru have totaled $359 million since 1971. The last outlay was in 1983, $31.3 million for fishing port construction, it said. Watanabe said the Japanese government is aware of reports that Fujimori wants to visit Japan, but had not received any official notification. If Fujimori indicates he wants to visit, ``we would welcome him and would like to arrange meetings with those people he wants to meet,'' he said. Fujimori, 51, is the eldest son of Japanese emigrants who traveled to Peru from Japan's southern island of Kyushu in 1934. In Lima, they opened an upholstery shop that failed during a boycott of Japanese businesses during World War II. Fujimori earned a degree in agricultural engineering and became a school administrator. Japanese emigration peaked in the decades before and after World War II, but has always been relatively small. Japanese settlers never have exceeded 1 percent of the population of their host countries. Brazil was the principal destination of Japanese settlers in North and South America in the prewar years, followed by the United States, Canada and Peru. In recent years, Japan's prosperity and stability have discouraged further emigration. Last year, only 3,851 Japanese settled in other countries, the Foreign Ministry says.

DOC.HEAD: Native Groups Worried About Court Adoption Rulings
DOC.TEXT: Eskimo and Indian groups as well as Alaska officials say two recent court decisions undermine a federal law meant to guarantee tribal rights in adoption cases. The Alaska Supreme Court in December and a Southern California Superior Court judge in February ruled that tribes have no right to intervene in adoption proceedings involving Eskimo or Indian children if the mother gives up the child voluntarily. Representatives of Indian and Eskimo rights groups in Alaska and the Lower 48 have criticized the rulings, saying they violate the intent of the Indian Child Welfare Act. ``Essentially, the Alaska Supreme Court has sanctioned a loophole'' in the federal law, said Lloyd Miller, a lawyer for the Anchorage-based Cook Inlet Tribal Council. The tribal council earlier this year appealed the state Supreme Court's decision to the U.S. Supreme Court, but the panel declined to hear the appeal. The Indian Child Welfare Act was enacted by Congress in 1978 after it reviewed evidence that up to 50 percent of some tribes' children nationally had been put up for adoption. Congress agreed with Indian advocates that adoption of Indian children by non-Indian parents was threatening the integrity of tribal groups and that such adoptions can cause long-term soct Tribal Council, wasn't notified. The mother later changed her mind and sought the council's assistance to recover her child. ``If the birth parent asks to remain anonymous, in other words, chooses not to have the tribe notified, we believe the mother's right to privacy supersedes the tribe's right to be notified,'' said Jim Caldarola, executive director of Catholic Social Services, the state's largest private adoption agency. But Indian groups contend the Indian Child Welfare Act was meant to protect the child's rights, not the mother's. The second case involves an Aleut girl from the Kodiak Island village of Akhiok. Her 19-year-old mother from Cypress, Calif., decided to give up her child to a non-Aleut couple in Canada, but Akhiok village leaders learned of the case and want the child back. ``We're trying to get the baby out of Canada and back down here to our community,'' said Akhiok Tribal Council President David Eluska. ``Too many of our tribal members in the past have been adopted out and we have no idea or inkling where they ended up.'' State, tribal officials and Indian advocates believe that when children are not adopted by their own people, they are removed from their ancestral heritage and thrust into a sort of cultural and ethnic limbo. From 1985 through 1987, the last year for which statistics are available, 474 Eskimo and Indian children were adopted, according to the Alaska Bureau of Vital Statistics. Ninety-two were adopted by couples who were neither Eskimo nor Indian. State officials agree the notification issue creates a loophole in federal law. ``The state's position is that the notice should be required,'' said Myra Munson, commissioner of the state Department of Health and Social Services. ``We believe it (the federal law) should be amended.'' Indian advocates have said the court cases are important, not just to Alaska but to the entire country. ``It's of a great deal of importance nationally,'' said Jack Trope, a lawyer with the New York-based Association of American Indian Affairs, a non-profit legal aid and advocacy group concerned about Indian issues. ``Up until very recently the tribes were certain under the act that they had the right to intervene,'' Trope said. The recent case ``indicated that the right to intervention is not as clear cut in the act as everyone thought. That's of great concern.'' Trope predicts legal battles across the country to clarify the law. ``We'll certainly be looking to fight these things in the court system,'' he said. ``The law is on our side, notwithstanding what the Alaska Supreme Court says.''

DOC.HEAD: Fast Food Chain Recalls Water Bottles
DOC.TEXT: A fast food restaurant chain is voluntarily recalling 300,000 sports water bottles because the mouthpiece can present a choking hazard to children. Taco Bell Corp. of Irvine, Calif., began last Monday offering the bottles for 99 cents to customers who made food purchases at its 2,700 stores nationwide. But the promotional campaign was suspended three days laer after the company ``received a report from a customer that his 21-month-old child had dismantled the bottle's mouthpiece and attempted to swallow it,'' the Consumer Product Safety Commission said. When a CPSC inspector tried to purchase a bottle last Friday he was told store managers had been instructed to pack them up and ship them back the day before, the agency said in a written statement. ``It's the fastest work on a recall I've ever seen,'' said CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt. Consumers should return the bottles to the Taco Bell where purchased for a full refund. More than 20 million of the water bottles, which have become a popular fixture among sports enthusiasts, have been marketed in the last ten years by Specialized Bicycle Components of Morganhill, Calif., according to company president Mike Sinyard. Specialized has redesigned the bottles and plans to ship them to customers like Taco Bell by June 25, he said. The company also will replace mouthpieces on all other bottles it distributed. Consumers should contact Specialized at 1-800-735-4668.

The Coast Guard also backed away from earlier reports that the 886-foot tanker had begun buckling because of the intense heat, the shifting cargo and the contiuous stream of water being poured on the vessel. ``There is no evidence at all of any structural damage,'' said Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Gene Maestas. He said crews on the scene 57 miles southeast of Galveston reported no signs of damage. The Norwegian tanker was transferring some of its cargo of 38 million gallons of oil to a smaller tanker when the first explosions occurred. Two of the 41 crew members were killed and two are missing and presumed dead. On Monday, the Coast Guard said there was a slightly increased chance the ship would sink because waves were washing over the back end. The Coast Guard said today they believed less than 2,000 gallons of light crude remained in the water. The rest of the up to 100,000 gallons believed spilled since Saturday had either dissipated or burned off, officials said. As a precaution, the U.S. government asked Mexico to send oil skimmers to help with cleanup operations if the situation worsens. ``We're in the planning stages for what may be a catastrophic incident,'' said Maestas. The rear of the Mega Borg has dropped more than 60 feet since the Norwegian tanker was crippled early Saturday by explosions and fire. The drop indicated either that the cargo had shifted or the ship was taking on water, officials said. The dropping stern ``increases the danger of sinking but only incrementally,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson said. ``We are not talking right now about sinking.'' Rear Adm. William Kime, commandant of the Coast Guard, flew over the crippled ship and said that despite the setbacks, ``We're cautiously optimistic.'' However, Bob Schuller, a naval architect in Houston, said the dropping added pressure on the ship's structure. He said he did not know the extent of damage but speculated the pressure could crack the ship or sink it. The Mega Borg carries more than three times as much oil as was spilled by the Exxon Valdez off Alaska in March 1989 in the nation's worst oil spill. Authorities, however, noted the oil spilled in Alaska was heavy crude, which doesn't dissipate nearly as rapidly as the light crude aboard the Mega Borg. Also, much of the oil spilling off Texas was being consumed by fire. Currents and winds were expected to push the oil toward a 200-mile stretch of coast between Freeport and Corpus Christi. But the Coast Guard said the currents were expected to keep the spill from coming ashore. Gary Clark, Houston Audubon Society president, said the coast is ``probably the most sensitive breeding bird area in the United States'' and that a huge spill would come at the worst time _ the height of the breeding season for many birds. The tanker, operated by Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway, was bound from Palanca, Angola. It was scheduled to travel to Aruba after Galveston. ELF, a Houston-based oil distributor that was going to market the tanker's cargo, is paying an undetermined amount for the cleanup. Texas officials, meanwhile, urged lawmakers to better prepare the big oil-producing state for spills by unifying the state's approach to prevention and planning. ``The focus has not been there. There hasn't been any concerted effort to put such a contingency plan together,'' said Andy Mangan, the state's deputy land commissioner.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Ambassador Welcomes First Capri Exported to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Australia's ambassador circled his embassy in a sporty red convertible Tuesday to introduce the first Australian-built car line to be exported to the United States. Australia hopes to export more than $300 million worth of the newly designed Mercury Capri convertibles for sale by U.S. Lincoln-Mercury dealers, said Ambassador Michael Cook, who held a news conference with Ford Motor Co. officials on the embassy's front walk. In the mid-1960s, Australia's car exports exceeded those of Japan, Cook said. But Japan has surged way ahead of Australia, which has never before exported cars to the United States. The Capri is a front-wheel drive convertible with a small, two-place seat in the rear. It is expected to compete with the fast-selling, Japanese-made Mazda Miata. Ford is partners with Mazda, which helped developed the Capri chassis and power train. The base price of the Capri is $12,500, with an airconditioned XR2 model selling for $15,900. The only major option is a removable hard top for about $1,200. About 30,000 1991 Capri are to be brought to the United States with another 10,000 built with the driver's seat on the right side for sale in Australia, Ford spokesman Bill Gray said. The first shipment of 25 is to arrive for the District of Columbia's July 4 parade. Joe Chavara, Lincoln-Mercury district sales manager, said Ford expects more than half the buyers of the basic model to be women. The Capri model name has not been used by Ford for several years. The original Capri were built in Germany and later in the United States. Ford officials said the new Capri body was designed in Italy and the car uses some Japanese mechanical parts but it was manufactured and assembled at a $250 million Ford plant near Melbourne.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors Airlifted off Mountain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that rescuers were 500 feet below victim on mountain, sted 200 feet from him.
DOC.TEXT: Three members of a Japanese climbing team were airlifted off a 14,000-foot level of Mount McKinley following the death of one of the team's climbers. National Park Service officials said the three climbers, two with frostbite on their toes, were airlifted Monday evening and were to be taken to a hospital in Anchorage. Rescuers believe they just 500 feet below Hairoaki Ito, 38, when he died Sunday. He was the first person to die on McKinley this year. Officials said the party of seven Japanese climbers left much of their survival gear at about 17,000 feet early Saturday in an effort to make a quick ascent of the 20,320-feet summit. ``It's not uncommon to do that, although it's risky,'' said park service spokesman John Quinley. ``Their gear was a long way from where they were.'' After ascending a couple thousand feet more up the mountain's West Rib, Ito became too sick to continue and stayed behind while his companions went on and apparently made it to the top, Quinley said. The six other climbers became separated on the way down, two making a safe descent with another party down the West Buttress and four returning to Ito. The strongest remained with Ito, while the three others went for help, Quinley said.

DOC.HEAD: Bennett: Drug Crisis Primarily Spiritual, Moral Problem
With AM-Southern Baptists
DOC.TEXT: Drug czar William Bennett said the ``Great Deceiver'' is partly responsible for U.S. drug problems, and applauded the nation's largest Protestant denomination to bring drug abusers to God. In a speech filled with religious imagery, Bennett, a Roman Catholic, told a group of Southern Baptists that the drug problem ``is, in the end, fundamentally a moral problem. It is fundamentally a spiritual problem.'' He said crack users are searching for meaning in their lives, and some refer to the drug as the devil, or ``the big lie.'' Without referring specifically to the devil, Bennett said when looking at the drug crisis, ``One can speak of the Great Deceiver, the Great Deceiver everyone knows.'' At a luncheon Monday before their annual meeting, Bennett also told the group of Southern Baptists, ``I applaud your effort to bring those in need to the God who heals.'' The former education secretary said Americans need to have the ``courage'' to teach values in public schools. ``There is no earthly reason or divine reason public schools cannot talk about values,'' Bennett told reporters later. ``If you have a drug education program that is value-neutral, you have a valueless drug education program.'' He said America needs to bring the wisdom of the Judeo-Christian tradition to bear on the drug problem.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Meets With All Three Baltic Presidents
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to UPDATE with further details on meeting. Pickup 4th graf `Before the...'
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev met the presidents of all three Baltic republics today, the first time since the Soviet president called their steps toward independence illegal. The leaders held ``an exchange of opinions on the situation in inter-ethnic relations,'' reported Vremya, the government's nightly TV news, without giving further details. Vremya's reference to ethnic relations apparently referred to reports that the independence moves in the Baltic republics have heightened tensions between Russian-speaking residents and the native populations. The meeting appeared to mark a new stage in the diplomatic effort to end the impasse that began when Lithuania declared independence in March. Latvia and Estonia followed with resolutions setting transition periods to independence. Before the meeting, Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis sounded upbeat about seeing Gorbachev. ``Constructive dialogue is on the way,'' Landsbergis said upon arrival at the Lithuanian mission in Moscow. He earlier held a 40-minute meeting with Presidents Anatoly Gorbunov of Latvia and Arnold Ruutel of Estonia at the Latvian mission. Gorbachev, in a report to the Supreme Soviet parliament on his Washington summit, did not mention today's meeting. He acknowledged that some Americans oppose Senate ratification of a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement signed during the summit ``until Moscow grants independence to the group of Lithuanian separatists.'' ``But after I had contacts with the American people, it turned out that such demands do not reflect the position of the entire United States,'' Gorbachev told parliament. Gorbachev also held a meeting with the presidents of all 15 Soviet republics, and told them it was time to get down to practical work on revamping the Soviet federation, Vremya reported. The meeting included the Baltic presidents and Boris N. Yeltsin, president of the Russian republic, which deepened Gorbachev's problems today by passing a declaration of sovereignty, although a non-binding one. During his parliamentary address, Gorbachev did not mention that President Bush said he would not implement the trade deal until the Soviet parliament gives final endorsement to a law liberalizing Soviet emigration policies. Although Soviet Jews and other ethnic groups are leaving in record numbers, parliament last week adopted an agenda that delays until at least September final consideration of the law, which it has given preliminary approval. Reports from Washington inddents formed a united front last month to press their drives to restore the independence they lost 50 years ago when forcibly annexed. The leaders had asked for a meeting with Gorbachev. Estonia and Latvia have taken a more cautious path than Lithuania, tentatively declaring independence but setting no date for their secession. Gorbachev embargoed all oil, most natural gas and other raw materials shipments to Lithuania on April 18 to press the republic to rescind pro-independence laws. Lithuania has said since then that it is willing to negotiate on rolling back those laws but steadfastly refuses to revoke its declaration of independence.

DOC.HEAD: Supremacist on Arkansas Ballot; Black Seeks SC Gubernatorial Nomination
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Polls close at 7 p.m. EDT in South Carolina, 8 in Maine, 8:30 in Arkansas, and 8 and 9 in North Dakota
DOC.TEXT: A black businessman endorsed by his party's leadership competed against a Ku Klux Klan supporter Tuesday in an Arkansas runoff for the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor. Ralph Forbes, a former member of the American Nazi Party who advocates separate governments for blacks and whites, faced Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, an executive with a Little Rock company. Either man figured to be an underdog in November against the Democratic nominee, ex-Rep. Jim Guy Tucker. In South Carolina, Democratic state Sens. Ernest Passailaigue, serving his first term, and Theo Mitchell, a 16-year veteran of the Legislature, vied for the nomination to challenge popular GOP Gov. Carroll Campbell. Mitchell would be the state's first black governor. Both parties held primaries in Maine for the seat of Democratic Rep. Joseph E. Brennan, who is trying to regain his old job of governor. State Attorney General James E. Tierney was favored in a five-way Democratic race. Republicans chose between state Rep. John McCormick, an opponent of abortion rights, and David F. Emery, a former congressman who has changed his position and is now pro-choice. In Atlantic City, N.J., Mayor James L. Usry, under indictment on charges of political corruption, was in a non-partisan runoff with City Councilman Jim Whelan. Usry was the city's first black mayor. North Dakota voters decided whether to raise sales taxes from 5 percent to 6 percent for a year to improve education. They also voted for the non-partisan post of labor commissioner. Incumbent Byron Knutson, accused of sloppy management, was challenged by S.F. ``Buckshot'' Hoffner, head of the state Centennial Commission, and Craig Hagen, a political newcomer who won't reach the minimum age for the office of 25 until after the primary. In two counties west of Bismarck, an advisory vote was held to determine whether residents want to switch from Mountain to Central time to conform to the capital city.

Forbes, 50-year-old evangelist for the Sword of the Lord Good News Ministries, polled 46 percent of the 71,000 votes cast in a three-way May 29 primary, short of the majority needed to win the nomination. Harris, 36, placed second with 36 percent. The contest attracted little attention before the primary, partly because Republicans were preoccupied with an unusually bitter race for the gubernatorial nomination. The winner of that primary, businessman Sheffield Nelson, promptly repudiated Forbes and endorsed Harris, as did virtually all the state's GOP leaders. In an interview Sunday with the Arkansas Democrat, Forbes proclaimed that ``white Christian Americans are the true lost tribe of Israel'' and said that the sight of an interracial couple ``turns my stomach.'' Forbes has run unsuccessfully for several statewide offices, including a 1986 bid for the GOP lieutenant governor's nomination. He also managed the 1988 presidential campaign of former Klan leader David Duke, who is now a state representative in Louisiana. Harris is a property-management executive with JM Products Inc., a Little Rock company that manufactures hair care products for blacks. He has lost bids for seats in the General Assembly and the Little Rock Board of Directors. In South Carolina, Passailaigue, a 42-year-old accountant from Charleston, has frequently challenged the Senate leadership in his freshman term and made an unsuccessful push for tax reform. Mitchell, a 51-year-old Greenville lawyer and a lawmaker since 1974, has been a proponent of public transportation and assistance to the poor. In Atlantic City, Usry, a 68-year-old former school administrator, pleaded innocent in January to charges of illegally accepting $6,000 while hospitalized last summer. He said he was targeted for investigation because he is black. Whelan, 41, did not raise the issue of the indictment but blasted Usry for saying the night of the May 8 election that he would not campaign in two predominantly white wards. North Dakota's tax measure was designed to raise $42 million over a year to restore education cuts made after voters rejected new taxes last year. The time zone votes in Oliver and Mercer counties were not binding, but favorable votes could prompt county commissioners to petition the federal Department of Transportation make the change. Three GOP senators faced no primary opposition Tuesday in their bids for re-election. Sen. John W. Warner of Virginia won't even face a major party opponent in November. Sen. William S. Cohen of Maine will face Democratic state Rep. Neil Rolde in November, and Sen. Strom Thurmond of South Carolina will be challenged by Democrat Robert Cunningham.

DOC.FIRST: u ament of Teaching, said the numbers mean the nation had better pay more heed to improving the training of the next
DOC.SECOND: eneration of teachers. He said this group will carry the burden of
DOC.TEXT: reform for years to come. He said it was a mistake to focus almost exclusively on present teachers. ``Both older and younger teachers have to be considered, but if I were to draw a conclusion, I'd say we have been far too neglectful of educating the new generation of teachers who will be determining where schools will be going in the first quarter of the 21st century,'' said Boyer in a recent interview. Darling-Hammond added it's generally easier to train a new teacher in reform techniques such as team teaching than it is to persuade a veteran teacher to break long-cherished classroom habits. Some teacher colleges have begun to address these problems. The ``Holmes Group,'' a coalition of about 100 education schools interested in reform, is fostering programs allowing student teachers to practice new techniques in public school classrooms. Several such programs have started recently in Michigan, for example. The rise in the average age of teachers during the last two decades mirrors declining student enrollments and tight state school budgets. Those trends have been most pronounced in the Midwest and Northeast. Not all states keep teacher age data. But a check of state departments of education and local union affiliates found the average age of teachers in Connecticut, for example, is 43.3; in Georgia, 42; Indiana, 42; Michigan, 44; Maryland, 41.1; and New Jersey, 42.5. The median age in New York was 42.4 as the 1988-89 school year, and 25.1 percent of the teaching force is 49 or older. In Massachusetts, suffering the effects of a decade-old tax revolt measure and a worsening budget crisis, the average age is 47. By contrast, teachers in New Mexico, a Sunbelt state with a growing student population, average 37.7. Reformers concerned over average age emphasize they don't mean to belittle the skills of veteran teachers. ``More experienced teachers are more productive. They just won't make the mistakes a younger teacher would,'' said Gould. Nonetheless, the age statistics lend urgency to the need to update the skills of veteran teachers and create more collegial environments in public schools, said Darling-Hammond. ``By and large, teacher effectiveness increases during the first five to seven years of a career, then levels off and may even decline. Whether that happens depends on the school environment. Collegial environments that have lots of opportunities to develop and learn help foster professional growth. But that's not typical,'' she said. Educators believe that school improvement is most likely to take root in schools with a balanced mix of young and old teachers. ``From what I see, whether or not a person is willing to take a look at innovative ideas has little to do with age,'' said Keith Geiger, president of the National Education Association. ``I hear as many innovative ideas from 50 year-olds as 25 year-olds.'' But statistics suggest that the balance has swung toward a heavier concentration of veteran teachers, many of whom have seen reform waves come and go with little apparent effect and may be viewing current reform efforts skeptically. ``I think all teachers want to be part of exciting changes,'' Boyer said. ``But we have to ask: Which teachers will be prepared to harness technology? Will they be prepared to deal with an increasingly bilingual population? Will they be prepared to be creative and not just conforming?''

DOC.HEAD: Louisiana Senate Committee Votes to Lower Penalty For Beating Flag Burners
With AM-Flag Amendment, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A state Senate committee Tuesday approved legislation reducing to $25 the maximum penalty for beating someone burning an American flag. The panel's 3-2 vote came the day after the U.S. Supreme Court overturned the federal flag protection act. The bill was approved by the state House in a 53-39 Memorial Day vote. The full Senate gets the bill next. Rep. James David Cain said his bill was needed to demonstrate the people's desire for a constitutional amendment protecting the flag. ``The whole point of the bill is to send Washington a message to do something now,'' Cain told the committee. Cain's bill would amend state laws on simple battery. The crime now carries a maximum $500 fine and six months in jail. The change would specify that a person who commits simple battery on a flag burner would face no jail time and a maximum $25 fine.

DOC.HEAD: Former Rulers in Central Europe Show Good Staying Power
DOC.TEXT: Communist parties in Eastern Europe have shown surprising staying power in the region's first free elections in four decades. In Bulgaria and Romania, former Communists won elections. In Poland, Hungary, East Germany and Czechoslovakia, the Communist ideologoy has been largely dismissed by voters and replaced by reformers. But even in Czechoslovakia, where over the weekend President Vaclav Havel's Civic Forum was the big winner, Communists demonstrated a surprising core of power. ``I did underestimate the Communists, I would give them something like 8 percent of the vote,'' said Jan Urban, leader of Civic Forum, who watched the Communists get 13.7 percent of the vote. After the swift fall of a series of Communist governments in Central Europe last year, the Communist successes in free elections were not widely expected. In Czechoslovakia, many attributed the Communist vote to the country's relatively high standard of living in the East bloc and a long leftist tradition. But another reason seemed to be a fear of persecution on the part of many who were members of the old regime. ``I am convinced that the (anti-Communist) campaign ... and the demands to ban the Communist Party contributed to the fact that people who are still Communist Party members or ho recently left the party were afraid,'' said Petr Uhl, veteran dissident and Civic Forum member. ``They feared for their existence and their future and that brought them together,'' Uhl said. But he added that in spite of their limited success it was ``a party of the past.'' In East Germany, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland, Communists are virtually excluded from the new governments and expect to act as a parliamentary opposition. In Romania, reform Communists instrumental in the ouster of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu defeated a badly organized opposition led by figures who had been in exile for years. Bulgaria, probably the Soviet Union's closest ally in the East bloc, also voted in a government of reform Communists. Communists in all the countries may profit from the hardships during the region's transition to a market economy. ``This is the end of the euphoria of slogans, the time when according to some it was enough to bad-mouth the Communists,'' said Ladislav Adamec, Czechoslovakia's Communist leader. He expressed hope that things could swing the Communists' way again. ``It is probable that a new regrouping of political forces will take place, and that means new opportunities for us,'' he said. But the problems of his party are great. About 700,000 members have left the Communist Party since December 1989, mostly younger people who joined after 1981. That leaves a high percentage of older, more orthodox, members whose political future seems limited. Communists will not be permitted to join the new coalition government and the aging party membership seems unlikely to produce dynamic parliamentary politicians. The Czechoslovak Communist Party relinquished power under the pressure of a revolution. In contrast, the Polish and Hungarian parties were in the vanguard of reform, pushing their countries toward a more liberal system. Many people recognize that Imre Pozsgay, a leading reformer in the Hungarian Communist Party, played an important role in dismantling the one-party system in that nation. Yet despite the party's pioneering role in East European reform, it only won just over 10 percent of the vote in elections held in March and April. The Polish Communist Party tried to distance itself from its past by adopting the name Social Democracy of the Republic of Poland. Nonetheless, as local elections in the country showed recently, the Solidarity labor movement has virtually wiped out the former Communists as a political force. There are still several former Communist ministers in the Cabinet, however, under last August's agreement between Solidarity and the Communists.

DOC.HEAD: Outdoor Condom Campaign Launched in San Francisco
DOC.TEXT: Taxis, bus shelters, even the city's famed cable cars are displaying advertisements for name-brand condoms as part of a bold move to expand condom advertising. Schmid Laboratories, the world's largest condom manufacturer, took the step because ``while the awareness of the AIDS problem is very high, behavior changes are not as great as anyone would like to have it,'' company President Don Falk said Monday. City officials agreed the time has come for condom advertising. Unlike previous ad campaigns for condoms that took a public service approach, the new outdoor campaign tries to reach a broader audience by encouraging general condom use. The ads, which began appearing on 75 taxis, 10 cable cars and 23 bus shelters on Monday, show a box of condoms on a white background. Black lettering on the ads say: ``For extra protection _ Ramses condoms.'' The company coordinating the bus shelter campaign also supports the ads. The ads look good and there ``was never any question'' of not putting them up, said Lou Lillian, vice president-general manager of Gannett outdoor advertising. The AIDS epidemic shifted the focus of condom advertising from contraception to AIDS prevention, Falk said, but now the campaign strategy is shifting back somewhat. Falk conceded that the AIDS crisis opened doors for condom manufacturers by expanding the market and increasing the public's tolerance for open peddling of the product. Recent advertising stunts have included flying a plane over Fort Lauderdale Beach, Fla., and Padre Island in Texas during spring break with a banner that read ``Play safe with Ramses Extra.'' A similar tactic was used at the Indianapolis 500. The San Francisco project will last two months. Schmid will evaluate the campaign's effectiveness by tracking sales and conducting surveys. Coordinating the project's release with the upcoming sixth International Conference on AIDS was aimed at reaching a receptive audience. ``We thought the timing would be perfect,'' Falk said. ``The campaign would reach not only people in San Francisco who would be interested in condoms, but 10,000 to 12,000 people from all over the world who would be interested. ``I fully expect that if the project is a success we would repeat and expand it.''

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Trade Deficit Smallest in 6 Years
With AM-Bank Profits, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The deficit in the broadest measure of U.S. trade shrank to a six-year low of $22.94 billion during the first three months of the year, the government reported Tuesday, but analysts cautioned that the good news may be temporary. The Commerce Department credited a record level of American merchandise exports, increased spending by foreign tourists and higher U.S. investment earnings for the 14 percent improvement in the current account deficit compared to the fourth quarter, when the deficit had been $26.69 billion. The current account, also known as the balance of payments, is the most closely watched trade statistic because it measures not only trade in merchandise but also trade in services and investment flows between countries. The first quarter deficit was the smallest since a $20.5 billion gap in the first three months of 1984. But analysts cautioned that special factors had skewed the new figure and that the U.S. trade performance is likely to deteriorate in coming months. David Wyss, chief financial economist for DRI-McGraw Hill, said that $3 billion in first quarter export growth came from backlogged shipments at Boeing Co., which had curtailed shipments during a strike late last year. He predicted the overall deficit for all of 1990 would total $108 billion, essentially unchanged from the $110.03 billion for 1989. ``The first quarter was a bit of a false dawn,'' Wyss said. Even with the quarter's improvement, the United States is beginning the 1990s in a far different position from the beginning of the 1980s. A decade ago, America was the largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings on overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners in payments for imported cars and televisions, the investment cushion eroded. It disappeared altogether in 1985, when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. That means foreigners now own more in U.S. assets than Americans own overseas, a development that has led some to say the United States is losing control over its economic destiny. Tuesday's report indicates America's debtor position has now risen to around $670 billion, although the government's official accounting of the gap between U.S. holdings and foreign investments will not be released for several more weeks. Brad Larschan, an attorney with the Association for International Investment, a lobbying group for foreign companies doing business in the United States, said there was a growing push in Congress to restrict foreign investment, which he termed an ``unfortunate development'' given America's continued need to finance the shortfall in its current account position with foreign borrowing. For the first three months of the year, the merchandise trade deficit narrowed by 8.2 percent to $26.37 billion as an all-time high in U.S. export sales offset the highest volume of oil imports in more than 12 years. The surplus in the investment category rose by 8.3 percent to $608 million while the surplus in the services category, which covers such things as foreign tourist spending in the United States and banking and insurance earnings by U.S. companies operating overseas, rose 3.1 percent to $6.31 billion. The fourth category in the current account, unilateral transfers, covers U.S. foreign aid payments and pension benefits paid to Americans living overseas. It shrank by 25 percent to $3.49 billion in the first quarter.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Supporters Predict Close Victory on Amtrak Veto
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Will be topped after expected evening vote
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's backers predicted a close victory Tuesday in the Senate fight to protect his unblemished veto record and deny federal support for Amtrak. ``We have a good chance of winning,'' Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole said before the veto override battle. ``Everything's on track.'' ``It will be close, but we're hopeful,'' White House spokeswoman Marlin Fitzwater said. Tuesday's vote pitted $2 billion in federal support for the national passenger rail system against Bush's record of having none of his 11 vetoes overridden by Congress. The House voted 294-123 on June 7 to override Bush's veto of the bill, which authorized payment of the subsidy over three years. It was the first time either chamber had gathered the votes necessary for an override. A two-thirds vote is necessary in both houses to override a presidential veto. In the House vote, 58 Republicans joined in the override. The Senate has a 55-45 Democratic majority. Bush vetoed the bill May 24, complaining about a provision in the bill unrelated to Amtrak. He took issue with a requirement that the Interstate Commerce Commission approve any acquisition of railroads by non-railroad companies. Bush called it ``an unwarranted regulatory roadblock to the financial restructuring of the railroad industry.''

DOC.HEAD: Senator Criticizes Park Service Deal With Comedian
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., urged a Senate subcommittee Tuesday to stop the National Park Service from a land deal that would allow commercial development of pristine, Southern California land owned by comedian Bob Hope. Under the arrangement, Hope would give the National Park Service 864 acres in the China Flat area of Jordan Ranch in exchange for 59 acres of national park land in Cheeseboro Canyon. Hope is selling other land in the area to developers of a golf course and luxury housing who need the 59 acres that now belongs to the government to reach Hope's property. As part of the arrangement, the developers have agreed to pay the Park Service up to $1 million to build a new visitor center for the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area and give the service all revenues from a parking concession at golf tournaments on the Jordan Ranch. Hope also has agreed to sell 4,772 acres in the Santa Monica Mountains to the Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy, a state agency, to be preserved for public park and recreational use. Cranston call the deal troubling. ``Jordan Ranch has repeatedly been identified for federal acquisition as part of the Santa Monica Mountains National Recreation Area,'' Cranston told the Senate Appropriations interior subcommittee. ``The Park Service should be seeking to acquire that property and to protect the resources of Jordan Ranch.'' Cranston described the ranch as 2,308 acres of pristine canyon lands and said the property supports an abundant bird population. ``I am dismayed that the National Park Service is opening the door to commercial development of what one day should be national parkland,'' said Cranston. ``In my judgment they are acting directly contrary to the mission of the Park Service.''

DOC.HEAD: Sailor Swims to Get to Ship on Time
DOC.TEXT: A sailor who was afraid of reporting late to his ship swam across the Columbia River because he figured it would be faster than walking over a bridge, police said. Police noticed the man in the river before 6 a.m. Tuesday and expected they would have to rescue him, said Marvin Hoover, a police officer in Rainier, Ore. Few swimmers attempt the dangerous, half-mile crossing. But the sailor, Armano Joseph Alvarez, climbed out on a dock at Longview and was met by police who said he was barely winded. Alvarez, 21, of Santa Fe Springs, Calif., said he had to make it back to his ship, the USS Kiska, and thought swimming would be faster than walking across a bridge, police said. The Kiska was docked at the Port of Longview overnight, returning to the sea after a weekend at the Rose Festival in Portland. Alvarez was returned to ship in time before it left Longview. A Navy spokesman in Seattle, Cmdr. Jim Britt, said if sailor returned to the ship in time there would be no action taken against him.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds Weight Training Helps 90-Year-Olds
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 4 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.TEXT: Pumping iron in the geriatric set does not necessarily mean gulping down Geritol. Researchers say that giving frail 90-year-olds a regimen of high-intensity weight-training can dramatically increase their muscle strength and may help them avoid accidents associated with weak muscles. The findings, reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association, are based on a study of 10 residents of a Boston nursing home, ages 86 to 96. ``Our findings suggest that a portion of the muscle weakness attributed to aging may be modifiable through exercise,'' wrote the researchers, who were led by Dr. Maria Fiatarone of the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Human Nutrition Research Center on Aging at Tufts University in Boston. ``Because muscle strength decreases by perhaps 30 percent to 40 percent during the course of the adult life span, it is likely that at the end of training these subjects were stronger than they had been many years previously,'' the researchers wrote. They called it the first study to examine the effects of weight-training in such an old population. But Kim Herling, who works with the elderly as director of cardiovascular rehabilitation at the University of Chicago Medical Center, said the number of subjects in the study was too small to apply to the general population. ``The last thing you'd want to have happen is have a group of 60- to 90-year-old people going out and weight-lifting'' because of the risk of injury, Ms. Herling said. She said elderly people who want to lift weights should consult a physician. During the study, conducted in the summer of 1988, six women and four men participated in an eight-week weight-training program that focused on the quadriceps muscle at the front of the thigh. Three times a week, for eight weeks, the subjects performed leg lifts with weights for about 45 minutes a session. By the end of the eight-week training period, the nine subjects who completed the study had at least doubled the amount of weight they could lift, and some had tripled and quadrupled that amount, said Ms. Fiatarone. The average increase in single-leg exercises went from 16 pounds at the beginning to about 42 pounds by the end of the training, she said. One 86-year-old man stopped after four weeks because of pain at the site of a previous hernia. The rest completed the training with little pain and no injuries, the researchers said. They called the results ``remarkable'' considering the subjects' age and poor health condition at the start of the study. Seven had arthritis, six had heart disease, and four had hypertension. The subjects stopped weight-lifting at the end of the eight-week period, and four weeks later, they had lost about one-third of the strength they had gained, Ms. Fiatarone said. A similar loss would be expected in a younger person, she said, noting that for the results to be lasting, weight-training must be done on a long-term basis. Although the study focused only on leg muscles, Ms. Fiatarone said it can be assumed weight-training also would strengthen upper-body muscles in the elderly. The researcher said the results indicate that weight-training can be used in the elderly to help them gain strength and possibly avoid the falls and other accidents associated with weakness. But Ms. Herling said more research is needed to determine if weight-training strengthens upper-body muscles in the very old, adding that those muscles tend to be the weakest in the elderly. But she also said that the study ``certainly sheds new light on the capabilities that these elderly patients ... can achieve, and that's promising.''

DOC.HEAD: United States Will Not Increase Number Of Soviet Jewish Refugees
With AM-Baker
DOC.TEXT: The United States won't increase the number of Soviet Jews allowed into this country despite pressure from the Soviet Union and Arab nations, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday. ``We make the point to the Soviet Union that we have had some rather dramatic increases in the numbers that we are admitting, that at this time at least we don't think (the United States can) permit further increases because of budgetary concerns,'' Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The unprecedented number of Jews allowed to leave the Soviet Union in recent months has outraged the Arab world, which is worried that Israel's population will increase and that emigres will be settled in territories captured from Jordan and Egypt in 1967. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev has said the Kremlin was under intense pressure from Arab governments to stop the emigration to Israel, expected to reach as high as 150,000 this year. Gorbachev, at the end of a four-day summit with President Bush earlier this month, said emigration might be cut off unless Israel stops settling Soviet Jews in the predominantly Arab West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel denies it has such a settlement policy. However, Baker said he had been assured by his Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze that the Kremlin would not stop Jewish emigration despite Gorbachev's warning. ``My sense is they (the Soviets) are not going to cut it off, but that could be ... proven wrong,'' Baker said. The Soviet Union is eager for congressional approval of a trade agreement signed by Bush and Gorbachev at their summit. But lawmakers told Baker they would withhold support for any trade concessions if the Soviets stop Jewish emigration. Baker said the Soviets have asked if the United States would accept more Soviet Jews as refugees or immigrants. The United States, he said, said it had increased the number of permits for Soviet refugees from 14,000 in 1988 to 50,000 in 1990 and was taking in another 20,000 Soviets not classified as refugees.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf of 4th item to DELETE INCORRECT reference to Kona as an island
DOC.TEXT: Shark hunter Frank Mundus, who claims to be the model for the Quint character in ``Jaws,'' says he's retiring to Hawaii next year after half a century on the seas off Long Island. ``Anybody that's been in this business for 50 years has to have his head examined,'' said Mundus, 64. Mundus is in the record books for catching the biggest great white shark ever snared with a rod and reel, a 3,450-pound fish caught off Montauk Harbor in August 1986. Last summer, when Mundus tried to renew his lapsed captain's license, the Coast Guard discovered he could barely read. He was denied a license and had to hire a licensed captain to operate his boat legally. After decades of piloting his own boat, he asked, ``What do I need a bit of paper for?'' Mundus is a living legend in Montauk, which bills itself as the fishing capital of the world. He claims, and is generally believed, to be the inspiration for the cantankerous shark hunter who meets his demise in the teeth of a great white in Peter Benchley's ``Jaws.'' His opinion of the movie? ``The funniest thing I've ever seen. Hilarious. Stupid.'' In October, Mundus sold his charter fishing business and his boat, Cricket II, to two used car salesmen. He said he intends to move to Kona, on the island of Hawaii, at the end of the 1991 summer season.

DOC.HEAD: Owner of Minesweeper Wearing Out Welcome at Port Huron Docks
DOC.TEXT: It's not that folks dislike George Baker. They simply mind his minesweeper docking along the Black River. ``I feel like an orphan. ... This boat has become my obsession, too much of an obsession I suppose,'' Baker said of the 98-foot Atlas. ``Right now though, I need some place to park this damn thing.'' Baker, 48, acquired the World War II era vessel in 1988, when it sat on the bottom of the harbor at Superior, Wis. He raised the ship, repaired it and brought it his hometown, where he owned a steel fabrication business. In May 1989, Baker sold his steel business, sailed the Atlas to Algonac, anchored off Harsens Island and began turning the vessel into a recreational ship for charters he hopes to take in the Virgin Islands next year. Last November, he sailed into Port Huron, working in a factory by day and spending his free time renovating the Atlas for the trip next winter to Jacksonville, Fla. For now, though, Baker and the Atlas apparently have used up their welcome in Port Huron. Property owners along the Black River already forced Baker to leave two of his moorings, and the city is threatening to seek a court order barring the Atlas from any mooring in the city without permission from the property owner. Michael West, a lawyer representing the city, said he knows that Baker isn't annoying people on purpose, but folks see him as a nuisance just the same. ``We would prefer not to take him to court. I wish he would just hurry up and move out of here. If he had permission to be where he is, that would be fine. But he doesn't,'' West said. Baker, who has built or owned 54 boats in 30 years, said he needs just one more berth and a few more weeks on the Black River before the Atlas will be ready to leave Port Huron forever. ``I certainly haven't wanted to stir up a hornet's nest. But the spring came so late this year I haven't been able to do the work that's necessary to get this old girl out of here,'' he said. ``I am trying. Believe me I am trying.''

DOC.HEAD: Russian Republic Passes Non-Binding Sovreignty Declaration
With AM-Soviet Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The republic of Russia on Tuesday proclaimed its sovereignty in a sharp break with the central Soviet government, and deputies said it will begin to chart its own course, particularly on economic matters. The declaration, passed by the republic's legislature, carries no legal weight, but is to serve as a blueprint for future decisions on the republic's relations with the central government. Some deputies also said the republic had no intention of trying to secede from the Soviet Union. The vote by the Russian Congress of People's Deputies came just before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with the heads of all 15 republics, including Russian president Boris N. Yeltsin, who led the sovreignty drive. It was Yeltsin's first public meeting with the Soviet leader since being elected president of Russia on June 5. The huge republic has Moscow as its capital and contains two-thirds of Soviet territory and just over half the country's population. Gorbachev summoned the presidents of the republics to begin work on ``realizing the key idea of deeply reforming our federation,'' he said. The nightly news program ``Vremya'' showed him speaking to the leaders at a long table in the Kremlin. Gorbachev has long promised a revamped treaty among the republics guaranteeing their sovereignty. But the republic decided to ``take its fate into its own hands,'' Ruslan Khasbulatov, deputy chairman of the Congress of the Russian Federation, told reporters. He said the sovereignty declaration, although it would have no immediate legal effect, meant Russia will no longer have to wait ``for intelligent thoughts to come down from above.'' The announcement of the 907-13 vote on the declaration was met with a rousing ovation by lawmakers. Tuesday's measure was weaker than an original proposal that would have proclaimed that Russia's sovereignty and total control of laws on its territory would ``come into force from the moment of its passage.'' The version that was passed serves only as a political statement of intent. Khasbulatov said the stronger version ``was unacceptable and would have called forth a big clash. And we needed to pass the declaration.'' ``I think it has great political significance for our government'' and will hasten decentralization, said Khasbulatov, a strong supporter of Yeltsin. He said Russian leaders were particularly eager to start acting on their own ideas on economic reform. Deputies stressed that the proclamation did not amount to a declaration of independence like that made by the Baltic republic of Lithuania. ``We didn't declare ourselves a separate government from the U.S.S.R.,'' Khasbulatov said. ``We think our Russian fate should be within the framework of the U.S.S.R.'' Earlier in the day, deputies voted 704-206 not to drop the ``Soviet Socialist'' from the formal name of the Russian Soviet Federated Socialist Republic. Yeltsin has been a strong proponent of Russian sovereignty. He included it in his platform for the presidency and predicted it would be declared in the first 100 days of his tenure. There was no immediate public reaction to the sovereignty vote by Gorbachev, who has warned that the Kremlin cannot carry out its reforms if the Russian heartland is not firmly behind it. Yeltsin has said he hopes to cooperate with Gorbachev despite their personal and political differences, but that his first priority is defending Russia's interests.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves Program to Find Airliner Defects
DOC.TEXT: The House on Monday approved a $10 million research program to develop new technologies and inspection programs to find defects in airplanes before they cause accidents. The bill by Rep. Tom Lewis, R-Fla., was passed on a voice vote with no opposition. A similar plan is being considered in the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee. The legislation was prompted by the crash landing last July of a United Airlines DC-10 at Sioux City, Iowa, and an April 1988 accident in which part of the top was ripped off an Aloha Airlines plane during a short inter-island flight. The National Transportation Safety Board said both accidents could have been prevented through adequate inspection and maintenance programs. For example, the United crash landing _ in which 112 of the 296 aboard were killed _ was caused by an engine failure due to a crack in a fan disk from a defect when the DC-10 was manufactured in 1971. The section of the Aloha airliner was ripped off as the result of cracks in the outer metal covering that began almost 17 years earlier but went undetected, the NTSB said. In both cases, the Federal Aviation Administration began mandating inspections of aging airliners for such defects and cracks only after the accidents. ``The status quo for too long has been to do something about a problem only after it costs lives,'' Lewis said. The bill would require the FAA to devote $10 million of its research over the next three years to addressing the risks of component failures and coming up with a program to prevent them.

DOC.HEAD: Gray Smoke From Supertanker As Fireboats Pour Water
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Towering columns of black smoke and balls of flames were replaced Tuesday by a gray cloud surrounding the rear section of the crippled supertanker Mega Borg. That signaled that firefighters were gaining control of the blaze after four days. Although the plume could be seen on the clear horizon from Galveston, 57 miles away, the fire clearly was at its lowest level since the tanker erupted in flames early Saturday during the transfer of some of its cargo of 38 million gallons of light African crude oil. Five fireboats showered the rear section of the tanker with 10 water cannons _ three of the hoses pointed at the listing left side and the seven others aimed at the right rear. Another water hose was anchored to the deck of the Mega Borg and pointed toward the fire-ravaged superstructure. The superstructure, wracked by explosions and flames for three days, was engulfed in gray smoke Tuesday. The left rear of the ship was extremely close to being awash, but the thick smoke prevented a view of the stern, which the Coast Guard said Monday had dipped below the surface of the Gulf of Mexico. Earlier, a long trail of flaming oil snaked from rear of the ship. But by Tuesday, only a small pool of oil about a half-mile away was burning. The Coast Guard said later it had burned itself out. A slick of rusty brown oil extended a short distance from the rear of the ship, while a thin and broader sheen was more widespread around the vessel. One fireboat was fastened to the right side of the tanker, another vessel moored near the bow on the left side. Blue barrels containing chemical foam were clearly visible on some of the fireboats but were untouched as of Tuesday morning. No flames could be seen. A Coast Guard cutter patrolled the area west of the ship while several other boats, with oil-collecting booms extending from their sides, were sucking up patches of oil farther from the tanker. A mile or so away, the heat from the fire created its own waterspout, its thin dark finger spinning lazily like a slow-motion mini-tornado out of the smoke cloud.

DOC.HEAD: Doggie Drive-Thru Offers Fast Food for Fido
DOC.TEXT: If Fido goes into a frenzy over fast food, you can always pick up a dog biscuit shaped like a cheeseburger at a drive-through window that caters to canines. When Maggie Patterson opened her Doggie-Drive-Thru in April, her idea was met with skepticism. ``People told me I was crazy,'' Patterson said Tuesday. ``But now that I'm open, they tell me it's the greatest idea since sliced bread.'' Now besides her homemade dog biscuits in the shapes of french fries and cheeseburgers, she's trying to develop a pizza-shaped biscuit and a ``diet'' puffed rice treat for the pooch with a paunch. She mixes and bakes the biscuits using her own recipe of minced garlic, wheat germ, margarine, eggs, cheddar cheese, molasses, dry milk and whole wheat flour. She works with a veterinarian and a hospital dietitian. When the owner drives up, Patterson asks the dog's name and then offers a sample. If the dog seems too shy or aggressive, she'll have the owner give it the treat. After telling her biscuits' ingredients and the prices (45 cents for a cheeseburger biscuit the size of a large cookie), she gets the owner to talk about the dog _ something she finds people love to do. ``Meanwhile, the dog is freaking out. He's getting all the attention and nobody but him is getting anything to eat,'' she said. Sometimes, owners take their dog through as a birthday surprise, and Patterson accommodates by taking the dog's picture as a memento. On a busy Saturday, she said as many as 100 cars pull up to her window. The 9-week-old business has created such a craze, Patterson said, she has received dozens of requests for franchises. Patterson, 33, said she owes the idea to her three dogs and their love of fast-food _ the people kind. ``I used to give them cheeseburgers when we'd go through McDonald's, but they started getting fat,'' she said of her Labrador, cocker spaniel and poodle. ``But every time they'd see those golden arches they'd still go crazy.''

DOC.HEAD: Hugo Leaves Flower Rainbow Along Coast
DOC.TEXT: Hurricane Hugo left death and destruction along South Carolina's coast _ but also, apparently, a rainbow of flowers. Beside the creek here, for example, bright petunias bloom in yards where they never were planted by human hands. No one knows for sure where the flowers came from. But many believe Hugo brought them. ``We've got all kinds of stuff out of place. That's the only logical thing for us to come up with,'' said Georgetown County agricultural agent Laval Oxendine. When Hugo hit in September, the seeds of perennial flowers were mature and soon would have fallen into bed for the winter. But the storm's flooding and winds spread the seeds all along the coast, Oxendine said. He said the seeds also may have come from wildflowers being planted to beautify highways. ``(Hugo) brought me a lot of weeds and it killed all my azaleas and it killed all my dogwoods, but now I have a beautiful yard of petunias,'' said Norma Thompson, who lives here.

DOC.HEAD: Vote Tallies Misread; Smoking Restrictions Lose
DOC.TEXT: An anti-smoking measure in a rural town lost its place in Colorado history when city officials discovered it hadn't passed after all. ``The election judges read the results backwards,'' City Administrator Roy Lauricello said Monday.
