About 17 percent of the estimated 4,600 registered voters in this conservative eastern Colorado town voted June 5 on the proposal to limit smoking in public. Afterward, the city said the ordinance passed 431-355, giving the City Council 60 days to decide how strict to make the regulations. But a recount Monday revealed the measure actually failed by 11 votes, Lauricello said. ``I'm in a state of disbelief that an error of this size could have been made,'' said Mark Simmerman, a public health nurse who campaigned for the measure. Thirty-four Colorado cities and counties have enacted smoking restrictions, but this would have been the first passed in a rural town, according to the Group to Alleviate Smoking Pollution.

DOC.SECOND: Appeals Court Overturns SEC's One Share, One Vote Rule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0656 to restore dropped slug line
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court struck down Tuesday a Securities and Exchange Commission attempt to prevent corporations from creating unequal voting rights among their stockholders. The three-judge appeals panel unanimously ruled in favor of an association of top corporations that had contended the SEC was exceeding its authority by imposing a so-called ``one share, one vote'' rule. The rule in question, SEC Rule 19c-4, was adopted in July 1988. It prohibited publicly traded corporations from weakening the voting power of existing stock holders by issuing new classes of stock with superior or ``supervoting'' rights. The court upheld the arguments of The Business Roundtable, which claimed the rule interfered with corporate governance _ authority traditionally left to the states. The SEC had claimed it had a right to impose the one share, one vote rule as part of its mission under the 1934 law that created the commission to protect investors in publicly traded companies. But the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia disagreed. In an unusually sharp rebuke, the court chastened the SEC for trying to put its own ``spin on a statutory fragment.'' SEC officials had no immediate comment on the ruling, saying they hadn't yet read it. ``It's a very important decision that limits the SEC's attempt to regulate corporate governance,'' said Washington attorney Robert D. Rosenbaum, who represented The Business Roundtable in oral arguments last November before the appeals court. The Business Roundtable is an association of 200 corporations, including such corporate giants as American Express Co., Xerox Corp., Citicorp and General Mills.

DOC.HEAD: Winter Wheat Forecast Virtually Unchanged from Month Ago
DOC.TEXT: Farmers are harvesting a bumper crop of winter wheat despite some losses from wet weather and lower quality in some areas, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday. Production was estimated at a nine-year high of 2.09 billion bushels. That was down fractionally from the May forecast, but still 44 percent more than last year's drought-battered harvest of 1.45 billion bushels. Figures released by the department's Agricultural Statistics Board showed the decline from the May forecast was only about 0.1 percent, or less than 2.4 million bushels. The average yield, based on indications as of June 1, was estimated at 41.2 bushels per acre, compared with 41.1 bushels indicated last month and the 1989 yield of 35.1 bushels. Farmers are expected to harvest fewer than 50.7 million acres, down from 50.8 million indicated in May. ``Wet conditions have caused yield declines in the (Mississippi) Delta area,'' the report said. ``Early harvested fields in Arkansas had low test weights, and diseases are a problem.'' The Missouri crop is developing late, with about 23 percent ``turning color'' in the ripening process as of June 3, about 10 days behind the usual pace, the report said. In Kansas, winter wheat production was estimated at 460.2 million bushels, unchanged from the May forecast and more than double the shriveled 1989 harvest of 213.6 million bushels. Winter wheat is planted in the fall and harvested the next year. It accounts for about three-fourths of the U.S. total wheat production. The remainder is planted in the spring. The USDA's first official estimate of 1990 production of all wheat will be issued July 12. The first estimates for corn, soybeans and some other major spring-planted crops are scheduled for Aug. 9, along with revised figures for wheat. No official estimates of total 1990 wheat output based on field surveys were included. However, department analysts in a related report did project ``highly tentative'' 1990 production of all wheat at almost 2.69 billion bushels, up from fewer than 2.04 billion bushels last year and virtually unchanged from the May projection. Projections for all wheat and some other crops were based on yield trends and an assumption the crop would have normal weather the remainder of the growing season. The 1990 corn harvest was projected at 8.1 billion bushels, up from 7.53 billion harvested last year and unchanged from May. Soybean production was projected at 1.925 billion bushels, also unchanged from last month and virtually the same as the crop of 1.927 billion bushels in 1989. According to the supply-and-demand report, the U.S. wheat stockpile was drained to a 15-year low of 452 million bushels on June 1, the beginning of the new wheat marketing year. But with the expected larger 1990 harvest, the wheat stockpile could be rebuilt to about 772 million bushels a year from now. The projected larger 1990 wheat harvest is putting pressure on market prices, which were indicated in both May and June in the range of $2.90 to $3.30 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with an estimated $3.71 last season. If corn production turns out at the projected level of 8.1 billion bushels, it still wouldn't be quite enough to match domestic and export demand, the report showed. Thus, the U.S. corn stockpile, which may be around 1.28 billion bushels next fall, could edge lower by Oct. 1, 1991. Corn prices were projected at $2.35 to $2.75 per bushel in 1990-91, compared with the current season's forecast of $2.35 to $2.40 per bushel. That was up 10 cents per bushel from last month's 1990-91 projection. Soybeans were indicated at an average of $6.25 per bushel in the 1990-91 marketing year that begins Sept. 1, compared with $5.70 this season. That was unchanged from May.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection to Begin in Central Park Jogger Case
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection begins Wednesday in the trial of three teen-agers accused of raping and beating a Central Park jogger _ a case that relies mainly on what the defendants told police about each other. The first hurdle will be finding 12 jurors who haven't made up their mind about the ``wilding'' case, which has received vast amounts of attention from New York newspapers, radio and television stations. About 500 people are expected in court to form the first pool from which lawyers will try to pick the dozen jurors and six alternates. The jury will hear the cases against Antron McCray and Yusef Salaam, both 16, and Raymond Santana, 15. They and three other youths are charged with attacking an investment banker while she was jogging through the northern end of Central Park shortly before 10 p.m. on April 19, 1989. According to authorities, a pack of more than 30 youths had entered the north end of the park together for what they called wilding, a violent rampage through the park. Eventually, splitting up into smaller groups, they allegedly attacked two male joggers, a homeless man, and the female jogger, who was gang-raped and left for dead. Police said there were several rapes reported that night, and there has been at least one equally brutal rape of a woman since. But the Central Park case was especially shocking to New Yorkers and continues to hold public attention. On Tuesday, Justice Thomas Galligan decided against allowing audio-visual coverage of the trial, including live televiation and lies perpetrated against scared teen-agers and their uncomprehending parents and guardians. Without the statements, defense lawyers said after Galligan's ruling, the prosecution would have had no case.

DOC.HEAD: Appeals Court Overturns SEC's One Share, One Vote Rule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Retransmitting a0663 to restore dropped slug line
DOC.TEXT: A federal appeals court struck down Tuesday a Securities and Exchange Commission attempt to prevent corporations from creating unequal voting rights among their stockholders. The three-judge appeals panel unanimously ruled in favor of an association of top corporations that had contended the SEC was exceeding its authority by imposing a so-called ``one share, one vote'' rule. The rule in question, SEC Rule 19c-4, was adopted in July 1988. It prohibited publicly traded corporations from weakening the voting power of existing stock holders by issuing new classes of stock with superior or ``supervoting'' rights. The court upheld the arguments of The Business Roundtable, which claimed the rule interfered with corporate governance _ authority traditionally left to the states. The SEC had claimed it had a right to impose the one share, one vote rule as part of its mission under the 1934 law that created the commission to protect investors in publicly traded companies. But the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia disagreed. In an unusually sharp rebuke, the court chastened the SEC for trying to put its own ``spin on a statutory fragment.'' SEC officials had no immediate comment on the ruling, saying they hadn't yet read it. ``It's a very important decision that limits the SEC's attempt to regulate corporate governance,'' said Washington attorney Robert D. Rosenbaum, who represented The Business Roundtable in oral arguments last November before the appeals court. The Business Roundtable is an association of 200 corporations, including such corporate giants as American Express Co., Xerox Corp., Citicorp and General Mills.

DOC.HEAD: Bakers Says PLO Must Discipline Leader if Dialogue Is to Continue
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to place emphasis in lead on Baker saying PLO must discipline top leader and ADD bullet material. Picks up 7th graf pvs `_Predicted Soviet ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Liberation Organization must discipline one of its top leaders as well as publicly condemn an attempted terrorist attack on Israel to avoid cutoff of its dialogue with the United States, Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday. Baker told the Senate Foreign Relations Committee that ``an extraordinarily large number of our allies and friendly governments'' have urged the Bush administration not to precipitously cut off the contact begun in an effort to promote peace in the Middle East. However, Baker said the United States ``will not allow our pursuit of peace to undercut our commitment to fight terrorism, and I think the PLO understands that.'' The dialogue began in December 1988 after PLO leader Yasser Arafat renounced terrorism and acknowledged Israel's right to exist. In wide-ranging testimony before the panel, Baker summarized progress made at the recent U.S.-Soviet summit and reiterated administration hopes that a strategic nuclear weapons treaty can be sent to the Senate for approval by the end of the year. Baker also: _Said the United States and the Soviet Union could team up to sponsor peace talks in Angola, and that a cease-fire could include agreement by the two superpowers to halt flows of arms to the warring sides. _Said the United States would not increase its ceiling on the number of Soviet Jews allowed into this country. _Predicted Soviet aid to Cuba eventually will be curtailed because of Moscow's increasing domestic needs. _Said the administration accepts that Congress will not approve a new U.S.-Soviet trade agreement until Moscow eases an economic embargo against freedom-minded Lithuania. _Praised recent multiparty elections in Czechoslovakia in which pro-democracy groups received a plurality. However, he said the administration would reserve judgment on the Bulgarian elections, where the socialist party _ the former communists _ received almost half the vote. _Said Moscow would have to understand U.S. insistence on full NATO membership for a united Germany and why continuation of th alliance is indispensable. Speaking about the aborted attack against Israel, Baker said he told NATO foreign ministers meeting last week in Scotland that there were two conditions for continued U.S. diplomatic contacts with the group: specific condemnation of the thwarted May 30 attack on a beach near Tel Aviv, and steps toward disciplining Abul Abbas, a member of the PLO's executive council and leader of the radical faction that carried out the attack. ``We are hopeful we will get these responses,'' Baker said. ``Not optimistic, but hopeful.'' So far, PLO statements ``have fallen short of the mark,'' he told the committee, because they neither specifically condemn the raid nor indicate the possibility of punishment for Abbas, leader of the Palestine Liberation Front. Baker's comments came as seven senators, including Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, introduced a resolution calling for a cutoff of the dialogue if the PLO fails to condemn the attack and expel Abbas from the executive committee ``in the immediate future.'' Other sponsors included Sens. Connie Mack, R-Fla., Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn., Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, Bob Graham, D-Fla., and Don Nickles, R-Okla.

DOC.HEAD: New Clash in Central Asia Leaves Another 32 Dead
DOC.TEXT: Another 32 deaths have been reported in a Soviet Central Asian republic convulsed by ethnic fighting. The latest violence brings to 139 the number of people killed in the region since June 2, the official news agency Tass said Tuesday. Tass reported ``the situation is stabilizingp@holesale home heating oil, which fell 0.49 cent on Monday, added 1.57 cents to close at 48.29 cents a gallon. In natural gas trading, prices were lower almost across the board. The July contract fell to $1.558 per 1,000 cubic feet from $1.572 Monday. Only the December and May 1991 contracts managed to post gains; other contracts settled marginally lower. Much of the oil buying was technically motivated, representing a reaction to the recent steep declines in crude prices. Peter Beutel, who tracks the energy markets for Merrill Lynch & Co., said gasoline prices were driven higher by short covering, which is buying by investors who had previously sold under a short contract. Refiners and others bought crude aggressively against the gasoline contract, he said. Various factors also gave energy brokers an incentive to buy. An announcement from Royal Dutch-Shell that it was curtailing shipments of its petroleum products to the United States in its own vessels supported prices. The oil giant has been concerned about liability costs associated with environmental damage from recent tanker spills. News that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries might convene an emergency meeting to discuss oil price weakness also spurred buying. United Arab Emirates Oil Minister Mana Saeed Otaiba said at a news conference in Egypt that the oil cartel has begun preparation for a new OPEC ministerial conference and, ``if neccessity calls for such an emergency conference, it will be held.''

DOC.HEAD: Havel Calls On Ex-Communist To Form New Government
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel on Tuesday told Premier Marian Calfa, an ex-Communist, he can keep his job and form the country's first democratically elected government in more than 40 years. Havel and Calfa are leaders of the two groups that led last winter's anti-Communist revolution and won last week's elections. The official news agency CTK said Havel tapped Calfa after a meeting of the leaders of the two groups _ Havel's Civic Forum and Calfa's Public Against Violence _ agreed Calfa should form the new government. The two groups together won 46 percent of Parliament's 300 seats in the elections, held Friday and Saturday. They need a five-eighths majority to push through constitutional reform. Calfa's spokesman Ivan Fiala said he believed Calfa would be ready to present the new government and its program to Parliament within two weeks. Parliament will then elect a new president, almost certainly Havel, to serve for two years before new elections. The leader of Slovakia's conservative Christian Democrats, who came in third in the election after the Communists, told CTK in an interview that his party will stay in the opposition. ``The Christian Democratic Movement will not join a coalition with the Civic Forum and will have no participation in the future government,'' CTK quoted Jan Carnogursky as saying. Carnogursky, a former leading dissident, indicated his ambitions would be limited to his native Slovakia. Calfa, a Slovak, was Havel's choice for the premiership. Sources inside Civic Forum and Public Against Violence made clear before last weekend's elections however that they were not happy with the choice of a former Communist. Calfa, 44, became premier during the bargaining that led last December to the formation of a ``government of national understanding'' dominated by Civic Forum. The premier, a lawyer from Slovakia, turned in his Communist party card in January and since then is said by Havel aides to have impressed the president with his political skills. Calfa was a top candidate for Public Against Violence in the elections. Civic Forum and its ally won 46 percent of the vote, and a projected 169 of the 300 seats in the federal Parliament. Key officials such as Foreign Minister Jiri Dienstbier and Finance Minister Vaclav Klaus are considered certain to keep their jobs. It is uncertain who will be interior minister, the government's top law enforcement official. The incumbent, Richard Sacher, has come under fire from Civic Forum for alleged reluctance to investigate the files of the now disbanded Communist secret police. A top official of Sacher's People's Party, Josef Bartoncik, was publicly accused by Havel's aides Saturday of having worked for the secret police for the last 17 years. The People's Party, one of three parties in the Christian Democratic coalition, denies the accusations.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Says Arms To UNITA Might Be Cut If Elections Promised
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III said Tuesday the United States might consider cutting off arms supplies to rebels in Angola if the Soviet-supported government agrees to hold free elections. Baker also said the United States and Soviet Union had proposed joint sponsorship of talks between the Angolan government and the UNITA rebels on ending the African country's 15-year civil war. The United States secretly funnels weapons to UNITA, an acronym for the first letters in Portuguese of the name of the group, the Union for the Total Independence of Angola. U.S. aid has been estimated at between $40 million and $80 million annually. The State Department contends the Soviets provide the Angolan government weapons worth about $600 million to $800 million a year. Asked at a hearing of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee about a Soviet suggestion that both sides stop arming their allies in Angola, Baker said ``that would be a part, I think, ... of an agreement perhaps, if we could ever once get to a cease-fire and a commitment that there could, in fact, be open, free and fair elections.'' A U.S.-backed cease-fire between the warring sides failed last summer, and repeated attempts to start peace talks through the mediation of Zaire's President Mobutu Sese Seko failed. A possible breakthrough occurred last April, when the rebels and government representatives met in Portugal and agreed to meet again. But Angola's President Jose Eduardo dos Santos still refuses to accept UNITA's demands for free elections in the one-party state. ``I think there is potential for moving toward peace in Angola as a consequence of United States-Soviet cooperation'' in various parts of the world, Baker told the committee. Baker said that when he met with his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, at Namibia's independence celebrations last March, the United States proposed joint sponsorship of Angolan peace talks, ``and the Soviets thought it would be a good idea.'' Soviet and U.S. cooperation in resolving conflicts in their spheres of influence around the world has already led to the agreement for Namibia's independence from South Africa. Also, Presidents Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev announced at the end of their summit earlier this month that they had agreed to fly U.S. food on Soviet planes to starving Ethiopians. Meanwhile, a group of black leaders met with House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., Tuesday seeking a congressional review of U.S. policy towards Angola, including a cutoff of aid to UNITA. ``It didn't produce much in the way of concrete results,'' Randall Robinson of the Transafrica lobbying group said of the meeting. He said he and others were ``not pleased'' with the lack of urgency expressed by Foley and Reps. David Bonior, D-Mich., and Steny Hoyer, D-Md. Jesse Jackson, one of the blacks who attended the hour-long meeting, said the bottom line was that the Democrats have been working hand-in-hand with Republicans in promoting the current policy on Angola. Jeff Biggs, a spokesman for Foley, said the House members were interested in the black leaders' views but they made no immediate commitment on policy.

DOC.HEAD: Excerpts of Russian Federation's Proclamation of Sovereignty
With AM-Soviet-Russia
DOC.TEXT: The Congress of the Russian Federation proclaimed sovereignty on Tuesday with a declaration that carried no legal force but pointed to a wish for greater independence from the Soviet central government. The Union Treaty mentioned several times in the declaration refers to a future voluntary agreement among Soviet republics incorporating them into the country under newly negotiated terms. It is not known when the treaty will be offered up for negotiating, nor what its terms will be. Here are excerpts of the 15-point declaration, translated by The Associated Press:

The First Congress of People's Deputies (of the Russian federation), aware of its historical responsibility for the fate of Russia, testifying to its respect for the sovereign rights of all peoples united by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, expressing the will of the people, solemnly proclaims the state sovereignty of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic on all its territory and declares its determination to create a democratic, law-based state in the framework of the renewed Soviet Union.

The Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic is a sovereign state created by the peoples who united in it historically. The sovereignty of the (republic) is a natural and necessary condition of the existence of the statehood of Russia, which has history, culture and traditions of many centuries.

In order to maintain the political, economic and legal guarantees of sovereignty of the (republic), the full power of the (republic) is established for deciding all questions of governmental and public life, except for those that are voluntarily given over to the Soviet Union, (including) the priority of the (Russian) Constitution and (the republic's) laws on all the territory of the (republic); the validity of acts of the Soviet Union that contradict the sovereign rights of the (republic) are suspended by the republic on its territory. Disagreements between the republic and the Union are resolved according to a procedure set in the Union Treaty.
The (republic) reserves the right to freely secede from the U.S.S.R. in a procedure established by the Union Treaty and the laws based on it.
This declaration serves as the basis for working out a new (Russian) Constitution, contracting the Union Treaty and perfecting republic laws.

DOC.HEAD: New Crayons Let Kids Color the Sky Cerulean
DOC.TEXT: Kids in the '90s will have bolder, brighter Crayola crayons: fuchsia, dandelion and cerulean _ a fancy word for sky blue. Crayons in orange red, violet blue and other boring _ er, simple _ colors their parents and grandparents used will fade into history. For the first time since 1972, the company is adding eight colors and for the first time since Crayola crayons were created in 1903, retiring eight others. ``We're introducing the new colors in response to what kids told us they wanted,'' said Brad Drexler, spokesman for Binney and Smith, the maker of Crayola crayons in this eastern Pennsylvania city. The company interviewed about 150 children aged 7 and under more than a year ago, and learned that they wanted crayons in bolder, brighter colors, Drexler said. Binney and Smith developed new hues, and gave them upbeat names like wild strawberry, vivid tangerine, teal blue, royal purple and jungle green, as well as fuchsia, dandelion and cerulean. To make room in the deluxe 72-crayon case, Binney and Smith decided to discontinue the colors blue gray, green blue, violet blue, orange red, orange yellow, lemon yellow, maize, and raw umber. For example, Drexler said the ``bright and brilliant'' dandelion replaces maize, ``a dull, pale, almost mustard yellow.'' Crayon packs with the new colors are already being shipped from the plant, but they may not appear on store shelves until July, Drexel said. The largest package of 72 crayons comes in a plastic case with a handle, what Drexler called a ``yuppie'' version of the classic 64-pack that dates from 1957. It was upgraded in 1972 with eight fluorescent colors. Binney and Smith makes 2 billion crayons a year, Drexler said.

DOC.HEAD: East German Sees Bush, Gorbachev Moving Closer on Germany-NATO
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere rejected a Soviet suggestion Tuesday that a united Germany be only an associate member of NATO. Bush said, however, that it was a proposal that U.S. and Soviet officials would discuss ``without rancor'' in an effort to reach agreement. And de Maiziere, who met with Bush on Monday, said he sees Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev coming closer together over the military stance of a unified Germany. Gorbachev said in a speech to the Supreme Soviet legislature Tuesday that he could accept a German associate status in NATO, provided there were no changes in the ``mutual obligations'' that East Germany now has to the Eastern bloc and West Germany to NATO. Bush reiterated his insistence that the new Germany belongs in the Western military alliance with no strings attached and said the latest proposal sounded similar to what Gorbachev discussed at the superpower summit here two weeks ago. ``But the more talking we do, the more convinced I am that they will see that what we're proposing is more stabilizing and is best for the Soviet Union as well as Western Europe and Eastern Europe,'' Bush said. De Maiziere told the National Press Club that he, too, rejected Gorbachev's latest idea. ``We have heard in the past a series of Soviet proposals on what the solution could be,'' de Maiziere said. ``And now we have one from President Gorbachev. I believe it is one of the proposals that will be discussed but it won't be the solution.'' He said he relayed to Bush a position that Gorbachev presented to him during the Warsaw Pact summit in Moscow last week, moving toward a treaty covering the temporary presence of Soviet troops in East Germany after East and West Germany unify. ``And I had the impression that he (Bush) listened with great interest,'' de Maiziere said. The East German leader, who came to power as a result of East Germany's first free elections last March 18, said he was sympathetic to Soviet concerns about withdrawing troops from East Germany. Gorbachev insists that the 380,000 Soviet troops stationed in East Germany remain there for a transitional period. ``Of course, we're trying to establish a sovereign, united Germany,'' de Maiziere said. ``It remains to be seen whether we can find a treaty settlement that contains the presence of troops for a specified time. ``We accept that the immediate withdrawal is neither socially nor ecologically nor economically feasible,'' he said. The two Germanys are merging their currencies on July 2 and are headed toward full political union.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd item to UPDATE throughout with Checker comments, details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Rock 'n' roller Chubby Checker vowed to go on with the show Tuesday after his touring bus struck a tractor-trailer, leaving six members of his entourage injured. ``Everybody lived. It seems like nothing fatal happened,'' Checker said after the early morning accident on Interstate 35, just north of the Texas line. ``No one's near death. We're getting a truck together and we're getting a couple cars and we're going on to San Antonio. ``I think we're OK enough to do a show tonight.'' Checker's bus was traveling south on the highway when it struck a semi-tractor trailer that was pulling onto the highway from a rest stop, the Oklahoma Highway Patrol said. The six injured passengers, including Checker's brother, Spencer Evans, were treated at three hospitals for mostly minor injuries. The most seriously injured was the bus driver, who was listed as stable, authorities said. The driver of the truck was not injured, the patrol said. Checker, 48, gained international fame in the early 1960s for popularizing the dance the twist.

DOC.HEAD: Procedures Outlined for Compensation in Letelier Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to show that U.S. and Chile have reached formal agreement on procedures to pay compensation, sted Chile agreeing to pay compensation, which was reported earlier. Picks up 2nd graf pvs `Orlando Letelier ...'
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Chile have reached agreement on procedures for Chile to pay compensation to the family of a former Chilean diplomat who was assassinated in Washington in 1976, the State Department said Tuesday. Orlando Letelier and an associate died in a car bombing, and U.S. authorities blamed agents of the military government that then ruled Chile. Chile's new, 3-month-old government has agreed to pay compensation for the deaths of Letelier and Ronni Moffitt without admission of official liability by the previous government. The military government ignored a 1980 order by a U.S. federal district judge to pay families of the victims $2.9 million. An international commission, set up years ago to help settle bilateral disputes, will determine the amount of compensation to be paid, the State Department said. The Chilean Congress then will be asked to approve the request. The bilateral agreement outlining the procedure was signed Monday. Letelier, an outspoken opponent of the military government, had served as foreign minister and held other high posts in the government of leftist President Salvador Allende. The State Department statement referred only briefly to the question of culpability for the murders. ``Both governments recognize that bringing to trial those responsible for the murders of Orlando Letelier and Ronni Moffitt is of utmost importance,'' it said. During the administration of President Augusto Pinochet, Chilean authorities refused to turn over three security officers wanted in the United States for the killings. But a few weeks after Pinochet turned over the presidency to an elected successor, Patricio Alwyn, the Chilean Supreme Court decided to reopen the case. A Cuban exile who had eluded authorities for 12 years was arrested April 11 in St. Petersburg, Fla., on five felony charges related to the bombing. Jose Dionisio Suarez Esquivel, indicted in 1978 with seven others, has pleaded innocent to the charges.

DOC.HEAD: States Sue Mobil Over Hefty Trash Bags
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `In March ...' to CORRECT spelling to Gray sted Grey; Version moving on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: Five states sued Mobil Chemical Co. on Tuesday, charging the company falsely claimed its Hefty trash bags and grocery bags would decompose. Mobil announced in March that it would stop referring to its Hefty bags as biodegradable because of confusion about what degradable means. Lawsuits were filed by Massachusetts, Minnesota, Texas, California and Wisconsin. New York and Washington state were also expected to file lawsuits. The lawsuits contend Mobil made false claims for the Hefty bags in advertisements by saying they break down when exposed to sun, wind and rain. Allen Gray, a spokesman for Mobil Chemical, said the company had been talking with states and had hoped to resolve questions about its claims without a lawsuit. ``We're disappointed here,'' he said, and noted that the company already voluntarily agreed to drop its claims for bags because there is no agreement on how to define the term biodegradable. The Massachusetts lawsuit said the degradability claim violated the state Consumer Protection Act. The bags do not perform as promised because they are ultimately incinerated or disposed of in landfills, where they decompose no faster than ordinary plastic bags, the lawsuit alleges. ``Promoting plastics as degradable may actually cause consumers to increase the amount of their litter because they may believe that the products will degrade rapidly if littered,'' said the lawsuit filed in Superior Court at Suffolk County. In March, Gray said claims that the bags degrade in sunlight had been fully substantiated by tests and that the company never said the bags would be the answer to the country's waste disposal problem. The company said it would continue to make Hefty trash bags with an ``environmentally safe additive'' that speeds up their decomposition when exposed to sunlight. Gray conceded that, ``If left out in Arizona somewhere as bag with the additive can quickly decompose in a couple of months, but in a northern climate like Chicago it could take well over a year.'' Mobil made its announcement shortly before it was to meet with a task force of state attorney generals investigating deceptive advertising and packaging. Massachusetts is seeking civil penalties of $5,000 for each violation of the state Consumer Protection Act. In Massachusetts, Mobil sold or distributed an estimated 112,000 cases of Hefty bags and more than 75 million Marketote grocery sacks between June and December of 1989, according to the lawsuit. Tom McNaught, a spokesman for state Attorney General James Shannon, said the state also wanted assurances that Mobil has permanently dropped the degradability references. Minnesota is seeking $250,000 in damages. ``Unfortunately, Mobil's advertising claims break down faster than their garbage bags,'' said Minnesota Attorney General Hubert Humphrey III at a news conference in St. Paul, Minn. The California lawsuit seeks civil penalties of $500,000 and an injunction to formally halt the ads. In Wisconsin, Attorney General Don Hanaway said, ``These claims prey on people's desire to play a role in protecting the environment.'' Hefty bags need to be exposed to a minimum of 26 to 42 days of sunlight in Arizona or Florida, and up to six months in other parts of the United States, to trigger degradation of the bags, according to the lawsuits.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Snow in Oregon
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell Tuesday in much of the Midwest, as well as in sections of the West and the South, and northern Oregon got June snow. At midday, showers and thunderstorms stretched from Michigan to Wisconsin, Minnesota, northwest Iowa, Nebraska, Kansas, the panhandles of Oklahoma and Texas, and New Mexico. Showers stretched from southern South Dakota to northwest Nebraska, northern Colorado, southern Wyoming and northern Utah and northwest Oregon. Three inches of snow fell overnight in Oregon's northern Cascade Mountains, and snow advisories were posted for higher elevations. In the South, showers and thunderstorms reached from the Texas coast to southern Louisiana and southern Florida. Showers were scattered over western West Virginia into southern Ohio and northeast Kentucky. Warnings of winds gusting to 50 mph were posted for the Front Range of the Montana Rockies, and for gusts approaching 45 mph and blowing dust and sand in Southern California's Antelope Valley and Mojave Desert. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 37 degrees at Yellowstone National Park, Wyo., to 99 degrees at Carlsbad, N.M. The low temperature for the Lower 48 was 27 degrees at Truckee, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Lauds Gorbachev Talks with Baltic Leaders
DOC.TEXT: President Bush hailed talks between Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Baltic leaders on Tuesday as a ``heartening development'' in the long standoff between Moscow and the three independence-minded republics. ``I hope that out of that comes a further step towards self-determination for the Baltics,'' Bush said. ``I view dialogue as something that's very important.'' The president said he is still weighing whether to end talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization to protest the May 30 guerrilla attack on an Israeli beach. He said the attack should be ``condemned and those who did it condemned.'' The PLO issued a statement on Monday renouncing terrorism, but not specifically renouncing the beach attack. Speaking to reporters in the Rose Garden, Bush expressed satisfaction with Gorbachev's meetings with the leaders of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. ``I think that's a heartening development,'' Bush said. ``I view dialogue as something that's very important. I've said all along we want dialogue to go forward.'' Gorbachev ``knows I have a difference with him on the status of Lithuania, the United States never having recognized its incorporation into the Soviet Union,'' Bush added. Bush commented as he took questions from reporters after giving a talk reiterating his support for a constitutional amendment to outlaw flag desecration Gorbachev, trying to resolve the impasse, met with Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis and with the leaders of the two other Baltic states for the first time on Tuesday since he declared their independence moves illegal. Bush, asked whether he had decided to end the dialogue with the PLO that began in December 1988 to protest the thwarted attack on a Tel Aviv beach by Palestinian guerillas, replied: ``No decision on that yet.'' ``There's quite a bit going on behind the scenes. But I just can't tell you,'' he said. Bush said he had discussed the attack on the phone earlier Tuesday with Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak. ``But I'm not prepared to make my decision known on that yet,'' he said. ``I want to see that terrorist act condemned, and those who did it condemned,'' he added. On other subjects, Bush: _Declined to comment on a published report that linked the CIA to the arrest of anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela in 1962, saying ``I haven't looked into it'' yet. But, he said, ``I'm very pleased that he's coming here.'' Mandela will visit Washington on June 25. _Declared he feels like ``a spring colt'' on his 66th birthday. ``It's been a good birthday. I hadn't thought so. But good cake, good cards and _ not bad.'' _Cheered Texas Ranger pitcher Nolan Ryan's setting of a new major league record by pitching his sixth no-hitter on Monday. ``Look, what's Nolan, 43? Just the tops _ top human being and a top performer. And it's a great symbol for the kids around this country that love baseball as much as I do.'' Bush's oldest son, George W. Bush, is a part-owner of the Rangers. ``It was a wonderful moment. I wish I'd been there,'' the president said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules IRS Needlessly Harassed Couple
DOC.NOTE: Eds: $2.46 in 5th graf cq
DOC.TEXT: A judge said an Internal Revenue Service agent was incompetent and rude in her dealings with a couple who owed back taxes. U.S. District Judge B. Avant Edenfield on Monday removed IRS agent Sherilyn Heyward from the case of Brenda and Alan Stout, owners of a Garden City convenience store. ``The combination of incompetence and rudeness with which the Stouts were treated at the hands of Heyward and her supervisor is unacceptable,'' the judge's order said, adding that it ``demonstrates the IRS's lack of organization and respect for the taxpayers.'' The judge last month voided a search warrant he had approved for a search of the Stout's business. The affidavit contended Mrs. Stout was switching bank accounts in an effort to conceal assets and avoid paying $10,900 in back taxes. The Stouts have complained that IRS officials gave them four different figures to satisfy the taxes. Their business was raided May 10 by six agents who took $2.46 belonging to an employee and money collected from the sale of novelty clowns by a private citizen, evidence showed. The agents also rifled through business records, froze the company's bank account and filed a lien on the company that supplies the business oil and gas. The Stouts are now trying to sell their business to satisfy the IRS bill. The judge said the IRS agent's affidavit was probably intentionally misleading. While the affidavit said the Stouts owed $7,532.95 plus penalties, it did not mention nearly $90,000 in back taxes were paid within the last year. Heyward could not be reached for comment Tuesday afternoon. Telephone information in Savannah lists only an S. Heyward with a non-published number. An IRS spokesman in Atlanta said the agency's lawyers would review the order before issuing a response.

DOC.HEAD: Single Berlin Government Meets for First Time in Four Decades
DOC.TEXT: A single Berlin government met for the first time in four decades on Tuesday and decided to swiftly demolish the rest of the Berlin Wall. City council members from both sides of the city gathered in East Berlin's historic Rotes Rathaus, a monumental red-brick building that was the seat of local government for more than a century. The two councils agreed to begin on Wednesday the final demolition of the wall that split the city for 29 years. ``We are already now one city,'' said East Berlin Mayor Tino Schwierzina, who was elected in East Germany's first free local elections in May. One section of wall is to remain standing as a memorial to the people who were killed trying to flee from East Germany to the West. The demolition is to be completed by July 2, when the two German states are to merge their economies in the major step to full unification. The meeting of the West Berlin Senate and the East Berlin Magisrat was the first involving local officials from both Berlins since 1948, after Germany and its capital were both carved in two by the victorious World War II Allies. The two councils, which meet separately once a week, plan to meet jointly every two weeks until full unification takes place and a single government is chosen in new local elections. East Germany's former Communist government was toppled by mass protests in October and the wall was opened in November. Since then, Germans have been able to pass back and forth between the cities and the two nations. Border crossings still are staffed by guards on both sides of the wall and cursory passport checks are still made. Foreigners can pass only through two points. Some of the most famous stretches of the Berlin Wall have already been demolished, but most of the wall still snakes around West Berlin. Berlin was divided into four sectors following World War II, with the Soviets in control of the East and France, Britain and the United States in control of the West. East Berlin is the capital of East Germany, but West Berlin is still technically under military occupation and not part of the territory of West Germany. The four Allies are expected to negotiate an end to their direct involvement in the cities during the series of ongoing talks that also are dealing with the future strategic allegiance of a united Germany. The Allies are to hold their next negotiations on June 22 in East Berlin. ``The unity process in Berlin is being carried out considerably faster than in any place else in Germany, but also the problems are greater than anywhere else,'' West Berlin Mayor Walter Momper told a news conference after the council meeting. Last week, U.S. officials said they would take down Checkpoint Charlie, the Allied checkpoint that was perhaps the world's most famous border crossing and a symbol of the Cold War. Many Germans expect that Berlin will return as the capital of Germany after unification. The West German seat of government was moved to Bonn after the war.

DOC.SECOND: AM-Right to Die Poll, 1st Ld-Writethru, a0615,610
DOC.HEAD: 8 of 10 Believe Some Patients Should Have Right to Die
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS spelling to Kevorkian from Kervorkian thruout
DOC.TEXT: Eight of 10 Americans believe patients should be allowed to die in some circumstances and about half say some incurably ill people have a moral right to commit suicide, according to a poll released Tuesday. The poll, by the Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press, was conducted a month before Dr. Jack Kevorkian, a retired pathologist in Pontiac, Mich., assisted in the June 4 suicide of Janet Adkins, who had been diagnosed as being in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease. Diane Colasanto, a researcher for the Times Mirror Center who is based in Princeton, N.J., said the survey did not include any questions about physician-assisted suicide, but added, ``I think what we found is relevant to the Kevorkian case.'' The survey found that 80 percent of those polled believed there are some circumstances in which a patient should be allowed to die. Only 15 percent thought doctors and nurses should always do everything possible to save a patient's life. Forty-nine percent said a person with an incurable disease has the moral right to commit suicide, compared with the 40 percent who expressed such a view in a 1975 Gallup poll. Fifty-five percent said there is a moral right to commit suicide if a person is suffering great pain with no hope of improvement. Forty-one percent held such a view in the 1975 survey. Susan M. Wolf, a lawyer with the Hastings Center, a research institute in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., that studies medical ethics, said there is a clear distinction between a doctor withholding life support and a doctor assisting in a suicide. ``Both medical ethics and law treat those things as exact opposites of one another,'' she said. ``In both ethics and law, it is very widely agreed now that the doctor is really mandated to stop life-sustaining treatment at the patient's request. On the other hand, when you get to the question of physician-assisted suicide, both medical ethics and the criminal law roundly condemn that as it stands.'' Many states have right-to-die laws, but the question has remained a controversial one. The Supreme Court is expected to rule soon on the efforts of a Missouri couple to remove life support from their 31-year-old daughter, Nancy Cruzan, who was severely brain damaged in a car crash. The Justice Department has sided with the state of Missouri in attempting to block removal of the life-support equipment. In 1985, the Lou Harris polling organization asked whether a patient who was terminally ill, with no hope in sight, had the right to ask a doctor to be put out of misery. Sixty-one percent said, ``Yes;'' 31 percent said it would be wrong to make such a request. Ms. Colasanto said the percentage of affirmative responses was an increase over previous polls on the same question. A poll last year by Opinion Research Associates said that 66 percent of people surveyed believed a physician should be allowed by law to end the life of an incurably ill patient, she said. Kevorkian has not been charged. Oakland County Circuit Judge Alice Gilbert ordered him to stop using a device he calls the suicide machine or taking other steps to help people kill themselves until prosecutors decide whether to try him. Prosecutors say toxicological tests on Ms. Adkins' brain, to determine whether the 54-year-old, Portland, Ore., woman had Alzheimer's disease, will take up to two months. The Times Mirror center, an adjunct of the Times Mirror publishing and broadcasting organization, conducted telephone interviews with 1,213 adults from May 1 to May 5. It said the results are subject to an error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, GOP Lawmakers Ask Quick Flag Vote; Dems Say They'll Get It
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 14 grafs with new Bush, Foley comments, picking up in 6th graf pvs, Senate Minority; edits to tighten
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying flag desecration is ``unacceptable and must carry a price,'' asked Congress on Tuesday to pass a constitutional amendment restoring special protection by the Fourth of July. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley said he would allow a vote within two weeks, but added that he would break tradition and vote on the measure himself in order to emphasize his opposition to what he saw as meddling with the First Amendment. Foley accused Bush of trying to ``take political advantage'' from an issue that goes to the heart of the Bill of Rights. ``What that flag encapsules is too sacred to be abused,'' Bush said at the White House after receiving on his 66th birthday a miniature replica of the Iwo Jima Memorial, the Marines' famed flag-raising sculpture. Bush joined Republican lawmakers in demanding quick action from the Democratic-controlled House and Senate on the amendment, which would restore legal protections wiped out by Supreme Court rulings last June and again on Monday. Foley, D-Wash., said they would get their vote, but he also said he didn't like what was being done in the name of patriotism. ``Every country has a flag. We are one of the few countries that has a Bill of Rights,'' he said before Bush spoke. ``To make it a partisan issue, to attempt to take political advantage out of a question that has a deep relevance to the protection of our constitutional integrity and to the protection of the First Amendment, is not in my judgment worthy of the president, and I'm sorry he's doing it,'' Foley said. Bush said it was not a partisan issue, but he said ``You're darn right'' when asked if he planned to talk about the flag in the upcoming election campaign. He said the amendment was ``an American issue. And so I call on the Congress to act by July Fourth, this nation's birthday.'' ``The law books are full of restrictions on free speech and we ought to have this be one of them,'' said the president. Flag burning ``endangers the fabric of our country and I think it ought to be outlawed,'' he said. Bush said the amendment is ``the surest, safest way to guarantee that while speech remains free, flag desecration is unacceptable and must carry a price.'' He lavished praise on the replica of the Iwo Jima Memorial by sculptor Felix Deweldon of Oregon. They were joined in the Rose Garden by Sen. Mark Hatfield, R-Ore., who fought at Iwo Jima, where almost 7,000 Americans perished in the 1945. Hatfield voted against the constitutional amendment last year, but his office said he would reluctantly support it now. Earlier, GOP leaders emerged from a strategy meeting with Bush sharply criticizing the Supreme Court's 5-4 ruling Monday striking down the federal flag protection law enacted last October. Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., pulling a small flag from his pocket, said he would press for a vote on Thursday, Flag Day. ``The Democrats should give us a very quick vote,'' said Dole. ``We don't need more hearings.'' He took a jab at Supreme Court Justice John Paul Stevens, who voted to uphold the federal law but in his dissent criticized politicians who ``manipulate the symbol of national purpose ... for partisan disputes.'' ``We're not manipulating,'' snapped Dole. He said Stevens has a right to criticize politicians, ``and we have a right to criticize the court, and they're wrong.'' Bush made an issue in the 1988 campaign of his opponent Michael Dukakis' veto as governor of Massachusetts of a law that would have penalized public school teachers who refused to lead the Pledge of Allegiance. Bush went to the actual Iwo Jima Memorial in nearby Arlington, Va., last June 30 to unveil his proposed amendment, which states: ``The Congress and the states shall have power to prohibit the physical desecration of the flag of the United States.'' That was two days after the first Supreme Court ruling striking down state laws that made flag desecration a crime. The Senate subsequently fell 15 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed to pass the Bush amendment. It got a bare 51-48 majority. The Bill of Rights, comprising the first 10 amendments to the Constitution, has never been amended. A constitutional amendment requires two-thirds majorities in both the Senate and House and approval by 38 of the 50 state legislatures. Rep. Craig Washington, D-Texas, said Tuesday, ``We're called upon in this body to decide what is more sacred _ the Constitution or the flag. It would seem to me the Constitution is more sacred.''

DOC.HEAD: Wrong-Size Bolts in Airplane Windscreen Blowout
DOC.TEXT: Wrong-size bolts were fitted to a jetliner windshield that blew out in flight, sucking the pilot halfway out the cockpit, government officials said Tuesday. British Airways said a maintenance engineer involved in the installation was suspended, as standard procedure during inquiries. Cabin staff saved pilot Tim Lancaster, 41, on Sunday, clutching his ankles as he was bounced against the nose cone for 15 minutes over England until the co-pilot of the twin-engine BAC 1-11 made an emergency landing at Southampton. An interim report from the Department of Transport's Air Accident Investigation Branch said the diameter of 84 of the 90 bolts was too small for the captive nuts into which they fitted to hold the windshield in place. Lancaster suffered broken bones, bruises and frostbite but Southampton General Hospital said it expected to discharge him Wednesday. Investigators said the blowout occurred as the 18-year-old aircraft was climbing from Birmingham airport at 17,000 feet carrying six crew and 81 passengers bound from Birmingham to Malaga, Spain. The 2-by-3-foot windshield was found on the ground. Investigators were trying to find out if the bolts were wrongly manufactured or incorrectly packaged when delivered or if the airline's own engineers selected the wrong bolts. They said the windshield was fitted during routine maintenance the day before the incident, not two days, and the plane was at 17,000 feet when the blowout took place, not 23,000 feet _ as earlier reported. British Airways was checking out all its 34 BAC 1-11s.

DOC.HEAD: Arab States Warn Israel's New Gov't Could Lead to War
With AM-Israel Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Israel's Arab neighbors warned Tuesday the Jewish state's new right-wing government is a threat to the peace process and could lead to war. In a statement, the Egyptian government said Israel has apparently begun ``to prepare for aggression and war.'' The official Cairo Radio reported that President Hosni Mubarak telephoned President Bush to ``discuss current developments in the Middle East.'' The radio gave no further details. Egypt is the only Arab state to have signed a peace treaty with Israel. In Jordan, King Hussein called the new Israeli government a ``dangerous threat'' and reiterated his call for a peaceful solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict. ``The form of the new Israeli government constitutes a dangerous threat to the stability of this region because the foundations which led to the establishment of this government make it the most extremist Israeli government ever formed,'' Hussein told the visiting Soviet deputy foreign minister, Vladimir Petrovsky. Hussein's statements were carried by Jordan's official Petra news agency. On Monday, Parliament narrowly approved a new government headed by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. The governing coalition also includes several far-right and religious factions. The government has promised new measures to crush the 30-month-long Palestinian rebellion against Israel's occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip and is committed to increasing Jewish settlement in those areas. Shamir's alliance has also ruled out any direct or indirect talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. One two-man party within the governing coalition advocates the expulsion of Arabs from the occupied territories. In Syria, President Hafez Assad warned of a new war with the Jewish state and said a confrontation will be bloodier than any of the previous wars. Speaking at a session of the National Council, or Parliament, Assad said: ``Wars today will not be like the wars fought in the past which left low casualties.'' Assad said Israel remains ``technologically superior and can cause disasters in times of war. However, the Arabs can reciprocate and the disasters will be more serious to Israel.'' Israel has fought four wars against its Arab neighbors since the Jewish state declared independence in 1948. Israel emerged victorious in the wars of 1948, 1956, 1967 and 1973, but at considerable cost. Israel also invaded Lebanon in 1982 in an effort to drive the PLO from that country. Israel withdrew the bulk of its invasion force in 1985, but still maintains a small security strip along its northern frontier. Tensions in the Middle East have been increasing as Arab countries continue to stockpile missiles and develop chemical weapons in an effort to match Israel's military superiority.

DOC.HEAD: House Sends President Bill That Would Erase Some Hatch Act Restrictions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf pvs `By a ...' to UPDATE with vote breakdown. Picks up 3rd graf pvs `Unlike the ...' ADDS 4 grafs of background
DOC.TEXT: The House, in the face of an administration veto threat, voted overwhelmingly Tuesday to send President Bush a bill allowing federal workers to take an active role in politics for the first time in half a century. By a 334-87 vote, the House forfeited its own version of Hatch Act changes to adopt a Senate bill that is less onerous to the White House but is still opposed by top administration officials. Ninety of the 176 Republicans, including Minority Leader Robert H. Michel of Illinois, joined 244 Democrats to pass the bill. Three Democrats _ Reps. Anthony Beilenson of California, Charles Bennett of Florida and Thomas Foglietta of Pennsylvania _ voted against the measure. Unlike the original House bill approved more than a year ago, the measure that being sent to Bush retains prohibitions against federal workers running for partisan office or soliciting campaign funds from the public. The Senate passed the same bill last month by a vote of 67-30, but GOP leaders there have expressed confidence they can persuade one or two of their colleagues to change votes to sustain a veto. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a letter Tuesday that he and other senior Bush advisers would recommend that the president veto the bill. ``Such a reversal in the role of partisan politics in the ethic of public service would permit virtually unbridled partisan activities by federal employees,'' Thornburgh said in a letter to House GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. As passed by both houses, the bill substantially erases prohibitions under the 51-year-old Hatch law that restrict th nation's 3 million federal civil service and postal employees to little more than voting. If enacted into law, those employees could begin holding office in local, state and national political party organizations for the first time. They also could solicit campaign funds from co-workers on behalf of federal employee union political action committees, but only when not working. However, federal workers would still be prohibited from running in a partisan election for public office or soliciting campaign funds from anyone other than fellow members of government employee unions. The original House version approved by a 297-90 vote in April 1989 would have allowed government workers to take leaves of absence to run for partisan office and solicit campaign funds from anyone. ``Government workers in the Soviet Union enjoy more freedom to practice politics than America's government workers,'' said Rep. William Ford, D-Mich., one of the bill's sponsors. ``We are not advocating the gray masses ... rising up in a coup,'' Ford said. ``We're only asking for the simple right to put up a yard sign, display a bumper sticker, send a check or stuff envelopes.'' The Hatch Act was enacted at the height of the New Deal to protect the emerging civil service from being coerced by political appointees to contribute to or work on behalf of candidates. ``The Americans who guide the planes we fly ... and who deliver the mail deserve our trust in the very modest right to participate in the political process,'' said Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn. Opponents argue that the law's protections against a spoils system are still needed. ``Times have changed but the factors that make the Hatch Act necessary have not changed,'' said Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va. ``Human nature has not been repealed by Congress. The inevitable result will be a politicizing of the federal work force.''

DOC.HEAD: Teen-ager Elected to School Board on Day After Graduation
DOC.TEXT: It took Jeffrey Card exactly one day to go from mortarboard to school board. Card graduated Sunday from Richmond High School. On Monday, he was elected to a four-year term on the Board of Education in this rural community 30 miles northeast of Detroit. Card missed the April filing deadline for board candidates, but not on purpose; he wasn't old enough. He turned 18 May 16. Waging a write-in campaign, he collected 703 votes to 545 for Victoria Bonino, 30, the only other candidate on the ballot. The new board member said he decided to run after his father died about 1{ years ago at age 41 of a brain tumor. ``If you want to take advantage of life, you'd better do it now,'' said Card, who plans to attend the University of Detroit on a scholarship this fall. Card will have his hands full when he's sworn in July 1. While Richmond voters were electing him, they also rejected proposed tax increases for school buses and equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Midol Manufacturer Agrees to Fine, Will Alter Ads
DOC.TEXT: The makers of Midol, a menstrual relief medication, agreed Tuesday to pay $375,000 in fines to settle a complaint that the company had made unsubstantiated advertising claims. The consent agreement with the Federal Trade Commission ``is without admission of any wrongdoing,'' said Terry Kelley, a spokesman for Sterling Drug Inc., which makes Midol. Kelley said the company, the nation's largest manufacturer of over-the-counter menstrual relief medicine, entered into the agreement ``to avoid protracted, costly litigation.'' It would have involved ``highly technical scientific issues,'' said Kelley. ``This does not involve our current advertising,'' Kelley said, explaining that all of the questionable advertising had been stopped by March. ``Sterling will continue to manufacture and market the Midol brand products.'' The FTC said Sterling had violated a 1985 order prohibiting a firm from making performance claims ``unless it has a reasonable basis to substantiate the claims.'' The complaint said Sterling ran certain ads for ``Original Formula Midol'' and ``Maximum Strength Midol for Cramps'' from March 1985 to January 1986 and in April 1988 that claimed or implied one of the ingredients was a muscle relaxant for menstrual cramps that would quickly help relieve muscle contractions. ``The company did not have competent and reliable scientific evidence for those claims,'' the agency said in its complaint. ``The ingredient in question has been removed from the product,'' according to Sterling. Virtually all of the company's products were included in the FTC's advertising complaint. Also cited were ads for ``Maximum Strength Midol PMS'' which claimed ``total'' or ``complete relief'' for the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome. The FTC also said the company had ``no competent and reliable scientific evidence'' for claims that ``Original Midol Muti-Symptom Formula'' and ``Maximum Strength Midol Multi-Symptom Formula'' relieved menstrual bloating and water-weight gain. Sterling is based in New York City and is a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Eastman-Kodak Co.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Review Ordered
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon's top personnel official has been asked to recommend cuts in the number of military officers needed in the coming years, the Department of Defense said Tuesday. Deputy Secretary of Defense Donald Atwood asked Christopher Jehn to coordinate the study in anticipation of a ``smaller force structure in light of changing world conditions and declining budgets,'' the department said in a statement. The study will look at the number of officers expected to graduate through 1997 from military service academies, reserve officer training corps, officer candidate schools and other programs. Jehn will coordinate the study with the secretaries of the various military departments and Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. The report, the statement said, should include recommendations on ``appropriate reductions'' in the officer corps for fiscal years 1991 through 1997. Atwood said in his memo that the Defense Department must manage its reduction ``to ensure that the Department maintains the military capabilities it needs to defend the nation and protect American interests around the globe.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's proposed 1991 budget has called for reducing the armed forces by about 38,000 men and women.

DOC.HEAD: White House Won't Comment On Reported U.S. Role In Mandela Arrest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to update with Bush comments and edit; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The White House on Tuesday brushed aside a report linking the CIA to the 1962 arrest of anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela, saying there was ``no value in reviewing a 30-year-old history.'' ``I haven't looked into it yet,'' Bush said in response to questions about the report, published earlier this week in an Atlanta newspaper. His spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, earlier dismissed the report, saying, ``We just don't comment on these kinds of intelligence matters and we don't intend to.'' ``Our attitude toward Mr. Mandela is one of total support and we want to demonstrate that to him when he comes,'' Fitzwater said. Mandela, 71, who heads the African National Congress, will visit the White House on June 25. He was freed from a South African prison earlier this year after 27 years. In a sometimes testy exchange with reporters, Fitzwater repeatedly refused to confirm or deny a report in an Atlanta newspaper earlier this week that the CIA had helped arrange Mandela's arrest on Aug. 5, 1962. Nor would he say whether the administration felt Mandela were owed an apology. ``We welcome Mr. Mandela to this country. The president personally called him and invited him. We recognize the outstanding contributions that he has made to the fight against apartheid in his country and the contributions he has made to fight racism around the world,'' Fitzwater said. ``We want his presence here to highlight that fact. We want to fight apartheid as best we can. And we find no value in reviewing a 30-year-old history in this case.'' Asked whether Bush, as a former Central Intelligence Agency director, was concerned about allegations, Fitzwater said: ``I'm not going to comment on it. I just won't do it.'' The Atlanta Journal-Constitution reported that a senior CIA official claimed credit for Mandela's capture within hours of his arrest. The newspaper quoted an unidentified ``intelligence officer'' as saying that a tip from a paid CIA informant led to Mandela's arrest. Bush was asked whether he would apologize to Mandela. ``I don't know what I'll do about that. But I'm very pleased that he's coming here. I'm very pleased that he is free,'' the president said. ``I saw a story about that. But ... I cannot attest to it. I haven't looked into it yet.'' Asked if turning someone in to another intelligence agency would have been proper for the CIA, Bush responded, ``I can't comment on that matter.'' Fitzwater told reporters: ``Don't beat me up for what the Kennedy administration did.'' ``I don't like it when people question our motives in regard to blacks or Mandela in relation to something the Kennedy administration did,'' he said. John F. Kennedy was president in 1962 when Mandela was arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Postpones Action on Controversial Section of Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Patrick Leahy, chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, delayed action on the commodities section of the 1990 farm bill Tuesday after fellow Democrats opposed his strategy to appease Republicans. Meanwhile, the House Agriculture Committee met in closed session on the conservation section of its farm bill, trying to settle disputes between environmentalists and farmers. Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., who led the drafting of the original Democratic commodities proposals, said the bill Leahy and ranking Republican Sen. Richard Lugar created for committee markup sounded more like a Republican bill than a Democratic one. ``We're in the majority,'' Kerrey said. ``What we were saying to the chairman was you should vote the Democratic proposal.'' The dispute between the Democrats and Leahy became obvious when a morning session scheduled for a vote was so poorly attended that Leahy decided to cancel it. Leahy said in a statement that he didn't agree with all parts of the bill he was putting on the table, but that ``it represents the basis of a bipartisan compromise on commodities.'' During markup sessions, committee members can radically change legislation through amendments. But Kerrey said the minority Republicans should be the ones trying to amend the proposals, not the Democrats. Lugar has threatened to cause trouble for the Democrats on the floor if the committee doesn't approve a bill that freezes target prices, loan rates, and acreage reduction levels and omits budget gimmicks. ``I disagree strongly with the loan rate freeze,'' Kerrey said, adding that there was room for compromise in the other areas. Loan rates determine the amount of support the government will give farmers to assure they have enough money to plant crops. Kerrey wants government support tied to production costs as a way of protecting small and medium farms. ``Lugar is saying if you don't give me 100 percent, I'm going to make life miserable,'' Kerrey said. ``It's a tough choice for the chairman,'' Lugar said after Leahy called off the markup session. ``If he goes with the Democrats, he would have rather creative and vigorous opposition on the floor.'' Leahy said he wanted to postpone a vote until he corresponded with Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter about a letter Yeutter sent him Tuesday. But Lugar, who had asked Yeutter to write the letter to articulate the administration's position on the farm bill, said Leahy was using it as an excuse to delay.

DOC.HEAD: Moynihan Mauls Drug Czar for Cuomo Criticism
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs with 2 new grafs to UPDATE with no comment from Bennett
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan denounced Tuesday the ``tough guy talk'' used by national drug policy director William Bennett last week in a verbal attack on New York Gov. Mario Cuomo. ``I have to say that if a year ago I had any reason to suppose that Dr. Bennett would use his office in this manner, I would have taken whatever measures necessary to see that he was not confirmed for it,'' Moynihan, D-N.Y., said in remarks submitted to the Congressional Record. Bennett, in Albany, N.Y., last Thursday to meet with state drug officials, attacked Cuomo's drug fighting record and challenged the Democrat to run for president. ``Nobody's afraid of this guy,'' Bennett said. ``He's got a record to run on and the record on drugs, I have to tell you, is not what it should be.'' Moynihan expressed surprise Tuesday at Bennett's choice of words. ``How does such a man come to refer to the governor of the state of New York as `this guy'?'' Moynihan asked. ``We recognize the idiom. It is so-called `tough-guy talk.' It can be learned from Hollywood movies, also from detective novels.'' Bennett declined to respond to the ``tough-guy'' remark, according to spokesman Don Hamilton. ``We really don't have a lot to say on this.'' Hamilton said. ``His substantive criticisms have been made before and they've been responded to before.'' Last week, Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., rushed to defend Cuomo and strike back at Bennett. He said the drug policy director could not point to any successful program that has brought the nation closer to solving its drug problems. Rangel is chairman of the House Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse and Control.

DOC.HEAD: Annunzio Says Thornburgh Will Have Reserved Seat at S&L Hearing
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh will have a reserved seat at a savings and loan fraud hearing even though he hasn't responded to an invitation to testify, the chairman of a House panel said Tuesday. Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., said his House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions had received no reply to a May 25 letter offering Thornburgh his choice of three hearing dates. FBI Director William Webster and Assistant Attorney General Edward Dennis already have testified about the administration's efforts to combat financial institution fraud; Thornburgh has not. Justice Department spokesman Douglas Tillett said Thornburgh may have had a conflict with Annunzio's proposed hearing dates. He said Thornburgh would testify when it is appropriate. ``I will not deny the attorney general an opportunity to appear if he so chooses, even at the last minute,'' Annunzio said. ``There will be a chair and a nameplate at the witness table'' at the June 28 hearing. Congressional Democrats in recent weeks have stepped up their criticism of the Bush administration, complaining of a backlog of uninvestigated fraud cases. The administration, in turn, has pointed to a growing list of convictions and its $50 million program to establish fraud task forces in 27 cities.

DOC.HEAD: Mid-Level Managers Suffer High-Level Depression, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Climbing the corporate ladder can plunge some people into depression, but an early diagnosis could spare middle managers a serious case of the office blues, researchers said Tuesday. A study of 1,870 white-collar employees of Westinghouse Electric Corp. in Monroeville, a Pittsburgh suburb, showed 16.6 percent of female and 8.6 percent of male managers were clinically depressed in the year prior to the survey, which was taken in 1987 and 1988. The figures exceed the latest depression rate for all Americans, 4.4 percent in 1986, according to the National Institute of Mental Health. ``The bottom line for you is that depression is eminently treatable,'' said Dr. David Kupfer, chairman of the psychiatry department at the University of Pittsburgh. The research findings were presented to about 100 personnel directors, health-insurance managers and corporate doctors at a conference on mental health. Thirty-six percent of female and 23 percent of male Westinghouse managers qualified as clinically depressed at some point during their lives, the study said. According to the American Psychiatric Association, a person suffers from major depression when he or she shows at least five of the following symptoms within a two-week period: irregular sleeping patterns, irregular eating habits, recurrent thoughts of suicide or death, depressed mood, loss of interest or pleasure in daily activities, significant weight loss or gain, agitated or retarded movements, feelings of worthlessness or guilt and lack of concentration. At least one of the symptoms must be a depressed mood or loss of interest or pleasure, the APA says. Herbert Freudenberger, a New York City psychologist and consultant to companies on white-collar stress and depression, said the Westinghouse study is significant because it marks the first time a large company allowed such an examination of its workers. Westinghouse employs about 120,000 people worldwide. Mid-level managers often are depressed because they find themselves trapped between the gripes of their subordinates and demands of their own bosses, he said. ``The first-line managers are the ones who get hell from over them and hell from under them,'' said Dr. E. Carroll Curtis, Westinghouse's medical director. Pitt and Westinghouse interviewed the managers, most of whom were white males, under a grant from the National Institute of Mental Health. The most common causes of depression at work were lack of rewards, a cloudy job future and specific events such as pay cuts or bad evaluations, the study said. The most common cause of depression at home was a spouse with a history of psychiatric disorders, the study said. Mark Kamlet, an economics professor at Carnegie Mellon University, estimated that depression-related absenteeism, lost wages, hospital costs, prescriptions and suicides will cost the U.S. economy $36.9 billion in 1990. Researchers said companies could train more executives and managers to spot depression's symptoms and tactfully address the illness with employees. The Westinghouse study said although depression usually can be treated without hospitalization, 70 percent of the depressed managers didn't seek treatment. ``It's not preferred procedure for a manager to turn himself in to any psychologist,'' Kamlet said. ``Particularly with males, someone will tell you to buck up and take a few shots of beer, then you'll be all right,'' said Jim Jefferson, 43, a Mellon Bank building manager who recently returned to work after treatment for depression. But, he said, ``It doesn't work that way.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Jury Selection Drags On; No Public Word on Re-Election Plans
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 5th-6th grafs pvs with 3 grafs, `In courtroom,' to update with jury selection process
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection ground through a seventh day Tuesday in Mayor Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial while top Barry aides said anew that he would announce he was abandoning his re-election plans. ``He will do it, but the only question left is when,'' said one top Barry adviser, speaking only on condition of anonymity. ``We're all just waiting.'' The mayor was meeting with his staff late Tuesday, but city officials said they expected only a routine discussion of city affairs. Barry told his top advisers and fund-raisers at a meeting Sunday that he would give up his plans for a fourth, four-year term. Several aides said the mayor was making that move in hopes of restarting stalled plea bargain talks in his drug case. In courtroom proceedings Tuesday, 10 more people were assigned to a pool of prospective jurors by U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson. That brought to 68 the number of people accepted for the pool from which 12 jurors and six alternates are to be chosen. One woman included in the pool said she attended church three times a week and that she prayed for Barry. She also works in the city Department of Human Services, but said she didn't know any of the more than 50 potential witnesses in the case. Those on the list include David Rivers, the former human services department chief who is now on trial for alleged bribery and conspiracy in connection with city contracts. The judge said he was unable to conclude the woman was lying. He said also that her prayers for the defendant were not inconsistent with her assurances that she could be a fair and impartial juror. Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use.
