The judge has said he expects jury selection, which began June 4, to continue through this week.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Offers New Union of Sovereign States in Baltic Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Gorbachev offering new federation of sovereign states, details, quotes. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos MOSB1,2,19
DOC.TEXT: Mikhail S. Gorbachev moved to hold together a splintering Soviet Union on Tuesday by proposing the 15 republics agree on a new, looser federation of sovereign states, officials said. The presidents of Lithuania and Latvia emerged smiling from two meetings with Gorbachev and indicated it could be the beginning of a solution to the country's problems with its restive republics. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis hinted Gorbachev might soon end the economic embargo against his republic, which declared independence from the Soviet Union on March 11. By redefining the Soviet federation, Gorbachev could deal with the three Baltic republics' demands for independence as well as lesser separatist moves across the vast country. On Tuesday, those problems heightened when Russia's parliament, led by Gorbachev rival Boris Yeltsin, approved a resolution declaring its laws supercede the national ones. This could drmatically reduce Gorbachev's authority because the Russian republic includes 52 percent of the Soviet Union's population and three-quarters of its land mass. Latvia came away from Tuesday's meetings in the Kremlin with an offer from the Soviet president on starting negotiations toward independence, according to Latvian President Anatoly Gorbunov. At a Moscow press conference with Gorbunov, Landsbergis implied that Gorbachev also offered his republic a compromise on independence. But he refused to elaborate, saying he would tell the people of Lithuania first. Asked if Gorbachev would end his embargo of Lithuania, which has put 26,000 people out of work, Landsbergis replied, ``The blockade will not be canceled tomorrow, but the day after tomorrow, we shall see.'' Gorbachev ordered the blockade of oil, most natural gas and other raw materials to Lithuania on April 18 because it declared independence. Latvia and Estonia, the other Baltic republics, have proceded with slower transition periods toward independence, which they lost when annexed in 1940. Estonian President Arnold Ruutel said on republic radio Tuesday night that Gorbachev had recognized the need for talks and a transition period toward independence, Neme Brus of Estonian Radio said without elaboration. The Russian parliament approved its resolution declaring sovereignty by a 907-13 vote. The statement was weaker than originally proposed, however, because it says sovereignty and priority of its laws over national ones will be worked out in a new Russian constitution and a new union. Gorbachev told the presidents of all 15 Soviet republics in a separate meeting Tuesday to nominate representatives and prepare drafts for a union ``that would have elements of a federation, a confederation or some such pluralistic relationship,'' said Landsbergis. He said Lithuania would consider this. Earlier Tuesday, Gorbachev told the Supreme Soviet legislature ``if Lithuania will suspend the implementation of this act of independence, we may start to talk. That means suspend its implementation at least for the duration of the talks.'' The Baltic officials met with Gorbachev after participating in Tuesday's meeting of Gorbachev's advisory Federation Council, where he offered ideas for a new type of Soviet Union ``as a union of sovereign states,'' Landsbergis said. The official Tass news agency said the Federation Council considered ``the urgent need to work out and conclude a new union treaty, which will guarantee the actual economic and political sovereignty of the union republics and their effective interaction.'' It continued by saying this would lead to a ``union of sovereign socialist republics,'' adding the word ``socialist'' not mentioned by Landsbergis. The Baltic republics have dropped the words ``Soviet Socialist'' from their names. Soviet television showed Gorbachev telling the Federation Council it was time to find practical ways to realize ``the key idea of the deep revamping of our federation.'' The news announcer said the Soviet Union's planned move to a market economy to help end widespread shortages and productivity problems should create mutually profitable relations between the republics and would help bind them together. Gorbachev has pledged repeatedly since fall to work out a new union treaty but this is the first sign of action. Gorbachev offered Latvia ``immediate concrete negotiations'' on that republic's legal status during its transition period to independence if it freezes its declaration for the duration of the negotiations, Gorbunov said. Gorbunov suggested that during the transition period, Latvia's parliament would be considered sovereign. In addition, conflicts during this period over such issues as the conscription of Latvians into the Soviet Army would be decided in separate agreements ``on the basis of equality.'' He said the Latvian parliament will consider Gorbachev's offer on Wednesday. The Federation Council meeting also brought Gorbachev face-to-face with Yeltsin for the first time since his rival and former protege was elected president of Russia over Gorbachev's opposition. Gorbunov said the two men both offered constructive suggestions and treated each other with respect. Earlier in the day, Gorbachev, speaking to the Supreme Soviet pariament about his Washington summit, acknowledged that some Americans opposed Senate ratification of a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement signed during the summit ``until Moscow grants independence to the group of Lithuanian separatists.'' ``But after I had contacts with the American people, it turned out that such demands do not reflect the position of the entire United States,'' Gorbachev told parliament. During an hour-long address, and another hour of answers to written questions, Gorbachev did not mention that President Bush said he would not implement the trade deal until the Soviet parliament approves a draft law guaranteeing free emigration. Although Soviet Jews and other ethnic groups are leaving in record numbers, the parliament last week adopted an agenda that delays the emigration law until at least September. The parliament already has given the law preliminary approval.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Sets Conditions for United Germany's NATO Membership
With AM-Soviet Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev shifted gears on Tuesday and suggested a united Germany could be an associate member of NATO if the Western alliance switches from its Cold War position against the Soviet Union. Western diplomats said Gorbachev appeared to be showing more flexibility on the German issue only days after he had again expressed Soviet opposition to NATO membership during the visit of Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. The president also told the Supreme Soviet legislature in his hourlong speech, broadcast live on Soviet TV, that ``huge results'' were achieved in arms control at his May 30-June 3 summit in Washington with President Bush. The address gave Gorbachev the opportunity to highlight his area of greatest success, foreign policy, as his domestic policy _ plagued by economic woes, ethnic strife and secessionist strains _ draws increasing fire at home. Gorbachev, smiling often and speaking calmly, told the legislators his warm reception in the United States and the signing of a U.S.-Soviet trade agreement showed U.S. faith in his domestic reform program. He reported on his talks with Bush on a united Germany joining the North Atlantic Treat Organization. West Germany now belongs to the Western military alliance and East Germany to the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact. Gorbachev said, ``Our position is thus: We could agree to the joining, if you accept associative participation, the principle of blocs coming together in conjunction with the unification of Germany in the process of which mutual obligations are not changed, neither from the side of West or East Germany, and if simultaneously the blocs are reformed in natural connection with Vienna and the all-European process.'' He did not spell out what associate membership for Germany would comprise. Vienna is the venue for arms reduction talks and the Europe-wide Conference on Security and Cooperation aimed at reducing tensions. Later, official Radio Moscow said: ``It might be possible to agree with Germany being in NATO as an associated member provided there are changes in the nature of the military alliances, both NATO and the Warsaw Treaty organization.'' The Kremlin up to now has sought membership in both NATO and the Warsaw Pact for a united Germany. Bush said in Washington that ``a unified Germany should be in NATO with no conditions,'' but said he was prepared to listen and discuss ``without rancor'' any ideas the Soviets have on the issue. He spoke in reply to reporters' questions about Gorbachev's speech. The Soviet president seemed to be demanding that a united Germany fulfill East Germany's obligations to the Warsaw Pact only during a transition period. His comments appeared to signal ``positive movement'' on the German issue, said one Western diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The West German newspaper Sueddeutsche Zeitung said Monday that Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere of East Germany would carry a new Gorbachev proposal to break the deadlock to a meeting with Bush. It said Gorbachev would agree to NATO membership for a united Germany if the Western alliance made ``a clear decision to transform itself into a political alliance.'' Gorbachev said Tuesday of the summit: ``As a whole, I think huge results were achieved in Washington toward limiting nuclear and conventional weapons.'' ``All this has great meaning. Another practical step was taken to realize the idea of a non-violent, non-nuclear world.'' He said hard work lies ahead, but the Cold War danger has begun to recede. Gorbachev and Bush signed agreements to eliminate the two sides' chemical weapons and to reach a final accord this year to cut deeply their strategic nuclear weapons.

DOC.HEAD: Balaguer Wins Election; Formal Proclamation Pending
DOC.TEXT: President Joaquin Balaguer made it just another day at the office Tuesday, without acknowledging that official results indicated he narrowly won a sixth term as president. No rallies were held and no victory speeches were made following Monday's declaration by the Central Electoral Board that the 83-year-old, blind Balaguer had defeated 80-year-old leftist challenger Juan Bosch by a margin of fewer than 25,000 votes in the May 16 election. A review of balloting results caused the almost monthlong delay in concluding the election results. The board reported Balaguer had received 678,268 votes, or 35.7 percent, to 653,423, or 34.4 percent, for Bosch. Under Dominican law, Balaguer will not be proclaimed president-elect until the board rules on all vote challenges, a process that took almost two months in the last four elections. Inauguration for a four-year term is set for Aug. 16. Two opposition parties filed formal challenges with the board Tuesday, charging irregularities and fraud in the electoral process. Such challenges are routine in the Dominican Republic, but are generally regarded as a technicality and rarely result in significant changes in the results. Bosch's Dominican Liberation Party called a meeting for Wednesday evening to determine its course of action. Thousands of candles twinkled in working-class neighborhoods in a symbol of protest after the board's figures were announced on television. Police arrested 140 people for disturbing the peace by lighting candles or chanting anti-Balaguer slogans, but most detainees were quickly released. The electoral board said 40.8 percent of the 3.2 million registered voters stayed home on election day, the highest abstention figure in any election since dictator Gen. Rafael Leonidas Trujillo was assassinated in 1961. Bosch, a former president, was overthrown by a military coup in 1963. Balaguer was a figuerhead president during the 31-year Trujillo dictatorship. He was first elected president in 1966 and served three consecutive terms before losing in 1978. He was re-elected in 1986. He appeared to be in trouble before the election because of this Caribbean island country's economic crisis, frequent electricity blackouts and water shortages. Opinion polls had Bosch leading by up to 10 points. Bosch is a Marxist, but says he is not a communist and recognizes capitalism as necessary for reviving the Dominican economy.

DOC.HEAD: Boycott Effort Keeps Voter Turnout Low in Algeria
LaserPhoto ALG2
DOC.TEXT: At least half of Algeria's voters apparently heeded an election boycott call Tuesday as the ruling party battled Islamic fundamentalists in the first contested ballot since French rule ended in 1962, observers said. A majority of district races appeared dominated by the National Liberation Front, the nation's sole political party until last year's constitutional reforms. The fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front, the only other major party on the ballot, benefitted by the withdrawal of several groups that urged a boycott. Official results were expected Wednesday. Boycott leaders claimed the election was rigged in favor of the ruling party because it controls nearly all the media, has greater resources than other parties and has its functionaries in local government offices where the votes will be counted. Charges of vote-rigging surfaced immediately after the polls closed at 7 p.m. The Interior Ministry said 55 percent of the 13 million eligible voters went to the polls. But figures showed a considerable range, from 73 percent in the town of El-Tarf to 16 percent in the Berber town of Tizi-Ouzou. Fifteen thousand seats were contested in this North African nation's 1,541 municipal councils and 48 provinces. In all, 11 parties were on the ballot. Hocine Ait Ahmed, leader of the opposition Berber movement, the Front of Socialist Forces, and former President Ahmed Ben Bella's Movement for Democracy in Algeria led the boycott effort. Police were deployed throughout the country as the official media urged Algerians to vote in ``this first test of democracy.'' Fundamentalist leader Abassi Madani, a philosophy teacher, predicted several days ago his party would capture 75 percent of the vote. He challenged the legitimacy of the election in advance if the result failed to reflect this figure. The statement was denounced as a ``trouble-making provocation'' by several hundred fellow university professors and lecturers. For months, fundamentalist supporters have been accused of harrassing single women and disrupting nightclubs in the Algiers region, prompting denunciations from most political groups. In the Algiers suburb of El Harrach, the National Liberation Front withdrew from the elections, accusing the fundamentalists of ``exercising moral violence against the voters and committing serious violations against the election law.'' The statement did not elaborate. The official news agency reported several groups of Islamic supporters tried to overrun some Algiers voting stations, alleging the vote counting was influenced by the government. Numerous voters in the Algiers district were turned away from polling booths when they appeared without the necessary documents. Among those blocked were men who tried to exercise their right to vote on behalf of their wife _ or wives _ without written authorization. The National Liberation Front's was forced to give up its monopoly on power after soldiers killed scores of people in October 1988 riots sparked by deteriorating economic conditions. Constitutional changes adopted in February 1989 legalized pluralism. The Islamic Salvation Front seeks to establish the Islamic legal code, the Sharia, as law and openly opposes the democratic process.

DOC.HEAD: Witnesses Say Ceausescu's Brother Did Not Shoot Protesters
LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: Witnesses told the military court trial of former Gen. Nicolae Andruta Ceausescu on Tuesday that he did not shoot at protesters seeking the overthrow of his Communist dictator brother. Ceausescu, 66, former commander of the secret police, was put on trial in late March on a charge of ``inciting genocide'' during attempts to quell the popular revolution that ended Nicolae Ceausescu's 24 years in power. The dictator was executed by firing squad on Christmas Day. His brother was accused in the indictment of ordering his cadets to fire at demonstrators and of killing seven people himself. Earlier witnesses swore they saw him approach the crowd with his gun on Dec. 21, and fire. On Tuesday, however, Stefan Antohie, an officer of the secret police securitate, told the panel of three military judges that he heard warning salvos, but ``Ceausescu did not shoot ... and I did not hear him ordering fire.'' Antohie said he saw Ceausescu several times during Dec. 21, near the scene of the alleged shooting. Securitate officer Cornel Manescu, 33, on duty at the police academy on Dec. 21, said he heard no one at the time saying Ceausescu fired at demonstrators. An official death toll lists at least 1,033 people as being killed in the December revolution. Judge Adrian Nitoiu told a reporter Wednesday's session ``will be important, the prosecutor might change the charge'' to a lesser one, but offered no details. Nitoiu said the trial will end and a verdict and sentence will be pronounced in ``a couple of days.''

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Meets Swedish Ministers to Discuss Flight 103
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh met Tuesday with two Swedish ministers for talks on international terrorism and the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. Thornburgh, who arrived from Scotland, met with Swedish Justice Minister Laila Freivalds and the interior minister, Bengt Johansson, the local TT news agency reported. Goran Regner, head of the legal division of the Ministry of Justice, told TT that Thornburgh and Freivalds discussed the bombing of the Pan Am flight and also ways to fight international terrorism and drug trafficking. There were no further details. Two hundred seventy people in the air and on the ground were killed when a bomb destroyed Pan Am Flight 103 over the Scottish town of Lockerbie in December 1988. Swedish police have supplied their Scottish counterparts with information concerning two Palestinians suspected in the bombing. The two Arabs, Mohammed Abu Talb and Marten Imandi, both received life terms in late 1989 for separate bombings in Denmark and the Netherlands in 1985 and 1986. After the meeting Thornburgh departed for Italy. He will later travel to Ireland for a meeting with ministers from the European Economic Community to discuss methods of fighting international terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Conferees Stuck on Liability, Hulls
DOC.TEXT: Congress has been unable to agree on comprehensive oil spill legislation over provisions on ship construction and liability, two problems exemplified in the wreck of a Norwegian supertanker, officials said Tuesday. Since 1975, Congress has struggled to create a liability and response law that covers the estimated 8,000 oil spills that occur in the United States annually. Galvanized by the Exxon Valdez accident, both the House and Senate last fall passed sweeping legislation. But the approximately 100 members of a House-Senate conference committee have met only once to resolve differences in the bills. Last weekend, the supertanker Mega Borg caught fire 57 miles from Galveston and since then firefighters have struggled to bring the fire under control. The fire prompted members of Congress on Tuesday in calling for conferees to step up the pace. ``Once again, the need to prevent these spills is made all too clear,'' said Sen. Brock Adams. The bill creates a $1 billion cleanup fund through a 5-cent tax on each barrel of oil created in or imported to the United States. It also establishes Coast Guard oil spill response centers along U.S. coasts. But the House and Senate disagree on requiring supertankers to have double hulls and using international protocol to guide liability in a spill. Congressional staff members say conferees are close to resolving the double hull issue. But international protocol and its relationship to state liability laws has tripped up oil spill legislation for the past seven Congresses, officials say. Senators, led by Majority Leader George Mitchell, say liability limits set by international protocol aren't strict enough. ``They see it rightly as a back door attempt to pre-empt state laws,'' said Mike Matz of the Sierra Club. Nineteen states require unlimited liability for the oil companies or carriers to clean up damage to the environment. International protocols provide up to $260 million from an international compensation fund before any U.S. dollars are spent on an cleanup, say House backers. And they must be in place for the United States to hold foreign vessels liable for spills that could affect U.S. water, they say. Currently, the Norwegian owners of the Mega Borg could walk away from liability for damage the wreck causes the U.S. shoreline because the fire occurred in international waters. ``We're living on the good graces of the Norwegians right now,'' said Rep. Billy Tauzin, D-La., a House conferee and proponent of the international protocol. ``I hope this incident drives the Senate to reconsider.'' But Mitchell said full compensation for catastrophic spills cannot be obtained from international protocol limits. He said the House version, for instance, would have limited Exxon's liability for last year's Alaskan spill to less than $60 million. Damage from the Valdez spill is estimated to be more than $2 billion, said Mitchell, D-Maine. ``Exxon's victims could not have obtained more than $260 million from the international regime and $1 billion from the federal trust fund, if this bill had been enacted,'' Mitchell said of the House version. But Rep. Jack Fields, who flew over the Mega Borg fire Monday, said the accident ``clearly begs for acceptance of international protocols.'' ``States like Maine want to punish the shippers,'' said Fields, R-Texas. ``They want to be able to squeeze as much blood from the turnip as possible rather than make those who have been damaged whole.'' The House bill requires new oil tankers to have double hulls and existing tankers to be retrofitted in 15 years. The Senate recommends study of ``double hulls or better'' means to prevent oil spills.

DOC.HEAD: Former FBI Agent Pleads Guilty To Slaying Kentucky Woman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead. SUBS 11th graf, `Putnam's confession ...,' to ADD he was indicted Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: A former FBI agent who solved a year-old homicide by confessing to the crime pleaded guilty Tuesday to strangling a pregnant informant with whom he'd been having an affair. He was sentenced to 16 years in prison. In a signed confession, Mark Putnam said he choked Susan Daniels Smith, 27, on June 8, 1989, ``in an act of extreme rage'' while the couple arued over support of her expected child. Putnam, 30, of Sunrise, Fla., entered a guilty plea to one count of felony manslaughter in Ms. Smith's death. Immediately after the hearing, Putnam was handcuffed and taken into custody by Kentucky State Police officers. It was apparently the first case in FBI history in which an agent had been charged with a homicide, said Terry O'Connor, the FBI's top agent in Kentucky. ``As far as the FBI is concerned, this is a difficult day ... but I would hope that our entire record ... is what's going to govern the way that people think about the FBI,'' O'Connor said. The victim's family expressed outrage they were not consulted in the drafting of Putnam's plea bargain. They had wanted him to stand trial for murder. The victim's sister, Shelby Ward of Freeburn, was cited for trying to conceal a .38-caliber handgun in the courtroom by Kentucky State Police, and was released. Putnam appeared tense during his 20-minute appearance in Pike County Circuit Court. Putnam, who resigned Friday, worked in Pikeville for about two years until his transfer to Miami in May 1989. He used Ms. Smith as an informant in a bank robbery and car theft case. Putnam's confession was attached to an indictment returned Tuesday by the Pike County grand jury. In the statement, he recalled a bitter, violent argument with Ms. Smith about her pregnancy. Putnam had returned to Pikeville for several days to work a car theft case he had investigated. Ms. Smith ``kept telling me the baby was mine and that she was going to `hang me' over this. She said she would tell the FBI, my family and the newspapers,'' Putnam's statement said. The couple was driving on a rural eastern Kentucky highway at the time and pulled off the road at Peter Creek Mountain. Putnam said he and his wife would adopt the child but Ms. Smith refused, and began slapping Putnam. The agent recalled that ``in an act of extreme rage ... I started choking her and telling her to shut up.'' Putnam said he tried in vain to revive her. He said he placed the body in the trunk of his rented car and dumped it the following evening off an old coal mine road about nine miles north of Pikeville. Prosecutor John Paul Runyon, the Pike County commonwealth's attorney, said that without Putnam's June 4 confession, ``we had absolutely no evidence. Not one scintilla or shred of evidence to bring a charge or convict this man.'' ``In the 28 years that I have been a prosecutor, this is the first experience that I have had where a lawyer called me on a telephone and said I have a man who wants to confess to murder, or homicide, and wants to go to the penitentiary, and we had absolutely no evidence,'' Runyon added.

DOC.HEAD: Panel's Attorney Recommends Durenberger Be Denounced
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 14th graf, ``Sen. Durenberger,'' further comment from lawyer that some penalty is appropriate; SUBS 3rd graf:: ``Durenberger, in,'' to conform
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Dave Durenberger has brought ``dishonor and disrepute'' on the Senate and should be denounced by his colleagues for engaging in unethical conduct, the Senate Ethics Committee's special counsel recommended Tuesday. Robert S. Bennett's recommendation was a surprise on the opening day of the panel's hearings into Durenberger's alleged financial improprieties. Bennett called the Minnesota Republican's conduct ``reprehensible.'' Durenberger, in a written statement, said ``the sanction of denouncement ... is harsher than warranted.'' The senator, who appeared stunned as Bennett made his recommendation, later admitted in a written statement that he had made ``mistakes and even some violations of rules,'' and his lawyer conceded some penalty was appropriate. But Durenberger contended his actions ``were taken in good faith.'' Bennett said the evidence showed a ``pattern of unethical conduct'' by Durenberger in a book-promotion deal, transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium and his acceptance of free limousine rides. ``Your loyalty here is not to Sen. Durenberger,'' Bennett told the committee. Durenberger sat with his hand on his cheek as Bennett pointed out to the six-member committee that they sat under a Senate seal. ``Sen. Durenberger has tarnished that seal and has brought this institution to dishonor and disrepute,'' the counsel said. ``Your loyalty to this institution now summons you to denounce this senator and his actions.'' Only the full Senate can decide to punish a member. If the chamber eventually followed the counsel's recommendation, it would pass a resolution denouncing Durenberger's conduct _ an action that would have greater consequences for the senator politically than for his position as a senator, which would not be affected. Bennett reminded the panel it could consider stripping Durenberger of his seniority and committee assignments, as well as ordering restitution. But he did not recommend such actions. He also said the most serious punishment, expulsion, has been reserved for senators who violate the law and shouldn't apply in this case. Durenberger's lawyer, Jim Hamilton, told the hearing: ``What we have is mistakes and sloppiness. Sanction such as denouncement is simply not appropriate.'' He told the committee that Durenberger ``relied on a bevy of lawyers'' in all his financial transactions and there were no ``venal motives'' or a ``grand conspiracy'' to violate the rules. ``Senator Durenberger feels that some sanction is appropriate because he was inattentive and unwise,'' Hamilton said, but the attorney did not specify any punishment. The lowest form of punishment would be a mild letter of rebuke. Bennett, who earlier told the committee that Durenberger exhibited ``very serious insensitivity to the ethical demands of his office,'' told senators they should ``denounce Sen. Durenberger publicly for knowingly engaging in unethical conduct which has brought dishonor and disrepute to this institution.'' The hearing took on the aura of a trial as the 12-year senator stared from across the room when Bennett, standing at a lectern, accused Durenberger of making fake promotional appearances in 1985 and 1986 for his two books. The speeches were really ``a gimmick'' to ``magically'' turn honoraria earned from appearances before trade groups into book promotions, allowing Durenberger to make $100,000 beyond his Senate salary and exceed the chamber's speaking-fee limits, Bennett said. The scheme was concocted, Bennett said, as the senator neared the legal maximum for honoraria. Bennett said Durenberger's attempts to change ownership of his Minneapolis condominium was a scheme to improperly collect $40,055 in Senate travel reimbursements from 1983 through 1989. He would not have been eligible for the payments if he had owned the residence outright, Bennett said. ``The senator consistently engaged in a pattern of unethical conduct and showed very serious insensitivity to the ethical demands of his office,'' Bennett told the six-member committee. About 200 spectators attended the first of the hearings, which the committee will use to determine if Durenberger broke the chamber's rules and federal law. The panel has found ``substantial credible evidence'' that Durenberger may have committed violations in the condominium deal, the book arrangement and the limousine trips. If the panel finds wrongdoing, it can recommend that the Senate punish Durenberger by handing out anything from a mild rebuke to expulsion _ although the latter is unlikely. In his book deal, Durenberger received $100,000 from a Minneapolis publisher, Piranha Press, in return for addressing trade groups that sent their speaking fees to Piranha. Durenberger contended the speeches were made to promote books, but Bennett said the real purpose was for the senator to collect honoraria in excess of Senate limits: $22,530 in 1985 and $30,040 in 1986. ``This very hungry fish, Piranha Press, was allowed to engage in a feeding frenzy'' to make money, Bennett said. Durenberger, he added, ``allowed himself and his office to be used as the bait and he got $100,000 for his trouble.'' The scheme made a large profit for Piranha, which earned $248,360 from Durenberger's speeches and only $15,560 from the sale of books. In calling the book arrangement a scam, Bennett told the committee that in the 113 appearances being investigated, the host groups thought they were hearing a typical honoraria speech. Some of the groups ``strenuously'' objected when they learned Durenberger's speech was classified as a book promotion and withdrew the invitation. In addition, Bennett said, the two books Durenberger wrote on national security and health issues were displayed at only three of the 113 appearances. At one appearance, Durenberger commented, ``This is a book, but what it really is is 44 speeches'' compiled into a book. In describing the complicated condominium deal, Bennett said Durenberger wouldn't have been able to collect Senate travel reimbursements if he had owned the residence. So Durenberger schemed not once, but twice, to have business partnerships take ownership and lease the condominium back to him when he stayed there _ thus allowing Senate travel expenses to be paid. When the original partner decided to end the initial partnership in 1987, four years after it was formed, Durenberger entered into a similar arrangement year with his former campaign manager. Bennett also said Durenberger showed a ``pattern of insensitivity'' when he accepted free limousine rides on 21 occasions in 1985 and 1986 from groups and individuals interested in legislation. Durenberger has said the rides were to his marriage counselor and were arranged in conjunction with official appearances. A senator could accept only up to $100 in gifts from those with an interest in legislation, Bennett said. The limousine rides were valued at $4,935.

DOC.HEAD: Work Begins for Pollution Crews Once Fire is Out
With AM-Tanker Blast Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Crews from a company named OOPS brought in equipment from all over to be ready to collect and contain oil from the crippled supertanker Mega Borg once the flames on board were smothered. ``I'm confident that we've got the pieces (of equipment) that we need here now. And I'm confident that we've explored where we can get other pieces, if needed,'' Jim O'Brien, president of OOPS Inc., said Tuesday. OOPS stands for O'Brien's Oil Pollution Services of Gretna, La. OOPS was hired by Elf, a Houston subsidiary of the French oil distribution company whose oil the Mega Borg was carrying. O'Brien was the technical adviser on the cleanup of the Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska. OOPS has brought in booms, skimmers and water separators from the Gulf Coast and California. Other equipment was to arrive within 24 hours from the Northeast. O'Brien said his company has no equipment of its own. Coast Guard Capt. Thomas Greene said Tuesday that although the tanker fire had eased, ``we're still not completely safe from a major release'' of oil. But he added that there ``is not a great chance'' of any oil coming ashore because the light African crude is likely to break up and evaporate. O'Brien said his company had enough equipment to handle a major spill. OOPS' first priority will be to right the 886-foot ship to prevent further spillage. Crews then will begin transferring oil to smaller ships and pumping water into the Mega Borg's emptying cargo tanks to keep her steady. The Coast Guard on Tuesday revised its estimate of the amount of oil on the water to less than 2,000 gallons, a fraction of the 100,000 gallons estimated earlier. Much oil had either burned off or evaporated, officials said. The length of the slick on the water continued to shrink, officials said. The amount that spilled from the Norwegian tanker, which was carrying 38 million gallons, was not determined. The rear of the Mega Borg dropped more than 60 feet since the tanker caught fire early Saturday while transferring cargo to a smaller vessel. Two of the 41 crewmen died, two were missing and presumed dead and 17 were injured, none seriously. Airplane crews have sprayed dispersants to break up the heavier oil patches and remained ready to spray more if needed, Greene said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Tell Stores to Stop Selling Rap Album
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `The group's ...,' to CORRECT attorney's name to `Rogow,' sted `Rogon.'
DOC.TEXT: City police warned record stores Tuesday to stop selling the controversial album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' by rap group 2 Live Crew or face possible obscenity charges. ``There's no prior restraint. We're just asking for voluntary compliance,'' said Lt. Jerry Pittman, commander of the vice squad. In about five days, police will begin conducting undercover investigations and arresting anyone still selling the album, Pittman said. ``Unfortunately, when something like that occurs, the clerk that sells the record is often the one that gets arrested,'' he said. ``I don't think the business owners want that.'' Pittman said Bexar County Assistant District Attorney Mike Schill reviewed transcripts of the album lyrics and listened to them on tape before determining that some words violate state obscenity law. However, Schill, reached later by telephone, would say only that the lyrics in question could violate state obscenity law. ``I have my opinion, but my opinion doesn't count,'' Schill said. ``It's what the jury or the judge think.'' Schill said his role would be to decide whether to prosecute a case if police bring him one. But, he added, ``I think the federal judge in Florida was correct _ which was that it's obscene.'' In Florida last week, U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez ruled material on the album obscene under that state's law. On Sunday, two 2 Live Crew members were arrested on obscenity charges after performing the banned lyrics at an adults-only nightclub concert. Two days earlier, a record-store owner was arrested on an obscenity charge for selling the album. The group's attorney, Bruce Rogow, said he filed an appeal Monday with the 11th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta. Pittman said, ``We believe that it is obscene as well in the state of Texas,'' adding that the album describes ``deviant sexual intercourse'' and ``is inundated with obscene language.'' State law requires that someone convicted of selling obscene material be aware that it is obscene, Pittman said. He said officers are ``diplomatically'' going to about 84 local stores to explain what the album contains, and added, ``We're getting compliance.'' Sound Warehouse stores in San Antonio removed the records Tuesday to comply with the law, said branch manager Mark Christy, who had a note from vice detectives saying the records contain obscene lyrics. ``I'm glad to see that they're doing it,'' Christy said. ``I'm not one of the people for censorship, but I think this music is ridiculous.'' Greta Colvin, manager of a Hasting's Records and Tapes, said local stores in that chain also are removing the albums, but said she disagrees with police. Ms. Colvin said officers came to her store Tuesday and asked her to sign a statement that she had been informed the lyrics violate obscenity laws. She said she told them that Hasting's rates albums and that any rated ``R'' may not be purchased by people under 18, but the officers didn't seem to care. ``It's censorship,'' she said. ``If someone comes out with another song that somebody with a political influence finds offensive, they're going to come around again.'' Pittman said he'd hoped to keep the police action out of the limelight at first to avoid publicity-boosted sales. The penalty for conviction of selling obscene material in Texas _ a Class A misdemeanor _ can be up to a year in jail and a $2,000 fine. 2 Live Crew is to perform in Huntsville, Ala., on Saturday. City Attorney Clyde Blankenship said some lyrics on the album appear to violate the local obscenity ordinance, which the City Council on Monday night expanded to include live performances. A local pastor threatened to block off the concert center with ``a human ring'' if the group is allowed to perform. But the council said it could not block the performance, which the band's promoter, Eddison Walters, said would be appropriate ``for kids.''

DOC.HEAD: Woman's Suicide Kills Roommates
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES 3rd graf, which duplicates 2nd.
DOC.TEXT: A woman who committed suicide by running her car in a closed garage also killed her two roommates, apparently without intending to, police said Tuesday. The body of Ruth M. Goran, 55, was found Friday, two days before her daughter's wedding. Mrs. Goran was clad in a nightgown, and was sitting in a car with the ignition on, said Sgt. James Flonacher. Inside her condominium, Claude R. Hillhouse, 42, and Gordon Geer, 32, were also dead. Both men were dressed, with Hillhouse in the living room and Geer in the bathroom, police said. The same carbon monoxide fumes that took Mrs. Goran's life had seeped into the condominium and killed the men, Flonacher said. Police are still unsure why Mrs. Goran would want to kill herself, but seemed that she did not intend for the two men to die. ``There are absolutely no signs of foul play. ... We are convinced the deaths were accidental,'' Flonacher said. The bodies were found when the daughter, Karen McLaughlin, went to her mother's house Friday and called police when no one answered the door. Mrs. McLaughlin, 29, had come from Las Vegas on Friday to be married. She married Jon McLaughlin, 33, also of Las Vegas, in a ceremony Sunday. ``We had the wedding because we knew Mom wanted us to,'' Mrs. McLaughlin said. She said she had spoken to her mother earlier in the week. ``She wasn't suicidal,'' Mrs. McLaughlin said. ``She was real happy. We were looking forward to holding the reception at her home. We were going to bring everything over Friday night.'' Mrs. McLaughlin said she thought her mother's action was more of a cry for attention than an actual attempt to commit suicide. However, she previously told two detectives she thought her mother had a history of instability and was capable of killing herself, Flonacher said. Mrs. McLaughlin said Hillhouse was her mother's boyfriend and that Geer had roomed with Hillhouse before the two moved in with her mother several months ago. Mrs. Goran was widowed, and had moved to Arizona from Michigan. Friends and neighbors said she had not seemed suicidal. ``There was no indication of despondency. All the employees were very shocked at what happened,'' said Alice Huff, a secretary at Terrell Battery Corp., where Mrs. Goran worked as a bookkeeper.

DOC.HEAD: Amtrak Authorization Vote Upholds Bush's Veto Streak
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 8th graf: ``Sen. Robert,'' with similar bill being introduced in Senate
DOC.TEXT: The Senate failed to muster a two-thirds majority Tuesday to override President Bush's veto of legislation providing federal support for the Amtrak passenger rail network. The action kept Bush's his streak of successful vetoes intact at 11. The 64-36 vote to override on Bush's 66th birthday was three votes shy of the two-thirds majority needed. Bush had vetoed the measure last month because he objected to a requirement tightening regulation of freight railroad ownership, and the House voted last week to override him. Republicans maintained that Bush otherwise supported the $2 billion Amtrak authorization provisions even though his and the Reagan administration before him have routinely proposed an end to federal subsidies for rail passenger service. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, voted to sustain the veto in a parliamentary move aimed at giving Democrats another shot at overriding the president. Only a member of the winning side may ask that a vote be reconsidered, and Mitchell promptly did so, giving the Democrats time to try to switch votes. Another vote was not immediately scheduled. The other 54 Democrats in the Senate voted for the override. They were joined by 10 of the 45 Republicans. The vote ``shows that we obviously had the strength,'' said White House spokesman Steve Hart. Earlier, White House officials had predicted a close vote. Sen. Robert W. Kasten Jr., R-Wis., noted that a bill without the objectionable part has already been introduced in the House and later, Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont., introduced a similar bill in the Senate. ``The fight is not over the funding of Amtrak,'' said Kasten, who lead the Republican debate. Hart at the White House added, ``If they send us the bill without the ICC provision, he'll sign it.'' It was Bush's first veto of 1990. He returned 10 bills to Congress last year. None of them had been overridden. The bill authorizes government subsidies for the passenger rail system for three years. It also includes a provision that allows planning for a commuter line between Washington, D.C., and northern Virginia suburbs. Bush vetoed the bill May 24 over a requirement that the Interstate Commerce Commission, which regulates railroads, must approve any acquisition of a major freight line by a company not in the railroad business. The commission already must approve the acquisition of one railroad by another. Bush called it ``an unwarranted regulatory roadblock to the financial restructuring of the railroad industry.'' But Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., and other Midwestern lawmakers said that without closing that regulatory loophole, thousands of miles of track could be ripped up and be sold off to repay the debt incurred in a buyout. ``The president's veto is wrong in terms of passenger traffic in this nation,'' Simon said. ``It is infinitely wrong in terms of the ICC approval.'' ``What we want to avoid is a situation where people come in and buy the railroad and then just dismember it,'' he said. Sen. J. James Exon, D-Neb., argued that Republicans should put national interest over concerns with a favor for Bush. ``I hope that we can get back not to what's nice for the party, but what is right for America,'' he said. ``Overriding this veto is certainly right for America and its transportation needs.'' In the House vote last week, 58 Republicans joined 236 Democrats for the override. The vote against was 123. It was the first successful override vote in either chamber in the Bush administration. However, a successful override requires a two-thirds majority in both chambers.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Troops Fire Tear Gas Into U.N. Clinic
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 9th graf pvs `The official' to UPDATE with officer sentenced for throwing tear gas grenade. Pickup 10th graf pvs, `Officials of...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops pursuing Palestinian stone-throwers fired tear gas into a U.N. clinic in Gaza City on Tuesday, and 66 infants and toddlers were treated for inhaling the fumes, the army said. In Jerusalem, a 17-year-old Jewish seminary student going to prayers at the Western Wall was stabbed twice in the stomach. He was reported in fair condition at a Jerusalem hospital. Police immediately rounded up 100 Palestinians for questioning. Meanwhile, the army demolished the homes of three Palestinian families and sealed three others in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Members of the families were accused of throwing firebombs or killing Arabs suspected of collaborating with Israel, the army said. The house demolitions came on the first working day of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new right-wing government, which has pledged to ``uproot'' the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. Since the rebellion against the Israeli occupation began in December 1987, 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians. An additional 221 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israeli authorities. Forty-five Israelis have died in the violence. An army official said the tear gas was fired into the U.N.'s Rimal Health Center in Gaza after an army patrol came under a barrage of stones and blocks. He said the rocks were thrown from the clinic compound. The official said on condition of anonymity that soldiers are barred from firing tear gas into enclosed spaces. He said troops involved in Tuesday's incident would be punished. Late Tuesday, a local military commander sentenced a reserve captain to 10 days of hard labor for the incident, an army spokesman said. Officials of the U.N. Relief and Works Agency, which runs the clinic, said the incident began when about six Israelis in civilian clothes ran into the building, apparently in pursuit of Palestinian boys who had stoned their car. When army jeeps pulled up outside, they came under a hail of stones, the officials said. Dr. Zihni Wahidi, director of the clinic, said there were about 200 pregnant women and babies inside the building when the tear gas was fired. He said many babies were overcome by gas. ``Most were treated at the clinic, and some were taken to Nasser Hospital,'' he said. The army said 66 children were affected by the tear gas, and doctors at nearby Nasser Hospital said they treated 58 youngsters between the ages of 1 month and 3 years. They said 16 of those were admitted. A U.N. relief agency spokesman, Rolf van Oye, said a complaint would be filed with the Israeli military government. The victim in the stabbing in Jerusalem's Old City was identified as Yosef Edri, 17. In an interview on Israel radio, Edri said his assailant carried ``a big sword and a pocket knife'' and stabbed him with both. After the stabbing, police forced scores of Arab-owned shops to close. The Western Wall, where Edri was going to pray, is the remnant of the ancient Jewish Temple destroyed by the Romans in 70 A.D. and is regarded as Judaism's holiest site. The Palestinian homes that were demolished were in the village of Yatta and the Jalazoun refugee camp in the West Bank and the Khan Yunis refugee camp in Gaza, the army said. Those sealed were all in the West Bank, it said. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories said a total of 293 Palestinian houses have been destroyed and 173 sealed for security offenses since the uprising began. The U.S. government and human rights groups have opposed house demolitions and sealings, saying they constitute collective punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Patching Work on Cruise Liner Delayed Again
DOC.NOTE: Eds: `Hual Ingrita' in 6th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: Sunny skies Tuesday raised hopes that patch-up work might begin on the cruise liner Bermuda Star's torn hull, but choppy seas delayed the effort to contain thousands of gallons of oil within the ship. Winds reaching 35 mph whipped up waves around the liner in Buzzards Bay, prompting divers to suspend their survey of the hull, the Coast Guard said. ``With the waves so high, the diver could be thrown into the hull,'' said Chief Warrant Officer Tom Blair at the Marine Safety Office in Providence, R.I. ``He has to watch what he's doing very carefully, and he can't use the video camera, so the whole survey is being slowed up,'' Blair added. ``It's nice and sunny out there today, but those winds are still pretty strong,'' he said. ``It's great weather for sailing but not for something like this.'' The Coast Guard said that John Neary, who was piloting the Bermuda Star when it ran aground Sunday, also had been piloting the car-transport vessel Hual Ingrita in February when it ran aground on Jamestown Island, R.I., in Narragansett Bay. But the Coast Guard determined that a failed steering mechanism caused the earlier accident, Cmdr. Larry Doyle, executive officer of the Marine Safety Office, told a news conference. The cause of the Bermuda Star accident remained under investigation. Neary, of the Northeast Pilots Association in Newport, R.I., was brought aboard the liner to guide it through local waters, the Coast Guard said. Drug tests of Neary, the Bermuda Star's captain and several other officers were not complete Tuesday. Doyle said a container with a urine sample from Neary broke en route to a Philadelphia laboratory, and that another sample would be taken Tuesday. He said the delay would not hamper tests for potential substance abuse because traces remain in the body for several weeks. The Bermuda Star, carrying more than 1,060 passengers and crew, ran aground in dense fog Sunday morning on a rocky ledge off Falmouth. The vessel was freed that night, and towed to anchor about three miles away. The accident ripped a 90-by-2-foot hole in the ship's hull, exposing tanks holding about 110,000 gallons of fuel, the Coast Guard said. About 7,500 gallons spilled, and 500 gallons to 1,000 gallons washed ashore on Naushon Island at the eastern end of Buzzards Bay. Workers began cleaning the oil Tuesday in an effort expected to take about two weeks. The island, sparsely inhabited at the time, becomes crowded during the summer. No additional oil was leaking from the liner, Doyle said. A small sheen trailing off the rear of the ship was thought to be oil clinging to its waterline and would be cleaned when seas calmed, he said, adding that water pressure should keep more oil from leaking. Coast Guard officials decided against unloading the fuel to a barge before towing the liner to dry dock because of the heavy seas. Rear Adm. Richard Rybacki said he was disappointed by how long it took for the necessary equipment to get to the accident scene. ``I would like to have seen a quicker response on Sunday when we had good weather,'' he said. Rybacki said Coast Guard personnel responded as quickly as possible but that the Coast Guard has only ``first-aid equipment'' and must rely on commercial contractors for help in serious spills. Relatively small booms were placed around the Bermuda Star within two hours of its grounding; larger booms were supplied seven to eight hours later.

DOC.HEAD: State Department Denies Asking Imelda for Help
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 11th graf, `The leases...' with one graf to CORRECT that leases expire in 1991, not this summer.
DOC.TEXT: Imelda Marcos' racketeering trial resumed Tuesday for the first time since the former first lady of the Philippines coughed blood in court. ``I feel fine,'' Mrs. Marcos said when she arrived at the courthouse. The federal court trial had been in recess since May 31 when Mrs. Marcos collapsed in the courtroom with a stomach ailment and was hospitalized for three days. As the trial resumed, the U.S. State Department denied that Mrs. Marcos had been asked to help negotiate military base leases in the Philippines. A New York Post article on May 31 quoted Mrs. Marcos as saying she was approached in New York by State Department representatives who suggested a deal in which she could stand trial in her homeland in return for her assistance in resolving the U.S.-Philippine base agreement. In a letter to the prosecutor's office and made available to reporters Tuesday, Jamison M. Selby, the department's assistant legal adviser on East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said the report was ``entirely without foundation.'' Selby said he spoke with more than a dozen officials who would have authorized or been aware of such a meeting. However, one of Mrs. Marcos' attorneys, Benjamin Cassiday, insisted that two ``State Department connected'' people did meet with the former first lady of the Philippines during Memorial Day weekend. Cassiday said he knew their identities but refused to say who they were, or under what auspices they went to see her at 2 a.m. on May 25. ``It's political and it isn't part of our case,'' he said. The leases on Clark Air Force Base and Subic Bay Naval Base in the Philippines expire Sept. 16, 1991. The United States is seeking to extend the leases despite opposition in the Philippines. Mrs. Marcos, 60, has been on trial since March 20 on charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. She is accused of helping her late husband, ousted Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos, embezzle more than $220 million from their country's treasury to buy real estate and art in New York. Her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership of the real estate. The trial resumed without mention of Mrs. Marcos' collapse. The only indication that she had been ill was an emergency medical kit next to her personal doctor who was seated behind her. Mrs. Marcos also returned to court without a portable monitor she had previously worn because of a blood pressure condition. In testimony, the prosecution called FBI agent Robert Reich to explain a large chart that outlined the flow of funds from the Philippines for the purchase of an office building at 200 Madison. The building is among four New York properties the government claims that the Marcoses bought with embezzled money. The chart showed that the Glockhurst Corp., a business allegedly controlled by the Marcoses, bought the building in November 1983 for $50.5 million. The prosecution previously showed similar charts for the other three buildings _ 40 Wall St., the Crown Building and Herald Center. The prosecution is expected to complete its case this week.

DOC.HEAD: Israel Invites U.N. to Send Envoy to Occupied Territories
With AM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Israel on Tuesday invited the U.N. Secretary-General to send a personal envoy to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to investigate alleged abuses of Palestinian human rights. The move by Israel's day-old conservative government comes almost 2 weeks after United Sttes vetoed a United Nations measure calling for the Security Council to dispatch a team to the occupied territories. The United States vetoed the measure but said it supported a personal mission sent by the U.N. chief. ``The government of Israel, on our own initiative, extends to the secretary-general an invitation to (Secretariat Director) Jean-Claude Aime to visit Israel as an envoy in the framework of a visit to the region,'' Israeli Ambassador Johanan Bein told reporters. He said it was the ``first action of the new Israeli government in the international arena.'' The hard-line government received parliamentary approval Monday. Bein made the statement after a meeting with Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar who had sought to send both Aime and a special adviser to the occupied territories. Bein, Israel's acting permanent representative, said Israel ``definitely will extend full cooperation'' to the U.N. envoy. But he said the invitation was limited to Aime. He did not give a date for the visit, but U.N. officials said it could take place soon. Arab nations demanded emergency action from the United Nations to protect Palestinians living in the occupied territories after an apparently deranged Israeli gunned down seven Palestinian laborers and wounded 11 others on May 20. The shooting sparked widespread rioting in the occupied territories and a crackdown by Israeli troops. Israel's invitation may ease diplomatic tensions that emerged after the U.S. veto. Arab nations have threatened to seek an emergency session of the General Assembly to consider the situation in the territories if no action was taken by the United Nations.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists File Suit To Block Restart Of Nuclear Plant
DOC.TEXT: Two environmental groups have filed a lawsuit to prevent the restart of the Savannah River nuclear weapons plant on the grounds it would violate the federal Clean Water Act, an attorney said Tuesday. The lawsuit was filed Monday in U.S. District Court in Columbia by the Natural Resources Defense Council and the Energy Research Foundation. The groups charge that hot water discharges from one of three reactors scheduled to restart in December would exceed temperature limits set by the 1972 Clean Water Act. The discharges would send scalding water into the small streams adjacent to the plant, said Jimmy Chandler, attorney for the Energy Research Foundation. ``This hot water discharge will wipe out virtually all aquatic life and all vegetation within the receiving streams,'' Chandler said. ``It will cause a loss of 10 to 12 acres of forested wetlands each year.'' The reactor will discharge water at between 150 degrees and 170 degrees, while federal law prohibits hot water discharges of more than 90 degress, he said. U.S. Department of Energy spokesman Tim Tomastik, whose organization owns the Savannah River Site, refused to comment on the lawsuit because the issue was in litigation. The government has 60 days to respond. The reactors, located near Aiken near the Georgia line, were closed in 1988 after an accident at one unit raised questions about safety standards and the risk of mechanical failures. More than $1 billion is being spent to upgrade the reactors and retrain workers. The plant produces tritium, a radioactive isotope of hydrogen used to make H-bombs. Tritiums decays at a rate of 5.5 percent a year, meaning quantities in warheads must be replenished. The government says its stockpile of tritium is running low, although information about tritium inventories is classified. In May, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins announced a tentative schedule providing for the restart of the K reactor in December. However, a cooling tower that would lower the temperature of discharged water is not scheduled for completion until 1992. The lawsuit filed Monday asks that the K reactor not be operated until the cooling tower is completed. ``Restarting K reactor is unsafe and unnecessary,'' said Frances Hart, local coordinator of the Energy Research Foundation, a private non-profit environmentalist group. ``It's time the government started obeying its own laws.''

DOC.HEAD: Highly Decorated General, Armor Expert, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Retired Army Gen. Isaac David White, a highly decorated officer who led major armored assaults in World War II and Korea, has died. He was 89. White died Monday at the Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Center. Much of his military career paralleled the development of modern armor and armored warfare tactics. In April 1945, White's forces played a major role in sealing Germany's Ruhr Valley pocket, covering 190 miles in 13 days and capturing more than 45,000 prisoners. His troops were the first Allied soldiers to cross the Elbe River on the way to capture Berlin and end the war in Europe. Before Korea, White headed the Cavalry School at Fort Riley, Kan., and commanded the U.S. Constabulary in Germany for three years before serving as commanding general of the Armored Center at Fort Knox, Ky. White also created a tank training center at Vilseck, West Germany, which has become a model for armor training around the world. White helped speed the design, manufacture and procurement of new armored weapons for the Korean War, and went to Korea in 1952 to command troops through three mountain campaigns. He was awarded an Oak Leaf Cluster to the Distinguished Service Medal and the Korean Order of Military Merit Taeguk for those initiatives. White held 13 U.S. and 16 foreign decorations, including the Distinguished Service Medal. He was born in Peterborough, N.H., graduated from Norwich University in Vermont in 1922 and later became a trustee of the school. He retired to Dublin, N.H., in 1961 after more than 38 years of active duty. He was director of the New Hampshire Council on World Affairs.

DOC.HEAD: USAir: Dukakis Should Have Been Detained, Questioned After Bomb Joke
DOC.TEXT: USAir said its staff erred in not detaining Gov. Michael S. Dukakis for questioning when he warned as he boarded a plane that there could be a bomb in a White House aide's luggage. An airline supervisor who was present recognized the governor and determined the comments were made in a joking manner, Patricia Goldman, a spokeswoman for USAir in Arlington, Va., said Monday. The flight Sunday night took off from Logan International Airport as scheduled, bound for Washington D.C. Ms. Goldman said allowing Dukakis to board was an ``error in procedure.'' Federal Aviation Administration rules say anyone who comments about devices that could threaten passengers faces detainment, questioning and a possible fine. Dukakis aimed his barb at Ron Kaufman, a Republican political operative who Democrats claim conspired with a police union to disrupt the state Democratic Convention in Springfield with a demonstation June 2. ``After going through the experiences that the Democrats went through in Springfield, I can tell you we will always be concerned when Mr. Kaufman is around,'' Dukakis told reporters in Washington. As to his comment, the governor said, ``The humor of it was obvious to everyone who was there.'' Kaufman said he didn't think bombs were funny. ``Given the psychological terror people have of bombs and flying, it was irresponsible for a man in his position to joke about something like that,'' he said in a telephone interview.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Making no Promises on Sanctions, but Mandela Hopeful
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela met with top West German politicians on Tuesday to argue for continued international sanctions against South Africa but came away with no clear promises from Helmut Kohl. Mandela told reporters after his meeting with the West German chancellor that Kohl had initially favored a review of sanctions when the European Economic Community meets this month in Dublin. ``But I think, without speaking for him, after listening to our argument he is now prepared to reconsider. That was my distinct impression,'' the deputy leader of the African National Congress said. Mandela is on a tour of Europe and North America to urge the West not to lift economic sanctions against the white-led government in South Africa. Some countries, notably Britain, have said South African President F.W. de Klerk should be rewarded for the steps he has taken toward ending the country's system of racial discrimination. Those measures have included freeing Mandela after nearly three decades in jail, legalizing the black nationalist movement and, engaging in a dialogue with black leaders, including Mandela. Mandela maintains it was only the persistence of the African National Congress and the economic sanctions that prompted peace talks, and that apartheid has not been completely dismantled. Without directly addressing the sanctions issue, Kohl's office issued a statement saying: ``The chancellor underscores the necessity for the quick and complete elimination of the existing apartheid structures and the full inclusion of all South Africans'' in the political process. Mandela said his position was unequivocably endorsed by West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher, a member of a junior coalition partner in Kohl's government. ``He is a strong supporter of the view that sanctions must be maintained,'' said Mandela, who met with Genscher for an hour Tuesday morning. In his meeting with Kohl, Mandela said he also raised the issue of economic assistance from West Germany to help with the repatriation of an expected 20,000 returning exiles. The European Economic Community, of which West Germany is an influential member, agreed on a series of non-binding measures against South Africa in 1986, banning the imports of iron, steel and gold coins, worth $600 million in 1985. The EEC also banned new investments in South Africa. Although no agenda has yet been set, the issue of sanctions is expected to come up next week at a meeting of community foreign ministers in Luxembourg and at the full meeting later this month in Dublin. In February, Britain unilaterally lifted its ban on new investments in South Africa. Mandela was freed from prison that month after 27 years in jail by the de Klerk government.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Peace Talks Begin in Sierra Leone
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with first day's talks end, quotes, funeral services for slain civilians, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Liberian government and rebels began peace talks Tuesday, and President Samuel K. Doe reportedly said he would welcome an international peacekeeping mission to his West African nation. In Liberia, government officials took journalists 35 miles from the capital to the international airport to prove the government still controlled the airport contrary to claims by the rebel National Patriotic Front. The peace talks were held in the auditorium of the U.S. Embassy's cultural center in Freetown, with Liberian religious leaders acting as mediators. Talks were to have opened Monday but were delayed when rebel sources said their delegation was taking a roundabout route to neighboring Sierra Leone to avoid the danger of attack. Host Foreign Minister Abdul Karim Karim opened the meeting by saying Sierra Leone wants an end to the 5{-month-old conflict, which has killed more than 1,000 people and prompted thousands of Liberians to flee into Sierra Leone. Sierra Leone and U.S. officials then left and the Liberian delegations met behind closed doors. Tambakai Jangaxa, chief government delegate and president pro tem of the Liberian senate, and Thomas Woweiyu, a top leader and spokesman of the National Patriotic Front movement, both strongly stated their positions, mediators said. The rebels accuse Doe's people of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. The Rev. Levee Multon, peace talks chairman and president of the Liberian Council of Churches, said after the session adjourned Tuesday night that talks will resume Wednesday. He added, ``Everything was done in an atmosphere of respect, cordiality and understanding and it looks like we are in for a fruitful conference.'' The talks could break down if rebels stick to their demand that Doe resign and leave the country before they will agree to a cease-fire. Doe agreed to the talks after the rebels, led by former civil servant Charles Taylor, advanced to within 25 miles of Monrovia. His troops, unable to halt the rebels since they invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24, were accused of killing hundreds of civilians believed to support the insurgents. Liberian state radio Tuesday quoted Doe as saying he would welcome the presence of an international peacekeeping force in Liberia if one were agreed to at the Freetown negotiations. The rebels met little resistance until a week ago, when government troops recaptured the headquarters of a U.S.-managed rubber plantation near the international airport. Rebels say they took back the plantation later. On Tuesday, foreign reporters accompanied by a government official drove to Robertsfield International Airport, which is next to the plantation. Reporters said they passed through heavily manned checkpoints and that many soldiers guarded the airport. They said they heard only an occasional gunshot. Airlines halted flights to the airport June 3. More than 100,000 plantation workers and war refugees, including at least 20 expatriate managers, have been trapped by the fighting. The British Embassy announced Tuesday it was organizing a convoy to Sierra Leone on Wednesday. More than 1,000 Britons remain in the capital Monrovia. The U.S. Embassy organized its last air evacuation Sunday. More than 1,000 Americans remain, many of them Liberians who hold U.S. passports. About 500 Liberian refugees are fleeing daily to Sierra Leone, Raymond Hall, a spokesman for the Office of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, said Tuesday in Geneva. He said 10,000 people recently escaped the fighting and his agency expected the refugee population to swell to 20,000. The United Nations estimates there are already about 60,000 Liberian refugees in the Ivory Coast and 80,000 in Guinea. In Clay Ashland, Liberia, hundreds of wailing and weeping mourners on Tuesday buried three civilians, including prominent sculptor R. Vanjah Richards, who were reported killed by soldiers. ``The soldiers who attacked us, brutalized us and did this are paid by us, the taxpayer,'' Episcopal Bishop George D. Brown told mourners outside the Baptist church at Clay Ashland. Richards, 48, was mayor of the small town just west of Monrovia and professor of fine arts at the University of Liberia. Many descendants of the freed Americans slaves who founded Liberia oppose Doe's government. Doe seized power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted elitist Americo-Liberians who had governed the country and discriminated against native Liberians.

DOC.HEAD: South American Kidnappers of U.S. Miner Upset With Currency
DOC.TEXT: Attempts to free an American miner kidnapped by South American guerrillas hit a snag when a go-between brought the ransom in U.S. dollars instead of Colombian pesos, the hostage's father said Tuesday. ``The intermediary had problems getting up the river (to the kidnappers) because they've had heavy rain and the river is swollen,'' Roy Heimdal said. ``Then the guerrillas got upset because the ransom money came in U.S. dollars instead of pesos. When they tried to exchange it, they had trouble finding enough pesos,'' Heimdal said. ``So things aren't going so smoothly.'' Heimdal said he and his wife, Marge, had believed the kidnappers wanted $60,000 in U.S. currency in exchange for the freedom of their 27-year-old son, Scott. The Heimdals traveled to Chicago on Tuesday with their daughters, Linda and Angela, to obtain passports so they can travel to Quito, Ecuador, when their son is released. Roy Heimdal said the kidnappers also were upset after seeing coverage on Cable News Network of the family's effort last week to raise the ransom. ``They saw pictures of our house,'' Heimdal said of the family's modest, wood-frame bungalow in a middle-class Peoria neighborhood. ``Our house is no mansion. But by their standards it is. I guess they figure anyone who eats three square meals a day has $60,000 laying around.'' Heimdal said the unidentified intermediary was trying to convince the kidnappers the working-class family really is financially strapped. The family's life savings were wiped out by medical bills after Mrs. Heimdal was seriously injured in a 1983 wreck with an uninsured drunken driver. There were no reports Tuesday from Ecuador. Heimdal said recent heavy rains there have swollen rivers, making travel to the guerrilla's jungle hideout difficult and slowing negotiations. But the family has solved its own transportation problems. Heimdal said a Florida travel agent has stepped forward to guarantee them passage to Quito. Last week, Midway Airlines donated two plane tickets to get the Heimdals to Miami, but they did not have tickets to South America. ``A woman who wants to remain anonymous called and offered us tickets the rest of the way,'' Heimdal said. ``She said her daughter was kidnapped and murdered a few years ago and she wants to help us out. She is arranging a flight to Quito from Miami.'' Heimdal said the family will stay in Illinois until they receive word their son is free before leaving for Ecuador. The Colombian guerrilla group believed to have kidnapped Scott Heimdal on April 28 has a long history of kidnappings and violence, State Department records show. John Reap of the State Department's counterterrorism bureau said that while there is no proof the group known as EPL was involved in the abduction, it seems likely. ``We feel it's a strong possibility, since kidnappings strictly for money, with no political factors involved, have been part of their past conduct,'' he said. Reap said the United States is not treating Heimdal's kidnapping as an act of international terrorism because the only motive appears to be money. Scott Heimdal was abducted while working for the Iminco Gold Mining Co. in northern Ecuador near the Colombian border. His purported captors, the Popular Liberation Army (EPL), initially demanded $1.2 million for his release, but later lowered their demand to $60,000. According to State Department documents, the Popular Liberation Army _ the EPL stands for its Spanish name ``Ejercito Popular de Liberacion'' _ was formed in late 1967 by a small group of Colombian Maoists.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0741 to fix to 747-200 in editor's note
Change in Boeing Plane Urged but Sabotage Ruled Out in Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with two grafs to CORRECT aircraft designation to Boeing 747-200 Combi sted 747-400. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `The plane ...'
DOC.TEXT: An investigator has recommended modifications to a Boeing aircraft after blaming a fire in the cargo section for the crash of a South African Airways jet. The 1987 crash near Mauritius killed all 159 people aboard. Sabotage was ruled out in the report by Justice Cecil Margo in newspapers Tuesday but no cause could be determined for the fire in the Boeing 747-200 Combi. The plane, en route from Taipei, Taiwan, to Johannesburg, plunged into the Indian Ocean about 1,500 miles east of Johannesburg on Nov. 28, 1987. Most of the passengers on Flight 295 were Japanese, Taiwanese or South African. Margo called for changes in the Combi configuration planes that have an extra-large cargo hold on the same level as the passenger section and cockpit. He said smoke and gasses spread quickly through the passenger section and possibly the cockpit. Plastic and cardboard packing were involved in the blaze, according to the investigation report. ``There was a strong possibility'' gases and smoke overwhelmed the flight crew, the report said. Margo's report said the smoke-detection, firefighting equipment and safety procedures on the plane were inadequate. Until such problems are corrected, ``the Combi configuration, with passengers and cargo on the same deck ... should be prohibited as creating an unacceptable risk,'' Margo said. He said the U.S. National Transportation Safety Board had rejected his recommendation for modifications to the plane, but the U.S. Federal Aviation Administration had issued new directives to minimize fire hazards on the Combi. South African Airways has since removed the cargo section from the passenger level on its one remaining Combi. Jack Gamble, spokesman for Boeing Commercial Airplane Group in Renton, Wash., said company officials had not seen the judge's report. He noted the FAA had called for changes in firefighting procedures and ``some minor design modifications'' in DC-10 and 747 combination passenger-cargo aircraft. New planes incorporate the recommendations, and manufacturers are working to retrofit older aircraft, Gamble said. ``We feel those (FAA) recommendations are adequate,'' he said. ``How those changes relate to what the judge ordered, we don't know.'' Margo prohibited public release of the full transcript of the cockpit voice recording, saying it might be misunderstood or cause embarrassment. The release of the report was slowed by the complicated recovery of wreckage from about 15,000 feet underwater. The report said investigators could find no evidence of an explosion in the wreckage. ``It is virtually certain there was no sabotage,'' the report said. The investigation probed the cause, not liability. The airline reached an out-of-court financial settlement with relatives of the victims and no court cases are pending or expected.

DOC.HEAD: Firefighters Begin Taking Control of Stubborn Supertanker Blaze
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf, `Greene said ...,' to include earlier comment that fire confined to engine and pumping rooms; INSERTS four grafs after 6th graf pvs, `The Coast ...,' to UPDATE with slick growing, Mexican vessel sent, picks up 7th graf pvs, `Crewmen boarded ...' Minor editing elsewhere to conform.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HT6,14; LaserColor HT7; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Firefighters boarded a burning supertanker Tuesday, and brought under control the fierce blaze that has left the oil-laden vessel crippled and leaking in the Gulf of Mexico, officials said. Oil continued leaking from the ship, the Coast Guard said. A thick cloud of gray smoke surrounded the superstructure of the 886-foot Mega Borg, replacing the balls of flame and towering columns of black smoke that had been billowing from the Norwegian vessel since an engine-room explosion Saturday. Coast Guard Capt. Tom Greene said that Ted Hoskins, who heads the salvage operation, boarded the ship with a crew. Hoskins ``said he would characterize the fire as under control,'' Greene said. Greene said he could see no fires in the latest videos taken on the ship, but added a fire was still burning below deck. The fire has been ``pinned down'' in the engine room and the pumping room, spokesman Daan Kaakebeen of Smit Internationale, the Dutch salvage company leading the firefighting effort, said earlier in Rotterdam.
