The Coast Guard also revised its estimate of the amount of oil on the water to less than 2,000 gallons, a fraction of the 100,000 gallons officials estimated earlier. The amount that had spilled from the tanker, which was carrying 38 million gallons of light African crude, was not determined. Much of the oil that spilled had burned off, but with the fire now confined, ``there is more oil in the water and the slick is continuing to grow,'' Greene said. Still, Coast Guard officials said they believe a disastrous spill can be avoided because the light crude can be easily dispersed. Meanwhile, Mexico sent a collector vessel to help clean up the spill. Pemex, the Mexican government oil monopoly, said that at the U.S. government's request, it sent the 146-foot Ecopemex, which can suck up oil and water at the rate of 2,000 barrels an hour, separate out the oil and store it in special tanks. Crewmen boarded the tanker to determine if it had cooled enough to be sprayed with flame-smothering chemical foam. Foam spraying has been delayed since Monday because the ship was too hot and crews feared another explosion even if the flames were doused. Officials speculated it could take as little as an hour to pump the foam into the engine room and other areas still burning. ``We're hoping the foam application is a success,'' said Coast Guard Petty Officer Howard Holmes. If it isn't, ``we can't deny the fact that we could be in trouble, but we are optimistic that the foam will work.'' Crews aimed 10 water streams from five fireboats stationed at the sides of the tanker, and firefighters had placed another water hose on the deck, pointing it toward the burning stern. ``They've kept applying water in great quantities and it's continued to cool the structure,'' Greene said. ``They'll continue to do that. There's progress being made. They're making ground.'' Efforts to dissipate an oil leak apparently also were having some success. The oil slick around the ship diminished to three miles by 10 miles, Petty Officer Gene Maestas said. Most of what remained appeared in a light sheen with few heavy concentrations. The ship is 57 miles southeast of Galveston. None of the spilled oil is expected to reach the coastline immediately. The Coast Guard said it was moving daily about three to four miles to the northwest. ``We're still not completely safe from a major release until the fire is out and the ship is stabilized and it is brought on an even keel,'' Greene said. Once the fire was extinguished, an 825-foot British-registered tanker, the Vic Bilh, was standing by to begin receiving the remainder of the Mega Borg's cargo of crude, Maestas said. Greene said that operation could be dangerous because the ship is listing slightly and crews might have to pump water into the holds to keep the vessel balanced. Earlier Tuesday, the Coast Guard said part of the vessel showed signs of buckling because of the intense 900-degree blaze, the shifting cargo and the continuous stream of water being poured on the hulk. But later, officials said crews at the scene reported no signs of major structural damage. The ship's left rear section, however, was very close to the water line. On Monday, the rear had dipped below the surface, heightening fears the vessel might sink. ``I'd say the chance of sinking is very slight at this point because they have the fire well pushed back in the ship,'' Greene said Tuesday. The rear has dropped more than 60 feet since the tanker caught fire early Saturday while transferring cargo to a smaller vessel. Two of the 41 crewmen died, two were missing and presumed dead and 17 were injured, none seriously. The Norwegian government scheduled a hearing for Wednesday morning in Galveston to interview crew members who were aboard at the time of the blast and try to determine how it occurred. Little oil spilled at first, but five explosions within 20 minutes Sunday sent burning crude pouring into the Gulf. By Tuesday, a burning trail of oil that extended for hundreds of feet behind the stricken tanker had diminished to a small pool. The Mega Borg was carrying more than three times as much oil as was spilled by the Exxon Valdez off Alaska in March 1989 in the nation's worst oil spill. But the oil spilled in Alaska was heavy crude, which doesn't dissipate nearly as rapidly as the light crude aboard the Mega Borg. Also, much of the oil spilling off Texas was being consumed by fire. Currents and winds were expected to push oil toward a 200-mile stretch of coast between Freeport and Corpus Christi, an area considered a prime bird breeding and shellfish harvest area. The tanker, operated by Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway, was bound from Palanca, Angola. It was scheduled to travel to Aruba after Galveston. Elf, a Houston subsidiary of a French oil distribution company, owned the cargo and said it would participate in the cleanup. But a company official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Tuesday he did not believe Elf was liable for the costs.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed, Two Injured As Fireworks Plant Leveled by Explosions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with identities of dead and injured in both blasts, damage figure in Maryland, inspections ordered, other details. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CCD2
DOC.TEXT: Explosions leveled a fireworks factory Tuesday, killing two workers, injuring two others and shaking windows as far as 30 miles away, authorities said. ``It sounded like the biggest bomb that ever was,'' said Norma Oswalt who lives about three miles northeast of the plant. ``It shook my back porch and shook the screens all over the house.'' Another fireworks plant blast seriously injured a worker near Elkton, Md. One of the several explosions about 9 a.m. at the Mid-South Pyrotechnics plant six miles southeast of this east-central Mississippi town killed two employees, Lowndes County Coroner Don Harris said. They were burned beyond recognition but were identified as Herman J. Hallman, 65, and Frank Young, 37, both of Columbus, he said. Employee Sally Brandon was hospitalized after being thrown 100 feet by one of the blasts, Harris said. Golden Triangle Regional Medical Center Hospital spokeswoman Cynthia Rose would say only that Brandon was in stable condition. Plant owner Gene Beatty was slightly injured, and a visitor to the plant escaped injury. Agents of the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms arrived to help determine what sparked the explosions, local emergency Director Bennie McDow said. A metal girder flew 300 feet from the plant and smoldering bits of wood and concrete and firecracker wrappers landed even further away. One of the blasts left a crater about 5 feet deep and 50 feet wide. ``We felt two distinct booms, and the windows on the east side of our building, which is located in the center of campus, were rattled,'' said Sammy McDavid, spokesman for Mississippi State University, 30 miles to the west. ``It did no damage here. ``It was one of those things that you say, `What was that?''' A one-mile area was evacuated for fear more blasts would occur, but by midafternoon the evacuation area was reduced to about 200 feet around the brick building, which once had been a school. Firefighters spent the afternoon dousing the charred rubble. Remnants of the plant's stock crackled and popped in the smoking debris. ``My concern is that there is another full ton of fireworks that haven't exploded there,'' said Sheriff Ed Prescott. The worker injured at the New Jersey Fireworks plant in northeastern Maryland had worked there for nearly 30 years and was the only person in the building at the time, state fire marshal's spokesman Bob Thomas said. George Carroll, 65, was in critical condition at a Baltimore hospital after suffering second and third-degree burns over 72 percent of his body, Francis Scott Key Medical Center spokeswoman Terrie O'Sullivan said. The first explosion occurred in a building used to make Roman candles. Fire then spread to a second building; both buildings were destroyed, a fire department spokesman said. The explosion was the second in a week near Elkton, said Al Ward, deputy state fire marshal, who estimated the damages at $6,000. As a result, State Fire Marshal Rocco Gabriele ordered inspections of Maryland's four fireworks plants, all in Cecil County, Thomas said.

DOC.HEAD: Court Upholds Congressman's Sex Charge Conviction
DOC.TEXT: U.S. Rep. Donald Lukens' conviction on a charge he had sex with a teen-age girl was upheld Tuesday by a state appeals court. The 59-year-old Republican was convicted May 26, 1989, of a misdemeanor charge of contributing to the unruliness of a minor. He was accused of paying a girl to have sex with him at his Columbus apartment in November 1988 when she was 16. Lukens was sentenced to six months in jail and fined $500. The congressman has 30 days to appeal to the Ohio Supreme Court and will remain free on bond during that time, said an attorney for Lukens, Thomas Tyack. Lukens spoke with Tyack and other attorneys by telephone from Washington to discuss the case, said Lukens aide Joe Bukovac. ``In the decision passed down there is a determination of errors made by the judge in the courtroom on several issues,'' Bukovac said. ``At this point, there are a concensus of Lukens' legal advisers leaning toward further appeal.'' A three-judge panel of the 10th Ohio District Court of Appeals rejected arguments by Lukens' attorneys that Franklin County Domestic Relations Judge Ronald Solove erred by barring testimony about the girl's record of juvenile offenses. Lukens' attorneys also contended that Solove's definition of an unruly child differed from the definition in Lukens' indictment. In addition, they said the judge improperly overruled defense motions for a mistrial after prosecutors tried to use inadmissible testimony of sex between Ms. Coffman and Lukens in 1985. They further said the court abused its discretion in sentencing Lukens. The appeals judges rejected all the arguments. ``I get frustrated in cases of this nature to be told yes, there were errors committed but it doesn't matter,'' Tyack said. Tyack said the evidence about the girl's past was necessary to establish she already was unruly and to challenge her credibility. But the appeals court said Tyack failed to show the records were relevant. Lukens lost his bid for a third consecutive term in the 8th Congressional District GOP primary in May. A week before the election, he publicly apologized for what he called ``a dumb mistake'' and asked voters to forgive him. But he maintained he was innocent of the charge. Allegations that Lukens had sex with the girl surfaced in early 1989. Shortly afterward, a Columbus television station broadcast a videotape of a November 1988 meeting between Lukens and the girl's mother, Anna Coffman, who confronted Lukens about the relationship. Lukens did not know the meeting at a local fast-food restaurant was being taped by a TV crew. On the tape, Lukens offered to find Mrs. Coffman a government job after she accused him of ``messing around'' with her daughter. Lukens served two terms in Congress, from 1967 to 1970, and then made an unsuccessful attempt to gain the GOP gubernatorial nomination in Ohio. After 15 years in the Ohio Senate, he was returned to Congress by voters in 1986. He was re-elected in 1988.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tops six grafs reflect actual remarks; Picks up 4th graf pvs. ``This year's election; SUBS 12th graf: ``Bush and,'' to remove redundant identification of Quayle
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, likening himself to a ``spring colt'' on his 66th birthday, prodded Republicans Tuesday night to ``end the Democratic stranglehold'' on Congress by recapturing the Senate. ``I feel it in my bones, we can get the majority of the Senate,'' Bush told a GOP fundraiser in his honor. More than 4,000 Republicans at the banquet stood and sang ``Happy Birthday Mr. President.'' Former Senate Republican Leader Howard H. Baker of Tennessee said the event raised some $6.9 million for Republican Senate and House candidates for fall elections. The current Senate Minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, told Bush that the Senate vote earlier in the evening sustaining Bush's veto of a $2 billion Amtrak authorization bill was the president's real birthday president. And Vice President Dan Quayle said that ``the Democrats have had their turn. Now it's our turn'' to control the Senate. Bush told the gathering: ``What's scaring the heck out of our opponents is the simple fact that this fall, they're up against the Republican record.'' ``This year's election presents an opportunity for us to regain a majority in the Senate. We can end the Democratic stranglehold on the U.S. Congress,'' Bush said. Democrats now control the Senate by 55-45. Earlier Tuesday, Bush said turning 66 was ``slightly worse than being 65 but not bad.'' ``I feel like a spring colt,'' Bush told reporters. However, he did admit to starting off the day ``kind of regretting it.'' ``It's been a good birthday. I hadn't thought so. But good cake, good cards and _ not bad,'' he told reporters after giving a talk in the Rose Garden reiterating his support for a constitutional amendment to ban flag-desecration. Senior White House staff members gave Bush a brown leather briefcase for his birthday. And Bush was being feted at a GOP dinner expected to raise several million dollars for GOP Senate and House candidates. Bush and Quayle were hosts of the annual $1,500-a-plate President's Dinner, which this year falls on the president's birthday. Composer Marvin Hamlisch was to perform a song specially written for the event. Earlier, Republican lawmakers burst into a rendition of ``Happy Birthday'' at a White House GOP leadership meeting. Some reporters showed up at a picture-taking session at the start of the meeting wearing children's birthday hats to honor the occasion. ``It's a vast improvement,'' Bush said. He agreed to amend his own policy against answering questions at picture-taking sessions. But, Bush said, ``only those wearing hats get their questions answered.'' In response to one query, Bush said he did not know if Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had sent him a birthday card. But, he added diplomatically, ``I've got to be careful. He may well have sent something.'' Bush's wife, Barbara, turned 65 last Friday. The annual black-tie GOP event was sponsored by the National Republican Senatorial Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee. Some 4,000 guests paid for tickets. It was at the same event two years ago that then-Vice President Bush was formally endorsed for the GOP presidential nomination by President Reagan.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Early Educational Intervention Helps Low-Birth-Weight Babies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Berry is cq in 15th graf
DOC.TEXT: Premature, low-birth-weight babies given special education from the start scored significantly higher on IQ tests at age 3 than their counterparts who weren't helped, researchers said Tuesday. Infants born weighing between 4.4 pounds and 5.5 pounds who received special educational help in addition to medical care scored an average of 98 on IQ tests taken at age 3, the researchers wrote. That was 13.2 IQ points higher than subjects who were born in the same weight range but who received only the medical care, said the researchers, who were led by Dr. Ruth Gross of Stanford University. Infants who weighed about 4.3 pounds or less at birth and were given the educational help scored an average of 91 at age 3, or 6.6 IQ points higher than counterparts who got only medical care, the group reported in Wednesday's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``The predictiveness for the scores at age 3 means good things for the kids (who were helped) in the years ahead,'' said Dr. Donna Bryant, a study participant and research psychologist at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. ``The fact that the differences were so great means that fewer of these kids will be held back in school,'' she said. The four-year study involved 985 babies born in 1985 in eight states _ Arkansas, New York, Massachusetts, Florida, Texas, Washington, Connecticut and Pennsylvania. One-third received the educational help, two-thirds did not. Almost 7 percent of babies born annually in the United States, or 250,000, are of low-birth weight, 5.5 pounds or less, said Gross. Thanks to advances in technology, almost all babies born weighing more than 4.5 pounds survive, and those weighing about 2 pounds have a 20 percent chance of survival, Gross said. But she added that all low-birth-weight babies risk developmental problems. Of the children studied, those not helped educationally were 2.7 times more likely to have IQs in the mental retardation range, below 70, the study found. An average IQ for all people is 100. In the study, the babies who were helped had researchers visit their families' homes weekly during the child's first year to advise the parents and make sure the babies had educational toys. At 1 year old, the child started going to a child development center five days a week, while researchers continued visiting the home every two weeks. The researchers also held group meetings for parents every two weeks to give advice about child rearing and health and safety. Berry Brazelton, a pediatrics professor at Harvard University's medical school, said the study results ``certainly showed the importance of early intervention. ... The critical part of this study is the first year.'' But Arnold Sameroff, a psychologist who teaches at Brown University and practices at Bradley Hospital in Providence, R.I., said other researchers will find it hard to tell what in the multifaceted treatment made the difference. Universities involved in the $33 million study were the University of Arkansas, Little Rock; Albert Einstein College of Medicine, New York; Harvard Medical School, Boston; University of Miami in Florida; University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia; University of Texas, Dallas; University of Washington, Seattle; and Yale University, New Haven, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Liberal Vice Minister of Culture Dismissed
DOC.TEXT: China's most famous actor-politician, Ying Ruocheng, has been dismissed as vice minister of culture, the official Xinhua News Agency said Tuesday. Ying, along with the culture minister, short-story writer Wang Meng, was a proponent of greater artistic freedom. Wang was fired as minister in September. No explaination was given for Ying's dismissal. Official reports initially said Wang wanted more time to write, but later said he was in poor health. Both moves appeared to be part of the Communist leadership's effort to restore tight controls over artists since suppressing last year's mass pro-democracy demonstrations. Ying played no public role in the student-led democracy movement and is not known to have supported it. But the crushing of the movement created a political backlash in which conservatives gained the upper hand and have tried to rein in liberalism, especially in the arts. As a director, Ying introduced several Western plays to Chinese audiences, including Shakespeare's ``Measure for Measure'' and ``The Tempest,'' and Arthur Miller's ``Death of a Salesman,'' in which Ying played Willy Loman. In Bernardo Bertolucci's movie ``The Last Emperor,'' filmed in China, Ying played the jailer who helps remold deposed Emperor Pu Yi into a socialist citizen. He also played Mongol emperor Kublai Khan in the 1982 television mini-series ``Marco Polo,'' produced by Italy, the United States, Japan and China. Ying's dismissal was one of several high-level personnel changes approved since May 18 by the State Council, China's cabinet, Xinhua said. It was the first time any of the changes have been disclosed. Also dismissed was a second vice minister of culture, Wang Jifu, a career party official. Xinhua said Ying and Wang were replaced by Xu Wenbo and Chen Changben. Xu is a member of the party's Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, which is in charge of disciplining party members.

DOC.HEAD: Sen. Packwood Announces Divorce
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Robert Packwood, R-Ore., announced Tuesday that he had filed for a divorce from his wife of 25 years, Georgie. A brief announcement from the senator's office said ``with much regret'' that a temporary separation begun in January had not helped the couple resolve problems in their marriage. A spokeswoman for the senator, Julia Brim-Edwards, said the divorce papers were filed Tuesday in Multnomah County in Oregon Since the separation, the 57-year-old senator has kept an apartment in Washington. Georgie Packwood lives in a Maryland suburb of the capital. They have two children, a son Bill, 22, and a daughter Shyla, 19. Neither lives at home.

DOC.HEAD: Baptists Keep Fundamentalist Administration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with Chapman news conference, action on Washington lobbying group; picks up 12th graf, `The campaigns...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Southern Baptists-Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Southern Baptists elected a fundamentalist minister president Tuesday, solidifying conservative control of the nation's largest Protestant denomination. The Rev. Morris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, defeated the candidate backed by moderates, the Rev. Daniel Vestal of the Atlanta suburb of Dunwoody. The 21,471-to-15,753 vote gave Chapman a 58 percent majority. The convention moved toward curtailing funding for the Washington-based Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, which lobbies for religious freedom on behalf of nine Baptist bodies. Fundamentalists have denounced the lobby for opposing organized prayer in public schools and for not opposing abortion. The election outcome extended fundamentalist control for the 12th straight year. Some moderates predicted they would give up trying to retake control of the 14.9 million-member denomination. Some also said its national operations, with a budget of more than $440 million a year, would lose much support from moderates. Chapman said at a post-election news conference that he would seek ``peace and harmony'' in the denomination, but ``what we believe about the Bible is non-negotiable.'' He said he has ``never advocated any wholesale housecleaning'' of those not accepting belief in an infallible Bible. Nearly all Southern Baptists are theological conservatives, devoted to the Bible's authority, but fundamentalists stress its ``inerrancy'' _ that it is without error in any way, historically, scientifically or religiously. They also have imposed detailed questioning in denominational agencies and institutions to assure adherence of personnel to the expanded requirements. The Southern Baptist presidency is one of the most powerful offices in U.S. Christianity, with appointive powers controlling selection of governing trustees of a far-flung network of agencies and institutions. Chapman said he would advocate attrition to get rid of staff members, executives or seminary professors who could not subscribe to an ``inerrant'' Bible. He said he felt that in time they would ``find a home more in line with their convictions.'' Members of First Baptist Church in Wichita Falls, where Chapman has been pastor since 1979, said they think Chapman is the kind of person who can mend the denomination's rift. ``I see him as someone that can play the role of a peacemaker. So I'm excited about it,'' said Tom Bacus, 44, a deacon of the 4,000-member church. Although some moderates including Vestal are fundamentalist, or literalist, about the Bible, they leave room for other understandings under the Baptist view of ``soul competence'' of the individual. The Rev. Jerry Vines of Jacksonville, Fla., who is completing his term as president, told the convention that some want to leave ``room for all'' in the denomination, but ``that's too much room.'' He said denominations that haven't insisted on an ``infallible inerrant'' Bible were bound for ``the garbage dump.'' The convention approved a change recommended by the executive committee to turn over religious liberty concerns to the denomination's Christian Life Commission. This was expected to lead Wednesday to a vote to cut out 87 percent of Southern Baptist support, or $365,328, from the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs. Numerous speakers protested turning over lobbying to a commission concerned with morality and abandoning the joint committee. Henry Green of Cocoa, Fla., pleaded that ``we maintain fellowship'' with other Baptists, saying ``it is unbilibal to railroad through this plan to destroy cooperation.'' The campaigns for the presidency were intensified this time by added fundamentalist attacks on seminaries, including the administration and some professors at the 131-year-old flagship Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in Louisville, Ky. Its president, the Rev. Roy Honeycutt, and the faculty have struck back, calling accusations of ``doctrinal infidelity'' false distortions that ``sow seeds of hate.'' Chapman, 49, a Mississippi native, got his theological education at Southwester Baptist Theological Seminary in Fort Worth, Texas. He was pastor of churches in Albuquerque, N.M., and in Waco and Rogers, Texas, before assuming his present pastorate at First Baptist Church in Wichita Falls, Texas. Vestal, 46, the son of an evangelist, also got his ministerial education at the Fort Worth seminary. He previously led churches in Arlington, Fort Worth and Midland, Texas, before becoming pastor of Dunwoody Baptist Church in suburban Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Two States, New York City Win Federal Order Against Tanker That Spilled Oil
With AM-Tanker Blast
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ordered an oil tanker impounded Tuesday so that New Jersey, New York and New York City can guarantee that the vessels owner pay for damages resulting from last week's 260,000-gallon oil spill. ``This order gives us the power to prevent them from moving the ship until we're satisfied,'' said Gordon Johnson, an assistant attorney general for the state of New York. Johnson said Govs. Jim Florio of New Jersey and Mario Cuomo of New York decided to seek the impoundment of the vessel because officials received word that the ship BT Nautilus could be ready to move as early as Wednesday from Bayonne, where it was docking Thursday when it ran aground. Charles Anderson, a New York City attorney representing the 811-foot ship's owners, Nautilus Motor Tanker Co. of London, characterized U.S. District Judge Nicholas Politan's order as routine in maritime cases.. Anderson said the ship was under repair and no decisions have been made on moving it. He said the company's underwriters are working on posting a bond to guarantee payment of cleanup costs. Workers collected about 100 gallons of oil waste that washed up along a five-mile stretch of Sandy Hook beach Tuesday, including three miles of beaches where swimming is normally permitted, according to the National Parks Service. The beach was clean by 5 p.m., said parks service spokesman Manny Strumpf. The Coast Guard has not determined the cause of the grounding. Navigational charts of the area where the BT Nautilus ran aground are accurate, and the accident would not have occurred if the ship had been following the proper route, said Capt. Robert North, coordinator of the cleanup. A grand jury is to meet this week to consider charges that the tanker's first mate, Gregory Frederick Geoffrey, 52, of New Marske, England, was operating a vessel while intoxicated, said Christopher Florentz, a spokesman for the New Jersey attorney general's office. The Coast Guard said tests of the captain, Albert Ainscough, and the pilot, Jim Naughton, showed no traces of drug or alcohol use. The BT Nautilus ran aground while being docked, ripping a 30-foot-long gash in its hull and pouring 260,000 gallons of No. 6 industrial heating oil into the Kill van Kull, a busy waterway separating Bayonne from the New York City borough of Staten Island. Attorneys for New York and New Jersey argued that the captain and crew were ``incompetent, inattentive, reckless and otherwise grossly negligent in their duties, which resulted in the general unseaworthiness of the BT Nautilus.'' That condition caused the ``illegal discharge of oil,'' according to papers filed in federal court. Anderson said the allegations were ``totally unfounded,'' and noted that the cause of the investigation remained under investigation. The spill was the fourth major one in the waterway and nearby Arthur Kill this year.

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 9 Takes,0705
Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of June 4-11:
DOC.HEAD: Newsprint Suppliers Raise Prices 5 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Most North American newsprint producers increased prices about 5 percent in June, the first broad hike in more than two years. But buyers say they'll resist paying it because of plentiful supplies. Industry analysts and purchasers say the $35 increase, which raised the benchmark eastern U.S. list price of standard newsprint to $685 a metric ton, hinges mainly on whether labor negotiations are settled at mills in eastern Canada, the world's largest single source of newsprint. ``The labor dispute is probably the only thing that's keeping the price increase in place now,'' said Dan Dowis, director of newsprint for Knight-Ridder Inc., one of the nation's largest newspaper groups. If the negotiations are settled without a strike, ``you'll see a lot of (the increase) going back to purchasers in the form of discounts or even rollbacks on what's being paid now,'' Dowis said. ``Our policy is that we won't pay the increased price.'' The price hike, which went into effect June 1, was first announced in February by Abitibi-Price Inc. of Toronto, the world's second-largest newsprint maker behind Fletcher Challenge of New Zealand. It is the first since an industrywide increase of 6.6 percent on Jan. 1, 1988, and producers say the hike is overdue because of declining profits that have left them struggling at the margin, threatening mill shutdowns. ``Sellers have been getting killed. All the Canadians, who are two-thirds of the North American market, are making no money because they're selling at $525 (a ton) and that's their cost to produce,'' said Mark Kurland, an analyst with Mabon, Nugent in New York. Newsprint is now sold at about a 19 percent discount from the list price. The increase raises actual transaction prices to about $555-560 a metric ton from about $525. Newspaper companies have been stockpiling inventories of about 50 days in anticipation of a possible strike at Canadian mills, which have already begun to cut production. The industry is closely watching talks that began May 31 between Montreal-based Stone Consolidated Inc. and the Canadian Paperworkers Union, which is seeking wage increases of 8 percent a year in each of two years. A strike at Stone, which would likely spread to the entire industry, would sharply curtail supplies. It also could force the shutdown of some Canadian mills, which already face the prospect of a costly retooling from virgin pulp to recycled production. ``The increase will go through for now. If Stone settles, then newsprint purchasers will have the upper hand and it will probably argue against the increase holding,'' said Kurland.
DOC.HEAD: Knoxville Newspapers To Dissolve Joint Operating Agreement
DOC.TEXT: The city's two newspapers decided June 8 to dissolve their joint operating agreement, ending a lawsuit filed by the morning Knoxville News-Sentinel against the afternoon Knoxville Journal. Under the JOA, the News-Sentinel provided sales, production and distribution for the Journal. Editorial departments of the two newspapers are separate. The lawsuit claimed that the Journal's owner, Persis Corp., violated terms of the agreement when it purchased The Daily Times in nearby Maryville last year. Journal Editor and Publisher Gerald Garcia was made president and publisher of The Daily Times. The News-Sentinel, which recently began a zoned edition in Maryville, considered The Daily Times a direct competitor. The lawsuit contended that with Garcia in the dual roles, The Daily Times would have access to the News-Sentinel's confidential business information and trade secrets. The arrangement to end the JOA calls for the News-Sentinel to pay Persis $40 million in two $20 million installments. The money will be in lieu of payments the Journal would have received from Dec. 31, 1991, through the scheduled end of the agreement on Dec. 31, 2005. The plan calls for the JOA to end in December 1991. Until then, the News-Sentinel will continue to act as agent on some business matters for the Journal. The News-Sentinel, owned by the E.W. Scripps Co., has a daily circulation of 101,000 and a Sunday circulation of 169,000. The Journal publishes Monday through Saturday with a circulation of 40,000.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 1st Add,0835
Computer Use Linked to RSI Problems at Newsday
DOC.TEXT: A government study conducted for Newsday and its union shows there is ``significant association'' between computer keyboard work and repetitive strain injury, one of the researchers said June 7. The study, the first comprehensive survey of repetitive strain injury in the U.S. newspaper industry, also concluded that computer terminal use among workers at Newsday and New York Newsday presented ``a hazard to workers' health.'' It did not quantify or elaborate on the risks. The study by the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health and the University of Michigan found no single cause for the injuries, Cincinnati-based NIOSH researcher Susan Burt said in a telephone interview. She said several factors contribute to the risk of getting repetitive strain injury, or RSI, including: _Repetitive motions, like those made while typing on a computer keyboard. _Work positions, like extending the wrists up in an awkward position in order to type. _Static position, caused by holding arms up in order to type. The study also found that how long a person worked at a keyboard without a break and how fast they typed contributed to problems associated with RSI. ``We do not recommend working at a keyboard for extended periods without taking a break,'' she said. No specific time limit was given. The study group included 834 workers at Newsday and New York Newsday. They included reporters, editors, clerical and secretarial employees who worked in the editorial, financial, advertising and circulation departments. Burt said the employees were asked if they had experienced any pain, aching numbness, tingling or burning in their hand-wrist, elbow, shoulder and neck area within a 12-month period. By definition, she said the pain had to last at least a week or occur at least once a month. They also had to have no previous history of acute injury to the area and the pain had to have started on their current job. Survey results showed that 331 of the 834 employees, or 40 percent, reported one or more symptoms in at least one of the four regions some time within the past year. Burt cautioned that the results were based on self-reporting and said NIOSH estimated they were ``twice as high than if we had done physical examinations as well as questionnaires.'' Of all the employees questioned, she said ``reporters appeared to be at higher risk'' than the other workers. Some believed that the type of keyboard used may contribute to RSI, but Burt said ``we found no significant difference.'' Researchers did say, however, that work stations crowded with computers, desks, chairs and other equipment could contribute to the problem. Repetitive strain injury is listed as the leading cause of occupational illness by the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics. The bureau said 115,400 cases of RSI were reported nationwide in 1988, representing 48 percent of all workplace illnesses. The malady has been reported in a wide range of workers including office employees, assembly-line jobs and within the meatpacking industry. The study was requested by Newsday and the Graphics Communication International Union Local 406, which represents nearly half of the newspaper's 3,100 fulltime employees. Researchers recommended that Newsday establish a labor-management committee to handle RSI problems and train employees on how to use adjustable equipment and change their work habits. Assistant Managing Editor Robert Keane said the newspaper has already initiated those recommendations. John McDonald, vice president of the union's editorial unit, said further studies may be done to show how individual work habits and equipment contributes to RSI. Burt said the agency is beginning work on two more studies on RSI at the Los Angeles Times and U.S. West, a large telecommunications company.
DOC.HEAD: Maxwell Negotiating for American Newspaper
DOC.TEXT: British publishing magnate Robert Maxwell says he is negotiating to buy an American newspaper. Maxwell, the chairman of Maxwell Communications Corp. PLC, declined to name the company but said the deal would be worth ``hundreds of millions'' of dollars. Maxwell, whose interest in buying more papers is widely known, made his comments to reporters June 4 after the annual meeting of one of his companies, Berlitz International Inc., in New York. Industry analysts named a few papers that Maxwell could be targeting, including the New York Daily News, owned by the Tribune Co. of Chicago, and the Chicago Sun-Times, which the New York-based investment firm Adler & Shaykin bought from Rupert Murdoch in 1986. Tribune Co. spokeswoman Martha Lindeman and Leonard Shaykin, a managing partner of Adler & Shaykin, both said their companies do not comment on rumors of negotiations. Maxwell owns the London Daily Mirror and recently launched The European, an English-language newspaper distributed throughout Europe. Maxwell announced last month that he planned to buy three U.S. supermarket tabloids, Globe, National Examiner and Sun, from Montreal-based Globe International Publishing Inc. His biggest acquisition to date in the United States was his $2.6 billion purchase in 1988 of Macmillan Inc., the publishing and information services company.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 2nd Add,0720
Lawmaker Seeks Repeal of Newspaper Preservation Act
DOC.TEXT: The Newspaper Preservation Act is fattening publishers' wallets but eroding press freedom and the quality of the nation's journalism, a Republican congressman says. ``It seems ironic that some of the very voices which call for free market forces to work in other industries seek government protection for creating monopolies in their own,'' said Rep. Carl Pursell of Michigan. Pursell introduced a bill June 6 to repeal the 1970 law, which allows newspapers in the same city to operate as a single business entity while maintaining separate news staffs. The bill would not affect the partial mergers already in place. But it would prohibit similar arrangements _ known as joint operating agreements or JOAs _ in the future. Leaders of Citizens for an Independent Press, a national coalition of small newspaper publishers, business and civic leaders, endorsed Pursell's bill. They accused the large newspapers that have entered into JOAs of sacrificing principle for profit. ``These crybaby billionaires have for many years enjoyed one of the biggest and most enduring special-interest giveaways in American history,'' said Bruce B. Brugmann, editor and publisher of the San Francisco Bay Guardian, a weekly newspaper. Newspapers in 19 cities were operating under JOAs last year. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh approved two others, in Las Vegas and York, Pa., this year. Some of the country's oldest and best newspapers would be out of business without JOAs, said Joseph Ungaro, president and chief executive officer of the Detroit Newspaper Agency. His company administers a JOA between the Detroit Free Press and The Detroit News. The Free Press' daily circulation was 629,275 in March 1989 and rose to 639,767 by March 1990, Ungaro said. The News' circulation fell from 693,943 in March 1989 to 526,147 in March 1990, largely because of a decision to scale back circulation outside the Detroit area and to make the News an afternoon paper instead of retaining most of the previous morning editions, Ungaro said. ``I'd have to say that the readers are voting with their pocketbooks every day by buying the product,'' he said. Ungaro noted that Knight-Ridder, which owns the Free Press, had indicated it would close the money-losing newspaper if the JOA were denied. ``Is one paper with a monopoly better than two voices in the community? I don't think so,'' Ungaro said.
DOC.HEAD: Cox Newspapers Buys Direct Mail Company
DOC.TEXT: Cox Newspapers has acquired Main Street Advertising USA Inc., an Atlanta direct mail company, for an undisclosed price. The acquisition ``complements the other media choice Cox offers to advertisers,'' said William B. Disbrow, vice president-finance for Cox Newspapers. ``The quality of service that Main Street delivers previously was only available to major companies with large advertising budgets.'' Last year Cox purchased two other direct-mail firms: Tampa, Fla.,-based Stuffit Inc. and The Clipper Inc. of Atlanta. Cox plans to expand Main Street, which provides such services as marketing advice, copy writing and database information to independent businesses. Within a month, additional offices will open in Dallas, Houston, Nashville, Philadelphia and Tampa. James G. Verhey will remain as president of Main Street. Cox is the parent company of The Atlanta Journal-Constitution. Atlanta-based Cox Enterprises also owns cable television and broadcasting operations.
DOC.HEAD: Photoengravers Laid Off in Second Round of Personnel Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The second round of layoffs at the Daily News in two weeks was unrelated to contract negotiations, an executive for the newspaper says. John T. Sloan, the News' vice president of human resources, said June 4 the laying off of 13 full-time and eight part-time photoengravers stemmed from ``the soft newspaper economy, and because we are overmanned in the photoengraver department.'' Union leader Stanley Aslanian called it ``a further tightening of the screws,'' though he agreed the cuts were permissible under provisions of the contract. On May 29, the newspaper announced the layoff of 17 machinists because of reduced advertising revenue. Intense negotiations have been taking place over Daily News labor contracts that expired March 30. Both sides acknowledge that the survival of the News is at stake, although the paper says it must eliminate workers and increase productivity to survive, and the unions say the paper is trying to decimate them en route to shutting down the paper or selling it.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 3rd Add,1102
Papers Publish Letter to Anderson From Daughter
DOC.TEXT: Lebanon's eight daily newspapers on June 7 published a letter to American journalist Terry Anderson from his daughter, Sulome, who was born after his abduction. In addition to the letter in Arabic, the prestigious An-Nahar and four other dailies printed the original English-language text of the letter, which Sulome addressed to her father on her fifth birthday in the hope that Anderson would be allowed to read it. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western captive among the hostages. He did not know Arabic when the pro-Iranian Islamic Jihad _ Islamic Holy War _ kidnapped him in west Beirut March 16, 1985. Sulome, in the letter addressed to ``my darling daddy,'' wrote: ``Tomorrow is my birthday. I will be five years old. I know you have never seen me.'' ``I also have never seen you, but my mummy tells me everything about you and how you used to call me an active little baby,'' the letter said. ``I like listening to stories about you, they make me happy. Mummy says you will soon come to us. Please come home daddy,'' Sulome's letter said. ``I love you daddy. I pray for you and the others every night,' she concluded. Anderson and five other Americans are among the 16 Westerners held mainly by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions in Lebanon. The other Western captives are four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross, an Italian and an Irishman.
DOC.HEAD: Judge Considering Dismissal of Secord Libel Suit
DOC.TEXT: A federal district judge is considering whether to dismiss a $38 million libel suit filed against two journalists by Iran-Contra figure Richard V. Secord. Lawyer Dean Ringel told Judge George H. Revercombe on June 5 that Secord's suit against Leslie and Andrew Cockburn and the Atlantic Monthly Press should be dismissed because no actual malice has been proved. But W. Michael Kramer, attorney for the former Air Force major general, contended the authors, in a 1988 book, falsely linked Secord to narcotics trafficking said to have been carried out as part of the effort to finance the Contra rebels. Kramer asked the judge for additional time to take depositions and search for further evidence in the case. Revercombe took both motions under advisement. Kramer contended that the clear intent of the book, ``Out of Control: The Story of the Reagan Administration's Secret War in Nicaragua,'' was to exploit the Iran-Contra affair by putting the administration and its key players in the worst possible light. But Ringel, appealing for dismissal, said, ``Mr. Secord seems to assume that since the book takes a political position opposite to that of the previous administration that is evidence of malice.'' Secord's libel suit was filed in March 1988, the same day he was indicted for his Iran-Contra role. He was sentenced to two years' probation on one of 12 original counts after a plea bargain. But he is appealing, alleging that independent counsel Lawrence Walsh lacked jurisdiction to prosecute for an offense arising out of Secord's congressional Iran-Contra testimony.
DOC.HEAD: Newspapers Exchange Fire in Basketball Feud
DOC.TEXT: Newspapers in Portland and Detroit have gotten into the rivalry over the NBA Finals between the Trail Blazers and the Pistons. ``Just what sort of place is this Portland?'' The Detroit News asked on its editorial page June 5. Well, for starters, the News says, there is the cultural tone of the Oregon city. ``Portland's image is pretty well captured by its mayor, Bud Clark, a tavern owner who posed as a flasher in a promotion for the local arts community a few years back. The poster showed Mr. Clark, back to the camera, raincoat wide open, flashing a sculpture above the slogan `Expose yourself to art.''' Portland is also a place where ``the City Council renamed the boulevard where all the hookers hang out after Martin Luther King.'' The Oregonian returned fire in an editorial two days later. ``Detroit, a French word meaning `Let's move to Houston,' was founded by Antoine de la Mothe Cadillac, who settled there when the transmission in his canoe gave out,'' the newspaper said. If The Detroit News thinks Portland is boring and snooty, The Oregonian thinks Detroit may be too exciting for its own good. ``The last time the Detroit Tigers won a World Series, in 1984, Detroit's major league fans celebrated by setting the city on fire,'' The Oregonian said. ``The National Guard complained, but city planners thought it was a good idea.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper, Judge Battle Over List of Jurors
DOC.TEXT: The public and press have the right to a list of jurors' names, even if those jurors, fearing the revenge of a defendant they sent to jail, ask that their identities remain secret, The Boston Globe argued June 6 before the 1st Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals. A former U.S. solicitor general countered that while a judge cannot halt the ``obnoxious and harmful'' process by which jurors become media personalities, he does not have to make the reporter's job any easier. The Globe challenged a ruling last April by U.S. District Court Judge Edward F. Harrington, who withheld the names of jurors in a money laundering case. In briefs filed in support of the case, the newspaper held that the jurors are acting in a public role when they render a verdict and that the public has a historical right to know who they are. Assistant U.S. Attorney F. Dennis Saylor IV also argued for the names to be released, in an appearance against the presiding judge that Senior Circuit Judge Frank Coffin termed ``highly unusual.'' Saylor told the appeals court the U.S. government did not consider the security of the jurors in the case threatened. Former U.S. Solicitor General Charles Fried, arguing on Harrington's behalf, said the judge was under no obligation to provide the list. Reporters were free to corner jurors on their way out of the courtroom if they could, he said. But a judge, Fried argued, has the right to say, ```I'm not going to make (the reporter's) job easier. I cannot stop it, I cannot shut it down, but I will not facilitate it.' That is the heart of this case.'' The money laundering case involved alleged members of organized crime, and one of the defendants was still at large at the time of the trial. Jurors in the case had asked that their names not be disclosed because they feared retribution by the defendants.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 4th Add,0793
Journalist Shot in Home Dies
DOC.TEXT: A Mexican journalist died June 9 after being shot by gunmen who broke into his home in southern Mexico, a newspaper reported. Alfredo Cordova Solorzano, a correspondent in the southern state of Chiapas for the Mexico City newspaper Excelsior, was shot June 6 when three assailants invaded his home in the town of Tapachula on the pretext of stealing his car, Excelsior said. He was shot five times in the chest and abdomen when he confronted the assailants in an attempt to protect his wife and 12-year-old son, the newspaper said. It said Cordova was unarmed. The newspaper said the 34-year-old Cordova died of respiratory failure in a Mexico City hospital, where he was transferred after being treated locally. Cordova was also founder and publisher of the 5-year-old Chiapas newspaper Uno Mas Dos. The newspaper said Cordova had been threatened in recent months for his journalistic investigation of two Chiapas families and drug trafficking. On May 31, he was attacked and beaten in a restaurant, the report said. Chiapas Gov. Patrocinio Gonzalez Garrido called for a complete investigation of the shooting, the newspaper said.
DOC.HEAD: Press Group Protests Soviet Slander Law
DOC.TEXT: The International Press Institute sent a letter to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to express concern over a new law that imposes prison terms and fines for slandering the president. The London-based group representing journalists, editors and publishers worldwide said in the June 6 letter that the new law, passed by the Soviet legislature, ``violates international standards of press freedom, including Article 19 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.'' The law imposes penalties of up to six years and fines of up to $40,000 against those who insult or slander the Soviet president, the letter said. ``The law is vaguely worded about what kind of comments would be considered insulting or slanderous and whether it would apply to foreign correspondents and foreign publications,'' said the letter signed by Peter Galliner, director of the press group.
DOC.HEAD: Soviets Telling Their Story With Faxes to U.S. Newsrooms
DOC.TEXT: Newspaper editors around the country reported getting a newsroom-size fill of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of glasnost _ through the fax machine. ``I have been just inundated. Our fax machine has been going almost constantly,'' said Frank Partsch, editorial page editor of the Omaha World-Herald. Partsch said June 5 he was holding 30 to 40 pages of Soviet material, about half of what had come in during the superpower summit in Washington. ``It's the first time I've ever seen this,'' said Bob Haring, executive editor or the Tulsa World, who received 20 to 30 pages of faxed material from the Soviet Embassy in Washington. The Soviets say it's nothing unusual, just another embassy using technology to reach the media. ``We're using modern know-how to reach newspapers. If, politically, countries are changing, why should information agencies work in the same manner, the old manner?'' said Alexander Malyshkin, senior information officer for the Soviet Embassy. ``American media is very fast, you know,'' he said. Malyshkin said his office has one fax machine and aides work constantly to relay articles by the official Novosti Press Agency, opinion pieces by Soviet officials and even lighthearted features on life in the Soviet republics. But if calls to a handful of newspapers are any indication, there may be more openness than the American media can handle. ``I haven't had a chance to do anything with them,'' said Virginia Hall, opinion pages editor of the Kansas City Star, which received about 10 Soviet faxes on various topics. ``I haven't had a chance to read it,'' said Partsch. ``There's a lot of it and I don't like faxes.''
DOC.HEAD: Newspaper's Founder Didn't Take Money _ Former Spokesman
DOC.TEXT: The state attorney general is investigating allegations that a founder of a newspaper sold by the homeless took money after resigning, a spokesman said June 9. A newspaper representative called the allegations rumors spread by former workers. New York Newsday and the Daily News, quoting unidentified sources, reported that employees of Street News have told the attorney general's office as much as $250,000 is unaccounted for. Edward Barbini, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert Abrams, said the office had received reports that co-founder Hutchinson Persons, who resigned June 6, may have taken money from the paper. Street News spokesman Jeffrey Sussman said Persons had submitted his resignation, but said he had no evidence of misappropriation of funds. Sussman told the News that the allegations were ``rumors fabricated by ex- employees. ... You'd have to be pretty tupid to take money with the whole world watching you.'' Persons could not be reached for comment.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 5th Add,0879
NBC Affiliates Seek Help From Congress
DOC.TEXT: About 300 NBC station executives mounted a major lobbying effort June 5, asking Congress to help them compete with cable and Hollywood studios. The network-arranged appeals had two main goals, said Cyril Vetter, head of the affiliates' government affairs board: _To urge support for a change in Federal Communications Commission rules barring networks from the lucrative syndication market and from a financial interest in shows others produce. _To push for a solution to what they say is the problem of cable systems transmitting their broadcast signals without having to pay for them. The visit by station executives came during the network's first affiliates convention ever held in Washington. It reached more than half of the House and Senate members, said Vetter, a Baton Rouge, La., broadcaster.
DOC.HEAD: Phone Company Poll Finds Many Want Cable TV Competitors
DOC.TEXT: Most Americans would welcome cable television competition, according to a Gallup Poll released June 4 by one of the telephone companies eager to get into the business. A majority of those surveyed also said they would like to have two-way video services _ such as movies on demand, library services and office-in-the-home services _ that could be provided through a network of high-capacity, fiber-optic telephone lines. ``This is a clear indication that the public would favor competition and innovation,'' said Kent B. Foster, president of GTE Telephone Operations, which commissioned the study. The poll results were released as congressional committees, beset by constituent complaints of high prices and poor service, consider legislation to re-regulate the cable industry. A proposal by Sen. Conrad Burns, R-Mont., would lift some provisions of the 1984 Cable Act that prohibit companies such as GTE from providing video programming within their telephone service areas. Other federal laws prohibit the seven regional Bell companies from selling cable TV programming. The poll was conducted April 30-May 2 by telephone with 1,000 people. It's margin of error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
DOC.HEAD: Senate Committee Passes Bill To Re-regulate Cable TV Rates
DOC.TEXT: A Senate committee gave near-unanimous approval June 7 to a bill that would allow local governments to control some cable television prices. The 18-1 vote by the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee marked the first time lawmakers have moved to restore some of the regulation of the cable industry that Congress lifted in the 1984 Cable Act. The 1984 law ended local rate regulation effective in 1987, and since then members of Congress have been deluged with complaints of soaring prices and poor service. More than 20 re-regulation bills were introduced in Congress in the past two years, and the Senate communications subcommittee held nine hearings before the compromise bill emerged. The bill, among other things, would: _Allow local governments to regulate prices for a ``basic tier'' of channels including local over-the-air broadcast channels. Ad-supported pay cable channels such as ESPN, CNN and MTV would not be subject to local rate regulation. However, if local authorities or a subscriber complains about rate increases for such ad-supported cable channels, the FCC could establish ``reasonable rates'' if it finds them to be excessive. _Require cable operators not to discriminate against cable programmers like movie channels with which they have no affiliation. Some cable companies are owned by giant conglomerates that also own movie channels. _Require that all cable programmers make their programming available to home dish owners.
DOC.HEAD: Turner Promises Apology for Religion Remarks
DOC.TEXT: Cable TV mogul Ted Turner has promised to apologize for calling Christianity ``a religion for losers'' when he speaks at a church luncheon, the church pastor says. ``He made the statement he wants a chance to apologize to the world, but would say other things we might not like,'' said the Rev. Johnny Hunt of the 3,500-member First Baptist Church of Woodstock. Hunt said Turner initiated the idea for the June 13 luncheon at the suburban Atlanta church, where a former girlfriend and a fishing buddy are members. Turner criticized Christians last year and again last month at the National Convention of the American Humanist Association when he was named Humanist of the Year. Hunt speculated that maybe Turner ``hasn't met the right ones.''
DOC.HEAD: Rose Headed to Fox
DOC.TEXT: Charlie Rose is leaving the overnight CBS interview program ``Nightwatch'' for a daily interview show on the Fox network. The Emmy winner, who has headed ``Nightwatch'' since it began in 1984, will join ``Personalities'' as its anchorman, Fox announced June 5. Rose also has been anchorman on ``Face the Nation,'' ``CBS Morning News,'' ``CBS This Morning'' and ``Newsbreak.''
DOC.HEAD: News Show Going Off The Air
DOC.TEXT: A news program co-produced by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette and a public television station will have its final broadcast June 29. ``The News at 10,'' which airs weeknights on WQEX-TV, features Post-Gazette editors and reporters discussing the stories that will appear in the newspaper the following morning. WQEX station manager Michael Fields said he hoped the show would return at some point. He said budget cuts recently announced by WQEX's parent company, QED Communications, were not responsible for the cancellation. He said he felt the program had fulfilled its mission.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 6th Add,0629
Holtz Returns as Publisher of Journal & Courier
DOC.TEXT: Richard L. Holtz has returned as publisher of the Journal & Courier, replacing W. Curtis Riddle, who has been named publisher of the Lansing (Mich.) State Journal. Holtz, 50, was publisher of the Journal & Courier from 1986 to 1988 before holding the same position at The Stockton (Calif.) Record. Both newspapers are owned by Gannett Co. Inc. Holtz, a Huntington, W.Va., native, has 30 years of experience in the newspaper business. He joined Gannett in 1970 with the Commercial-News in Danville, Ill. He also worked as advertising director of The Herald-Dispatch in Huntington, W.Va., and The Burlington (Vt.) Free Press, and was publisher of the Marietta (Ohio) Times.
DOC.HEAD: Brown Becomes Publisher
DOC.TEXT: Richard Brown, a circulation consultant for the Mid-South Division of Thomson Newspapers, has been named publisher of The Daily Advance of Elizabeth City. Brown succeeds Frank Wood, who has accepted a similar post with the Times West-Virginian in Fairmont, W.Va. Both companies are in the Thomson Newspapers group. Wood will replace Rob Hammond, who was named publisher of The Register-Herald of Beckley.
DOC.HEAD: Gaut-Correll Named Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: Licia Gaut-Correll, lifestyle editor of the Hendersonville Times-News, has been named to a newly created position of managing editor. Ms. Gaut-Correll, 36, has been lifestyle editor since January 1989. She started as a reporter at the newspaper and served as news editor for seven years.
DOC.HEAD: Patrick Promoted to Managing Editor
DOC.TEXT: City Editor Mike Patrick of the Arizona Daily Sun was named managing editor of the newspaper on June 8. Patrick, 34, has previously been news editor and sports editor at the Sun. He started there in 1983 and left the next year for the Lawrenceville (Ill.) Daily Record, where he stayed a year before returning to Flagstaff.
DOC.HEAD: SF Examiner Names Two New Editors
DOC.TEXT: The San Francisco Examiner announced the retirement of one editor and the appointment of two new editors June 10. Tom Dearmore, editorial page editor since 1978, will retire at the end of the month, to be be succeeded by Lee Dembart, 43, whose career has included assignments at the Los Angeles Times, the New ork Post and The New York Times, said Examiner Publisher William Randolph Hearst III. Hearst also announced the appointment of David Talbot, 38, as managing editor of the Sunday Image magazine. Talbot was senior editor at Image when it began in 1986, and has free-lanced for publications including Interview, The New Yorker, and Rolling Stone. Talbot left the Examiner in 1987 to write the book, ``Burning Desires: Sex in America,'' published by Doubleday last year.
DOC.HEAD: Don J. Smith Appointed City Editor
DOC.TEXT: Don J. Smith was promoted from assistant city editor to city editor at the Seattle Post-Intelligencer on June 5. Smith returned to Seattle last November after six years at the Dallas Morning News, most recently as assistant metropolitan editor. He previously worked for Fournier Newspapers, now the Valley Daily News, which published weeklies in three Seattle-area communities. He was executive editor and oversaw a move to daily production. Smith replaces John Dunphy, who left the Post-Intelligencer in November.
DOC.HEAD: Robinson Moves to Sports Information Director
DOC.TEXT: Sports Editor Brent Robinson of the Kearney Hub was named sports information director at Kearney State College on June 5, replacing Don Briggs, who is retiring. Before joining The Hub, Robinson worked for the Hastings Tribune, the Lincoln Journal-Star and the Scottsbluff Star-Herald. He won the Nebraska Press Association's award for Best Sports Column in 1982. In 1983 he received a first-place award in sports writing in the Associated Press Newswriting competition.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 7th Add,0935
DOC.TEXT: Jon Akass, a 30-year veteran of Fleet Street, died June 4 of cancer at age 56. Akass began his career as a messenger for the Glasgow Herald. He worked for regional newspapers and came to national attention at the Manchester office of the now-defunct Daily Herald when he was asked to write a front-page story about a plane crash at Munich Airport. At age 24, Akass was called to the newspaper's head office in London to write a column four times a week. Akass is survived by his wife, Peggy, and four children.

Forest W. Amsden, a veteran journalist and executive of the Medical Research Foundation in Portland, died June 1 of a heart attack at age 64. Amsden began his journalism career in newspapers, rising to become executive editor of The World newspaper in Coos Bay. From 1964 to 1979, he worked for King Broadcasting Co. at KGW-TV, KGW-AM radio and KINK-FM radio, all in Portland. He was vice president and general manager of KING-TV in Seattle from 1979 to 1981. Survivors include his wife, Claire, and three children.

John Brownell, the youngest journalist to become a top news executive at the Los Angeles Times, died June 9 of complications of AIDS. He was 33. Brownell served in a variety of editing posts during his 10 years at the Times, and had was promoted to deputy managing editor in February. He died at Sherman Oaks Community Hospital. Brownell began working as a copy editor at the Chicago Tribune while a senior at Northwestern University, where he graduated in 1978. After working at The Milwaukee Journal, he joined the Times' national desk in 1980, and went on to work as assignment editor in the paper's Washington bureau, senior editor of the Times magazine and editor of the lifestyle section. Brownell is survived by his parents, one sister and five brothers.

James W. Jackson Jr., writer-producer for the 1970s PBS series ``Lowell Thomas Remembers,'' died in a car crash June 5. He was 66. Police said his car skidded out of control and struck a tree near Winnsboro, where he lived. Fairfield County Coroner Joe Silvia said Jackson's Porsche was traveling about 120 mph when it crashed. At the time of his death, Jackson was working on a television series about former South Carolina Gov. Robert E. McNair. Earlier in his career he was a sports editor for The Columbia Record, and an announcer and promotion manager for WIS-TV in Columbia. Jackson is survived by his wife, Jackie, a daughter and two sons.

Donald L. Mulford, a former publisher of the Montclair Times and past president of the New Jersey Press Association, died June 3 at his home in Montclair. He was 72. His first major story, while working as a student reporter for the Daily Princetonian, was the explosion and crash of the German airship Hindenburg in 1937 in Lakehurst. He joined the Montclair Times in 1940, after graduating from Princeton University. Mulford served as a combat correspondent in the Pacific during World War II, returned to the newspaper and was named publisher in 1979. He became publisher emeritus after it was sold in 1989. Survivors include his wife, Penny, two daughters, a stepson, two stepdaughters and three grandchildren.
DOC.HEAD: Inter-American Press Association Awards Announced
DOC.TEXT: The Inter-American Press Association, in its annual awards competition, has honored The Miami Herald for overall coverage of inter-American affairs and The Patriot Ledger of Quincy, Mass., for a supplement on the drug problem. The Miami-based group also honored three human-rights activists _ Elizardo Sanchez Santa Cruz, Hubert Jerez and Hiram Abi Cobas _ who have been imprisoned in Cuba for talking to U.S. journalists. The three were winners of the Pedro Joaquin Chamorro Freedom of the Press Award, named after the slain Nicaraguan publisher. The Miami Herald will receive the IAPA-Tom Wallace plaque for its year-round attention to inter-American affairs, exemplified by the series ``A Desperate Journey,'' documenting the flight of Nicaraguan refugees to the U.S. The award is named after the first president of the IAPA. The Patriot Ledger will receive the IAPA-La Nacion of Buenos Aires award for its supplement ``Crossroads _ Finding Our Way out of a World of Drugs.'' Kevin Sullivan of The Journal-Bulletin of Providence, R.I., was honored for his spot news coverage on Colombia and drug traffickers. Honorable mention in that category went to Diane Lindquist of The San Diego Union for a series about Mexico's ``maquiladora'' industry, in which U.S. parts are assembled using Mexican labor. The award for interpretive reporting went to Joel Millman for an article about the Salvadoran army in The New York Times Magazine. An honorable mention went to the Latin American staff of The Associated Press for a series of articles on ``A Continent in Crisis.'' The IAPA award for editorial writing went to Harry A. Fuller Jr. of The Salt Lake Tribune for a series on Latin American affairs. In the illustrations category, awards were given to editorial cartoonist Don Wright of The Palm Beach Post and photographer Ben Deboto of The Houston Chronicle, with an honorable mention to photographer David Walters of The Miami Herald. El Norte of Monterrey, Mexico, received the top award for Latin American newspapers. The awards will be presented at the IAPA's 45th annual General Assembly, to be held in Kansas City, Mo., Oct. 15-18.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: BC-AP Industry News, 8th Add,1101
Four Honored, Including Reporter Killed While Investigating Drug Lords
DOC.TEXT: The 10th annual Livingston Awards for Young Journalists were given June 6 to four journalists. The awards included a special posthumous citation for a reporter killed while investigating drug lords and revolutionaries in South America. Todd Smith, a columnist and reporter for The Tampa (Fla.) Tribune, was nominated for a story published in September connecting Peru's ``Shining Path'' guerrillas to drug lords in Colombia. While following up the story in Peru, Smith was kidnapped Nov. 17; his body was found on a soccer field in Uchiza, Peru, four days later. The Livingston Foundation created the posthumous award for Smith, who would have been 30. Peter Gumbel, 32, a Wall Street Journal reporter in Moscow, won the award for international reporting for a story on the perils of perestroika. Tom Ashbrook, 34, foreign editor of The Boston Globe, was awarded the national reporting prize for a story on how Asia was moving ahead of the United States in the world. Michele Norris, 28, of The Washington Post, won the local reporting prize for a story on a 6-year-old boy's life at home with a crack-addicted mother. More than 500 entries were submitted by editors from stories published or broadcast in 1989. Each winner receives a citation and $5,000. The awards are administered by the foundation at the University of Michigan and are meant to encourage excellence among journalists under 35.
DOC.HEAD: Religion Writers From Los Angeles, St. Petersburg Papers Win Awards
DOC.TEXT: Religion reporters from the Los Angeles Times and the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times were named winners of the top 1989 awards of the Religion Newswriters Association at its annual meeting June 9. Russell Chandler of the Los Angeles Times won the $2,500 John Templeton Reporter of the Year Award for the third time. Michelle Bearden of the St. Petersburg Times won the $500 James O. Supple Memorial Award, for distinguished religion writing. Don Lattin of the San Francisco Chronicle won second place in both the Templeton and Supple competitions. The association includes about 200 specialists who cover religion for the secular press. Joan Connell of the San Jose Mercury News in California accepted the Harold Schachern Memorial Award for the outstanding religion section. Second place went to the St. Petersburg Times and third to The Arizona Republic. Tom Price of the Elkhart (Ind.) Truth received the Louis Cassels Memorial Award for religion writing on newspapers with a circulation of 50,000 or fewer. Runners-up were Steve Brunsman of the Biloxi (Miss.) Sun-Herald, second, and Julia Sopalski of The Anchorage (Alaska) Times, third.
DOC.HEAD: Times Reporter Honored for Book
DOC.TEXT: Thomas L. Friedman of The New York Times, a State Department correspondent who formerly reported from the Middle East, was honored for excellence in journalism June 7 by the New York Public Library. Friedman, a two-time Pulitzer Prize winner, was given the Helen B. Bernstein Award for his book ``From Beirut to Jerusalem.'' The award carries a $15,000 prize. Top editors at 20 major newspapers and newsmagazines nationwide were asked to nominate reporters whose work as journalists led them to write a book on social or political problems.
DOC.HEAD: Children's TV Programs Honored
DOC.TEXT: ``CNN Newsroom'' and 19 other television programs were cited for excellence June 5 by Action for Children's Television and will be honored in a ceremony dedicated to the memory of Muppets creator Jim Henson. Commercial stations in only two cities, Pittsburgh and Boston, won awards from the group. ``It's a nationwide contest so it says that kids across the country are not getting enough choices from television,'' said the group's president, Peggy Charren. ``Pittsburgh and Boston are doing nifty local programs but for the country as a whole, local programs for children are kind of an extinct dinosaur.'' Action for Children's Television was formed 22 years ago in part to push for legislation to limit the number of television advertisements directed at children. The awards were as follows: Public Television: _WGBH, Boston for ``Long Ago and Far Away.'' _WNET, New York and Quality Family Entertainment for Shining Time Station. _WQED, Pittsburgh for ``Wonderworks.'' _Maryland Public Television for ``TimeLine.'' Commercial Television: _WCVB, Boston for ``A Likely Story.'' _KDKA, Pittsburgh, for ``Let's Read a Story.'' _WTAE, Pittsburgh for ``Cappelli and Company.'' _WHDH, Boston for ``Ready to Go.'' Cable Television: _CNBC for K-TV, ``features for kids on a lively magazine show.'' _CNN for CNN Newsroom, a daily, commercial-free newscast offered in schools. _Showtime for ``Familytime.'' _Nickelodeon for ``Make the Grade.'' _HBO for Babar. _The Disney Channel for ``Lunch Box.'' Home Video: _SVS Inc. and Rabbit Ears Productions for ``How the Leopard Got His Spots.'' _Media Home Entertainment and Joshua Greene for ``Noah's Ark.' _Media Home Entertainment for ``Madeline.'' _Fries Home Video for ``Lamb Chop's Sing-Along, Play-Along.'' _CC Studios for ``The Amazing Bone and Other Stories.''
DOC.HEAD: Editor of Soviet Magazine Chosen
DOC.TEXT: Vitaly Korotich, the Soviet Union's pre-eminent glasnost journalist, has been chosen as one of 14 media professionals and educators named to fellowships at the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University. Korotich is editor of the weekly newsmagazine Ogonyok. Under his editorship, Ogonyok has printed first-hand accounts of the Afghanistan War, uncovered crimes committed under Stalin and exposed corrupt Communist Party officials. In 1988, World Press Review named Korotich its International Editor of the Year, citing his ``courage, enterprise and leadership in advancing press freedom and responsibility, defending human rights and fostering excellence in journalism.'' Last year, Korotich was elected to the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, where he represents Kharkov in the Ukraine. He has published 42 books, some of which have been translated into as many as 15 languages. The Gannett Center for Media Studies is the nation's first institute for the advanced study of mass communication and technological change. Those who are named to fellowships work at the center on individual research projects that result in books, monographs and other materials. Korotich will reexamine ``Models for Coverage for Press Freedom.'' Also named for the 1990-91 class were Elena Androunas from the Faculty of Journalism at Moscow State University and Janos Horvat from Hungarian television.

Newspaper advertising spending fell by three-tenths of a percent for the first quarter of the year, to $7.296 billion, compared with the same period last year, according to estimates by the Newspaper Advertising Bureau reported in The New York Times. The group estimates that while retail advertising rose by 2.7 percent, classified advertising dropped 6.4 percent.
DOC.HEAD: End Industry News

DOC.TEXT: Congress is bracing itself for hard-core politics in an election-year renewal of the flag-burning issue now that the Supreme Court overturned a flag protection law. Congressional Democratic leaders strongly oppose amending the Constitution to ban flag burning. But votes were being scheduled around such symbolic days as the Fourth of July and Flag Day, June 14. House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., promised Monday that the House would vote on a proposed amendment by July 4. Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., chairman of the House Judiciary subcommittee on the Constitution and a leading House opponent of an amendment, predicted an amendment would fail again.

Former national security adviser John M. Poindexter received a six-month sentence and a stern lecture from a judge who said he undermined democracy by lying to Congress about the Iran-Contra affair. Poindexter became the first of seven people convicted in the scandal to receive a prison term when he was sentenced Monday by U.S. District Judge Harold H. Greene. The judge said Poindexter, who plans to appeal, deserved incarceration as the ``decision-making head of the Iran-Contra operation.'' Probation ``would be tantamount to a statement that a scheme to lie (to) and obstruct Congress is of no great moment,'' Greene said.

East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, fresh from an unprecedented White House visit, says NATO must be ``significantly changed'' if Soviet concerns about membership for a united Germany are to be met. But White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater says the United States believes ``considerable progress'' has been made in persuading Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev that a unified Germany inside the Western alliance will not threaten Soviet security or European peace. ``I made clear to him what psychological difficulties this would signify,'' de Maiziere said after his Oval Office meeting with President Bush. ``I made clear to him that it must be a significantly changed NATO in order to be acceptable to our East European neighbors.'' De Maiziere said he and Bush agreed that creating a new, lasting and stable security order in Europe is possible only ``if the role of the Soviet Union is written into it.''

Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has pledged to make peace a top priority of his new right-wing government, but he faces a major task in convincing Arab enemies he is not a ``monster seeking war.'' In an apparent effort to allay Washington's fears, Shamir and leading political allies have softened rhetoric about settlement-building that U.S. policy considers an obstacle to peace. Officials of Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc suggest their new government, which won parliamentary approval on Monday, will move quickly to improve ties with the Bush administration. They acknowledge that Israel's new government has an image problem.
