For Release Monday PMs, June 25, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Lobbyists' Ranks Grow But Most States Lack Oversight on Their Activities
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto, Logo, Graphic
DOC.TEXT: More lobbyists than ever are swarming through state legislatures, spending more money than ever before to influence lawmakers. But a 50-state look at lobbyists by The Associated Press found few states effectively monitor their activities. Rules regulating lobbyists are riddled with loopholes, and the legislators who make those rules receive lobbyists' campaign contributions, meals and gifts. In most states it is virtually impossible to know how much lobbyists are spending and which legislators they spend it on. ``Money buys access, and access buys a higher degreee of success,'' said Chuck Sauvage of the Washington state branch of Common Cause, which itself lobbies for more accountability by those who make and influence legislation. ``We're in danger of seeing government of the special interests, by the special interests and for the special interests.'' The growth in the number of lobbyists comes at a time when the responsibility for funding social welfare programs is shifting from Congress to the states, and legislatures are tackling such complex issues as the environment, abortion, gun control, smoking restrictions and car insurance. Pick any aspect of life and there is apt to be a lobbyist for or against it. Lobbyists represent baby doctors and undertakers; insurers and the lawyers who sue for claims; environmentalists and companies who bury toxic waste; gun control groups and the National Rifle Association; health care providers and tobacco and liquor interests; churches and casinos; corporations and unions; farmers and bankers; the media and local governments. Lobbyists persuade lawmakers to pass, kill or amend laws to benefit the special interest that hired them. They have a constitutional right to air their side, and they are an important source of analysis and expertise for understaffed legislatures that were created as citizen assemblies. Lobbyists get little mention in civics lessons. Yet leaving out lobbyists from the way a bill becomes a law is like having a road map with only interstate highways. They are the access ramps, back roads, shortcuts, cutoffs and detours. Lobbyists outnumber lawmakers nearly 6-to-1. The AP survey found more than 42,500 registered lobbyists at state capitols, an increase of 20 percent from the Council of State Government's registry four years ago when Ronald Reagan was in office. ``That new federalism Mr. Reagan gave us didn't necessarily mean less government; it sort of meant a change of address,'' said Roland Luedtke, a former lawmaker and lieutenant governor in Nebraska. Lawmakers insist they do not sell votes while lobbyists say they do not buy them. Indeed, examples of outright bribery are rare, but critics say the system is so ambiguous that wrongdoing becomes a matter of perception. ``It's ripe for abuse. There's the potential for corruption and undue influence,'' said Kirby Hendee, a retired lobbyist and former state senator in Wisconsin. ``People have got to get mad. Somebody's stealing the heart of government and they don't seem excited about it.'' Some point to campaign contributions as the most corrosive influence. ``It's a form of bribery. It's not cash under the table, but it's the equivalent of cash,'' said Florida Sen. Tom Brown. ``The public perception is that if you take things you're obligated to them. It's patently absurd to think otherwise.'' What do the persuaders get for their money? ``Access. It's access, the kind of access the typical voter doesn't have,'' said Pennsylvania Rep. Allen Kukovich. ``If they get on the phone or make an appointment, snap, they want to get in there. They want your ear. This is America. Money talks. Money buys access. ``I can't honestly say anyone's for sale. I think there are some members who are for lease,'' Kukovich said. ``I don't think lobbyists are bad. The problem is, I think, they have too much influence.'' How much lobbyists spend and how they spend it causes the most alarm among those who feel special interests dominate legislatures. For example, the day after lobbyists for Alamo Rent A Car treated 27 members of Florida's House Rules Committee to a dinner of steak, red snapper and conch chowder last year, the panel voted Alamo's way and killed a proposal to limit how much rental car companies charge for collision damage waivers. This year, Florida-based Alamo won a victory in the House Insurance Committee. It rejected a bill that would have forced car companies to charge less for refueling cars. Before the vote, at least 12 of the 17 lawmakers on the panel got $9,000 in campaign contributions _ all legal _ from rental car interests. Chairman Peter Deutsch got $1,000 each from Alamo and Hertz, which were on opposing sides. Alamo also provided free use of a Buick for four days to Rep. Steve Geller, chairman of the House Insurance Subcommittee, who voted Alamo's way. Geller said accepting the car was a misunderstanding and he paid for it after his using it became public. Car companies and lawmakers said no votes were bought or sold, but Kevin Bloom of the Florida Consumer Action Network said the two actions were revealing. ``It's one example of special interests like Alamo using affluence to influence the outcome of legislative matters,'' Bloom said. ``There's no way you can take gifts, or favors or anything of value and not be influenced.'' The AP examination of lobbyists found a hodgepodge of laws regulating them and their spending activities. Campaign contributions and gifts that are perfectly legal in some states would bring criminal censure in others. Most of the laws were written by lawmakers; only a handful of states have regulations enacted by voters. Four states don't require lobbyists to report what they spend trying to influence legislators. Lobbyists in the other states rarely have to identify the lawmakers they wine and dine or give gifts to. State governments spend little to monitor lobbying, ranging from about $750,000 in California to an estimated $400 in Oklahoma. Twenty-three states devote only one or a part-time staffer to oversight. A century ago, Massachusetts made the first attempt at making special interests accountable by requiring a detailed statement of all expenses and registration of those working for special interests. Only one state, Wisconsin, forbids lawmakers from accepting a gift, trip, meal, or anything of value _ even a cup of coffee _ from a lobbyist. But even it allows special interests to make campaign contributions. All states require lobbyists to register, but four _ Georgia, Louisiana, Utah and Wyoming _ don't require any reports on what they spend. The rules in most of the rest are written so lobbyists generally can report only their overall spending and don't have to identify individual legislators on whom money is spent. Of the 46 states that require some degree of reporting of lobbyists' spending, 29 do not audit the reports for accuracy and merely try to make sure the reports are filed on time. Twenty-eight of the 46 conducted no investigations of the previous reporting period. In a typical comment, McDonald T. Coker, assistant director of Delaware's Legislative Council, said of his state's law: ``There is no accounting system. ... The law is so loose you couldn't catch anyone if you wanted to.''

DOC.TEXT: Almost as revealing as what some lobbyists report is what they don't. Last year, California had an estimated $90 million reported spent by lobbyists. Yet in a loophole-ridden state like Pennsylvania, lobbyists as a group reported spending $362,000. That's a fraction of what was reported in smaller states like Connecticut, Montana, Mississippi, Hawaii, Nebraska, New Hampshire, South Carolina, Kentucky and Kansas. The top lobbyist in at least five states reported spending more than was reported by Pennsylvania's 799 lobbyists combined. Many former elected officials have found second careers as lobbyists; among ex-governors representing special interest groups are Marvin Mandel of Maryland and Anthony Earl and Martin Schreiber of Wisconsin. Some of the best paid lobbyists make six-figure incomes that are several times greater than even the highest paid legislators. In Maryland, for instance, lobbyist Bruce Bereano got more than $1 million in fees from 53 clients in 1989. The persuaders, not surprisingly, aren't in favor of more reporting. ``Requiring a lobbyist to report doesn't make them honest or dishonest. No lobbyist is going to report doing something illegal,'' said Hobson Waits, a lobbyist for the Electric Power Associations of Mississippi Inc. Watchdogs agree, but they say the point is the public interest would be best served if special interests reported in detail what they do to influence legislators. ``We've cut the average citizen out of the process,'' said Barry Kauffman of Pennsylvania Common Cause. ``It's the contemporary golden rule: Those with the gold make the rules,'' Kauffman said. ``People are turned off. They've passed apathy and gone to alienation. It's not their system anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Few Legislators, Lobbyists Prosecuted for Vote-Buying
With PM-The Persuaders I
DOC.TEXT: Lobbyists' largess to legislators has often upset citizens, but cases rarely have wound up in court in recent years. California Sen. Joseph Montoya was convicted in February of selling votes to special interests who were actually undercover federal agents. He was found guilty of racketeering, money laundering and five counts of extortion for demanding campaign contributions and speaking fees in exchange for votes. Last year, federal prosecutors in West Virginia won convictions or guilty pleas from two former Senate presidents, a Senate majority leader, a member of the House of Delegates, two lobbyists and a Senate aide in vote-buying cases. In Wisconsin, two dozen legislators and lobbyists violated the state's ethics law last year by accepting or offering meals, hotel rooms, tickets to sporting events or travel expenses. Wisconsin is the only state that bars legislators from accepting _ or lobbyists from giving them _ anything of value, even a soft drink. Eighteen of the cases involved inadvertent or minor infractions, but Sen. William Shoemaker pleaded guilty after he was charged with accepting illegal loans from a lobbyist and stealing money from his campaign committee. Shoemaker resigned his seat and served 60 days in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Businessmen Caused Furor With Campaign Contributions
With PM-The Persuaders I
DOC.TEXT: Chicken magnate Lonnie ``Bo'' Pilgrim came to the Capitol last July to argue for changes he wanted made in the workmen's compensation program. While he was at it, he handed out $10,000 checks to eight of the 31 Texas senators. Pilgrim said it was just a way to get access to the senators so they'd listen to his case. ``All it does is they will answer a telephone call or give you an appointment to listen, to hear issues,'' he said. One senator returned his check before reporters learned of them, and the others followed suit after news reports triggered a public outcry. Travis County District Attorney Ronnie Earle called the handouts ``outrageous'' but apparently legal. It wasn't a bribe under Texas law if reported as a campaign contribution. ``This is not a simple area of the law. It's not like somebody going to a 7-Eleven and saying, `Stick 'em up.' It's much more complicated,'' Earle said.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Americans Dubious of Lobbyists and Legislators Alike
With PM-The Persuaders I
With Graphic
DOC.TEXT: Americans believe state lawmakers regularly swap their votes for payoffs, and they favor strict regulation of political lobbying to curtail such influence peddling, a national poll has found. By overwhelming majorities, respondents to the Media General-Associated Press poll said state legislators are overly influenced by gifts or campaign contributions from lobbyists, and they favored banning such favors. Half the respondents, furthermore, said lawmakers are more interested in raising money for their re-election than in passing good laws. Nine in 10 favored limiting the amount candidates can spend to run for state office. Nearly two-thirds of the 1,071 adults polled expressed negative views of the ethical behavior of state lawmakers. An even stronger majority, 74 percent, rated lobbyists' ethical performance as ``only fair'' or ``poor.'' Lobbyists pervade the lawmaking process, representing businesses, unions and other organizations that have an interest in proposed laws. They seek, through information and persuasion, to draw legislators to their view. Lobbyists work at all levels of government, although much attention is focused on their efforts in Washington. The survey sought to gauge public awareness of lobbying at the state level. It found that statehouse lobbying is widely recognized _ and largely criticized. Nearly half the respondents said lobbyists have ``a great amount'' of influence in shaping state laws, yet only a quarter believed the information supplied by lobbyists to lawmakers is reliable. Fully half expressed an unfavorable opinion of lobbyists and said their influence in shaping laws is too great, the poll found. That criticism of lobbyists rose among the most educated respondents. Support for new lobbying regulations was overwhelming: Eight in 10 said they would back a disclosure law ``requiring lobbyists to publicly report all contacts they have with state lawmakers.'' Even more, nearly nine in 10, said it should be illegal for lobbyists to give gifts to state lawmakers; three-quarters said lobbyists should be banned from making political campaign contributions; and two-thirds said lobbyists should be barred from paying for legislators' meals. Few such restrictions are currently in place. No state requires lobbyists to report all their contacts with state legislators. Nor does any state ban lobbyists from making campaign contributions _ that would be an infrigement of their constitutional right to participate in the political process. Only one state _ Wisconsin _ prohibits legislators from accepting gifts or meals from legislators. The support for restrictions appeared to stem from concern over the effect of favors from lobbyists. Eighty-three percent said lawmakers are overly influenced by campaign contributions from lobbyists, and 75 percent said gifts from lobbyists create undue influence. In an even more damning assessment, respondents saw some forms of influence peddling as commonplace. Eight in 10 said lawmakers sometimes vote the way lobbyists want them to in exchange for gifts from the lobbyists, and nearly nine in 10 said lawmakers sometimes vote the way some organization wants them to in order to get campaign contributions from that organization. About six in 10 said they believe such incidents happen either ``most of the time'' or ``a good part of the time.'' The concern over lobbying and its effect on lawmaking spanned the political spectrum, with similar shares of respondents in accord regardless of ideology or party affiliation. Many lawmakers complain that the cost of political campaigns makes them devote considerable time to fund-raising, and the poll found a broad public perception that fund-raising is paramount to politicians. It asked, ``Which of these do you think is more important to most state lawmakers _ passing good laws, or raising money for their next re-election campaign?'' Fifty-one percent said fund-raising came first, and an additional 7 percent were unsure. Eighty-nine percent favored limits on the amount of money candidates can spend to run for state office. But just six in 10 of that group backed some form of public funding for political campaigns, even though courts have ruled that spending cannot be limited unless public financing is provided. The poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points. It was conducted Sept. 14-24, when most state legislatures were out of session. That time was selected to avoid having opinions on current legislative action influence more general views on legislators and lobbyists. Media General Inc., a communications company based in Richmond, Va., publishes the Richmond Times-Dispatch, the Richmond News Leader, the Tampa (Fla.) Tribune and the Winston-Salem (N.C.) Journal, and operates TV stations WXFL in Tampa, WCBD in Charleston, S.C., and WJKS in Jacksonville, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Legislative Appetizer: Entertaining Is Like `Wrench to the Plumber'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Business people know the value of entertaining their clients over a few drinks and a sumptuous meal in a relaxed setting. It's a cost of forging working relationships. And no one does it better than the special interests influencing state legislators in the 50 state capitols. Wining and dining goes with lobbying as easily as gin mixes with vermouth. ``The entertainment with legislators is the most important part of our business. It is the wrench to the plumber,'' said New Mexico lobbyist Edwin T. Mahr. He estimated 80 percent of the $1 million his firm spent in 1987-89 went for such entertainment. Lobbyists and lawmakers insist votes aren't exchanged for meals, but critics say special interests get special attention at the expense of the public interest. In a 50-state look at lobbying, The Associated Press found a crazy-quilt of laws that lacks significant oversight and fails to give an accurate national picture of how much special interests spend on entertaining and which lawmakers they spend it on. Getting to know the people who pass, change or kill legislation is vital for lobbyists hoping to persuade them to take the side of their special interest. ``There could be nothing worse for a lobbyist than not to be recognized,'' said Melvin Cooper, executive director of the Alabama Ethics Commission. ``They're selling ideas, just like somebody else is selling a car,'' said Jan Konesey of Delaware Common Cause, a group that itself lobbies for laws to make government more open to public view. ``When lobbyists go out to dinner with legislators or play golf with them or take them to a football game, you're just building relationships that make you a better salesman.'' Whether those contacts go too far is another matter. And voters have little to go on other than the word of legislators and lobbyists that there isn't undue influence. Four states require no reporting by lobbyists of their spending at all, and only 31 of the remaining 46 require lobbyists to break down spending into categories such as entertainment. However, the 31 states have thresholds whereby a lawmaker being entertained doesn't have to be identified unless the amount spent is above a set amount. In Arizona, for example, lobbyists don't have to list separate expenses if they spend less then $25 for each issue they discuss with a legislator. So a lobbyist could buy a lawmaker a $74 meal and not have to disclose it if they talked about three issues. ``The people who get hurt are those who are not at the table, and that's usually the taxpayer. There is this insider's game that is almost exclusionary of the public,'' said Chuck Sauvage of Common Cause in Washington state, which itself lobbies for more accountability by those who make and influence laws. Some states are considering tighter rules. On June 6, California voters overwhelmingly passed an ethics-in-government measure. Among other things, it prohibits lawmakers from accepting speaking fees and requires the legislature to bar or strictly limit gifts to elected officials And the public in general has strong opinions about accountability. In a Media General-Associated Press poll, 75 percent of 1,071 adults across the nation said gifts from lobbyists create undue influence. Eight in 10 said lawmakers sometimes vote the way lobbyists want them to in exchange for gifts. Eight in 10 said they would back a disclosure law requiring lobbyists to publicly report all contacts they have with state lawmakers. Contacts pay off, Nebraska Sen. Ernie Chambers contends. ``There have always been those senators who have gone to the trough with a glad heart _ the free meals, the free booze and the free whatever else they could get,'' Chambers said. ``And then they say that this is just business, that it doesn't buy their vote or influence them unduly. Bull!'' Florida Rep. Ron Glickman said: ``Lobbyists have natural advantages because they have things members want _ financial contributions and gifts. It may not be direct trade, but there's a feeling of good will. When an issue comes up for a vote. They'll say: `We helped you. It's time for you to help.''' Lobbyists do expect something in return for their hospitality, even if it's not an outright exchange, said Kirby Hendee, a retired lobbyist and former state senator in Wisconsin. ``If you buy a guy enough meals and buy him enough drinks, he's going to vote your way over time. You can't repeal human nature,'' Hendee said. The special interests decry the notion that the way to a lawmaker's vote is through his stomach. ``If you can buy him for a steak and a martini, he wasn't worth the time of having dinner with,'' said Victor Condello, a partner in a New York lobbying firm that makes more than $1 million annually. But lobbyists who don't have deep pockets appreciate the value of wining and dining. ``The problem is access if you can't afford to wine and dine. One feels lost,'' said Phil Kaplan, who lobbies on behalf of the poor in Olympia, Wash. And access is the name of the game. ``To me, access is the most important thing in the world,'' said John Larson, chairman of the California Fair Political Practices Commission. ``My God, you give me two hours with the president of the United States, that's all the access I would need!'' Not all entertaining is done at the dinner table. In New Mexico, lobbyist Truett Gill spent $300 to stock snack items for House leaders in 1989. Utah's 29 senators and their families were invited to spend a free weekend at the Deer Valley ski resort last year, and most them accepted, while considering a tax exemption for capital improvements at ski areas. The first attempt to pass the bill failed, although a modified version later passed. Florida has a lobbyist known as the ``beer fairy.'' A legislator announces he wants to have a party, and someone leaves cases of beer anonymously at the doorstep. Florida lawmakers and their families also are offered a free trip to Disney World every year, at a cost of $200 to $2,000 per lawmaker. Lawmakers recently passed a bill to prohibit customers from selling unused entrance tickets to the theme park, but House Rules Chairman Fred Lippman said the trip had no bearing on his vote. ``Mickey, Minnie and Goofy sure as hell don't convince us what to do with Disney World,'' Lippman said.

DOC.HEAD: Remodeler-Renovator Bob Vila is `Home Again' on TV
DOC.TEXT: Bob Vila got kicked out of the ``House'' and decided to go ``Home.'' For 10 years, Vila was host of ``This Old House,'' the highest-rated show on public television, teaching viewers home renovation and remodeling techniques. Then he was fired for making too many commercials. This fall, he'll be back on the job _ on commercial TV. ``The new show is aptly named `Home Again' because, in many ways, it puts me back on TV where I started 10, 11 years ago,'' Vila said from BVTV, his production company in Massachusetts. ``I'm doing construction and remodeling stories that are relevant to the remodeling homeowner and home builder.'' That wasn't the case on the Emmy Award-winning ``This Old House,'' which spared no expense when it undertook costly renovation projects, he said. ``I'm sure our viewers were entertained and pleased to watch some of the costly jobs that we did, but I could not relate to thousand-dollar toilets and other gilded lilies,'' Vila said. ``It's always ironic that people in public television have that money-is-no-object attitude,'' he said. With 15 million viewers, ``This Old House'' made Vila a celebrity among do-it-yourselfers. He cashed in with a string of TV commercials for Time-Life Books and various home improvement products. That grated on his show's corporate underwriters and on Boston's WGBH-TV, which produced the show. The underwriters saw Vila speaking for the competition. WGBH said Vila was hurting public TV's image. To put it kindly, he was nailed. ``It was tough for me for three months,'' said Vila, who found a new sponsor in Sears, Roebuck and Co. ``Home Again,'' syndicated by Group W, will air starting in September in 85 percent of the country, including on network affiliate stations in 24 of the top 25 television markets. ``As far as public television is concerned, I gave them 10 great years of my life,'' Vila said. ``I feel like I've done my duty for public TV.'' He still is a commercial spokesman for Time-Life Books, and he'll appear for Sears' line of Craftsman tools and home improvement supplies. But his other commercial ties, Vila said, have lapsed. ``Home Again'' will have a distinctly different flavor from ``This Old House,'' which continues on PBS. Vila and co-producer Michael Ferrone, a former developer, made 13 episodes of ``Home Again'' building a house on Cape Cod for $50 a square foot. In the Northeast, $60 to $80 a square foot is reasonable, Vila said. For fancy remodeling jobs featured in magazine layouts, he said, the cost is probably $100 a square foot. Vila said they kept costs down ``by doing drywall instead of skim-coat plaster, pine flooring instead of oak, by approaching everything with the budget in mind.'' Instead of master carpenter Norm Abrams, who remains on PBS, Vila has a new sidekick in carpenter Bob Ryley of Brewster, Mass. ``It's a happy circumstance, because I didn't think he'd be as good before the camera as he is a carpenter,'' Vila said. ``He has a pixie Irish quality that comes out nicely on the tube.'' The season's final 13 episodes will cover the renovation of a two-story ``graystone'' in the Wicker Park section of Chicago, which won't be confused with the affluent middle-class neighborhoods of ``This Old House.'' ``The neighborhood is certainly one that's in transition,'' Vila said. ``It's a wonderful mix of Polish, American blacks and Hispanics.'' Whether there's a second season, Vila said, will depend on the audience and the critics. But he said he's not going to worry about the future. ``I just feel like I'm home again with a better chance for an audience,'' he said.

Elsewhere in television ... CINEASTES AND AUTEURS DEPT.: Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Martin Scorsese are interviewed by TV film critics Roger Ebert and Gene Siskel in the duo's latest syndicated television special on ``the future of the movies.'' In addition to profiling the directors' careers, Siskel and Ebert will discuss the advent of wide-screen, high-definition TV and its potential to bring theater-quality sound and images to home viewing. The directors also will discuss their involvement in efforts to protect great films from physical deterioration and artistic mutilation. The special's syndication ``window'' is today through July 1. DOC.HEAD: Finnish Bass Looms Large on Opera Scene
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Brooding,'' ``hulking,'' ``towering,'' ``fearsome,'' ``wonderfully cavernous,'' ``superbly sinister,'' ``frighteningly big and mean.'' These are some of the terrible things opera critics like to say about Finnish bass Matti Salminen. Their words apply as well to his giant-size voice as to his menacing, 6-foot-5 figure. ``When I was young, my voice was smaller and more lyrical,'' Salminen, 45, said in a recent interview. ``But I studied and worked hard and it grew.'' That's an understatement, as anyone can attest who has heard his thundering tones easily penetrate the 4,000-seat Metropolitan Opera House. He was much in evidence there this spring, singing in all four operas of Wagner's `Ring Cycle.'' He was the greedy giant Fafner in ``Das Rheingold''; the cuckolded husband, Hunding, in ``Die Walkuere''; Fafner again in ``Siegfried,'' this time transformed into a sleeping dragon who is first awakened and then slain by the title character, expiring to music that is ``so beautiful, just like a Schubert song''; and the villainous Hagen who gives Siegfried and Bruennhilde a rough time of it in ``Die Goetterdaemmerung.'' The last role is by far the biggest and most challenging. ``Hagen's personality is vicious from the ground up, but he is one of the most interesting characters in the whole `Ring,''' Salminen said. ``Even though he doesn't appear in the earlier operas, his appearance is being built up to from the start.'' Hagen is the illegitimate son of Alberich, the dwarf whose theft of gold from the Rhinemaidens causes all the trouble to begin with. Alberich loses his treasure to Wotan, king of the gods, and spends the rest of the cycle scheming to get it back. Where the cringing, cowardly father fails, the daring, dastardly son almost succeeds. ``From Alberich's weakness, all of a sudden comes a strong figure,'' Salminen said. ``He manipulates everyone; he has incredible slyness.'' Salminen plays Hagen to the hilt. His voice brims with malice as he plots to ruin the heroic lovers and insinuates his way into their confidence. The pleasure he takes in his own scheming is evident from the gleam in his eye and the way he struts about the stage. It's a performance that has earned him unanimous raves from the reviewers. His Hagen will be one of the highlights of the Public Broadcasting Service's telecast of the Met's ``Ring Cycle'' production on four consecutive nights, June 18-21. He also will be heard as Fafner, but Hunding will be sung by German bass Kurt Moll. Wagner has played a major part in Salminen's career. He first came to international prominence in 1976 as Hunding and the giant Fasolt at the centennial production by Patrice Chereau at Bayreuth, West Germany. His Met debut was a triumph in the role of King Marke in Wagner's ``Tristan und Isolde,'' whose 20-minute monologue usually puts audiences to sleep. Last season he sang Daland in Wagner's ``Der Fliegende Hollaender.'' He has also performed such non-Wagnerian parts as the comic villain Osmin in Mozart's ``Abduction From the Seraglio'' and Rocco the jailer in Beethoven's ``Fidelio.'' Yet it rankles him that his Met career is not more varied. In Europe, he gets to portray the title role in Mussorgsky's ``Boris Godunov'' and Phillip II in Verdi's ``Don Carlos.' ``The Met tells me they really only want me for the German repertory,'' Salminen said with a sigh. ``Here I'm allowed to sing Ramfis (the priest in Verdi's `Aida'), but that's not much compensation.'' Salminen, who is married and has two children, has a home in Zurich, Switzerland, and also one in Helsinki, Finland. He grew up in the town of Turko, where at age 17 he won an amateur singing contest. Four years later he was singing in the Finnish National Opera chorus and appearing there in small roles such as Charles V in ``Don Carlos'' and Monterone in ``Rigoletto.'' In 1969, he went to Rome to study with vocal coach Luigi Ricci, and his career took off in the early 1970s. He is just one of several Finnish singers who have made names for themselves abroad in recent years. Others include baritone Jorma Hynninen, soprano Karita Mattila and the late bass Martti Talvela, whom Salminen mourns as ``a father figure to all us Finnish singers.'' Salminen said part of the reason they were driven to seek international careers was the lack of a Finnish opera house suitable for major productions. ``In a country of 5 million people, we have had only one tiny house that with great trouble could squeeze maybe six or eight violins into the orchestra pit,'' he said. ``So if you wanted to do something, you had to go outside.'' He now sings every summer at the Savonlinna Festival in Finland and looks forward to being involved with a new national opera house scheduled to open in Helsinki in 1993. He will not appear at the Met next season but will be back in 1991-92 for Ramfis, Daland, Rocco, Osmin and the Commendatore in Mozart's ``Don Giovanni.''

DOC.HEAD: Adv for Weekend Editions, June 16-17

DOC.TEXT: The United States and Mexico have taken the first steps toward negotiating a free-trade pact that ultimately could create a single North American market, the White House announced. President Bush and Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari agreed at a private dinner Sunday night to have their trade officials begin preparations for the formal talks, Bush spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Monday. The two countries will seek a pact that will ``improve and expand the flow of goods, services and investment between the United States and Mexico,'' Fitzwater said.

Donald Trump will get $60 million in new loans and some needed breathing room to shore up his real estate and casino empire under a tentative deal struck with his bankers. The proposal, which was worked out over the weekend, also would allow Trump to suspend interest payments on $2 billion in outstanding debt, sources familiar with the deal said Monday. In exchange, Trump has pledged as collateral some of his remaining real estate and casino assets that aren't otherwise committed to secure loans. Those assets include the Trump Plaza Hotel in Atlantic City, N.J., and the Trump Tower building in Manhattan, one source said.

Outspoken Chrysler Corp. executive Bennett Bidwell ended months of speculation about his early retirement and joined the executive exodus from the No. 3 automaker. The departure of the company's most colorful executive next to Chairman Lee Iacocca was announced Monday and is effective Jan. 1. It was the fourth resignation announced in the past six weeks. Bidwell is chairman of Chrysler Motors, in charge of car and truck making operations.

Korean Air signed a $4.8 billion order for 23 Boeing 747-400s, the third largest ever received by Boeing Co. in terms of contract value. The contract, signed Monday, includes spare parts and training and commits Korean Air to more of Boeing's most sophisticated and highest capacity jetliners than any other carrier except Japan Air Lines. JAL has signed up for 40 of the world's largest passenger jets. The Korean order is the third multibillion-dollar purchase of Boeing aircraft in as many weeks. The others also were from Asian air carriers: a $2 billion order from the Chinese government and a $3.1 billion order from Japan Air Lines.

One of every six jobs created through the turn of the century is expected to be in California, reflecting the continued shift of economic activity to the Sun Belt, the government said. National employment opportunities are expected to rise 14.3 percent to 151.5 million jobs, the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis said Monday. The study projected that the fastest job growth will be in Nevada, up 31.5 percent to 847,000, and Arizona, up 26.7 percent to 2.3 million.

The federal government can cut benefits paid to recipients who relied on a government employee's incorrect answers about their eligibility, the Supreme Court ruled. The court's 7-2 ruling Monday said the government, in such cases, does not have to pay for its employees' mistakes. The justices said the government always may deny benefits to those who do not qualify _ even when their eligibility was lost due to the erroneous advice they received.

Congress may have to provide a new savings and loan bailout fund _ roughly equal to last summer's $50 billion measure _ this year, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee said. The Resolution Trust Corp., the bailout agency created last August, ``appears to have plenty of money to meet its immediate needs. But Congress will have to act, probably later this year, to provide additional funds,'' Sen. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., said Monday on the Senate floor.

A Japanese businessman and his bond trader-wife settled federal allegations that they traded in the stock of John O. Butler Co. using illegal insider information about a pending buyout. Jiro Yamazaki and his wife, Ikuko Sekiguchi-Yamazaki, agreed to pay $99,703 in fines, restitution and interest without admitting or denying wrongdoing, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Monday.

Forty years after it introduced Orlon to the world of sweaters, socks and knit outerwear, Du Pont Co. said it will stop production of the acrylic fiber as soon as possible. The fiber has been overproduced worldwide and consumers now prefer cotton and polyester fabrics, Paul G. Gillease, director of Du Pont's textile division, said Monday.

The stock market snapped out of last week's slump Monday with a rally led by blue chips. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, down 38.59 points last week, rebounded 30.19 to 2,892.57. The dollar was lower against most major currencies except the Japanese yen. Bond prices drifted slightly lower. Corn and soybean futures posted strong gains; wheat futures advanced; energy futures were mixed; pork bellies surged, leading livestock and meat futures higher; cocoa futures plummeted; and precious metals rose.

DOC.HEAD: Interest Rates Higher at Auction
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose at the latest auction to their highest level in two weeks. The Treasury Department sold $8.6 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.73 percent on Monday, up from 7.69 percent last week. Another $8.6 billion in six-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 7.64 percent, up from 7.62 percent last week. The rates were the highest since May 29 when three-month bills sold for 7.80 percent and six-month bills averaged 7.74 percent. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 7.99 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,804.60 and 8.06 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,613.80. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, fell to 8.08 percent last week, down from 8.18 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: Bidwell Joins Ranks of Former Chrysler Execs
LaserPhoto DT8 of June 11
DOC.TEXT: Another key vacancy looms in Chrysler Corp.'s dwindling executive ranks after Bennett Bidwell, the outspoken head of car- and truck-making operations, said he will step down at the end of the year. Bidwell on Monday confirmed weeks of speculation about his tenure by announcing his plan to retire effective Jan. 1, 1991, at the age of 63. ``After 37 years in the automotive business,'' he said, ``I think it is time to stop worrying about 10-day sales reports. I'm in reasonably good health, but it's time to decelerate a little.'' Company spokesman Tom Houston said it was too soon to name Bidwell's successor. The departure of Chrysler's most colorful executive next to Chairman Lee Iacocca further drains the company's executive pool, which has suffered three other departures in the past six weeks. Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald left Chrysler May 30 to head a three-union bid to buy United Airlines for $4.54 billion. Michael Hammes, vice president for international operations, left earlier in May to head Black & Decker Corp.'s toolmaking operation. Chrysler Treasurer Frederick Zuckerman has said he plans to leave this summer. Because of those departures and Bidwell's expected retirement, Iacocca said late last week he would stay on past the Dec. 8, 1991, expiration of his four-year contract. It is unclear how long Iacocca will remain chairman and chief executive officer. The executive exodus has left few in line for Iacocca's job. The main contenders are Robert S. Miller, who took over Greenwald's title and many of his duties, and Robert Lutz, who assumed a few of Greenwald's responsibilities but had no change in his title of president of Chrysler Motors. The departures come as Chrysler struggles to recapture profit and market share. The company earned $71 million in the first quarter of this year, down 80 percent from a year ago, and is believed to have lost money on its core auto-making operations. Analysts don't expect any significant earnings improvement until the fourth quarter of this year. Last October, Chrysler began a $1.5 billion cost-cutting program, which included a reduction in the white-collar work force of about 2,500 people. At the end of last month, Chrysler's share of the U.S. car market stood at 8.3 percent, down from 9.6 percent a year earlier. Its share of the light truck market slipped to 20.4 percent from 21.6 percent. The financial problems have led to speculation that Chrysler could become the target of a takeover offer or stake purchase by some overseas automaker, such as Fiat SpA of Italy or Mitsubishi Motors Corp. of Japan.

DOC.HEAD: Damage in Asia Seen from US-Mexico Free Trade
DOC.TEXT: A free-trade pact between the United States and Mexico should spur an increase in investment in Mexico and make the country a potent competitor to the newly industrialized countries of Asia, analysts said. Figures recently issued by the U.S. Department of Labor showed that in 1987, the most recent year for which overall figures were available, it cost manufacturers $1.57 an hour to hire a worker in Mexico. That compared with $1.79 in South Korea, $2.12 in Hong Kong, $2.31 in Singapore and $13.40 in this country. In addition to low wages, Mexico's proximity to the United States gives it an advantage over Asian and European competitors in lower transport costs, said Nora Lustig, a former consultant to the Mexican government and a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution. She said she expected to see more industry develop in northern Mexico, near the U.S. border. She saw textiles and electronics as two areas where Mexico has much to offer investors. Ms. Lustig and Ernest L. Preeg, a former State Department trade specialist who holds a chair in international business at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, said prospects of a free-trade pact would pay immediate psychological dividends even if a treaty takes time to iron out. Investment is likely to increase as business people are reassured by the prospect of steady sales in the huge U.S. market for the Mexican goods, they said. In addition to U.S. and Canadian investors, companies in other industrial countries will want to start manufacturing in a place where costs are low and restrictions will be few on sales to the United States, Preeg said. Confidence stemming from free-trade prospects also could bring home some of the tens of billions of dollars wealthy Mexicans have stashed abroad, he said. The two analysts saw broad advantages for both Mexico and the United States from a free-trade agreement. The two countries want to see more jobs created in Mexico so more Mexicans will stay at home instead of migrating, legally or illegally, to the United States. Ms. Lustig said a treaty would give U.S. companies a chance to boost sales of machinery to equip the new factories in Mexico, and the possibility of making products such as auto parts more cheaply than at home. Not everyone sees the prospects so favorably. Last week Lane Kirkland, head of the AFL-CIO, and Shirley Carr, head of the Canadian Labor Congress, foresaw more unemployment in the United States and Canada from a U.S.-Mexico free trade agreement. The Council on Henispheric Affairs, another private study group, predicted that foreign companies would exploit Mexican labor and invest their earnings in other countries.

DOC.HEAD: `Money World' TV Show Planned For Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: ``Adam Smith's Money World,'' public television's weekly look at business, will be shown this fall on Soviet television, dubbed in Russian, according to The New York Times. The export of the show produced by Alvin H. Perlmutter Inc. and public TV station WNET appears to be another example of the Soviets' increased acceptance of capitalism. American shows are rarely found on Soviet TV. ``Adam Smith has come to the land of Karl Marx,'' said the show's host, referring to his namesake, the 18th-century Scottish economist who formulated the theories of capitalism. In interviews published Tuesday, the show's host, whose real name is George J.W. Goodman, and his Soviet colleagues said much of the information presented on the program would be beyond the typical Soviet viewer's comprehension. ``I think there's enormous confusion because the signals aren't clear there as they go to a market economy.'' Co Star, a Soviet joint venture company that produces and distributes films, will get the broadcast rights to ``Money World,'' and will sell 90 seconds of advertising to U.S. companies doing business in the Soviet Union. Those companies include General Motors and AT&T. In return, the show's U.S. producers will get technical support for a public television special on perestroika and glasnost, as well as for segments of ``Adam Smith's Money World.'' Goodman said talks with Co Star began last year when he was planning the hourlong special on perestroika and glasnost. No money is being exchanged in the deal, the Times said. ``Money World'' is underwritten by the Metropolitan Life Insurance and Unisys companies, the Times said.

DOC.HEAD: Amid Takeover Rumors, Foxboro Exploring Possible `Alliance'
DOC.TEXT: Foxboro Co., a leading international maker of manufacturing control systems, says it is looking at what it termed an ``alliance'' with other firms that could include the sale of the company. The announcement Monday came amid speculation that began last week about a possible takeover of Foxboro. The talk drove up Foxboro's stock, which closed Monday at $30 a share, up $1.50, in New York Stock Exchange composite trading. A week ago the stock sold for $24 a share. Last year it traded as low as $18.62{, said Albert Turner, a securities analyst at Duff & Phelps in Chicago. Foxboro systems are used to record and control processes in manufacturing such as temperature, pressure, humidity and liquid levels. Its customers are largely in the chemical and petroleum industries and include such familiar names as Exxon Corp. and Dow Chemical Co. The international company, based in the suburb of Foxboro, employs 7,000 people. The company reported a net loss for 1989 of $4.6 million, or 37 cents a share, on sales of $598 million. In a brief announcement, the company said it was ``exploring alternatives with respect to a possible strategic alliance with a limited number of firms.'' Such an alliance, it said, ``could add complementary strengths to the company's existing strong process control capability.'' The deal it is exploring, the company added, ``could involve an equity investment in all or a substantial portion of its stock.'' It also said, however, that no decision had been made on whether such a deal might even transpire. Telephone calls to John C. Fuller, a member of the Foxboro board and a vice president for investor relations, were not returned. Foxboro would be an attractive buy, Turner said. Among its attributes are an old and loyal customer base and a new product line first offered two years ago that enables Foxboro systems to be integrated with those of other companies. But the new system has had costly bugs in it, Turner said. ``It's not clear that all of the problems have been completely worked out in this new system, and this company has had to borrow money to finance its operations in the last four years,'' Turner said. ``They could use a little financial backing.'' Robert Sullivan, an analyst at PaineWebber Inc. in New York, said Foxboro is coming out of a restructuring period. ``The company's record in the last few years has been quite erratic, which has led to some dissatisfaction on the part of some stockholders,'' Sullivan said. ``It's a big and growing market and as (manufacturing) companies are forced by law to reduce pollution, one of the things they will be forced to spend money on is equipment to reduce pollution,'' Sullivan said.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were higher at midday Tuesday, boosted by widespread institutional buying. A British newspaper report that the government was considering joining the pound to Europe's exchange rate mechanism by the fourth quarter benefited stocks. Government officials described the Financial Times report as speculative. Shortly after midday in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 29.2 points, or 1.2 percent, at 2,378.0. Volume came to 263.4 million shares at midday, compared with 227.9 million shares at the same time Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Britain Will Link Pound to System in Fourth Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The government plans to link the pound to Europe's exchange rate mechanism in the fourth quarter of this year, the Financial Times reported Tuesday. The newspaper said Treasury officials have decided recently that Britain's underlying annual inflation rate will be low enough toward year's end to allow the pound to enter the European Monetary System's exchange rate mechanism. The underlying inflation rate is now about 6.25 percent and the full rate, including mortgage payments, is 9.4 percent. A spokesman for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's office said the Financial Times report was ``pure speculation.'' Mrs. Thatcher said at a European Community summit last June that Britain would link the pound once British inflation is nearer the community average, now about 5 percent, and there is free movement of capital in the community. The exchange rate mechanism links nine of the 12 currencies of the community to prevent wide swings in rates. In a statement to Parliament on Thursday, Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said the government will calculate its inflation in a way similar to methods used by other community nations. His remarks were taken to mean that the Treasury would strip out such things as the mortgage interest payments from the British index. Major also said significant progress has been made toward meeting Mrs. Thatcher's conditions but British inflation was still too high compared with the EC average. The Financial Times said the specific timing of the pound's entry into the exchange rate mechanism will depend on sterling staying strong against other European currencies. Putting the pound into the system at a high level would help control inflation. The newspaper said the government considers it wiser to join the mechanism on condition that the pound be allowed to move within a 6 percent band, rather than the 2.25 percent band to which most of the system's currencies are limited.

DOC.HEAD: Managing Editor at Entertainment Weekly Resigns
DOC.TEXT: The managing editor of Entertainment Weekly magazine has resigned and been replaced by the executive editor of People magazine, Time Warner Inc. announced. Jeff Jarvis cited ``creative differences'' as his reason for leaving Entertainment Weekly, which Time Inc. Magazine Co. launched in February. It provides reviews and information on television, movies, books, music and other forms of entertainment. His replacement is James W. Seymore Jr., who joined Time in 1977 as an assistant editor of People. He rose through the ranks at the weekly celebrity magazine, becoming executive editor in 1988. ``We are enormously grateful for all Jeff has done in bringing Entertainment Weekly to life,'' said Jason McManus, editor-in-chief of Time Warner Inc., in a statement released Monday. ``We're quite confident about the magazine's future, due in large part to the fine staff that Jeff has assembled.''

DOC.HEAD: Light Hamburger Joins Fast Food Chain's Menu
DOC.TEXT: Hardee's Food Systems Inc. today announced the debut of a light hamburger sandwich called THE LEAN 1. The hamburger is the lowest-fat quarter-pound burger offered as a standard-menu item by any national fast-food chain, company officials said. According to Bill Prather, Hardee's president and chief executive officer, THE LEAN 1 is made from 100 percent American beef and contains an average of 18 grams of total fat, which is about 30 percent less than Hardee's other quarter-pound hamburgers. Hardee's began testing the new sandwich last month in Peoria, Ill., Charleston, S.C., Montgomery, Ala., and Harrisburg, Penn. Hardee's is the third largest fast-food hamburger restaurant company in the world, Prather said, with more than 3,300 Hardee's and 648 Roy Rogers restaurants in 41 states and nine foreign countries. The company is headquartered in Rocky Mount.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler, Renault End Sport-Utility Vehicle Joint Venture
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with UAW workers in Toledo approving new contract; CORRECTS spelling to Valladolid. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and the French automaker Renault announced today that they have abandoned their joint venture in developing and building a new sport-utility vehicle. The ARCAD joint venture, formed in February 1989, ``is no longer economically attractive,'' the automakers said in a written statement. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston declined to elaborate. ARCAD was to begin producing a vehicle code-named ``JJ'' in the second half of 1992 at a Valladolid, Spain, plant leased from Renault's Spanish subsidiary. The four-wheel-drive vehicles were to be marketed worldwide except in North America, where ARCAD planned to build them at an existing Chrysler facility. Chrysler intends to develop the JJ project on its own, but a North American plant still has not been selected, Houston said. The decision to terminate ARCAD was not affected by Monday's vote on a new, seven-year contract by workers at Chrysler's two Jeep plants in Toledo, Ohio, Houston said. Members of Local 12 of the United Auto Workers union approved the contract by an 80-percent margin. Chrysler has said UAW contract approval was among the steps needed for it to bring new production to Toledo. The ``JJ'' was believed to be among the vehicles Chrysler was planning to build there. Local 12 officials did not immediately respond to word that Chrysler and Renault terminated ARCAD. The automakers had budgeted $500 million for ARCAD, but Houston could not say how much of that was spent. ARCAD production levels never were established, he said. Renault will continue distributing Chrysler's Jeep vehicles in Europe, the statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Banks Betting On Trump In Tentative Debt Agreement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS New 21st graf, The Daily ..., to UPDATE with report on Taj Mahal daily revenue. Picks up 21st graf pvs, If the ...
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's major bankers are betting the king of glitzy casinos and real estate can strengthen his cash-strapped empire under a tentative debt restructuring deal. But some analysts say the flamboyant developer, whose marital as well as financial troubles have been gossip-tabloid fodder, may have to pay dearly for the breathing room by giving creditors greater control over his holdings. Several major banks agreed over the weekend to extend $60 million in new loans to Trump and suspend interest payments on $2 billion in outstanding debt, banking sources familiar with the talks said Monday. In exchange, Trump promised to pledge as collateral some of his remaining real estate and casino assets that aren't otherwise committed to secure loans, said the sources, who spoke on condition they not be named. Those assets include the Trump Plaza Hotel in Atlantic City, N.J., and the Trump Tower building in Manhattan, they said. Trump also may have agreed to forfeit equity in other properties in return for the suspension of interest payments, and to make changes in his lavish, high-profile lifestyle, according to a report in Monday's Wall Street Journal, which first reported on the tentative bank deal. But the Journal article said Trump balked at a bank proposal to secure the $60 million loan with the apartment portfolio of his father, Fred Trump, who amassed a fortune in real estate and first taught the junior Trump the art of the deal. The banks hope to give Trump more time to restructure his operations while he waits out New York City's real estate slump and the downturn in the Atlantic City gambling market, analysts said. Without the extra breathing room, Trump could be forced to sell some of his major assets at bargain prices. ``By delaying any sale, they believe this is a way of maximizing the probability of being paid back,'' said Richard Mueller, an analyst with Duff & Phelps Inc. Christopher Mahoney of Moody's Investors Service Inc. agreed: ``The banks can't say to him, `If you can't pay, please sell your buildings today and give us the cash.' The buildings would sell for a lot less and he could go bankrupt. ``The banks would end up owning the buildings. The last thing they want to do is manage casinos.'' Jim McDermott, an analyst with Keefe Bruyette & Woods, said that while the restructuring keeps Trump out of bankruptcy court, it places him under tighter control of his creditors. ``I'd say he doesn't have as much autonomy as he did yesterday,'' McDermott said. Sources familiar with the negotiations said major banks' contributions toward the $60 million loan will be proportionate to the amount they previously lent. Citicorp and Bankers Trust would provide around two-thirds of the new loan. Sources said the next step is to sell the restructuring plan to smaller creditors, including Japanese banks, which reportedly purchased part of Trump's loans through syndication. Citicorp, Bankers Trust, Chase Manhattan and Manufacturers Hanover had scheduled a meeting Monday with about 10 additional banks, sources said. ``If any one of the other banks do not go along, then the deal does not work,'' the Journal quoted one unidentified banker as saying. Spokesmen for the banks and Trump declined to comment officially on the deal. Trump confirmed last week that he was negotiating with the banks, who reportedly were concerned about his ability to handle the billions in debt run up in buying big real estate and casino properties. The huge Trump Taj Mahal in Atlantic City has been a drain on his cash flow, as have interest payments on roughly $1 billion in junk bonds he issued to finance the purchase of hotels and the Trump Shuttle airline. The Daily News reported today that the Taj Mahal failed last week to take in a daily average of $1 million, the amount needed to earn a profit. It was the first week since the casino's April opening that the target wasn't hit. If the smaller creditors support the proposal, Trump likely would be able to meet an interest payment due Friday on the bonds for Trump's Castle casino. The Journal said some bankers were concerned that if Trump missed a payment on the bonds, it would jeopardize the gambling licenses for all three of his casinos. News of the restructuring agreement triggered a rally in the price of Trump's bonds Monday. The bonds were hammered by word of the bank talks last week, and some bonds trade for as little as 60 percent of face value.

DOC.HEAD: Microsoft, Everex File Suits Alleging Counterfeiting
DOC.TEXT: Microsoft Corp. and Everex Corp. say they have filed lawsuits alleging that 16 individuals and companies have made or sold a counterfeit version of Microsoft's popular MS-DOS computer operating system. The lawsuits, the first of which was filed under seal April 6, allege a counterfeiting ring introduced more than 30,000 bogus copies of MS-DOS into the United States. Microsoft estimated the counterfeits displaced legitimate sales valued at more than $1.5 million. MS-DOS, which stands for Microsoft disk operating system, is the most widely used operating system for personal computers made by International Business Machines Corp. and IBM-compatible computers. The operating system is the basic software that allows the computer to perform such functions as opening files and responding to the keyboard. The copies were counterfeits of MS-DOS marketed by Everex under the trade name ParCorp, the companies said Monday. Everex, of Fremont, Calif., is licensed by Microsoft to produce the operating system for its private-label computers. Seizure orders issued with the lawsuits were executed at six locations in New Jersey and California between April 10 and May 8, with U.S. marhsals participating in some of the raids, Microsoft said. More than 1,000 counterfeit copies were seized, and several thousand more were subsequently surrendered by four of the defendants under an order issued by U.S. District Judge Charles A. Legge, the companies said. Named as defendants are J&S International, JIP Design and Joe Fok, all of San Jose, Calif.; American MultiSource Inc., Manufacturing Services Inc., Benny S. Lee, Norman Chan and Susan Chan, all of Fremont, Calif.; Micro-Generation, a division of Continental Technology Inc., in Edison, N.J., and its corporate officers Thomas Wu, Michael Wu and Frank Ho; and Asia Source Inc. of San Jose, Calif., and its corporate officers Tai Yen Chu, Robert Young and Christi Liang. Asia Source was a customer of Micro-Generation.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 463.20 up 0.41 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Earnings Up in First Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to include time element and attribution; minor changes throughout. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Earnings at the nation's 12,588 commercial banks bounced back in the first three months of 1990 after two soft quarters, the government said today. Despite heavy losses on real estate loans in the Northeast, banks overall earned $6.2 billion in the January-March period, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. That was a substantial improvement over profits of $2.1 billion in the fourth quarter of 1989 and a loss of $700 million in the third quarter. However, first-quarter earnings were still down 15 percent from the record $7.3 billion during the same period a year ago. L. William Seidman, chairman of the FDIC, which insures bank deposits, said the relatively good performance should continue this year. ``We don't see any precipitous change up or down,'' he said. While overall results are good, Seidman noted that banks in a growing number of states are experiencing problems with real estate loans. The level of sour real estate loans, as a percentage of all real estate loans, grew in 39 states and the District of Columbia. Nationally, banks continue to rely on real estate lending to support overall growth. Total real estate loans grew by $75 billion, or 11 percent, in the 12 months ending March 31. During the same period, delinquent real estate loans grew by $7 billion, or 40 percent. On the positive side, the FDIC reported that fewer banks are failing than last year. Thirty-six failed in the first quarter compared with 64 during the same period of 1989. The number of problem banks _ those in danger of failure _ declined to 1,058 in the first quarter from 1,289 in the same period a year ago. Seidman said the insurance fund backing bank deposits, which suffered losses in 1988 and 1989, should post a modest profit this year. The FDIC revised its report for 1989 bank profits to $15.7 billion, down $600 million from an earlier report. It attributed the revision to belated recognition of loan losses.

The stock market retreated this morning in light trading after a big runup the previous session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, up 30.19 points late Monday, fell 2.47 points to 2,890.10 by 11 a.m. on Wall Street. Gainers held a narrow edge on losers in New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 608 up, 585 down and 578 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 45.97 million shares in the first 90 minutes. The market advanced in early trading, but prices fell back later. Some traders appeared content to wait on the sidelines. ``The market is not doing a whole lot today,'' said Dudley Eppel, senior vice president and managing director of equity trading at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. ``I think it's just a matter now of people watching it for a little while before buying stocks again.'' Some analysts expected trading to pick up later in the week when new government reports on producer and consumer price reports could give fresh clues on the state of the economy. ``If there's something dramatic in the figures, it will pick up the volume,'' Eppel said. DOC.HEAD: Committee Hears Testimony on Privacy Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with committee testimony; Edits throughout to tighten. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Federal law should be changed to allow consumers _ not private credit reporting bureaus _ to control the use of their credit records, a House subcommittee was told today. ``Credit records are more than just account numbers. They are a consumer's reputation,'' Rep. Matthew Rinaldo, R-N.J., told the House Banking subcommittee on consumer affairs. The panel is considering ways to update the 20-year-old Fair Credit Reporting Act to keep up with major advances in computer technology that have made credit reporting a booming business. Rinaldo, sponsor of one of three proposed bills, said credit reports should be provided only for transactions initiated by consumers, not for such things as direct-mail marketing, mailing lists or pre-approved lines of credit. However, Jean Noonan, associate director of the Federal Trade Commission's Bureau of Consumer Protection, said that although there is a danger that use of credit reports can be an invasion of privacy, her office would rather regulate it than ban it. Subcommittee Chairman Richard Lehman, D-Calif., has proposed allowing credit reports to be used for solicitation if consumers are allowed to bar their own files from such use. Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., is sponsoring a proposal similar to Rinaldo's to ban such use of consumer credit files. Rep. John Hiler, R-Ind., ranking minority member of the subcommittee, said the proposals went too far. ``We also have to be concerned that we do not shut off the flow of credit to all but the most gold-plated credit risks,'' Hiler said. Bonnie Guiton, director of the U.S. Office of Consumer Affairs, opposed proposals to require credit reporting companies to provide customers a free annual copy of their credit record. The consumers will end up paying the cost, she said, adding that credit companies instead should have to conduct random checks on their own work and publish the results. The various proposals also include language to give consumers new power to correct errors in their credit reports, and require that they be notified when their credit report is used to deny them a transaction. On Monday, a Louis Harris & Associates poll reported that 71 percent of those Americans surveyed believe consumers have lost control over how businesses handle personal information about their customers. Consumers want the Fair Credit Reporting Act updated to guard against misuse of personal information, said Alan F. Westin, the Columbia University professor who conducted the survey. But Westin said consumers were willing to make a ``fair information bargain'' with the government and industry so they can still have access to conveniences such as direct-mail and credit cards. ``Consumers want it all,'' he said. ``They want both privacy and they want the benefits of a consumer society.'' The survey was commissioned by Equifax, an Atlanta-based company that provides information and technology to businesses including employers, insurers and credit companies. It found that 79 percent of those questioned were either very concerned or somewhat concerned about threats to their personal privacy, compared with 77 percent in a 1983 Harris survey and 64 percent in a 1978 poll. In 1970, only 34 percent said they were concerned about privacy issues. A large majority said privacy should be considered a fundamental right, and 30 percent said they had decided against applying for a job, credit or insurance because they didn't want to provide certain kinds of information about themselves, the survey found. But 78 percent said they would be upset if they couldn't get credit based on their record of paying bills. The random telephone poll included 2,254 interviews in January and February, and 2,253 interviews in April, with about half of the first group of people being re-interviewed. The margin of error was plus or minus 2 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: EC Submits Proposal to Liberalize Trade in Textiles
DOC.TEXT: The European Community on Tuesday submitted a proposal to liberalize trade in textiles and clothing by phasing out an existing agreement that regulates commerce in the politically sensitive sector. The EC plan presented to members of the 96-nation General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade aims at bringing trade in textiles into conformity with GATT's free trade principles. The sector has for the past 30 years been governed by the Multi-Fiber Arrangement which provides for quotas, negotiated on a bilateral basis. The current MFA is due to expire in July 1991. World trade in textiles totalled $89 billion in 1988 while the clothing sector was worth some $88 billion, according to figures from the Geneva-based GATT secretariat. The EC plan proposes that most existing MFA quotas should be gradually enlarged by a given percentage before they are finally abolished, according to trade officials. However, the EC also said it was prepared to negotiate a list of some products that could be brought into the GATT before the transition period begins. The 12-nation trading bloc did not set a timetable for liberalizing trade or specify the pace at which quotas should be increased during the transition period, trade officials said. One source, who declined to be identified, said some negotiators at the meeting criticized the proposals for being too imprecise. The EC plan to start from the basis of the existing MFA contrasts with the U.S. approach. The United States wants to abandon the MFA when it expires next year and introduce a new 10-year global quota system. Critics of the American plan argue that Washington is seeking to introduce new restrictions through this scheme in order to placate its powerful textile lobby which fears competition from Third World exporters. The 22-nation International Textiles and Clothing Bureau, which represents major Third World producers, is due to present a proposal on Wednesday to phase out restrictions on their exports within six years. New rules on textiles are due to be resolved in December, when the four-year Uruguay Round of negotiations is scheduled to end.

DOC.HEAD: How Americans Rate Products and Services
DOC.TEXT: In a survey of American perceptions of marketplace values, which came first, the chicken or the lawyer? The chicken not only won by a large margin, it placed first in the study while lawyers' fees came in next to the bottom, edged out for the very worst rating by hospital charges. The health-care area in general received low consumer acceptance marks, but the legal profession's activities might have something to do with that too. High health-care costs, explained Fabian Linden, head of the Conference Board's consumer research center, have an important legal component, primarily in the form of high malpractice insurance costs. The survey was conducted for the board by National Family Opinion Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, as part of an ongoing study of consumer confidence. Every second month, said Linden, there is room for special studies, such as this one. Generally speaking, the consumer acceptance ratings for late in 1989 showed little change from those of other years, except perhaps to show some slippage when compared to two or three years earlier. There were few surprises. As before, consumers expressed a relatively high level of satisfaction with foods purchased for home consumption, including poultry, meat, fish, fruits and vegetables. They thought rather highly of the values in video rentals, television sets, appliances, haircuts, electricity, telephone service, restaurant meals and, although the ultimate consumer was not questioned, pet food. Accompanying hospital charges and lawyers' fees at the lower end of the chart were credit card charges, premium pay television, health insurance, movies at theaters, admission to sports events, and automobile insurance. Contrary to some popular opinions that older people are more difficult to satisfy, the survey showed little difference in the attitudes of young and old. And, says Linden, surprising similarities were found through all income levels. The survey did reveal significant attitudinal differences in regard to foreign versus domestic cars. Despite impressions that consumers prefer foreign makes, they rated them only a bit higher than domestic cars, but differences became sharper with age. Foreign cars scored better with the young, domestic models with older people. Foreign cars also scored better on the East and West coasts, which Linden attributes to concentrations of younger people, while domestic models rated higher in much of the remainder of the nation. One of the best foreign-car ratings was in the Northeast where, said Linden, young workers in the financial industries often earned ``embarassingly large sums of money'' and sought to use those sums conspicuously. In all, the levels of consumer acceptance are perhaps close to what most people think they are. In the middle range of relative acceptance, for example, are such items as U.S. postage, furniture, prescription drugs, dry cleaning. Lower-middle includes mass transit, hotel stays, air fares, toys. Higher-middle includes men's shoes, men and women's apparel, personal care and eyeglasses. And what level is occupied by used cars, so often considered one of the more questionable values in the American markeplace? True, they were low in the consumer acceptance ratings, below home repairs and appliance repairs, but higher in acceptability than bank service charges. And considerably higher than those lawyers' fees and hospital charges.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Trade Surplus Continues Shrinking
With AM-Trade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Japan's trade surplus declined slightly in May, the 12th month in the last 13 during which the surplus narrowed from a year earlier, the Finance Ministry reported Tuesday. The May surplus of $3.13 billion compared with $3.76 billion in May 1989. Exports fell 0.9 percent from a year earlier to $21.52 billion, while imports grew by 2.4 percent to $18.38 billion. Economists said a slowing in the rate of export declines indicated the yen's recent weakness may cause a renewed buildup in the surplus. They added that slower growth in the domestic economy may be depressing imports. A cheaper yen makes Japanese goods more competitive in price overseas. ``After seeing these figures, I'm confident that possibly as early as July we could see a widening in Japan's trade surplus,'' said Jesper Koll, an economist at S.G. Warburg Securities. Bank of Tokyo economist Toshio Yamasaki said a weaker domestic economy will encourage companies to ship their products abroad. Lower oil prices also reduced the value of Japan's imports in May. Its crude oil imports increased 3.1 percent in volume, but dropped 4 percent in value terms, to $1.71 billion. Japanese importers paid an average of $16.79 a barrel for crude oil in May, down from $18.02 a year earlier. In trade with the United States, Japan's surplus shrank to $2.44 billion in May from $2.76 billion a year earlier. Japanese companies exported $6.82 billion worth of goods to the United States in May, down 4.5 percent from a year earlier. Imports from the United States fell 0.2 percent to $4.38 billion. Japan's surplus with the European Community shrank to $1.2 billion from $1.63 billion in May 1989. Exports totaled $4.07 billion, up 7.1 percent, against imports of $2.87 billion, up 32.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Emirates Oil Minister Urges Cooperation
DOC.TEXT: United Arab Emirates Oil Minister Mana Saeed Otaiba on Tuesday urged oil-producing countries within OPEC and out of it to cooperate in an effort to stabilize the world petroleum market. At a news conference held with Egypt's Oil Minister Abdel-Hadi Kandeel, Otaiba said an emergecy OPEC conference would be held as soon as needed. He stressed the importance for all OPEC countries to abide by the cartel's decisions and cited as an example the UAE which he said reduced its daily petroleum production quota to 1.9 million barrels from 2.1 million barrels. The UAE's 1.9 million quota is still far above its OPEC-decreed ceiling of 1.095. In May however, the UAE was reportedly producing 2.05 million barrels a day. Despite an OPEC agreement in Geneva on May 2 to limit overall production to 22.1-22.6 million barrels a day, production last month remained high at an estimated 23.68 million barrels a day, the Middle East Economic Survey reported Monday. The newsletter singled out Kuwait and the UAE as producing well above their quotas set by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. MEES said the average spot price for seven OPEC crudes dropped to $15.45 a barrel in May from $15.63 a barrel in April, significantly lower than the cartel's benchmark price of $18 per barrel. Otaiba said preparation for a new OPEC ministerial conference has begun, and ``if neccessity calls for such an emergency conference, it will be held.'' Otaiba said he expects the current oil market crisis to end in two months following efforts and contacts among OPEC and non-OPEC oil producing countries. ``I have great hope that we can control the temporary crisis and overcome the terror gripping the market,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bank of NY Appoints President of Bank Unit
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New York Co. on Tuesday named Alan R. Griffith, a senior executive vice president, the president and chief operating officer of its bank subsidiary. Griffith, 48, replaces Peter Herrick, who was elected vice chairman of the bank. Herrick, 63, plans to retire next year after serving as president of both the parent company and the bank. Both changes were approved by the company's board of directors Tuesday. Griffith, who was also named a director of both the bank and the parent company, began his career with the Bank of New York in 1966 and was appointed a vice president eight years later. Among his many accomplishments at the bank was helping expand Bank of New York's lending in the entertainment industry, the bank said. Griffith also headed Bank of New York's international banking business and served as chief credit policy officer during the merger with Irving Bank Corp.
