Even with the quarter's improvement, the United States is beginning the 1990s in a far different position from the beginning of the 1980s. A decade ago, America was the largest creditor nation. It ran surpluses in its current account as the earnings on overseas investments were enough to offset perennial deficits in merchandise trade. But as Americans handed over billions of dollars to foreigners in payments for imported cars and televisions, the investment cushion eroded. It disappeared altogether in 1985, when the United States became a net debtor for the first time in 71 years. That means foreigners now own more in U.S. assets than Americans own overseas, a development that has led some to say the United States is losing control over its economic destiny. Tuesday's report indicates America's debtor position has now risen to around $670 billion, although the government's official accounting of the gap between U.S. holdings and foreign investments will not be released for several more weeks. Brad Larschan, an attorney with the Association for International Investment, a lobbying group for foreign companies doing business in the United States, said there was a growing push in Congress to restrict foreign investment, which he termed an ``unfortunate development'' given America's continued need to finance the shortfall in its current account position with foreign borrowing. ``We are concerned about the rising protectionism in Congress and throughout the country,'' Larschan said. ``In a political sense, this is open season on foreign investors. This is coming at a time when the United States is scrambling to compete with other countries for investment capital.'' DOC.HEAD: NYSE Study Proposes Wider Trading Halts
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Adds details and quotes throughout, no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A New York Stock Exchange report released today proposed more widespread use of trading halts to curb stock-price volatility and recommended tighter regulatory control over financial markets to raise investor confidence. The report capped a six-month study into the reasons for unwieldy markets, which have dogged the securities industry since the market collapse of October 1987 and have been partly blamed for a declining interest in stock ownership by individual investors. But the NYSE's conclusions didn't significantly differ than other studies into the causes of wild price swings. They also found nothing inherently wrong with ``program trading,'' the computerized strategy of instantly buying or selling large quantities of stocks, which some critics have blamed for exaggerating movements in prices and frightening investors off. ``We found that the markets are essentially stable and sound, and that they are not `tilted' against the individual investor,'' said General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger B. Smith, who headed the 18-member blue-ribbon panel on market volatility and investor confidence. ``There is, however, ample room for improvement, particularly in increasing public understanding of markets and how they have changed in recent years,'' he said. Smith and fellow panelists spoke at a news conference at NYSE headquarters, where the long-awaited study was released. The market's failure to react to its conclusions suggested that people in the securities industry found nothing threatening about them. ``I don't think that's a primary concern right now,'' said Philip Rettew, a senior market analyst for Merrill Lynch & Co., the nation's biggest securities company. ``The market cares more about the economic numbers.'' Among the NYSE proposals was a ``four-tier circuit breaker'' that would halt trading for an hour when the Dow Jones industrial average moves up or down 100 points from the previous day's close; 90 minutes when it moves 200 points; and two hours when it moves at least 300 points. The proposed halts are for longer periods than previous, temporary circuit breakers enacted by the NYSE to control potential panic in the market. The panel was formed after the 190-point plunge by the Dow industrials last Oct. 13, which began with word that a takeover offer for the parent of United Airlines had collapsed. Some experts have said that single event, combined with speculative selling and program trading, destabilized the market. The NYSE study concluded that ``market volatility and program trading are not the primary concern of individual investors, who are more concerned about whether today's markets are operated fairly and honestly.'' Nonetheless, it said, ``the belief that program trading has diminished the fairness of markets reduces investor confidence.'' During the study, conducted in the summer of 1988, six women and four men participated in an eight-week weight-training program that focused on the quadriceps muscle at the front of the thigh. Three times a week, for eight weeks, the subjects performed leg lifts with weights for about 45 minutes a session. The average increase in single-leg exercises went from 16 pounds at the beginning to about 42 pounds by the end of the training, she said in a telephone interview. They called the results ``remarkable'' considering the subjects' age and poor health condition at the start of the study. Seven had arthritis, six had heart disease, and four had hypertension. The subjects stopped weight-lifting at the end of the eight-week period, and four weeks later, they had lost about one-third of the strength they had gained, Fiatarone said. A similar loss would be expected in a younger person, she said, noting that for the results to be lasting, weight-training must be done on a long-term basis. Although the study focused only on leg muscles, Fiatarone said it can be assumed weight-training also would strengthen upper-body muscles in the elderly. The researcher said the results indicate that weight-training can be used in the elderly to help them gain strength and possibly avoid the falls and other accidents associated with weakness. But Herling said more research is needed to determine if weight-training strengthens upper-body muscles in the very old, adding that those muscles tend to be the weakest in the elderly. But she also said that the study ``certainly sheds new light on the capabilities that these elderly patients ... can achieve, and that's promising.''

DOC.HEAD: Fast Food Giants Fan Flames of War on Fat
DOC.TEXT: Hardee's announced a new, leaner quarter-pound hamburger Tuesday, but competitors said the fast-food company is playing catch up. The Rocky Mount-based company announced ``THE LEAN 1,'' a quarter-pound burger with an average of 18 grams of total fat that it described as the lowest-fat burger in the business. The response from competitor Wendy's was a little frosty. ``This really isn't news as far as we're concerned although we applaud the efforts of people trying to bring more nutritious food to the public,'' said Charlie Rath, vice president for marketing at the Dublin, Ohio-based company. Rath said Wendy's quarter-pound single hamburger has 15 grams of fat, lower than any of the competitors. Not so, said Cori Zywotow, a spokeswoman for Burger King in Miami. Her company's comparable hamburger had 11 grams of fat, she said. ``You really need to listen to consumers and have a variety. We certainly work to please our customers,'' Ms. Zywotow said in a telephone interview. Fat content and other health-related issues have received more attention from fast-food companies in recent years due to heightened consumer awareness and activism. Officials at McDonald's Corp., the nation's biggest fast-food restaurant chain, had no comment Tuesday afternoon on the Hardee's announcement. But Hardee's spokesman John Merritt threw down the kitchen glove to any and all challengers. ``If anybody wants to do a comparison ... I'll pay any independent laboratory for the testing and bet $1,000 to any one of those groups that our LEAN burger is the lowest fat product on the market,'' Merritt said. He said that by percentage, Hardee's quarter-pound hamburger boasted a 17.9 percent fat ratio. That compared with 22.8 percent for Wendy's and 22.5 percent for Burger King, according to figures from testing by Hardee's, he said. The major chains already have taken other moves to educate customers or offer foods with less saturated fat, which has been found to raise the risk of heart disease. McDonald's said last Friday it would post complete nutritional information _ including fat and sodium levels _ on all of its products at its restaurants this summer. McDonald's also has said it is experimenting with using pure vegetable oil _ rather than the current beef shortening-vegetable oil mixture _ for frying its french fries and hash browns. Hardee's prepared statement released Tuesday said it was the first chain to introduce a non-breaded, non-fried chicken sandwich on its menu. More than two years ago, Hardee's switched to all-vegetable oil to cook its french fries. Burger King is testing the use of vegetable oil and has a grilled chicken sandwich. All of the four big chains offer salads.

DOC.HEAD: Rundown of Dow Jones Average Behavior by Quarter-Hour
ITT Selling Alcatel Stake for $640 Million, Reducing Interest to 30 Percent
DOC.TEXT: ITT Corp. said Tuesday it will sell 7 percent of Alcatel NV to its partner in the French telecommunications equipment manufacturing joint venture for $640 million. The sale of the stake to France's Compagnie Generale d'Electricite will reduce ITT's ownership in Alcatel to 30 percent, which was the level ITT sought to own in the 1986 negotiations on forming the joint venture. But in order to assure completion of the deal, which created the world's biggest maker of telecommunications equipment, ITT in 1986 agreed to take a 37 percent interest in Alcatel. ITT will report an after-tax gain of about $139 million from the transaction, which is expected to close on June 14. The gain will be included in ITT's second-quarter earnings, the company said in a news release. Proceeds from the sale will be used to buy back additional shares of ITT common stock under the company's stock repurchase program. Since the program started in 1987, ITT has bought back 25 million shares. Rand V. Araskog, ITT's chairman and chief executive and also chairman of Alcatel's supervisory board, said ITT's investment in Alcatel has grown handsomely since the Paris-based venture began. ``Our Alcatel shares have more than doubled in value in three years and our board of directors is pleased not only with this outstanding appreciation of our investment, but also with the positive working relationship developed between ITT and CGE,'' he said. The sale of 7 percent of Alcatel will allow ITT to realize a return from this increased value while retaining a substantial ownership position to take advantage of growth projected for Alcatel in the future, he said. Alcatel's growth has been spurred by economic development within European Community and Eastern Europe. The creation of a single European marketplace is expected to enhance demand for equipment Alcatel supplies. ITT said its assets in Europe total $5 billion, or 11 percent of its total assets. The New York-based company is primarily involved in the telecommunications field. It also has interests in the automotive, defense technology, electronics, pulp and timber, insurance, hotels and finance areas.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Chrysler, Renault Terminate Joint Venture
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. and French automaker Renault on Tuesday terminated a joint venture to build a small sport-utility vehicle, but Chrysler said it planned to continue developing the project. Chrysler spokesman Tom Houston said the company, which saw its first quarter profit drop by 80 percent, decided the ARCAD project is no longer economically attractive. ``Chrysler intends to continue with the `JJ' project and is reviewing various implementation alternatives,'' Houston said, declining to disclose details. His statement indicated the company may be considering developing the vehicle by itself or with another partner. The collapse of the $500 million ARCAD joint venture could delay Chrysler's plans to expand in Europe, which is seen as a potentially huge market once internal trade barriers are lifted in 1992 and former East Bloc nations continue liberalizing their economies. ARCAD was to begin producing the vehicle, code-named ``JJ,'' in the second half of 1992 at a Valladolid, Spain, plant leased from Renault's Spanish subsidiary. The four-wheel-drive vehicles were to be marketed worldwide except in North America, where ARCAD planned to build them at an existing Chrysler facility. During the past year, Chrysler has shown signs of growing in Europe, where it has had little presence in the past. The company recently signed a deal to build minivans in Austria. Last week, General Motors Corp. announced a joint venture with Volga Auto Works of the Soviet Union. GM executives said the project to provide fuel system components represented their entrance to a potentially huge marketplace. It appears unlikely that production of the ``JJ'' could begin in North America before late 1992, the original target date of the ARCAD agreement. ARCAD had not said where North American production would be located, but speculation surrounded Chrysler's Jeep plant in Toledo, Ohio. On Monday, members of United Auto Workers union Local 12 in Toledo approved a new local labor agreement seen as key to bringing production of the ``JJ'' and the Jeep Wrangler, now made in Canada, to the aging factory. The ``JJ'' would be built in pieces by suppliers and shipped to an assembly plant, said Joseph Phillippi, an auto industry analyst for Shearson Lehman Hutton in New York. ``There is no stamping, no machining, no painting,'' he said. Because of potential that the JJ would have to be priced low to fight competition from the Geo Tracker, Suzuki Sidekick and Daihatsu Rocky, per-vehicle profit would be relatively low, Phillippi said. Chrysler has been getting most of its profits from sales of its minivans and its Jeep line, which it acquired with the purchase of American Motors Corp. in August 1987. But recently, Chrysler's profits have been falling, its sales have been slipping and top-level executives have been leaving. The company earned $359 million last year, down 65.8 percent from 1988 profits. Through the first five months of this year Chrysler had sold 713,883 cars and trucks, down 12.8 percent from last year. Four top level executives, including former Vice Chairman Gerald Greenwald, recently have announced they were leaving Chrysler or would do so by year'd end.

DOC.HEAD: United States, Britain Continue Talks To Open Skies Further
DOC.TEXT: The Department of Transport said Tuesday that talks continued between the United States and Britain on allowing each other's airlines to fly to more cities, and the Times of London said an agreement was near. Although a department spokesman said there was no indication of a resolution soon, the Times reported that the countries have nearly completed a deal under which American Airlines, Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines would obtain rights to fly to Manchester, England, from Chicago, Boston and Atlanta, respectively. All three already fly to Manchester from other cities. The airlines would be given the opportunity to vary those routes, and they also would be allowed to fly on to Paris and Frankfurt if France and West Germany agree, the newspaper said, without identifying its source. In return, Virgin Atlantic Airways of Great Britain would be allowed to fly from London's Gatwick airport to Boston, the newspaper said, and British Airways and other British airlines would be allowed to fly to major American cities from any regional airport in Britain. Talks began more than a year ago on a new bilateral air services agreement to replace the Bermuda II deal, which was reached in the mid-1970s. The Times said British Airways, Britain's largest airline, is strongly opposed to the agreement, calling it a ``sellout'' of British aviation to the Americans. British Airways says the right to fly from British regional airports to the United States was useless because there was little demand for such service, the Times said. British Airways flies to New York, Boston, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh, Chicago, Detroit, Washington, D.C., Atlanta, Houston, Dallas, San Diego, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Seattle, Anchorage, Miami, Tampa and Orlando, Fla. Virgin Atlantic flies to New York, Miami and Los Angeles. Trans World Airlines, Pan Am, American, Delta, Continental Airlines, U.S. Air and Northwest fly to Heathrow and Gatwick airports in London, to Manchester and to Glasgow, Scotland.

DOC.HEAD: Gasoline Leads Oil Futures Rise Amid Mega Borg Jitters
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline for July delivery soared more than 2.6 cents a gallon Tuesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, erasing steep losses registered during the three previous trading sessions. Market analysts said the rally reflected a bevy of minor influences, including jitters about the crippled oil supertanker Mega Borg off the Texas coast. On other commodity markets, grain and soybean futures were mixed; livestock futures fell while pork bellies advanced; and precious metals were mixed. Wholesale gasoline futures settled 1.3 cents to 2.62 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July up 2.62 cents at 58.5 cents a gallon. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures finished 3 cents to 69 cents higher with July at $17.51 a barrel; wholesale heating oil ended .60 cent to 1.66 cents higher with July at 48.29 cents a gallon. Analysts viewed the rally partly as a technical correction after a three-day decline in which the July gasoline contract fell a total of 2.48 cents. Buying by wholesalers and distributors in the cash gasoline market also contributed to the runup, as did concerns about the burning supertanker in the Gulf of Mexico. ``It tends to conjure up images of last year's Exxon Valdez incident, which sparked a huge rally in the gasoline market,'' said James Ritterbusch, an energy analyst for PaineWebber Inc. An announcement from Royal Dutch-Shell Group that it no longer would use its own ships to send most petroleum products to the United States supported prices. The British-Dutch oil giant has been concerned about liability costs associated with environmental damage from recent tanker spills. The rally also reflected speculation that Tuesday's weekly American Petroleum Institute stocks report would show a drawdown in U.S. supplies of gasoline, Ritterbusch said. But the report, which was released after the close of trading, instead showed a 511,000-barrel increase in gasoline supplies along with a 1.26-million-barrel rise in crude oil stocks and a 479,000-barrel increase in distillate stocks. The crude oil number also ran counter to market expectations while the rise in distillate stocks was smaller than most traders had anticipated. Corn futures rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade while other grain and soybean futures finished mixed ahead of a government report on agricultural supply and demand. In the report, which was released after the close, the USDA lowered its 1990 winter wheat producton forecast to 2.089 billion bushels from last month's projection of 2.092 billion. The number was slightly above market expections and still well above last year's harvest of 1.454 billion bushels. The USDA also projected further shrinkage of U.S. soybean and corn stockpiles but said wheat stocks will rise. Wheat settled 1 cent lower to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.35\ a bushel; corn futures were 2{ cents to 4 cents higher with July at $2.92\ a bushel; oats were { cent to 1\ cents lower with July at $1.46 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1 cent lower with July at $6.07{ a bushel. Most livestock futures retreated on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, erasing some of Monday's gains. But pork belly futures advanced for the fourth straight day ahead of a report that showed a 3.04-million-pound drawdown last week in supplies of frozen bellies in warehouses outside of Chicago. The reduction was larger than expected. Live cattle futures settled .30 cent lower to .08 cent higher with June at 76.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .48 cent lower to .05 cent higher with August at 84.97 cents a pound; live hogs finished .40 cent lower to .10 cent higher with June at 64.32 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .02 cent to .75 cent higher with July at 70.50 cents a pound. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures settled 60 cents to 70 cents lower with June at $355.70 a troy ounce; silver was 0.5 cent to 0.8 cent higher with July at $5.04 a troy ounce.

DOC.TEXT: Stocks advanced to near-record levels Tuesday, strengthened by a late-afternoon rally that extended Monday's gains. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which rose 30.19 points on Monday, gained another 40.85 points to 2,933.42, much of that in the final hour of trading. It was the second highest closing level in history, eclipsed only by the record 2,935.19 reached June 4. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 1003 up, 545 down and 473 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 157.10 million shares, up from a two-month low of 119.55 million shares in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 187.36 million shares. Analysts attributed the rally to a bout of program trading, the computerized strategy of buying and selling large quantities of stocks and stock-index futures to exploit price disparities in the two markets. They said buying programs kicked in automatically late in the day when futures prices substantially exceeded stock prices, making stocks an attractive buy. Some analysts said the two-day surge provided evidence that last week's drop in prices was just a temporary setback. ``We know there's a lot of skeptics still on the fence, and the performance of the market has been dragging more of the skeptics into the market,'' said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer for First Albany Corp. Volume again was light, although analysts expected trading to pick up later in the week when the government releases reports on producer and consumer prices. The reports should provide fresh information on the direction of the economy. ``It looks like a market waiting for news, or waiting for something to happen,'' said Robert Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co. Among active stocks, Boeing gained ] to 58~ on top of Monday's 3-point gain, which followed another announcement of a large order for jumbo jets. Other active stocks posting gains included General Electric, up 1] to 70\; Exxon, up 1 to 48~; Coca Cola, up ~ to 45]; IBM, up ] to 120\; Westinghouse, up ] to 37~; and Philip Morris, up ~ to 45. Procter & Gamble jumped 3{ to 84\, while ITT rose 3\ to 60|. ITT on Tuesday reported plans to sell a 7 percent stake in a joint venture and use the proceeds to buy back shares. American Express was down \ to 30], while Eastman Kodak was down \ to 41]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $37.07 billion, or 1.07 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks gained 2.24 to 199.66. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 6.10 to 427.32, and S&P's 500-stock composite index increased 4.62 at 366.25. Jerry Vines of Jacksonville, Fla., who is completing his term as president, told the convention that some want to leave ``room for all'' in the denomination, but ``that's too much room.'' He said denominations that haven't insisted on an ``infallible inerrant'' Bible were bound for ``the garbage dump.'' The campaigns for the presidency were intensified this time by added fundamentalist attacks on seminaries, including the administration and some professors at the 131-year-old flagship Southern Baptist Theological Seminary in Louisville, Ky. Its president, the Rev. Roy Honeycutt, and the faculty have struck back, calling accusations of ``doctrinal infidelity'' false distortions that ``sow seeds of hate.'' DOC.HEAD: Panel: Program Trading Not To Blame for Market Drops, Wider Halts Needed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 3 grafs after 18th graf pvs, `The panel... to UPDATE with Breeden, Chicago Mercantile Exchange comment; PICKS UP 19th graf pvs, `Opponents of...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: A New York Stock Exchange panel Tuesday proposed new severe trading halts to curb wild price swings but said widely criticized program trading strategies didn't cause market volatility. The report capped a six-month study commissioned after the stock market plunged last October, driving away many individual investors already shaken by the 1987 crash and provoking an outcry against program trading. ``We need the small investor to feel he can go in and invest with confidence,'' said General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith, chairman of the 19-member Market Volatility and Investor Confidence Panel. The group proposed that the NYSE install ``circuit-breakers'' to slow trading during wide market fluctuations. The system would put a 400-point cap on the possible daily rise or fall in the Dow Jones industrial average and the nation's futures and options markets would coordinate trading halts. But the panel found nothing inherently wrong with program trading. The computer-driven strategy typically links the buying and selling of stock and stock-index futures and has been blamed for scaring away individual investors by feeding market plunges. It suggested that program trading was a public relations problem for Wall Street and the perception that such strategies were unfair to individual investors or an abuse of the markets ``is largely unwarranted.'' The panel was formed after the 190-point plunge by the Dow industrials last Oct. 13, which began with word that a takeover offer for the parent of United Airlines had collapsed. Some experts have said that single event, combined with speculative selling and program trading, destabilized the market. A type of program trading also has been blamed for worsening the Black Monday stock market crash of Oct. 19, 1987, when the Dow industrials fell 508 points. Since the crash, the securities industry has been attempting to address questions about program trading in order to head off possibly restrictive moves by federal regulators or Congress. The NYSE study concluded that ``market volatility and program trading are not the primary concern of individual investors, who are more concerned about whether today's markets are operated fairly and honestly.'' Nonetheless, it said, ``the belief that program trading has diminished the fairness of markets reduces investor confidence.'' Among the NYSE proposals: _A four-tier ``circuit-breaker'' coordinated among the U.S. stock, futures and options markets. Trading would stop for one hour when the Dow Jones average moves up or down 100 points from the previous day's close; 90 minutes when it moves 200 points; and two hours each when it moves 300 points and 400 points. The halts are longer than ones previously imposed by the Big Board. They would require approval by the NYSE, Chicago Mercantile Exchange and Chicago Board of Trade. _Revising federal securities laws to make it easier for corporations to buy back their own stock during market turmoil. _Develop new products that would enable individual investors to protect themselves from extreme intraday price swings. _Improve the exchanges' ability to police intermarket trading abuses. _Consolidating regulation of stocks and stock-related futures under one federal agency to improve investor confidence. Similar legislation is being considered by Congress. The panel admitted that trading abuses exist in the financial markets but ``they do not appear to be embedded in the system. In short, the markets are not `tilted' against the individual investor _ or anyone else.'' Securities and Exchange Commission Chairman Richard S. Breeden said he was ``extremely pleased'' the panel endorsed creating a single regulatory agency for stocks and stock-derived futures. Breeden said the report ``in essence fully confirms'' legislation backed by the Bush administration that would give the SEC authority over regulating stock-index futures. In a dissent filed with the report, Chicago Mercantile Exchange Chairman Leo Melamed, a member of the panel, opposed the single-regulator recommendation. He said ``a majority of the panel simply mirrored a popular perception that consolidation of regulation seems desirable.'' Opponents of program trading criticized the report. ``It's simply an affirmaiton of the fact that the NYSE has surrendered all of their hopes and dreams to the institutions,'' said Charles Wohlstetter, chairman of Contel Corp. ``They've accepted defeat without a fight.'' In a survey of 560 people included in the report, more than 50 percent of respondents said they didn't pay much attention to the stock market or thought it was ``stable'' or ``pretty good.'' More than half of the respondents said they hadn't heard of program trading. But among people who own stock and were aware of the term, 32 percent said program trading makes it hard for small investors to particpate in the stock market. On a rating of concerns, 58 percent of direct shareholders said their biggest concern was the honesty and ethics of stockbrokers, compared to 18 percent for market volatility and 11 percent for program trading. The Big Board defines program trading as any order for the simultaneous purchase or sale of 15 or more stocks. Index arbitrage, a form of program trading, involves rapid trading of stocks in New York and stock-index futures in Chicago to profit from momentary price discrepancies. ``Empirical evidence suggests that index arbitrage is most likely the messenger through which new information gets incorporated into stock prices, but it is not the primary cause of price changes,'' the panel concluded. ``Without index arbitrage, prices would still change, _ albeit possibly more slowly _ with the arrival of new information,'' it said. NYSE Chairman John J. Phelan Jr. said the report would be voted on by the exchange's board and its recommendations discussed with other financial markets. Phelan said the he was confident the Chicago futures markets would agree with most of the suggestions, including the circuit-breakers. The panel included officials from Wall Street, major corporations, state government and higher education.

DOC.HEAD: NBC Sets New Ratings Policy; CBS Plan Soon
DOC.TEXT: In another network attack on the current ``people meter'' ratings system, NBC on Tuesday announced its own plan for giving sponsors free ad time when its television shows get lower-than-promised ratings. NBC announcement, made less than two weeks after a similar announcement by ABC, comes at a time the three networks are sharply disputing lower ratings reported by the viewer-activated ``people-meter'' ratings system of A.C. Nielsen Co. Although Nielsen officials say last season's reported drop in network viewing is real, the networks argue that the Nielsen data is wrong. This has led NBC and ABC to use different statistical formulas aimed at cushioning each network from financial losses caused by the data from people-meters, which monitor viewing habits in 4,000 homes. NBC officials have estimated their network could lose as much as $100 million next season because of the lower ratings. CBS expects to announce its own plan on Wednesday, said CBS research vice president David Poltrack. The planned changes could leave advertisers and their representatives facing three completely different network formulas for dealing with so-called ``make-good'' agreements with advertisers. Poltrack said he expected the strategy of advertising agencies then ``would be to voice a preference for one plan over the others, and hope that that would bring the networks in conformance with one plan.'' ``I think this will be resolved fairly quickly _ but I may be wrong,'' he added. The network announcements come at the onset of the so-called ``up-front'' buying period by advertisers for next season, a period that can be worth $4 billion of the estimated $10 billion in total network sales for next season. The matter has gotten a lot of publicity, ``but it's not that complicated,'' said John Sisk, senior vice president for network negotiations at the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency. ``We negotiate a lot of things with them (the networks)...this will be part of the negotiations,'' Sisk said, referring to the beginning ``up-front'' purchase of commercial time for the 1990-91 season. ``It's a major part of the negotiations, but only a part.'' Sisk said he hadn't yet seen the details of NBC's plan, which bases its formula for make-goods on television audience data going back to 1982. ABC's plan uses a three-year average starting in 1987, when Nielsen's people-meter system became the industry's national standard. The system requires individual viewers in participating homes to ``log on'' to Nielsen devices when watching a TV set. The previous passive system simply recorded what was being watched, but not who was watching. Richard Kurlander, whose company buys commercial time for 110 TV stations, declined to comment on NBC's announcement until the network had provided him with its details. ``Obviously, there's some unhappiness, but it'll get all sorted out,'' said Kurlander, vice president of programming at Petry Television. ``I think we should wait until we actually sift through it.'' NBC's initial announcement was made in a corporate press release that among other things spoke of the use of a ``standard linear regression model'' in projecting television viewing levels for next season.

DOC.HEAD: Otto Sturzenegger, Chairman of U.S. Ciba-Geigy, Dies
DOC.TEXT: Otto Sturzenegger, board chairman of the U.S. subsidiary of the Ciba-Geigy pharmaceutical giant, has died of cancer at age 64, the company announced. Sturzenegger died Saturday in Westchester County, company spokesman Tom Chizmadia said. Sturzenegger's contributions to Ciba-Geigy Corp., the U.S. branch of Swiss-based company, ``have formed the foundation upon which this company has grown,'' said Richard Barth, president and executive officer of the U.S. company. Ciba-Geigy Corp., based in the Westchester County town of Ardsley, produces pharmaceuticals, agricultural chemicals, plastics, dyes and vision care products. Its 1989 sales were $3.5 billion. Sturzenegger ``was the driving force behind our success over the last two decades,'' Barth said. The Swiss-born executive began his career in 1952 in Switzerland as a production chemist with the former J.R. Geigy company. Two years later, he moved to the United States and took charge of that company's manufacturing activities. Geigy merged with Ciba in 1970 to form the Ciba-Geigy Corp., and Sturzenegger was named its president and executive officer. In 1978, he was named chairman of the board, and in 1986 he retired as chief executive officer while retaining his title of chairman. He also joined the board of directors of the parent company, Ciba-Geigy Ltd., of Basel, Switzerland. Sturzenegger had earned a bachelor's degree in science from the Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich, Switzerland, and master's and Ph.D. degrees in chemistry from Oklahoma State University. He also completed the Advanced Management Program at Harvard University. Sturzenegger also was a board member of the NCNB Corp. until April 1989, and was until his death a board member of a subsidiary of the International Business Machine Corp. that serves Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall, Dollar Firms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: Share prices failed to hold early gains and ended Wednesday morning's session lower on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, while the dollar rose against the yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 101.48 points, or 0.31 percent, ending the morning session at 32,220.83. The index, which lost 217.87 points Tuesday, rose more than 100 points in early trading before falling back. The dollar was changing hands at 154.68 yen at late morning. It opened at 155.08 yen, up 0.68 yen from Tuesday's 154.40-yen close, and ranged between 154.57 yen and 155.08 yen during the morning. ``Following the index's losses since Monday, as well as the yen's weakness, the Nikkei quickly fell as participants stepped off to the sidelines,'' said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The index lost 453.11 points on Monday. Morimoto said participants' buying interest has shrunk due to uncertainties over the movements in foreign exchange and bond markets. Currency dealers said the dollar fluctuated around 155 yen level as institutional investors bought the currency while exporters sold. Most market players, however, were reluctant to make major moves ahead of a series of U.S. economic data to be released this week, they said. Among the announcements are the nation's retail sales for May, due later Wednesday, April merchandise trade and May consumer and producer prices. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond inched up to 87.47 points from Tuesday's close of 87.45. The yield edged lower to 7.08 percent from 7.085 percent.
